choices: On the Side of a Deserted Road
1.content:
The unknown, a monster, is playing a cat and mouse game with his pawings scanty and scattered. Judging from my previous history, I can only guess the sketchy future. Whether there'll be nothingness or glory, I do not know. Glory or existence versus non-existence will surface from this cat and mouse chase.

I sensed this monster's existence rather early in my life. I know how he works. I know how he likes to give slight warnings, although only sometimes. I know how he likes to feel my tension, my discomfort, my hurt, and how an intimidating look of relief forms on his hideous, vile face, a look that extols his sacred bond with cruelty, but is he really cruel? Or is he something else?

I always wished he'd make one sudden, final leap to do away with what's left of me, but no. A monster likes to play with his prey. He will never choose the least hurtful way.

Before his final toss, he'll imply something, some kind of an offer, maybe the promise of another existence, but who can trust an underhanded monster? I wouldn't trust any information I could sneak out of him if I tried, although I am eaten up with curiosity.

I think I'll stick around and wait, for the omen of stormy weather lurks in the air, and the first gales have already reached me. Is this a warning?
1.title: The Unknown

11.content:
He stared out into the snowfall, the first of a cold, dry winter; his gaze was a vision refracted through an old, dusty window, stained with the yellow tint of burned cigarettes, his latest addition to the second-hand haze of the apartment still smoldering between his lips. An airy chill came through, and he bundled his jacket a little closer, letting smoke drift between his lips.

Carolina winter had been, was, and always would be an untimely thing for him; it was never the great heralder of blizzards such with his native New York, nor merely non-existant; some years it came, some years fall lingered through a cold spell, and teetered off sometime past where spring ought to have been. This year had luckily been the former, and the office had shut down; North Carolina was like that, too. In a city of near enough to a million, some bright mind had decided to buy a half dozen snow-plows, and only buy road-salt when it was abosolutely necessary-- the ice storm in '02 had nearly shut the center of the state down, and the rest of the displaced Yankees couldn't help but chuckle now and then at the sheer pandemonium raised up on account of a little snow.

He remembered his father's comments at times like this. "You quit your bitchin', kid." the old man had always said, half playfully, half ready to knock some sense into his head. "In my day, we walked through the snow, uphill both ways, and didn't complain one bit!" The old man had a harsh tone after Korea. Coughing into a closed fist, he supposed their winters were a bit colder over there-- if he was ever drafted, he recalled thinking in high school, he would make damn sure it would be to a tropical climate like Vietnam. Tapping ash into an empty coffee mug, he reconsidered that thought. Indeed, he was glad he had graduated after that whole mess.

He took one last drag and exhaled eleven minutes above his head, feeling a little warmer from the memories as he snubbed the life out of the cigarette.
11.title: The  First  Snowfall

111.content:
I remember the perfect autumn days where I grew up in the 1950's. Before our small New England town banned the fires, the smell of leaves burning was like perfume to me.

First, my friends and I would help Dad rake the fallen leaves into piles just at the edge of Cottage Street where we lived. I use the term "help" loosely, since we kids spent more time running and jumping into the leaves than working with Dad to make neat piles.

Once the pile was finally ready, Dad would always say, "Stand back so you don't get burned!" This was the magic sentence, after which he bent and poked a lit match into the edge of the pile.

Waiting for the flame to catch, we kids stood on the nearby sidewalk waiting for that first wisp of smoke. Soon, that tiny bit of smoke became flames, and that special time of the year began in earnest. The dancing flames threw out embers that rose high into the air.

Cars drove through and messed up the smoke drifting out across the road. Usually the people inside smiled as they shared the aroma of burning leaves. Most knew soon they would be doing this same autumn ritual near their own homes.

The best part burning leaves was the smell! There is no way to fully describe that wonderful fragrance. Even after all these years, though, I can close my eyes and that acrid odor rushes into my nose once more.
111.title: Autumn

1111.content:
Yes, fire. Fire...I know the smell of fire well. The smell, the feel, the sound...I learned it all so well that day. I don't think that memory will ever leave me.
I was raised in a little town, just outside Bethel. A quaint, pretty little town, with all the things people would expect in a small town. A church, a schoolhouse, a grocer--everything you'd ever want in a little town.
And then came the Baron.
One day, me and my friends were playing in the schoolyard, and then we heard them. Dozens of them. Big, armored vehicles came rolling into town, along the main street. I'd never seen anything like it. We all rushed to the fence, and stared, our eyes wide.
Then we saw him, standing atop the largest vehicle, surveying out little town.
Even now, after all these years, I can't get the image of him out of my head. That man...that "Baron".
Baron Faron 4. That's the name I could see, so boldly imprinted across his rumbling armored vehicle. Dressed in all white, he looked unlike any human I'd ever seen. He was 50 yards away, yet I could still map out every crease in his face, every fold in his skin--he had the hardened look of a man who'd spent his life around things most people pretended didn't happen.
The rest, though, is a blur. At some point, we were in the car, speeding out of town. At another point, we were at a blockade, then we were back in town, heading out the other way. But as we left, I looked out the window.
My mother tried to stop me--she ordered us to keep our heads down, not to look at our home.
But I did. How could I not? I had no idea what was going on.
Our entire town was ablaze. Our home, that humble little house where I'd grown up, the yard where I'd played, the schoolhouse where I'd first kissed Maddy Winchester, furtively, in a bathroom--all of it, ablaze.
Standing, watching it all burn, was the Baron. He was wearing a gas-mask, so I couldnt see his face, but that suit--that gleaming white suit, even the smoke wouldn't stain it.
He looked at us as we drove by, and though I never saw his eyes, I know he was looking right at me.
As we rounded the bend, seconds before he dropped out of sight forever, I saw him give me a thumps-up.
I still see him, every time I so much as smell a cigarette. That gleaming suit, that alien, inhuman mask, standing against my burning home, my burning town. Giving me a thumps-up.
1111.title: fire

11111.content:
Do you see that little, gray-blue house, so dark and empty? It sits, abandoned, with an overgrown, dead lawn and its windows, the plaintive, glassy eyes of the bungalow, staring out at the world, wondering, "What has happened to my family? Why do I feel so empty?" For it once knew the laughter of children in a neighborhood of senior citizens, the warmth of fires in the brick fireplace, and heard tales told to sleepy children ears so that they may sleep, the little eyes awakening the next morning to the glorious sight of virgin snow in a climate that hardly varied from between forty to sixty degrees Fahrenheit year-round. That old, derelict house once was my home in childhood, a place I shall never forget.
         Even having been moved away for four years has not scrubbed the indelible stain from either my heart or my being. After a day of grocery shopping, my mother, sisters, and I were driving home when we saw a beautiful rainbow arcing across the sky in front of us. Delighted by the sight, we savored the presence of color splashed against the gray clouds of life when stopped at a red light. Then, my mother made the discovery.
         As if not thinking, she had gone the route she had traveled what had seemed to be a million times when we were small, back when that ancient house had rang with laughter and play and high-pitched voices, things of the past that are nothing but dim memories and ghostly echoes. And, the rainbow stretching across the sky ended at none other than the dear, dilapidated bungalow that I still love and cherish to this day--the pot of gold at the rainbow's end.
11111.title: Home

111111.content:
Rainbow's end I thought and passed out. When I awoke I was inside the old homestead in my bed. Mother tucked me in and kissed me on my forehead. My heart was thudding so loud I thought she should hear it.
"Sleep well my child. Tomorrow is Christmas ."
I tremulously dared a glance across the room at my little sister. Janie was there snuggled up in her pink blanket.
"Are you asleep?" she whispered. In the semi darkness she looked angelic. Tears came to my eyes as I said,"Not yet."
"Okay,let's go," she said.
"Go where?" I asked her.
"To run away Dummy! You said nobody would think kids would run away on Christmas Eve"
Wide eyed I stared into the gloom. Why would I choose to leave this paradise of childhood?
"I,I can't go tonight," I stammered," I'm too sick."
"Sick! What kind of sick? You were fine at supper," she said in a hoarse whisper.
"It's my stomach," I lied," It really hurts bad,"

I lay perfectly still as the truth hit me,I was being given a second chance. That Christmas Eve we ran away had changed our lives forever.
Janie threw off her blanket and came over to gaze at me. "Are you just trying to ditch me again? Well it won't work. If you are going to leave you have to take me with you."
I wanted to smile. It was so wonderful just to see her again with her feisty ways.
I tried to remember why I had wanted to run away. Nothing seemed that important to me now. How could I have chosen to leave my loving family and run off into the snowy night?

Janie explained it for me then,"Don't you remember how mad you were when Daddy said you couldn't have a BB gun for Christmas? All your friends are getting them this year."
Yes,that was it. That was the big deal breaker. I ruined all our lives over a BB gun.
111111.title: Rainbow's End

choices: Did they make it out the door?
1111111.content: We had packed two camper-sized backpacks. Over the previous weeks we had gathered what we would need, with care. We were warmly dressed. Now we had to leave, silently. The distance from our bedroom to the front door had never semed so long.
1111111.title: Runaways

choices: Is the uneasy feeling for a reason?
Is the uneasy feeling just nerves?
11111111.content:
We ran quietly to the door, hoping not to get caught. Opening the door, I glanced behind us. Our parents were in their room, talking. We slipped out the door quickly, closing it, the door making a loud sound.
We froze, waited a few moments, and then were on our way. We ran all the way down the street until we got tired, then resumed walking. Janie and I chatted, but rarely. I had an uneasy feeling.
11111111.title: Did they make it out the door?

111112.content:
Peering out through frosted lashes, I wait in the softly falling snow, unable to see beyond the border where light faded and darkness began. Leaning against the cold concrete streetlight, straining my eyes against the blur of snow and empty blackness that lurked beyond my lamplight circle, I ignore the numbing cold that seeps in through my jacket, quieting my restless movements. Somewhere beneath the thick blanket of night my friend blunders, unable to find her way. I can faintly hear her disorientated cries; but I try notto acknowlege those sounds that tug at my heart. A solitary tear slowly freezes on my cheek as I wait, willing her to find her way into my safe sphere of lamplight, but I know the cold eats away at her will power, eroding the courage I admire so much.
Should I step out into the secretive dark and help her find her way? No, I think, feeling the familiar throb of fear grasp me as I contemplate dying in the soft, deadly snow. But I can't let her suffer the same sad fate. And if I stay here, protected from the creatures I am sure wait for me beyond my haven, I will still slowly freeze. A stab of guilt spikes within as I realise how selfish I am. All those kind words rendered hollow by this self-obsessed act of cruelty. Thus incensed against my own inaction, I step out of the circle, quelling my fear of the inexorable dark. Stumbling forth, hardly able to see through the snow and blackness, I turn back for a moment to look at the streetlight, and marvel at the silver silence that prevails. Then back to the suppressing night, to find my lost friend. Finally in the snow I find her, huddled up against the rough bark of an oak. Is she still breathing? I don't know, but I'll soon find out. Her frail frame seems light as I lift her, but the faint pulse I can feel tells the truth.
Suddenly the glaring brightness of my silver lamplight expands, drawing nearer. Help! I think, opening my mouth to speak and finding no words will come. It's low rumbling muffled by the snow, the ute pulls up beside us, and I carefully lower my friend onto the seat offered. In a thick, strangulated accent the driver mutters something,and I turn to look at him. Clearing his throat, he proceeds in a clearer voice: "No more room. One of you has so sit on back". He stares at me expectantly, and I shut the door on my friend and succumb to the inexorable cold.
111112.title: Snow

1111121.content: To this day I will never remember how I lived through that night. My memory is just as strong as before. A gunshot tore through the air. Everything after that is a blur. All I remember up until that point was the First shot. And then Joe. My friend. My brother. Fell to his knees, dark red blood dripping from the bullet hole in his neck and throat. Before he died I heard him say to me his last word. Go. But I couldn't move. My friend was dead. The soldier found our campsite. He held his pistol up and then a flash. My vision went black. I woke up, so much later. Two days and seven hours to be exact. I wasn't supposed to live. My death was a symbol to their forces. Now my life will be a symbol. Glowing in the dark times of this war like a single spark. But a spark is all it takes to start a wildfire.
1111121.title: Die another day

11111211.content:
Darkness.

I could feel sun on my face, but could not see where it was coming from. There was a slight breeze brushing against my face, coming through a window most likely, but I could not see the landscape outside. The smell in the room was a strange combination of cleaning products and flowers. Where were the flowers? On the bedside table probably. Now, where was the table?

Carefully, I start to wriggle my fingers. One at a time they shake off the sleep and begin to explore the world. They brush the top of a scratchy sheet that covered me and find the edge of the bed. It ends abruptly in a hard plastic barrier that feels similar to the handrails on a playground structure. My hand crests the top and I grip the railing. My other hand finds the edge of the bed on the opposite side and I pull myself upright.

There is something covering my face. I bring my hands to my eyes and feel some sort of cloth instead of skin. I feel for the edge of the bandage. There is was. Eager to get the pesky thing off my face I grip the edge and rip off the bandage.

I could now feel the breeze on my nose and forehead, but I could still not see. Worried, I feel my face again. My eyes were there. Nose too. Eyebrows, everything! Why could I still not see!

Oh! Glasses! I wore glasses. That's right. My eyes were terrible. I leaned over and fumbled around on the side table. There was nothing there. Great. Maybe it was on the other side. I leaned to the other side and reached my hands out again.

CRASH!! Well, it seems I had found the flowers. Why were there flowers here anyway?

Just then, I heard a door open. A fresh gust of air hit my face and I turn towards the wind. Still, I couldn't see squat. I was starting to get angry. Who had taken my glasses!

"Mr. Meyers! What are you doing with your bandages off?" The nurse sounded frantic. She then yelled to someone else.

"Doctor! It's Meyers. Your blind pacient. Have you got anymore medication for him? He's woken up again."

Blind! I wasn't blind! And who is this 'Doctor'? I wasn't in a hospital! I couldn't be!

"Mr. Meyers. Good morning. How did you sleep? Well I hope." That was the male voice, the doctor probably. "I'm going to give you some more medicine now. Help you to sleep some more. If you would just lie back down."

He put a hand on my shoulder and I flinched. I hadn't realized he was so close. Then there was a sharp prick in my forearm.

Darkness.
11111211.title: Darkness

111112112.content:
In the midst of a cold winter day,
The city and sky fall into gray.
A lonely hero walks the streets,
A destiny of expression he prepares to meet.
Lost in apathy and cursed with talent,
He seeks to leave a mark before his time is spent.
Custom Nike's and his hoody zipped up,
Carrying the torch was hard enough.
Now he holds spray paint cans in a pack,
Secret and hidden in the bag on his back.
A wall of gray appears before his eyes,
Devoid of meaning and epitomized.
Taking a glance he looks around,
A very good chance that he might be found.
Now he concentrates and starts to work,
Designs forming on the concrete at first.
As he draws, they align themselves,
Creating the portraits of his inner hells.
He empties his soul and his spray can too,
A job well done he believes to be true.
Eternalized and forever expressed,
Even though he has done his best,
He wants more as you might have guessed,
And will continue returning to finish the rest.
111112112.title: Undercover Artist

1111121122.content:
When I was still young,
I thought my life done,
from a heart that was broken
with words gone unspoken,
and To me the world was silent.

You walked along,
just singing a song
of a love too good for me,
and one not meant to be,
and To me the world was silent.

You stopped at my side,
said my dress caught your eye.
It was pretty as a rose,
and You had one of those,
then the world began to sing.

You said music has a way
of brightening the day,
and to prove it to be true,
I'll sing a song for you
then the world began to sing.

My soul felt a shiver,
as You crossed the river,
that kept me from hearing of love,
and To me the world was silent,
then the world began to sing.
1111121122.title: Healing through Music

11111211221.content:
A true friend knows it all, not only what shows on the outside
but that which is hidden quite inside, like a transparent sheet
without leaving you in a lurch, all vulnerable. Who'd have thought
that a true friend was such a great, fun blessing in disguise?

On Sunday nights, when your mood is down and you see it's
time to get up and get to work for six days again, your phone
chimes and there's a smile on your face when you read the IM
your true friend has left, relating to what you feel. Instant delight.

On Mondays when the coffee gets cold and you feel grumpy
on the very first day of the office, it's a true friend's face that
gets you cheered up, a little smile, a short laugh but it's all so
good in the end, a day, indeed, well spent!

On grieving days when all you see is gray and black around you,
it's a true friend in an angel's costume, literally, to make you roll
on the floor and pour your heart out and laugh it off, make you feel
better, a door to the colourful, bright, cheery rainbow just outside.

On happy days when you are promoted, achieve all your goals
and grow maybe just a year older in age but a year lesser in maturity
you spill the cake on a true friend's face who still laughs and hugs you
getting you dirty and cake-y, who knew a true friend could do that to you?

A true friend is surely a gift, without a doubt,
who changes your life, every moment you see
and spend it with him, you realize just how
much you hold each other dear. Never lose him.

290 words
11111211221.title: A True Friend

choices: In the Blink of an Eye
11111211222.content:
It's taken me years to perfect, and now it's ready. I call my friend Albie to tell him the good news, ask him to come over to the lab right away. Ten minutes later he arrives.

"You really think it's gonna work, Steve?"

"I know it will, I already tested it on Rusty three times, and he came back fine every time."

"But he's a dog, you might not notice any bad effects. What if you get your brains scrambled or something?"

"Well Rusty seems fine, I've had that dog for five years, I'd notice if he were acting any differently. So I'm gonna go for it.

"I don't mean to sound negative, but have you made any provisions in case of catastrophic failure?"

"Albie, you know me better than anyone. I got no family, my older brother got killed in Iraq right after that war started, and Mom & Dad passed away not too long after him. So I drew up a will leaving everything to you. I spent most of my inheritance on my research, but you're welcome to whatever is left, all I ask is you take care of my dog."

"Sure Steve, but I hope it doesn't come to that..."


"OK, Albie, enough of this talk, it's time for me to make history."

"Well, good luck Steve, see you when you get back."

I strap myself into the chair and hit the switch...
11111211222.title: The Future

111112112221.content:
When I hit that button, I my plan was to jump ahead a day and pick up a newspaper so I could see who the winners were, then jump back in time to go to the track with Albie and place a few bets and make some easy money. But as the old saying goes, God laughs at our plans.

Somehow the calibration on the machine got out of whack, now I don't know when I am. All I know is there are no people here. Is it the past, before this land was populated? Or the future, after mankind's reign is over?

I've been stuck here for two days now, walked a few miles in each direction. No signs of any type of civilization, let alone a place where I might be able to find the components I need to fix a busted control board.

Guess I'll have to pick one direction and stick with it and just keep walking until I figure something out. No point in hanging around here any longer, I don't know anyone else who has a time machine who might come and rescue me...
111112112221.title: The Undiscovered Country

1111121122212.content:
I'm no survival expert but I did read a couple books on the subject. One thing I learned was to always pack emergency rations and a water purifier when traveling into the unknown. Another was if you keep following rivers downstream you should eventually find civilization.

The small creek I was following emptied into a bigger river, and I followed that until it emptied into an even bigger river, and I followed that until it emptied into the ocean, still no civilization! Arbitrarily I decided to follow the shoreline south.

A couple days later when I was almost at the end of my supplies, I spotted a small village of huts. Naked children were playing in the sand, while women dressed in blue were busy preparing food around a large community campfire. I approached with caution, not wanting to alarm them.

When I was about fifty yards away I hear someone behind my back shout: " Unpercent or Ninedeenine!"
I turned around and was immediately surrounded by a group of ragged men who all had spears pointed at me. Their leader spoke again, "Answer! Publicaan or Emocrat? Unpercent or Ninedeenine?"
1111121122212.title: Savages

choices: A large woman taps my shoulder from behind.
11111211222121.content:
"Publican or Emocrat?" I scratch the side of my head and place the best puzzeled look upon my face that I can, without looking in a mirror. Then shaking my head I shrug. "I'm not sure what a Publican or an Emocrate, or for that matter, what is an Unpercent or a Ninteenine?"

The spears start to poke in all areas not just polite midrift and I cover with my hands those spots I hold more dear than other spots. With some rather persistant poking I find myself herded into the center of the little village.

I try to soothe their suspicions by moving willingly in the direction of their pointed instruction. When it seems I have arrived at the place they wish me I again try to clarify their question so I may give an honest answer, or better maybe derive a clue as the answer they wish to hear. "If you could explain what you mean by telling me what a Publican, Emocrat, Unpercent, and Ninteenine are I would be more than happy to tell you which of these things I am."
11111211222121.title: Publicaan

choices: Does he get to know the rest of the terms?
111112112221212.content:
...and I spin around and look up. I have seen large women but none were were ever this big! She's a mountain of muscle 8 feet tall!

"I am an Emocrat. I rule these people."

My houghts raced until she repeated herself and I snapped to attention, grumbling subvocally, "Pay attention!"

"You were brought here at my bidding to be my running mate, for life."
111112112221212.title: A large woman taps my shoulder from behind...

1111121122212121.content: ...no, he does not. No man (or woman, to be fair), ever gets to know the rest of the terms when they make that fatal agreement and say "I do.". "Till death do you part"... What if it doesn't? What options do you have? Adultery? Counseling? Divorce? Murder? Nobody said life would be easy...
1111121122212121.title: Does he get to know the rest of the terms?

choices: Why did you marry me, she asked?
Why did you marry me, he asked?
11111211222121212.content:
Murder isn't an option!

The first rule of a sailor is: Never tie a knot you can't untie!
There are three reasons (maybe four) to marry.
1) Lightning bolt. The illusion of Love. (sex)
2) Legitimate procreation. Continuation family name. (no bastards)
3) Money. Success. Personal advancement.
The fourth and the only one of value; unexplainable attachment! There are
no words that describe this very real and most important invisible contract that seems to form
and solidify a bond between two people where almost all outside spectators, if not all, have no idea what holds these two in balance when all can see they have not one common item between them to share!

This is the knot no sailor can untie! Unfortunately, or fortunately, this particular knot death has no power over either?
Counseling? They destroy a counselor's logic! What answer is there, you ask?

None but time itself! For these two must become as one.
11111211222121212.title: Murder

She decides, rejects, his proposal. "I'm going to pack and leave. I understand what you're saying, I just don't believe it."

1111121122212121212.content:
"Wait Desiree," he commanded in a voice filled with emotion!

With her huge frame in motion, she was on the stairway landing before he voiced his command.
Tears of fear and longing were replaced by hope as she paused to listen to what fate was to decree.

" I need you." he said.

Two days later they had breakfast.

They also talked a great deal about him and her and their place in the political life of the village. Things like political tradition.
11111211222121212121.title: In between his declaration of ...
