"I'm not a prize package. The only thing I could offer is my love."
"I'm not looking for prizes. Your love is more than enough." She said.
111112112221212122.title: Why did you marry me, he asked?

1111121122212121222.content:
"Look Desiree, you're an eight foot tall, beautiful woman and the ruling Emocrat!" "I'm six foot three and never felt small until I met you!"
"I don't know what my political beliefs are in this alien world I have found myself dealing with!" " For all I know I might be a Publicann!" "Could you live with that?" "Could this country have as its, First Family, a bi-polar, dysfunctional liason?" "I'm not talking about a short guy with a very statuesque woman!" "I'm talking about two completely different World views in bed together for an entire World to witness!"
" Until you and I can figure this out, why don't you and I see how we fit together?"
1111121122212121222.title: Or do they opt for cohabitation?

111112112222.content:
In the blink of an eye, I'm on an entirely different planet. I'm still sitting in the chair, strapped securely. The power cables are still connected to the pulse generator, which glows purple and gives off a subdued hum. But instead of the laboratory I just left, I'm sitting in a forest clearing. Golden afternoon light filters through aspen and pine, pooling on the needle carpet below. The air is dry and cool, evergreen-scented. I can hear birdsong and slight rustling--no doubt small forest animals--in the low bushes around me. I work quickly to unlatch the straps across my chest and legs and stand up from the chair, stretching briefly. A glance around the clearing reveals snowcapped mountains behind me, and a shallow, forested valley downslope. The clearing is fairly level, but it looks to drop off twenty or so feet ahead. Now I can hear the burble of a creek, and inhaling deeply of the mountain air, I smell heady odors of pine, grass, earth, and...ozone?
A slight whining sounds from my left before a beam of light lances a chunk out of the aspen next to my head. I instinctively throw myself backwards, manage to roll up to my feet and duck behind the metal chair. "What the fuck?" I spit through my teeth. A rough, strangely-accented voice calls out. "Give up now, smooth-skin! Maybe we'll even let you live!" A higher-pitched but equally gravelly voice adds, "But not before we have a little fun! Come on out and play!"
I'm about to shout defiance when I hear a twig snap behind me. I quickly spin, fists raised to face a scarred, pockmarked, skeletal grimace. Time seems to slow, yet I can't move my hand fast enough to block the butt of his rifle, which smashes into my jaw.
Pain, then blackness.
111112112222.title: In the Blink of an Eye

choices: Stars are the Streetlights of Eternity
11111212.content:
Better to light a candle than curse the darkness, or light a candle, curse the glare? Either one could be appropriate, depending on what the light reveals.

Here's another I like: "I will love the light for it shows me the way. Yet I will endure the darkness for it shows me the stars." That really opens up the possibilities.

How about "No matter how fast light travels it finds the darkness has always got there first, and is waiting for it." (Maybe the speed of darkness is faster than the speed of light?)

Or Ellen's take on Genesis: "In the beginning there was nothing. God said, "Let there be light!" And there was light. There was still nothing, but you could see it a whole lot better."

How about "When you possess light within, you see it externally. ~Anaïs Nin" (notice how when you include the author's name with this quote, it rhymes?)

A famous quote anthologist once said "Sometimes just looking up and seeing the light is enough." But is it really?

After all, What is true by lamplight is not always true by sunlight.

Hey Buddy, got a light?
11111212.title: Light

choices: the batteries die before I reach the stream
my feet are too painful for me to continue
111112121.content:
I held the small metal flashlight low and pointed at the trail just in front of my feet. It was slow going considering I was on the side of a wooded mountain trail, barefoot and bleeding. Not for the first time I considered just sitting where I was and wait for the sunrise. Maybe, I would sleep as well during the next eight or nine hours. Once again I dismissed the idea of stopping. My feet hurt from the descent but I knew if I didn't make it to the stream and stopped, then I'd be worse off than I was at the moment.

The small ring of light started to fade. I tapped the palm of my hand with the lense end of the flashlight to some minor success; the circle of light preceding me brightened again. Determined to reach the stream access before the batteried totally failed I gritted my teeth and took another step down the trail. The stone from where I stepped declared my agony with the dark wet splotch of bloody foot print I left behind.
111112121.title: This Little Light of Mine

1111121211.content:
and the darkness wraps me in its fist.

I lower myself to the ground and put the flashlight down behind a few rocks to keep it from rolling into my path. On hands and knees I continue up the trail moving into the middle of it where there's no obstructions to get in my way.

Dawn comes up before I find the stream and now my hands and knees are scraped.
1111121211.title: the batteries die before I reach the stream

1111121212.content:
Although I haven't had anything to eat or drink since yesterday evening and I really need the water, I realize I just can't continue on in my present condition.
I look around and find a sheltered level spot a short distance from the trail. I pile up some leaves for a bed, then tear a few strips of cloth from my t-shirt and proceed to bandage my feet. Hopefully I'll be in better shape after I get a few hours of sleep. Then I can make my way to the river once the sun comes up.
1111121212.title: my feet are too painful for me to continue

choices: She stays to let the licking continue.
She rolls over, onto her hands and knees, and starts up the trail.
11111212121.content: The sun was well up when my eyes opened. I flexed my feet and looked down at them to find a cat was being most thorough about cleaning the blood off of one. When my feet moved it stopped to stare at me and I wondered why it hadn't run off. A few seconds of silent regard unnerved me and I broke contact. The cat went back to its work, unperturbed.
11111212121.title: Sunrise

111112122.content:
When I awoke the stars were out.

Last I can remember it had been afternoon, and Seb, Bert and I had been drinking. I don't remember passing out but it's dark now, and cold and I'm laying on my back outside my highrise looking at the sky.

I held out a hand above me, blotting out millions of stars, millions and billions of tiny pinpricks of light, hundreds of millions of light years away from me.

I think it was my mother who used to say that stars were the streetlamps of eternity. Some nights I can believe it. I can trace my finger along the milky night sky giving form and name to the patterns I create like a modern Adam. Other nights, I can only see a jumbled mess.

My father used to say that we were made from collapsing stars. That within everyone of us is the remnants of prehistoric supernovas and white dwarfs. We inherited their nitrogen and calcium and carbon like I inherited my mother's eyes and my father's alcoholism.

In a few years, my body will begin to give out, not like a supernova, but like a flame extinguishing. First my liver, then my kidneys, then probably my heart, and while I lay dying, connected to machines that cleaned my blood, Seb and Bert will be dying too. I'll be the first to go, then Seb and finally Bert in the twilight of his life. Then they'll put us in the ground for the worms to break down into nitrogen.

From stars, to alcoholics, to dust.
111112122.title: Stars are the Streetlights of Eternity

choices: From a philosophical standpoint, where does all this put us. Are we worthwhile?
1111121221.content:
Did any of your science teachers tell you there were three heavens? None of mine did.

How old was I when I had it described like that? Twenty? Thirty? It would have to be after high school. Was it between 20 and 30? I think Mom said it.

The first heaven was the atmosphere, the second heaven were the stars. FromShe included the planets, their satellites, the asteroid belts, and the occasional visitor, in the second heaven which stretched across hundreds of billions of light-years and back, in time, to no one knows when.

The third heaven was the place called the New Jerusalem where God is reputed to live. I think she's right about everything except where God lives.
1111121221.title: The Heavens above.

choices: The way things used to be
1111121222.content:
"Good morning starshine, the earth says hello,
you twinkle above us, we twinkle below ..."

Scene: A run down homestead with a small garden. Green beans, squash, corn, and tomatoes barely surviving under the early morning hot sun. A middle aged man wearing a homemade straw hat is softly singing as he dips a tin can into an old five gallon bucket and doles out precious water to the plants. A younger woman works alongside him, scraping beetles off the bean leaves, collecting them in a jar.

"Pretty song, Steve. I never heard you sing that one before."

"It's an old one, way before your time. My mom used to sing it to me when I was little."

"Do you ever wish things were the way they used to be?"

"Well, life would be a lot easier if we still had all the modern conveniences, I suppose." He scratches his head, then looks at her, smiles and says, "But then again, I probably wouldn't have ever met you."
1111121222.title: The Earth below

choices: What can you remember about  days gone by?
11111212221.content:
I remember mum giving me two pence for the public baths. I was given a towel and a guest size soap then I was ushered into a small cubicle with a bath in and the door being closed behind me. I must admit I took a book in with me and found this time and experience a memorable treasure in my life. I was happy away from the business of life.
We had oil lamps for light and shared a toilet at the bottom of the close, my dad cut old newspapers up and put string through them for toilet paper.(Oh my!)
Walking to school each day was fun and we had to line up in the play ground, put our hands out and teacher would inspect us to see if we had clean nails and hands, tidy hair, tie straight and clean polished shoes. If not the consequence would be to write a hundred lines on cleanliness.
We would go to a hut in the summer holidays. My Granny owned one for each of the family and rented them out when we didn't need them. The hut was on wooden stilts with a wooden stair case on the side. We had gas stove run on cylinders of gas and it was perched on an old wooden tea chest.
We washed from a metal stand with an enamel basin on top, an enamel jug of water was on a metal shelf underneath and on the side next to the basin was a pull out piece of metal to hold the towel and the other side had a soap holder.
We had to walk along a path passing other huts and opening out into a sort of square pitch of grassed field with a water stand where we would fill our containers with the days water. Someone there would always start a water fight and we returned home soaked and happy, giggling away in conversation.
We had to walked along paths and across a field to get to the local group of three shops. (the sea was just across the road from the shops}. One shop was a laundry and the other was the grocery store come post office, come bakery. We would ask for our post if any! Then buy some hot, (just out of the oven) rolls and some bacon and eggs, then walk off back to our hut picking up coins that the inebriated had dropped out of there pockets the night before. I always new where to find some next to the amusements.
it was a simple and happy life and we had no worries. Mmmmmm!
Alexi
11111212221.title: The way things used to be

choices: Picked up a station sending on the radio from
11111212222.content:
I was still chuckling when my eyes opened to see a very small hand holding at least a quart jar filled with chunk ice and lemonade with a giant straw sticking out of what looked like two mint leaves suspended on icebergs.

We had citrus, avocados, stone fruits, complete garden greens, reds and yellows, herbs, habanero peppers, wild and domestic pigs, horses, Angus and Hereford cattle, dogs, cats, a couple Chiricahua Apaches, not as pets but friends and partners in our lifestyle.

We even had a little electricity for light at night when needed. The stream that flowed through Sabino Canyon supplied us with hydro-electricity for free as long as we could keep the turbine generating. It also was an unlimited source of all important water. Water in Arizona was around but not everywhere.

THE WAY THINGS ARE NOW not many people had any electricity and had found it really wasn't necessary to aid in the quality of today's lifestyle. Like in the early 1800's, when the sun goes down so do we. People still came from miles around though to watch and listen to the static coming through the radio as we fiddled with the knobs trying to hone in on a signal, none of us had heard for ten years and were pretty sure would never hear again.

The ice came from blocks I brought down from Mt Lemon in the winter. I had a giant ice box under the house and sold(traded/gave) some to neighbors and passersby. No money anymore. No cities either, all gone. Many people tore themselves to pieces trying to survive on products that were no longer being produced. When the canned goods were gone, so were they.

Fossil fuels, our addiction to the automobile in particular was our undoing! It's funny now when one thinks about it rightly.

In 1910, the car, the building of the roads it needed, Rockefeller's oil and the robber barons. The assembly line. Modern medicine/chemistry. Factories paying good money. Relatively overnight, everything changed.

What had been an agricultural nation, rural farms using extended family structuring to make farming and a 60 hour work week financially feasible, ended.

80% of America's population moved into cities where there were factories hiring. Mo Town was born. Motor City. Detroit Wheels. Chicago, the Windy City. Families disintegrated, scattered becoming nuclear families with sometimes a father and a mother and 2.2 children. Worse than that. The mind numbing, backbreaking, repetitive labor, day after day, week after week turned a population into mindless robots

Well here we are just over 110 years later without everything that my generation had no idea we would ever be without and took cellphones, computers, cars, running water, McDonalds, supermarkets and their supplies for granted. Pluck a chicken, carry water? Are you out of your mind?

To tell the truth, myself and most of the survivors (all of them) are of one mind. We've never felt this kind of satisfaction and peace before. The friendships are solid and racism is gone. No one is color blind but without exception anyone and everyone who survived did not do so without the help and trust of friends all making extreme sacrifices for others as the norm and not an exception, even to death.

It feels like Eden returning. A restoration of all things. Could this be the fulfillment of the prophecy," And Babylon was gone in one hour?"
11111212222.title: The way things are now

choices: What things do we take for granted in this day and age/
What woul you miss most if we didn't have the electric and gas
111112122221.content:
I wonder what would happen if we had a shortage of fuel or none at all?
We could not use electrical appliances. cooking would be primitive boiling water for instance would have to be done over a fire of wood.
Our mc Donald burgers for instance ,men would have to slaughter cattle in a way our ancestors did, manually. Then mincing would be a problem unless a manual grinder was available.
Candles would be popular come night. What about keeping warm because there would be no central heating, back to blankets and layering, and what about keeping cool, there would be no Ac. We would take up swimming in whatever pools of water was available.
Getting from one place to another, the Amish have the right idea, horse power, there is a lot to be said for them also bicycles would keep people slim as it's manual.
Harvesting our crops would bring back employment for many. Many people had fun and a better social life, also more satisfaction from a good hard days work and home made lemonade with whatever was available to eat at night.
Climbing stairs in a high rise would cause problems to start with but, eventually a fitter nation.
Hospitals would have to re- invent ways to look after patients. We would be back to water mills for power, treadle sewing machines would be back for making our closes and hand sewing.
Washing clothes by hand because the washing machine is starved of electric and ironing would go back to heating an iron on the cast iron wood burner.
That's just some of the things we take for granted every day. can you think of anything else, there is more?
111112122221.title: Picked up a station sending on the radio from

choices: Jim and his wife, Star Thundercloud with my wife and myself, two pack horse and
Caught trout for dinner at Bishop Lake
1111121222211.content:
Do you remember in the really well done old cartoons they stopped making long before we entered into the Time of Troubles, where a character like Bugs Bunny's jaw drops with mouth wide open and his eyes stretch out of their sockets about ten inches before re-entering his head and the sound effects guy gives a big Bo-i-n-n-g-g-g?

That's what I saw, only in real life and ten people held this pose, not just one cartoon character.

I was one of them. We all started talking at once after we simultaneously returned to the real world ready to discuss what miracle had just transpired.

If it wasn't a group hallucination brought on by a Jungian collective unconscious desiring so intensely for someone to be out there after ten years of searching the Arizona stratosphere for anything from anywhere.

All of us very familiar with the signals received in the far past from anywhere in the world due to how am radio waves functioned in desert nighttime sky.

Jim Thundercloud said drowning out the others to silence," I thought I heard the speaker mention Northern California."

"Yea, I heard that and Sacramento with some numbers before it faded to a squawk," Jorge Mendoza, my nearest neighbor volunteered.

"Please Lord," my wife prayed," let us hear some more."

Her prayer or begging was answered immediately by," cr-r-rrr-r, ss-sssss,
Hello, hello to anyone that might be receiving this shot in the dark. My name is
cr-r-s, vin Donner. That's Kevin Donner, sending at 650 on your dial from just outside of the City of Sacramento, California. My home is on the banks of the Lower American River, twenty miles from where Sutter stole his friends mining claim for himself. My latitude and longitude is 38.5817 degrees North, and 121.4933 degrees West."

" The reason I'm giving you lat. and long. is because If you are receiving this message, I need to find out. You don't have to sail here but it is possible and probably the easiest way to get here, now that there aren't cars, trains, buses. I have seen two motorcycles in ten years. Sailing and horseback is what we use. Mark Twain used to write for the Sacramento Union, Letters From Hawaii and took the paddle wheel steamer from Sacramento to San Francisco several times. If you can get to the City or are from around the Bay Area, go to the Marina District, Embarcadero, Pier 39. We got the old steamer running and make a river run once a month arriving at Pier 39 on the third Thursday of each month. The Sacramento River connects to the American and the Feather. They have become our highways just like old times."

" To those who may be out there, I broadcast at 12:00 am, 6:00, 8:00, 10:00 and 12:00 pm. I've found and been contacted by three listeners so far. Please, if you are receiving this, make every effort possible to inform me of your location, what parts you may need to receive better transmissions and if you find people on your way here who might want or need radios, I have a warehouse full of everything."

" Producing electricity is the problem but is not insurmountable. We are starting to use solar and we are getting better at it.

" Hope life is treating you well and looking forward to seeing you soon. This has been Kevin Donner, and yes, I am a descendant of the infamous Donner party where most came to a cruel end at Donner Summit. One more thing before I sign off. Gold isn't worth anything anymore but I've got a lot of it, so when you get here, I'll give you a pound or two. It makes nice jewelry and doesn't pollute our oceans and streams like lead sinkers did when I used lead when fishing. The fish like the shine off gold far better than lead. If you had of told me ten years ago that someday I would be fishing using gold in place of lead for my sinkers, I would have thought you a nut case."

" Be nice to each other out there, Kevin Donner, master of the air waves, signing off."


" Mary Jane, you are coming with me. Anyone else want a little adventure and to see how others are holding up, is welcome to ride along. I'm thinking, cut over to 395 at Bishop Lake and ride the mountain all the way to Tahoe. Parts of 395 are probably still usable. Maybe we can catch a sailboat back to Long Beach or LA and not have to ride our horses so far. Get a map. I think it's only a little over five hundred miles. Oh yea. It's summer so don't think about the Donner Party."

I went to sleep that night, hearing Dale Evans and Roy Rodgers singing, "Happy trails to you, until we meet again. Happy trails to you, keep smiling on til then. "

I woke up an hour later with a throbbing headache. It seemed to me after Roy and Dale finished, the Quicksilver Messenger Service took over doing their rendition of Happy Trails and right in the middle shifted to Smokestack Lightning.

Just like old times, it was so loud it felt like it broke my eardrums. Loved it when I was 16 and 17. I loved When I'm 64 by the Beatles too, but now that I'm 64 I hate both of them!
1111121222211.title: Picked up a station sending on the radio from

11112.content:
WAR! I yell, to the rising sun
Pick up your weapons, lads; lets have some fun!
With booming cannon and roaring gun
Face up to the foe, and see how they run

The echoes of battle fill the air
Heads up, men; no need to fear!
We’ll be home soon; many miles from here
So fight for the nation, and those we hold dear

Red runs in the earth, as it runs in the sky
Chins up, comrades; men don’t cry!
The fallen scream, as around us they die
Remember those soldiers, who fell where they lie

Empty eyes and grey, gaunt face
Stand up, Private; back to base!
Fall in line; pick up the pace
With the winners, take your place

This terrible memory rings in my head
Buck up, man; remember they’re dead!
Old and alone, with no words to be said
No hope for the fallen, riddled with lead.
11112.title: Memory

111121.content:
If I was being watched by any person from any direction, all they would see was my blank expression. I was sitting in this chair, uncomfortable, ripped and torn with the stuffing falling out in places. I shifted to the side slightly, barely noticeable by my own self. I continued staring out the window, the weather matching how empty I felt. How hollow I felt inside.
As if enough water wasn't falling outside, small drops of water formed at the edges of my eyes before trailing down my cheeks. An endless trail of sadness, words that were unspoken, that could not be spoken. I sat at this dreary window, watching the depressing weather outside, reflecting on life. How pointless it seemed now. Life, all that matters. Everything any human knows. Can be disrupted so easily by others. The day flashed in my mind again, the words that were spoken between us; the words that weren't spoken and should have been.
Nothing helped less, than the fact that it was all my fault. It always was. More liquid spilled slowly down my cheeks, silent sorrow flowing from the eyes. She left me with a broken heart. My life. Left me feeling hollow inside...
111121.title: Hollow inside

1111211.content:
I screamed a long "Aaaaaahhhhhhh," into the nothingness around me. Nothingness because she had gone and nothing, nobody could replace her. I had lost my grandfather, my grandmother, my mother, my step-mother and my father but never had I felt so sad, so empty and alone. She was with me for most of her life. She chose to leave her home and live with me because I didn't just hand out food and shelter, I loved her and cared for her and she returned the same to me.

I cannot talk to anybody about these feelings of loss because they will say, "She was just a cat, you can get another one." Love is love, you have it and you lose it because that is life. She was my friend, my companion, part of my own life, part of me has gone and yet I don't know where.

I knew that she was going to die; the Vet had not given me any hope. I mulled over whether I should have her put down, worried that she was suffering. She did not appear to be suffering as she lay on my chest, her head on my shoulder and her soft purring telling me that she was happy.

The day she died she said goodbye in the way that only she could. She lay on a chair in the sun while I hung some washing and not ten minuets later she gave a little cry. I immediately took her in my arms as the life faded from her and her little body seemed empty having lost its essence, that which was my precious darling, my friend, my companion. "Aaaaahhhhhhhhh!"

I cannot replace her but I can bring another home to give love to, other's like her on death row, being fed and cared for, but with a death sentence hanging over their head. I love you already little one, whoever you are!
1111211.title: Loss

11112111.content:
I smiled down at the cardboard box of tiny bodies, of little lives we had to nurture. "They're adorable," I murmured, venturing to pet the one with auburn fur as deep a red as my hair. Her minuscule eyes, rimmed with pink, blinked up at me, tiny sapphires set in her wrinkled face.
         "That one's Little Ann," Mom said, setting a ramekin of milk among the baby blankets. Annie pawed at one of my waist-length locks as it spilled over into her nest of warmth. "You know, like from Where the Red Fern Grows."
         I smiled, admiring the wriggling balls of fur and love. "Because she sits there and watches it with you when you stuff your face with Crunch N Munch!"
         "Naturally." Mom picked up the twin males in each of her hands. I could only tell who the sickly one was because of the tiny bald spot at the tip of his tail. "What did I name these ones?"
         "Well, Mom, I named the oldest Marco Polo, 'cause he was the first to wander away from the litter." Stroking his nose with my finger, I set my hair against the hue that was so like his sister's fur. The black rings around his dark eyes and nose reminded me of a raccoon or bandit. "Too bad he's such a scaredy-cat."
         "The other one's Tigger, then." Mom set Tigger in my lap, pointing out the stripes that reminded us kids of his namesake. "Don't let your father know that I told you, but he's his favorite. Tigger didn't breathe when he was born, and your father ended up doing mouth-to-muzzle to keep him alive."
         I nodded, smiling at Mellissa's favorite. "I know Annie's yours," I said, replacing Tigger in the box for feeding, "Tigger's Dad's, Marco's mine, and Gheradelli's Mellissa's...." The dark puppy, in stark contrast to Annie, began wrestling with her sister. Gheradelli ended up accidentally kicking the runt, who yelped and retreated into her favorite corner. "Let me guess, Sarah's the only one who likes this ugly thing." I wrinkled my nose at her. With her mis-matched coloring, she reminded me of a Rottweiler or something like that, except far more docile. "She's so ugly, she's cute."
         "You named her Johnette, right?"
         Laughing, I replied, "Well, she was the one that was born right next to the toilet."
         "The surprise puppy." Mom smiled at Johnette, replaced Marco, and took her in her arms. "We thought Murphy was only going to have four, then she came along. Sarah loves her because they're both the babies, I think."
         "Watch, she's the one we'll get stuck with."
         True to my prediction, Johnette--renamed Reeses, then Brandy--was our new companion. When she and her siblings were born on August 29, 2004 to my dog, Murphy, Murphy abandoned them after only a few weeks, leaving us to care for them. At four days old, Tigger died, a heartbreak to us all. Gheradelli left the remaining four first, finding herself in a good home. Then went Annie, the alpha female. I go to school with the son of the woman who took her in, and he tells me that she helps their other deaf dog and also assisted an ill family member on the road to recovery after having extensive hip problems herself. That left us with Marco and Brandy. Marco was a scaredy-cat, something hilariously in contrast with his large size and good nature. We called him a big, cuddly teddy bear. It was his size that forced us to take him to an animal shelter that did not dispose of unwanted animals by euthanasia.
         That left us with Brandy, my new companion. She turns six at the end of this month, but I can't even contemplate calling her ugly any more. We're constantly at each other's sides; she sleeps in my bed at night, waits up in the family room for me until I go to bed. Mom trained her to treat my two younger sisters and me like her own puppies, so she will even scold us if we've been out too long and cries until we get home from school or church.
         Before now, I never would have thought that I would love her as much as I do now, my Mama Dog, my constant companion.
11112111.title: A new companion

111121111.content:
She watched as they ran. At first, it was only the people who had been out on the street when it happened who started running, but as people started looking out their doors and windows to find out what was going on, it eventually became the whole town. It was strange to watch. Some were very organized about it, grabbing a coat and some valuables as they made for the door, but most were panicked to the point of near-hysteria, abandoning everything they had as they ran towards the edge of town. Away from her.

As the people got further away, she got tired of watching them. Instead, she looked down.

What had once been a young man was laying at her feet, nothing more than a burned-out corpse. Steam rose gently from his remains. What had once been his arm had broken off, and was now grasped in her hand, as burned as the rest of him.

She had grabbed his arm as she argued with him. That was all it took. That single physical contact, and her rage consumed him.

A shout from just ahead made her look up. Some men, some of whom she recognized, were walking towards her, carrying weapons. They were telling her not to make this harder than it had to be, to just surrender peacefully. She didn't understand why they thought they had to arrest her.

After all, it was just an accident. Couldn't they see that?
111121111.title: Accident

11112112.content:
Companion to a madman,
She spins the wheel, the throws the darts.
It's a story as old as time,
and each revel in their part

She straightens up, and spins the wheel,
as he lets another fly
Who was to know, on this day,
the marks were you and I?

Her laughter is the sunshine,
as his arrows hit his 'aims'.
Another day, passing the time;
Fate and Cupid, playing games
11112112.title: Companion to a...

choices: Comas could go on for a decade or more. Will he ever snap out of it?
If he does will he be able, will he be interested, in catching up?
111121121.content:
...and now Thanatos is up to bat.

He lies there with no awareness of the passage of time, no reaction to the people who come and go.

He doesn't see the tears and hear the pleas of those who want him to wake up and the beeps of life support equipment go on and on...steadily.

You see, he's been placed in The Indestructible Box from which he may never escape.
111121121.title: The games continue with The Indestructible Box...

1111212.content:
Hope may be the thing with feathers, but love is the one that keeps the secrets.

In seven years, when the statute of limitations runs out, I may begin telling our shared stories. Then again, I may not. I'm jealous like that.

The divot I tore out of Marshall Scuthrow's lawn has healed-you can no longer tell the section he re-seeded after I tore across his front yard at a hundred and ten. That car went to the scrap yard a year ago. It went about a hundred yards too far, riding on its roof. Speaking of roofs: the stone house where we played beer bottle baseball was condemned shortly after you left. It's in such disrepair you would swear it's slowly sinking back into the muddy earth. Missy went missing the month after you died, and was found three days later. It's officially listed as 'unknown causes' You'd never believe this, but I quit drinking. My body and my wallet just can't afford it any more. I still buy your girl birthday and christmas presents. She deserves to have someone love her as much as you did. She deserves you, but I understand your life was hard. I don't judge. I miss you, but I don't judge.

I have long ago forgiven you that last hundred dollars you could never seem to pay back. There are people I like less that owe me more.

I keep you memory gaurded in my heart, wrapped in that tattered black thermal you gave me in '04. You only come up in passing now, with people and places that share memories of you, and nights like tonight when sleep won't come.

Goodnight, my brother. I will see you in Valhalla.
1111212.title: Love

choices: Packing a bag, jumping in the car, and keep on driving till I find my home
111122.content:
How did I survive 13 years with him? It wasn't easy. It was like being in a dark room with no means of escape. The room was small and the darkness large, I would be in a corner with a small, flickering candle. At the worst of times the flame would give off no warmth and little light. I would open my eyes and pray to god that I was dead. Strike me with lighten, run with over with a bus, infect me with cancer. God, please just kill me. Of course, it never happen. Every morning I would wake up to another day in the dark room, except the darkness grew.
Then he goes to jail and we're free. No dark rooms and thoughts of death, right? Wrong! I felt different from the other kids and i was marked as an outsider at the new school. There was no longer a room but that didn't stop the darkness from chasing me into a corner. The candle was always there but it was never strong enough to beat back the dark. So what changed?
I became a gamer. Oh, sure, it began on an anime forum. That's where i met the first few people who changed my life. They couldn't see me and they didn't know my story. If they like me it was because of who I was. When the forum went down my brother got me into gaming. From there you know the rest. It was one mmorpg after the other. Always with the same three people by my side. Angelo, Tony, Marissa, and then there was my brother. They were my online family, they are my family. Its been five years since that anime forum, and now I can feel the darkness closing in again. It's funny how I never realized it had left.
I feel the darkness as it tries to chase into that corner, in that small room. I refuse to let it happen. My little candle has grown into a bonfire. That faint flickering light of hope grew. The darkness is all the wrongs done to me and, now, to my friends. The bonfire is all the things and people who mean something to me. Angelo, Tony, Hiro, Marissa, Joe, Brice, Andy, Kigen. My online family that pushed through high school. Even Nathan finds his way into the list, even though he added a little to the darkness too. Flyff, my favorite mmorpg, was the biggest help I ever had. It was what helped me meet my friends.
It's hard to explain , how they have giving me hope. I know my real family doesn't understand. I'm not going to explain.
You just wanted to know how I survived. Well there you go. Years from now I wonder if I can say that I made a difference in their lives liek they made one in mine.

*True story*
111122.title: A faint flicker of hope

1111222.content:
The concrete against my back feels cold and slick. My arms tire from squeezing my knees into my chest. Breathing is difficult regardless of my position. It's only been a week and still I can't find myself to leave the basement. Everything that I loved taken in one swift motion. How will I survive? I can't stay here any longer. It is unbearable to live in this house.
Outside the city is still booming with life, yet in here, in this house, life has stop. It has taken its last breath. I slowly release my knees and begin to slide up the concrete wall. My legs are sore from sitting for so long. I feel numb. My mind doesn't register everything around me and I feel like I'm in a fog that makes my vision blurred. I just can't stay here anymore. Tonight is the night. Tonight I pack my bags, jump in the car, and keep driving until I find my home. I just hope that I can find one.
I make my way up the old wooden steps for the last time. Avoiding the stair that creeks the loudest, I step this way and that following the habit that has been formed over the years. The lights no longer work but I know this house better than anyone.
My hand slides down the wall and I make my way through our hallways. I feel the photos hanging marking each year of my life with my parents. I run my hand over the notches just under them marking my height when they were hung. There will never be another notch. There will never be another picture. This can't be home anymore.
I walk into my bedroom and open the closet. My suitcase with the polka dots is sitting there waiting for me. I can't even remember the last time that I used it. I pull it out and begin grabbing clothes. I start to move quicker like a new found energy is seeping through my body. A drug that my mind has created is driving me to push faster than I actually feel I can go. I scrounge up whatever I can find and shove it hard into the suitcase. Putting all my weight on the top, I zip the zipper and run out of the house. I just can't be here.
With my bags packed I jump into the car. Cali has been great but it's just not home anymore. I think it's time to head east. I remember seeing pictures of forests covered in white. Like a wonderland that no person has ever discovered. Trees cover the roads like a canopy as rays of sun flicker through the leaves and branches.
Yes, that's where I will go. I will start again. Find my way and create a life in the wonderland of white and the undiscovered forest. I will allow nature to heal and mend me. I will find the place that will be called home by allowing my heart to guide me to the healing that it needs. I roll the windows down, blare the music, pull out of the drive way and move forward to my future.
1111222.title: Packing a bag, jumping in the car, and keep on ...

11113.content:
My home exists solely as a memory now. The humble little house with the white picket fence. The white picket fence, with the slats spaced so perfectly, one foot apart, held together by the boards painted so white. So white. Just like Baron's suit, so white, so white and pure and clean. I want to go back, to go back to Bethel and live there and stay there and smell the fire, the burning leaves and the burning air that burns my lungs as my house burns.

My life has been about getting back to Bethel. I've lived many places. As soon as I settle in one place, I need to move, to keep moving, moving like a shark. If I stop, I die.

Bethel. Even the name, just the name of Bethel, it's like warm spring days with kids riding bikes in groups, eating vanilla ice cream cones with one perfect scoop sitting on top of the beautiful, burnt-brown cone. Perfect children, with the boys dressed in button-down shirts and slacks. The girls would all have long hair with ribbons and gingham skirts. Their fathers would all have good jobs and drive big metal cars. Their mothers would all make meat and potatoes for dinner, with something rubbery and gelatinous for dessert. My mother would make pot roast with cooked potatoes and peas and carrots for dinner. With something rubbery and gelatinous for dessert. And I would drink milk, white milk. White, pure and clean.

I think about Bethel, even when I'm not thinking about Bethel. It's always in my mind, it's always the goal, the place I need to go to. There I can dig my hands in the dirt and plant vegetables, which I will have my mother cook with potatoes and serve with pot roast. Roasted meat, meat roasted in the fire, like the fire that took away my home and my past and my childhood. Like the man in the white suit.

I will find that man. Then I will find Bethel.
11113.title: Obsession

choices: And Then There Was Only One
111132.content:
I stand atop a skyscraper, overlooking the city. The glimmering lights from the street below, both automobiles and signs, reflect off my face.

The city really is weird. Rushing below me is a perfect example. I mean, I could point at a random spot on the road and most likely find something strange. A limousine with a second floor and green headlights? Really? Who would need that? Ah, what the good life will be like.

Why am I doing this to myself?

The wind lightly whips against my face, drowning out my thoughts. A red light blinks behind me as the stars blinked above. There's no need to worry. It's just one of the blinking scarlet beams that tells planes and helicopters alike "Watch out! Definite huge spire here! Do not hit!"

Speaking of helicopters, I hear one now.

Adrenaline rushes through my body. I'm not afraid to say I'm afraid. The copter passes by me, though, and continues on its nightly business. I glance behind me, to the small black box. Once my helicopter comes, I get $200,000 immediately, and millions wired into the bank account. No questions asked at all.

And I'm just the messenger. Even with the monumental amount I'm getting, the guy who took the box himself will get enough to buy and sell me fifty times over. Or a hundred. It doesn't really matter, does it? If you can buy and sell someone once, you can do it a billion times.

FWIP-WIP-WIP-WIP!

That's the helicopter. That's my ticket. Soon I'll be living the good life. Why? Why am I doing this? I know it's not right. I know I'll probably be contributing to some New World Order or some Illuminati crap like that. I lean down, grabbing the box. The chopper nearly deafens me as it lands. It exudes a dark aura, an evil aura. I can't do this. No matter how much I get.

SNAP-HISS!

The jet-black door slides open. I'm here, holding the box, as the rotors whip wind into my face, and across from me the man is walking out. I can't do this. There's no way. I knew I couldn't when I saw the pearly white hair flip back, and the scarlet eyes sparkle. He's wearing a custom suit, made as dark as possible. I'm wearing casual clothes. No, no, no. I reach to toss the box over the edge, but before I can he's trained a handgun on me.

"This is not the time to get cold feet," he says, in his impossibly suave, layered voice. I can hear the malice behind it. "That box is finally mine, and the contents will be as well."

"I won't give it to you," I say, in as confident a voice as I can. His very presence is intimidating.

"Then I'll shoot you. And I'll get the box anyway. As a matter of fact..." he says, looking up for a second, "I might just shoot you anyway. Save myself 3.2 million dollars."

"Then I truly do have no other option," I say.

"Correct. Now hand me the box."

"That's not what I meant," I say, as I lean backward. I see his face become instantly scared, like a movie villain who's just realized they've lost the upper hand.

So had he.

I hear a reverberating bang as I topple back, box in hand, over the side of the skyscraper. He screams, but I lose the sound in the few seconds before my body meets the cars.
111132.title: Cars

choices: Another day comes to an end
1112.content:
Leaves green, red, yellow, orange
falling as winter takes hold
untill springs rebirth
1112.title: leaves

11121.content:
Another day comes to an end,
through the cave, around the final bend.
I drift off into sleeping bliss,
to dream of souls so dearly missed.
Away from the worlds hand so cold,
to dream of being valiant and bold.
Dreams are a wonderful wonderful thing,
like when you recieved or gave your first wedding ring.
you can be so much more than you already are,
you could be a music or movie star.
But alas all things good come to an end,
untill you can return to dreamland again.
11121.title: Another day comes to an end

111211.content:
The sweet smell of rain,
Invigoratingly fresh
As the drops splash down.

Cool drops splash into
Puddles, draining into the
Fertile flower beds.

Tangled webs of roots
Drink the sweet liquid, gathering
Tomorrow's life in.

Sweet petals and leaves
Accept the sparkle of those
Cool, refreshing drops.

Raindrops sit on petals
As dazzling pearls, each a kiss
From God to the world.
111211.title: Rain

1112111.content:
Here I sit in the rose garden
And while away the hours
Thinking and singing and playing
Among the beautiful flowers.

The roses glow scarlet in mid-morning light,
The dancing daffodils in many a hue.
I sit on the bench in the dew-covered grass
To see the lark's wings as it flew.

Too much do we miss of the garden
When engulfed in everyday life.
The simplest of things are always the best,
And gardens of good are rife.

There is never a word nor look
Nor fear-inspiring phrase
To destroy the garden's peace,
For it is peaceful all of our days.

Here I sit in the rose garden,
Glowing in mid-morning light;
For the simplest of things are always the best,
Here I shall stay both day and night.
1112111.title: Rose Garden

11121111.content:
Peace was a perfect stranger to me for almost 19 years. From the time I was born my life was chaotic and cruel. My biological mother and her side of the family seemed bent on making my life hell, with the help of my classmates, the vast majority of whom didn't particuarly like me, simply because I dismally failed to be what was widely considered "cool." My only sources of relief were my father, my younger brother, and my two best friends, who were the only ones who didn't beat me down with snide remarks and mocking laughter. Most of my time was spent hating who I was, and of course, the world in general.

Then one night, on January 2, 2009, I was lying in bed, the thoughts of all I had gone through threatened to crush me under their immense weight. Silent tears rolled down my cheeks, and my body shook madly. I couldn't take it. I wanted, almost more than anything, to sneak into the bathroom and grab the shaving razor, the tool that had helped me for the past several years. But one thing held me back: the hope that if I cried out to a God who I wasn't even sure existed, and He responded, then I would be rescued from all my demons. "God please..........I can't do this.........just help me, God........" I whispered through my tears. Less than a minute later, I felt an overwhelming sense of peace, a peace that I had never known before. And I knew, in that moment, that God was real, and I was saved.
11121111.title: Peace

111211111.content:
After that experience I moved on physically, spiritually and emotionally. I experimented with different ways of being, exercising, meditating and practicing positive affirmations regularly. I was surprised to see how much difference it made to me.

For some reason I decided to take a few days break at the seaside. I stayed in a B&B just outside the town. It was quiet and the gardens were amazing filled with flowers and smells that I couldn't identify. I'd sit there most of the day, sometimes writing and sometimes simply enjoying the place and the peace it offered.

One day I went down to the main beach. It was manic with holidaymakers, ice creams, candyfloss, amusement arcades and rows of individual booths selling trinkets and gifts.

A woman called to me as I passed her stall, "You have the gift, don't you lovey?"

I stopped, startled, thinking I'd misheard her.

"Just give me a minute of your time and I'll show you." She reached behind her and drew out a small crystal ball. "Here, look into this and tell me what you see."

I laughed "I'm not a fortune teller."

"No," she said "You're more than that. Go on. Look."

And so I did and the clarity of the glass seemed to cloud and I could see two figures walking down the beach. I felt an urgent need to warn them that something bad was going to happen. I could feel my pulse rise but I looked away, knowing it was some sort of con.

"You don't believe do you?" the woman said. She pulled back a dark purple, heavy weight curtain and brought out an even smaller crystal. "This is for you. Use it or not."

"No thanks, I'm not shopping." I replied with a grin. Relieved to have been proven right.

"There's no charge" she said. "It's yours." She wrapped the crystal in dark cloth and handed it to me.

I hesitated before taking it.
111211111.title: Crystal ball

choices: The Lunatics Have Taken Over the Asylum
111211112.content:
"I hate to bother you, but my car broke down just down the road and I'm afraid I let the battery run down on my cell, can I use your phone to call for help?"

"Certainly, come right in! You look like you're frozen half to death, why don't you have a seat here in the parlor and I'll have Martha bring you a cup of tea first."

"Thank you sir, you're too kind. I noticed the sign outside, "Shady Grove," is this a convalescent hospital?"

"Not exactly, although it is a place where our residents can find peace. I'm Doctor Martin, I'm in charge here. Let me go see how Martha is coming along with your tea, I'll be right back."

In the kitchen: "Martha, why don't you slip a couple milligrams of Ativan into our guest's tea to make him more comfortable."

"OK Doctor, I have the bottle right here."

Back in the living room:

"Here's you tea, sir. Sorry, I didn't catch you name."

"I'm Leonard Davis, but you can call me Lennie. This tea is wonderful, it's so relaxing. I should probably call about the car now, can you bring me the phone?"

"All in good time Lennie, just rest a while first."

Martha walks into the room and giggles: "Look Doctor, he's fast asleep! Should I prepare a room for him?"

"Yes, the one at the end of the hall with the lock on the outside. Once it's ready you can help me carry him down."

"He seems like a fine young man, he could be useful in our experiments. Will he be staying on a while?"

"I believe he will, Martha, I believe he will..."
111211112.title: We're All a Little Insane

1112111121.content:
"Help! Get me outta here!"

A voice calls out from the other side of the wall: "Shhh! Be quiet or they'll come back! It's better if they leave us alone."

"Who are you?"

"I'm Estelle, I'm locked in the next room. I'm a nurse here, or I used to be until those two took over."

"So that man isn't Doctor martin?"

"No, his name is Norman Stringer, he was a patient here, so was Martha. This is a hospital for the criminally insane."

"What happened to the real Doctor Martin?"

"If you look out the window in the back yard you'll see three mounds of dirt, he's buried under the one on the left."

A voice calls out from outside the door: "Lennie! It's time for your treatment!"

Estelle calls out from the other side of the wall: "Whatever you do don't fight them, it only makes it worse..."

The door opens and Martha and the "Doctor" enter. He's holding a meat cleaver, she has a large syringe in her hand...
1112111121.title: The Lunatics Have Taken Over the Asylum

11121111211.content:
Lennie shoves Martha away as she approaches him with the hypo, cowers in the corner.

"No! Leave me alone!"

"Come now, Lennie, this is for your own good! The needle is nothing to fear, just something to relax you. If you insist on struggling I will be forced to draw some of the bad blood from your body through your neck to calm you down."
.
Martha approaches again with the needle, and this time, realizing he can't win, Lennie allows her to inject him. His vision begins to get cloudy as Martha grabs onto his arm to support him. They walk him out of the room and into the kitchen. They place him in a chair in front of a butcher block table. Lennie slumps helplessly, face down onto the table.

"Shall I sterilize the instrument, Doctor?" Martha asks

"Oh yes, by all means."

She turns on the gas stove and holds the cleaver in the flame for a minute, until whatever was left on it begins to smoke.
She hands it to the "doctor". He stretches Lennie's limp left arm across the table and slams the cleaver down, severing the tips of three fingers past their top knuckles. Lennie moans in his unconscious state, vaguely aware of the pain.

"He's bleeding quite a bit, Doctor, shall I cauterize the wounds?"

"Certainly, Martha."

She heats the cleaver in the flame once again, then presses the flat of it against the wounds, Lennie moans again in pain.

"That should be sufficient, Martha, the bleeding has stopped now."

The "doctor" looks down at the unconscious Lennie and speaks: "Young man, you have done quite well for your first treatment. Pain is part of the healing process, suffering will make you well again! Someday you will thank me for this valuable lesson."

He turns and speaks to his "nurse": "Martha, please help me get Lennie back to his room, our patient needs his rest..."
11121111211.title: Resistance if Futile

111211112111.content:
Escape?
Impossible.
Hugging myself in an
Insane asylum straightjacket
Locked away for life in a padded cell.
My family has forgotten.
I will never be free.
Escape? No way!
Inmate
111211112111.title: No Escape

11121111212.content:
I hear the child's bare-footed steps crunching the leaves. He's close, now. So close - closer! I can see his feet through a hole in the dirt, his little toe as long as I am tall. My body shivers, and I wait. Oh, please! Please look down! There is darkness all around. I can see naught but that great pink toe, as it digs into the soft dirt above me. I feel a chunk of mud fall upon my upraised face, but pay it no mind. The musty life of imprisonment has been with me too long; it bothers me little now.

My muscles tense as his feet dig into the ground to my right. But the next step leads him farther right. My heart falls, my stomach burns with injustice. I scream at him in my head, wish I could scream, wish I could call to him... but I have no mouth. I am trapped, forever trapped, down the rabbit hole.
11121111212.title: Down the Rabbit Hole

111211112121.content:
They were telling me all about all their problems ,like they usually do.

Martha, crying about how she felt so used because her children never picked up after themselves.

Then Ginger, wearing her usual skin-tight slacks and low cut blouse, not understanding why men always said suggestive things to her that made her feel bad about herself.

I try my best to recommend the obvious solutions to their problems, but they just don't listen. Instead they just come back, week after week, with the same complaints.

Is it any wonder psychiatrists have such a high suicide rate?
111211112121.title: They were telling me

1112111121211.content:
Honestly, Jolene, I don't know why I even try anymore. Ever since their father left, the boys have been such holy terrors to keep under control. Fighting, skipping school, talking back to me, and I just found a baggie of heroin or cocaine in Billie's pants pocket when I went to do the wash the other day, I just can't take any more!

What about that therapist you've been seeing, hasn't he been able to give you any help? Any ideas on what you should do?

Doctor Robertson? He's pretty much worthless. he tells me instead of yelling at them I should use logic and treat them like adults instead of like teenage brats, Said I should share my feelings with them. I tried that, what a bunch of crap! Just like the doctor suggested I told Billie "When you disrespect me by bringing drugs into this house it makes me feel angry and sad." and you know what Billie did? he said "Boo-fuckin'-hoo, too bad for you! I'm gonna do what I want, and if you say anything about it I'll tell the social worker you're a slut and a junkie, and those are your drugs." What can I say to that?

Well Martha, I have a friend on the police force, he's in charge of a program that's geared towards getting kids like yours turned around before it's too late for them. I'll give you his number if you want to look into it.

Thanks, Jolene. I'll write it down and give him a call after we're done talking.
1112111121211.title: Martha, on the phone:

11121112.content:
"The simplest of things are always the best", I couldn't have said it any better.

Not long after the divorce I got sick and tired enough of the L.A. rat race to throw it all away.
Quit my job, cashed in my 401K, and put the money into my savings account. (Don't trust the stock market anymore, too many greedy schemers trying to figure out how to rip us off.)

Ashley Bedroom Set, Lane Leather Sofa and Recliner, Sub Zero Fridge, Bosch Oven, 46" Sony LCD TV?
Sold them all on Craigslist for pennies on the dollar, glad to be rid of 'em.

Traded in my GS 460 for a '98 Silverado and a 25' Airstream.
Sold my condo for 270K, bought myself a 50 acre chunk of land 25 miles outside of Homer Alaska, got 200K in change that I used to buy gold. (Figured that might come in handy later on, if things really went to hell.)

Took my time driving up to Alaska, spent a couple weeks in campgrounds along the way.
Met a lot of good folks, really restored my faith in humanity.

Eventually I made it to my land in Alaska and got my trailer all set up. After a couple weeks of peace and quiet I decided that the best thing to do was...
11121112.title: The Simple Things

111211121.content:
The folks in the campgrounds had given me lots of advice. By far the most frequent was, "Lay in enough wood. It gets colder than you can imagine. When the winter comes you won't have time to chop any."

No problem. I'm young and strong, and if the pioneers could do it, so could I. Anyway, my land had lots of trees. Water too. I'd set up my trailer near a stream that gurgled into a clear pond, almost a small lake. I had plenty of buckets, so I'd have plenty of water. I had a chain saw, an ax, a maul, and several pairs of work gloves. I was all set.

So it was I woke on June 28 at 6am to brilliant sunshine and 58 degrees. This was the life. I ate a hearty breakfast of sausage and eggs and got to work. I scouted my property, finding lots of dead wood. This was great. Revving up the chain saw, I started in on a fallen tree not two hundred yards from my trailer. By noon I had cut up the tree into short sections and split a considerable amount. Boy was that hard work. My work shirt was drenched with sweat. I was ready to sit down for a couple of hours. I ate three ham sandwiches and finished my thermos of coffee.

In the afternoon I finished splitting the wood. Now it was time to transport it to my storage area. I was able to maneuver my Silverado to the work site and loaded as much as I could. Transporting took more trips than I had counted on. By six the sun was still bright with no indication of oncoming dusk. I had had a full day and was ready for a big dinner. As I started in on a beef stew, I heard a voice.

"Anybody home?" It was an old man about seventy. He was dressed in work clothes that were faded and soiled from hard use. He looked like the stereotype of the old prospector, complete with the worn hat.

"Come on in," I said, glad to see someone.

"Don't mind if I do," he said, hopping into my trailer. "New here, are ya?"

"Yup, just bought this land. Started chopping wood for winter."

"That's good, Sonny. I'm Pete Vaughn. I live mile or so from here. What brings you to Alaska?"

"I'm Jack Montgomery. I left LA. Starting over. This is a change from the big city rat race."

Pete regarded me and said, "Lots more people do that than you might think. Some even stay."

"Why would they leave? This is a great place, beautiful country, and it isn't the city."

Pete laughed. "Show me your wood, if you don't mid.

Mystified I showed him my day's work.

"Is that all you have? Son, you need more wood that you can imagine. When you think you have enough, you probably need three times that amount. That's what the city folks never understand. You left the big city, and you think this is the simple life. It is, but the simple life isn't the easy life. You'll spend all day every day putting in wood. Then the winter comes, it's dark all the time, and you sit by your stove hoping you have enough. Then the stream freezes and there's no water. 'Bout then the big city starts to look better and better."

I gazed at the old man in dismay. In my enthusiasm I had not looked at the hard work from that angle. "Why is it people come here?"

"Some are running, escaping from their past. Maybe you're different. I wish you luck, Jack." With that he left, walking away with a slow gait. He looked over his shoulder and said, " I'll be by next week to see how you're doin'."


Crazy old fool I thought. I worked hard the next . All the time I noticed how much harder it was to get the Silverado to where I'd been working. I watched as my woodpile grew, all the time wondering if the old geezer was on the money or just trying to scare me. Then the last two days of the week, the weather turned nasty and I just sat inside growing more morose by the hour. I hooked up the trailer to the Silverado and set out for the city.

A little while later Pete Vaughn came by and saw the empty camp site. He took out a cell phone. "Jerry? Yeah that Montgomery fella left. Doesn't look like he's comin' back. You can probably buy his land back for a good price."
111211121.title: Chp Wood and Carry Water

choices: return to my property to find...
returned and found everything as I'd left it
1112111211.content:
It took several hours to get to the first decent semblance of civilization and that consisted of a small merchantile with a bar and grill counter that seated seven, a gas station with old '60s style pumps with faded markings that read Texico, but who really knew what company supplied the gas now, and an old shack with a whitewashed wooden cross in front of it.

I pulled in front of the pumps and shut down my engine. Before I had the door open a portly woman with greying hair and a round face asked what I'd like.

"Fifty bucks worth in the back tank, please." I stretched and looked across the road where the merc was. "Is the store open for business, it looks a bit dark inside."

The woman opened the flap to my rear gas tank and scowled, then I remembered there were lock caps that needed keys; I dug the truck keys out of my pocket and unlocked the cap. "Sorry, I'm not use to full service pumps."

"Yup, the merc is open. Go ahead and leave yer truck here. It won't be a bother."

I smiled and walked over to the store and stepped inside. It was dim and smelled of stale woodsmoke. A couple guys were seated at the bar with partially filled beer mugs before them. On of the fellas was named Jerry, the same guy who sponsored the place I'd bought. I sat at the bar and acknowledged the guys with a nod. The barkeep wasn't in sight so I tapped once on the little bell to let him know he had another customer.

Before the barkeep showed up, Jerry had grabbed his mug and walked over to my end of the bar. "Mind if I join you?"

"No not at all. Have a seat."

"I see you have your rig across the street, you leaving already?" He grinned from ear to ear like the cheshire cat and tipped a drink.

"No, just needed to get away from the property for a little and brought my bed with me. Thought I'd get at least one night away before weather set in and I couldn't come in."

As I spoke I thought I saw his smile freeze on his face. His eyes seemed to narrow a bit too. But Jerry recovered quickly and left me wondering if I'd really seen his instant of disappointment.

"Well, good good to hear you are going to stick it out. How much wood do you have laid in?"

"Oh I am still cuttin' wood and hauling water, although, my water reservoir is nearly full now. I got it inside a small shed I can keep warm with a fire so hopefully it won't freeze."

Jerry scratched his head. "Well I hope that works for ya. Winter gets mighty cold and storms can keep ya from keeping a fire going in an out building."

About that time the lights popped on and cut the gloom in the store. Burt walked in from the back room wiping grease off his hands. "Oh heya, like a beer?"

"Actually, what I'd really like are some large jerry cans to put diesel in. I thought I might want to put in some extra fuel for the generator I bought a couple months back. Also, do you have some sacks of flour, sugar, and rice I can purchase; also some cans of crisco or other cooking lard, and maybe some other things you think I may need before the snow comes."

"Certainly, we can get you all that, here is a list of things I've found people have stocked up and some things they've told me they had wished they'd had before the snow melt." Burt handed over a small spiral note book. I opened it up and looked through it. All in all the back of the silverado was packed solid and the trailer too was packed tight with just enough room for me to walk through to get to the bunk the stove and the fridge.

I drank a couple more beers and listened to Jerry, Burt and Ralph talk about bears, wolverines, blizzards and some casualties of first-timers in these parts. I thanked them for all the advice and life lessons they offered and wondered why everyone was being so helpful in making sure I was prepared for the coming winter under the shadow of Denali. I admit when I first packed up and headed off my property I was set to keep on going south, but the longer it took to drive the more wrong it felt for me to just give up. This country was beautiful and wild and something called to me that I couldn't resist. It may be the death of me, but life in the lower forty-eight held no more promise of survival either. Jerry seemed down right determined to make sure I knew exactly what I was stepping into. He was a good Joe. Burt, too seemed concerned, he seemed worried that another city slicker was going to be pulled out feet first, but acknowledged that I had up a good stock as long as I had enough wood in for the winter. And Ralph, he seemed the most confident of the three that I just might make it long enough to decide if I'd like to try another year in the wild or go back to the pampered city.

I had pulled the truck and trailer in front of the merc to load it up earlier and Margie had just shook her head when she watched me load all the goods into my trailer and truck. She had her oldest son help me with the jerry cans filled with diesel and one with gasoline. I pulled into the turnabout at the edge of town, locked up tight, placed the 'bear bells' and line to trigger the alarm incase I had an unwanted visitor, then crawled into the bed and slept like a stone.

I woke early and stepped outside the Airstream to piss and greet the day. ,A beautiful sunrise! Salmon sky with a fog bank above the spruce, I'm so glad I decided to move here and leave the lower 48 behind!

I drove back to my homestead and was surprised to see an old Plymouth Voyager with Colorado plates parked out front. I called out "Hello! Who's there!"

A woman in faded jeans and a flannel shirt walked out the front door of my cabin. "Sorry I went in uninvited, but it was cold outside last night and the door wasn't locked."

I recognized her immediately. "Brenda? What the hell are you doing here?"

11121112111111.content:
Thank you so much for such a uniquely phrased question. "Does he get to stay there?"
As you know it is a promise that your questions will be answered. Your particular question is extremely fun to answer. Some are no fun at all as they require concise, articulate and definitive answers that make me feel no freedom or liberty in the answer but a type of incarceration, restriction or pragmatism. When this happens I am forced or herded into giving The Answer (the one and only)!
No, would be the answer to your question and I could stop there but what fun would that be. By the rules I am only required to answer your question or questions. and sometimes answer them before you ask. Within your question are other not so obvious questions I might address either to amuse, confuse and/or abuse your worldly sensibilities. Hopefully all three.
Backwards is the best way to explain," Does he get to stay there?" "There" implies a place that has definition. Although ambiguous, the writer of the question has an idea of where and what "there' is or might be. To "stay" means something ceases going away from or leaving behind but remains within something with borders, is stationary existing at a location arrived at.
Get to stay. Get by defination means to receive as a return: Earn. Get implies an authority having say over allowing or disallowing something to stay or not stay for any number of reasons.
Does he. He is masculine. Does the man.

Where is and what is "there" that he might or might not get to stay within? Where is and what is "heaven" to you? We have read or "it is written" that in heaven is no Greek or Jew, Man or Woman. So "he" in heaven isn't a he but is spirit that did arrive. Where? The "he" spirit was freed from the constraints of the World, his flesh and duality. They fell away. Did this spirit go anywhere or simply remember what it has always been when released from the deluge or captivity it was bound by being man for a time.
God is in heaven. God is omnificent, omnipotent and omnipresent. Omnipresent is hard to hear, bare and understand. It means in all places at all times. It is no easier to wrap one's mind around this as it is to contemplate infinity.
When asking where is God now or where and when is heaven, like he is coming here soon and taking everyone who believes to somewhere away, a place in the future located somewhere not here but somewhere else! " Does he get to stay there," isn't as simple as it seems with just a casual glance, is it??
No! "There," like time, darkness, good and bad, worldly perception and this sentence," Does he get to stay there," fall away, have no more meaning, cease to exist as if they never were.
"Does he get to stay there?" Not even close. 11121112111112.content:
"Whoa! Hold on a sec! I gotta get a grip!" I think I said or at least said some of this out loud, as I burst back into a waking reality much more concrete than the world I was exiting!
Damn it! It was a dream? Or was it? What was it and what does it or did it mean?
It's hard to figure when I still have one foot in two seperate realities. I quickly found the pen and paper I keep on my nightstand just for this purpose. The trick is to write down what you can remember as soon and as fast as possible before the trail goes cold and is completely erased in the Sea of Forgetfulness. You've got to be quick, concise and unhesitantly spontaneous. Those who have tried to be dream catures know it's like trying to capture smoke with a fish net.
I don't think the Dream World is any more or less real than the Waking World but have learned they require two seperate languages and that it is very close to impossible to think on or about dreams in the mindset and language (symbol interpretation) of our common physical (waking) reality. Carl Jung can help. He is known as The Father of dream interpretation and in his book, " Dreams, Memories And Reflections," gives some of his findings and insights into his explorations.
Was the experience an illusion? No! However, it was a dream, an unusually detailed and very realistic dream. I believe it was brought on by a very large and rich meal, a telephone call and an intense, revelatory Bible study with two close friends.
The Bearded Clam has crabs. All you can eat with Monday night football and 25 cent draft beer. We, Three Amigos ( our handle) went there after Bible study to put things back into perspective (life is a question of balance)! I got the phone call from Brenda while in the Bearded Clam and could barely make her out for the hoopla surrounding this gala event. I did sense her dispair, was fairly certain of the cause and was more than happy to give her a yay on my place for a little shelter from the storm.
The last time I had seen her she had a black eye. While taking a sabbatical from her problem at The Chataux Relaxo, my digs, I tracked her problem down. Brenda didn't know it and I didn't tell her. I knew she wasn't going to take my advice and kick the little wanker out of her house so I did what I could. I didn't hurt him bad but made him cry real tears of fears. I introduced him to the house of pain and he announced he had seen the error of his ways. It is amazing what can be accomplished with words. I will be really surprised to find he has been beating on Brenda again. The picture I left him with was for him to pretend or actually see that every hand he layed on Brenda he was really laying on himself. I informed him I didn't like him anyway and it was in his best interests to not have me come back and repeat myself. I explained the meaning of Just us!
I haven't figured out why Brenda shot me in my dream? I am blind in my right eye and am having surgery, a new lens put in two weeks from now. The damage wasn't caused by a knitting needle. There is no reward out for me that I'm aware of and I don't know anyone in Nogales! The heaven part of the dream must have been stimulated by some new insights we Three Amigos discovered that were hiding in plain sight. It must have opened some spiritual floodgates spilling out onto my dreamscape.
Brenda will be here in a few hours. Won't know for sure what's bothering her until she tells me so I think I'll work on this dream analysis til then. It feels like there is something here I'm supposed to understand a bit better?

111211121111121.content:
Time passed, but I was no closer to an answer. There was the sound of a vehicle stopping in the driveway and I got up and went to open the door.

As I reached for the knob I heard Brenda call, "Patrick, I need your help."

I stepped out onto the porch and reached one conclusion. I wasn't a seer. Brenda wasn't standing out there with a gun in her hand, waiting for me.

She was actually standing, looking down, at something in her trunk. I stepped out onto the driveway and her head came up as her hand shot up to slam the trunk closed.

With an effort, on her part, she brought that hand back down and stepped forward a few paces opening her arms to hug me, to stop me from advancing any further. She squeezed me in a bearhug, stepped back and took a deep breath.

She turned around, saying over her shoulder, "I brought company, Pat. It stopped struggling fifty miles from here. I don't if know it's alive or not."

I had come around to the trunk.and stood, staring. I wasn't prepared for a human, and I certainly wasn't expecting Billy! There he lay, motionless, and trussed up in electrical tape.

When I bent over to examine him, looking for blood, principally, he jackknifed, trying to knock me down. He, not it, was conscious, and the hatred was plain in every line of his body!

Seeing that his mouth had been taped shut; he wouldn't be biting anyone for a while, gave me an idea of how to handle him. I picked him up like a bride and slung him over a shoulder like a sack of potatoes!

When I backed up, Brenda slammed the trunk. I handed her the key for the front door and told her to unlock it. If he was going to struggle I might have my hands full.

"What about witnesses?", she asked. I answered, "I chose this house for its isolation. The nearest houses are still a quarter-mile away in any direction."

11121112111121222.content:
"Wasilla?", he thought, taking it all in at a glance. "Small place. Man's imagination is definitely outstripping his physical reality. Azazel was right in one regard. I have seen bigger places than this, hundreds of times, in cyberspace."

He passed through the wall of the bedroom where Brenda lay, sleeping, and stood over her, watching, and thinking.

"I have heard this illustration, dozens of times. A few of my strongest, most potent, demons came to me, at my summons. I listened as each one told me what he would do to disrupt the work of God's people. I dismissed them all except one. 'he said I'll tell them that there's plenty of time.' He, I sent out, knowing that he would be successful.' "

"I haven't done that, of course, but it would be successful, anyway. Humanity, for the most part, doesn't want to think about tomorrow, or any other time, for that matter. None of them wants to admit that I will be waiting for them when they shed these bodies."

He planted a sense of revulsion and rebellion deep in Brenda's mind, added a liitle juice, and returned to his home.
