"Now Jack, Billy's not a bad person, he just lets his temper get out of control sometimes. Hey, he even let me have this van to drive up an see you!"

"Brenda, he beats you up then gives you a rusty old minivan to leave town in and you think he's a nice guy? He's lucky you didn't press charges for assault!"

"Well that may be true, but right now I sure could use a shower and a couple hours of sleep in a real bed. The motels in Dawson Creek and White Horse were just too damn expensive, so I slept in the van at truck stops on the way."

"Sure, no problem Sis. I'll fix us up a good dinner after your nap. You have any ideas on what you want to do next?"
111211121112.title: Billy beat me up again.

choices: Should Brenda take up his offer?
Will she pull a disappearing act?
1112111211121.content:
On second thought I said, "How about eating elsewhere?"

She smiled, lopsidedly. We both knew how good a cook I am.
"How about if you get some rest while I find us a nice restaurant, then we'll go eat."

I sounded sincere, and it was easy. I had to eat my meals so I cooked as little as possible which only made the food worse. The food, of course, was secondary. I wanted to set up a guard around Sis and the guys I wanted went to our favorite hangout, theirs and mine.
1112111211121.title: Go into town and meet your friends.

11121112111211.content:
Luckily Brenda was too tired to protest and just shrugged and headed towards the couch. I stopped her from sitting and pointed to my bedroom, "Please, rest in there. It'll be more comfortable." Softly she gave my shoulder a squeeze, an action she had been repeating since we were kids, usually when she agreed with me.

Alone and pacing now, I had to think quick. I swore to her that this was going to be the last time that good for nothing boyfriend would do this. He would have no more opportunities now. She alwaysshushed me and when I flew off the handle in her defense. Why, why was she so forgiving? I needed to take her to a place that I wouldn't have to worry about her when Billy showed up and I confronted him. And Billy always shows up a day or so after she leaves. How he knows where to find her, because she doesn't always come to me, I have no idea. But I wasn't taking any chances this time- I had a gut feeling he'd show up though.

Tonight I would take her to The Pub where at least 4 of my main boys would be. The food would be homey which is what Brenda could use. The patrons will be strong, which is what I could use. In fact one of my friends, Frankie, had a long standing offer to help Brenda with this guy. He said he would do it for nothing and it would be quiet and quick. Seriously now I thought, should Brenda take up his offer?
11121112111211.title: Should Brenda take up his offer?

111211121112111.content:
She had gone to sleep, in exhaustion, leaving me questioning my toughness in the face of trouble.

Two hours passed while I stewed about that, and other things When would Billy show up? Will there be a breakdown in communication, for once? Billy had up alone, before, which led to how confident he was that I wouldn't be a problem.

The knocking on my front door broke through my preoccupation and I got up to answer it. Billy stood on the porch, alone, like every other time.

"I know she's here, Patrick, let me in."

"No, this time she's asleep. We're going somewhere else."
111211121112111.title: Enter Billy

choices: Is Billy going to get the beating of his life?
111211121112112.content:
She was worn out on account of Billy, as usual. I had had years to brood over this, brood and observe, and I had made a few discoveries.

It appeared that Billy had hold of her through blackmail. My sister wasn't a weak woman, in any sense of the word. She would have kicked Billy out of her life years ago but there he was, firmly tucked in. Somebody was, had to be, actively keeping Billy up to date and that person had to be close to her.

The question of who wouldn't trouble me for much longer. When Billy appeared I was going to beat the crap out of him.

She slept, and it was obvious that she had taken a lot of mistreatment. The worse the situation became the longer she would sleep, afterward.

The next night she dressed, casually, and we went to my favorite hang-out, O' Malley's. The guys were already there because I had called all of them to tell them that the meet had to be delayed while she slept.

The place was called O' Malley's, but the owner was a Yugoslav, descended from a long line of Yugoslavians.

We entered and one of the guys made a show of surprise like he hadn't been expecting us and the others joined in.
111211121112112.title: O'Malley's

1112111211121121.content:
Although I had made plans with most of the guys about this evening, it was something that I had done before countless times. Sometimes she'd be with me but many times she wouldn't. That's just how Brenda was, or rather, that's how Billy made her. So often she'd change her mind and dart back home. As we walked into O'Malley's there I could see surprise on some of their faces. They'd probably placed a bet on whether she'd show or not. In any case, with Brenda by my side this night, the boys knew that this wasn't a rehearsal.

Yugoslav was the first guy, or perhaps just the loudest guy, to welcome us and motioned to the table in the corner. Brenda wasn't paying attention though, her gaze rested permanently to a distance just before her, a small but decent smile chiseled under her nose, She was lost in thought and who could blame her? It was a relief however, seeing her dazed like this. In many ways this was her way of relaxing, much different than her usual scared eyed demeanor. Even when she was exhausted she seemed on the edge. Tonight, in her brother's company, she simply could tune out.

We sit down at the table and order the Shepard's Pie which was her favorite. "Aren't you going to eat anything?" she asked me after I placed her order. I wanted to tell her that I couldn't eat just yet. That whatever was going to happen tonight wouldn't be pleasant and that any food in my body would surely react badly. I knew that tonight I'd have to do without. "Nah, sis, nothing for me. I'll just munch on these peanuts." I saw her disappointment. She had a thing about eating alone. I grabbed a handful of nuts and stuffed them in my mouth, "See? I'm good," I grumbled with kid-like showmanship "oh, and I'll have beer." I said to Tammy, the waitress who had been standing there the whole time. Brenda smiled at my childlike eating and asked for water.

Yugoslav came over and sat down, his eyes on Brenda. "How's it going?" he asked her directly. She smiled, always her answer. He looked at me without expression and waited for an answer.
"She's alright, Yugoslav. Yeah, we're OK. Thought we'd stop in for a bite. It's been awhile since sis came to visit and she loves this place." I didn't know if he wanted to talk about Billy right here, in the open and in front of her.
"I see, that's good," he said "It's nice to see you Brenda. Thought I'd visit for a minute, gotta get back to the bar. Let me know if you need anything."

When he was completely behind her he shot me the look of one raised eyebrow. I wish I knew him better because I didn't understand.

"Does Billy know you're with me?" I ask innocently.

"No. Well, not that I know of" she muttered, looking at me or at that space just in front of her. "Who knows. All I know is that the game is up. I'm tired of putting up with this. I don't care what he does, I have to end this. What's more important? Living with this monster or him letting the secret out and if he does I will just have to live with the consequences."

It wasn't like my sister was always a good girl. She had a violent streak in her but that was in the past. The past apparently wouldn't let her go. For many years she'd try to figure out a way to get rid of this guy but each time she did he would threaten her, scaring her and immobilizing her from making any moves away from him. This guy couldn't keep a girl and pretty much lucked out with Brenda, because it would take his knowing a dirty little secret as the only way to keep a woman. Pathetic. Still, she had done something pretty terrible and her punishment was him.

The food arrived and in 2 minutes her cell phone buzzed, a text. She hadn't started to eat yet and pushed the plate away. "Don't read the text" I pleaded. I needed more time. She looked at her cell and gave me a knowing look and then her face dropped. "He's gonna do it," she quietly said, "he's gonna expose what I've done."

No time like the present, I stood up and called Frankie over. I didn't have to say anything, he knew. We wouldn't need to protect her here tonight. We would have to go find Billy and do what we should've done time after time. One of them would go to his house, the other to his hangout. Frankie would go to my house and wait there. All I had to do was remain calm, with Brenda. I demanded she give me her cell and she looked so sad, resigned and she put it on the table.

It buzzed again and again and again. I saw that it was from all different numbers not just Billy's. "Whats going on Brenda?" She wouldn't look at me. She just watched her phone vibrate on the table as text after text rolled in. I noticed one text when I pushed the cell to stop the noise. It read "Game's up sweetie" and it wasn't from Billy's number. "I don't understand, have you told me everything?"
1112111211121121.title: Beginning of the night

11121112111211212.content:
I had picked up the phone because all this texting had my attention held.

A message flashed onto the screen. It was from the local morgue.

Is Brenda there? I want her to come look at a body that arrived a few hours ago.

That set me aback and I turned to Brenda.

"That last text came from the morgue. A body has arrived and she wants to see if you can identify it."

"Guys, we have to go. Any ideas you come up with, hold. I'll be in touch."

We left for the morgue. When we arrived she told a receptionist what we doing there and the man gave us directions to the right room.

Brenda didn't stop until she stood in the doorway of the examination room. I walked into her and the bump got her moving again.

The medical examiner looked up from her examination and beckoned Brenda forward. She lifted the sheet off the head. Billy was lying there with his head nearly decapitated.
11121112111211212.title: Texting

111211121112112121.content:
I stepped back in horror, my eyes glued to the deep slice in Billy's neck.

Brenda was as casual as ever. In fact, she had been rather listless all night it seemed but I figured it was from all the drama. But now it was over, and she was standing over her tormentor. Was that a faint smile upon her lips?

Did I want to know what the deal was anymore? In fact, what did I not know about her? About him? I did not know this woman, my kid sister, who stood now smiling widely and to my shock, staring straight at me. "Whatcha smiling at, sis?" I croaked.

She just patted her belly. A grimace soon replaced her smile and then a look of worry. She turned abruptly and threw up on the gurney. I couldn't blame her, it was a disgusting sight.

"Morning sickness" she blurted as she wiped the slime from her cheeks.
111211121112112121.title: Which one throws up?

choices: Brenda, A friend of mine has a job for you in California if
Billy had some insurance.  Brenda buys a Harley
111211121112112122.content:
Not one word was spoken as they slowly, both wrapped in their own thoughts, walked into forever in
a hallway with no end!
Brenda, first to the door, opened it, stepped through but holding it open for her brother. He took two
steps into the parking lot daylight and stopped. As Brenda was releasing the door, she was turning towards
her big brother and was just in time to see him throw up something. At the same time he threw up something
he let out a rebel yell aimed at what was falling back down to his hand. YA-A-A-YAA-A-A-A-A-A, the scream
of exaltation ended as abruptly as did the fall of his car keys when he caught what he had thrown up.

While Brenda was so caught up in trying to understand what emotion her brother was expressing she hadn't realized she'd been neuroticly expending pent up nervous energy tearing a very large paper dinner naptkin
into a million itsy-bitsy pieces. When she returned into herself from where her mind had taken her on it's own,
and saw what she had been doing while she was gone, she threw up, all those little, itsy-bitsy pieces of naptkin soit looked like confetti in a ticker tape parade. Out loud she said," Oh, what the hell," and let go a rebel yell of her own! YA-A-AYA-AA-A-A! Her scream of finality ended when all those flitering pieces of confetti weren't
flitering anymore.
Her brother was smiling at her from the driver's seat but Lovely Rita, the Meter Maid wasn't! She was approaching rapidly, her mouth, an ugly scowl under her very visable mustache and one eyebrow. She had her ticket book out and was holding it like she was going to shoot me with it!
I told her," Those are blanks." " W-What?" she stuttered. " Those are blank pages, blanks." I iteratered.
She stopped reaching for her gun and a little deflatted (which was my intention) ordered me to pick up every single one of those itsy-bitsy pieces of white naptkin that, now (at least a piece) had found a residence from California to New York and North Dakota to Galvesten, Texas. I felt like I was Arlo Guthrie in Alice's Restaurant when he got caught dumping garbage off a cliff unto a gulley!

Looking back, I must have been in emotional limbo. I mean, I had just looked hard on someone I had deeply loved for over ten years with his head only just attached to his body with but a guitar string! And she is ordering
me to pick up a torn paper naptkin when I can see within my view looking just one direction at least thirty of them held to the cyclone fence by the breeze! I didn't lose it, yet!
I said to her in soft measured voice," You are out of uniform. I am not required by law to follow or accede to the commands of any peace officer who by being out of uniform is not authorized or empowered by the mandate and protocols while in violation of these governing laws and codes himself.

My brother was laughing so hard it looked as if his eyes were about to become satellites! I was seriously praying this powerless, insecure, no self-esteemed, non-entitied, atomaton wasn't going to ask me the question I new she was going to because it was really the only one she could ask. I had left myself no way out and I knew
today, retreat was not an option.

Her eyes seeing blood, her anger making her lip quiver and her eye spasam, she opened her mouth and told me," Her is the deal, cracker. You're gonna tell me, right now, how I'm outta uniform. If you been playin inside my head, I'm going to shoot you in the leg for trying to escape, comprande?

There it was and here I go! I looked her in the eyes about four inches apart and said to her seriously,"You forgot to shave this morning corporeal and your beard looks like ya tryin to be a hippie puke!" The look on her face told me I had struck a nerve so deep it was rooted in the very center of her being. Looking into her eyes I witnessed her humanity disappear devoured by her insanity. She was gone. Gone for good but I didn't find that out till later.

My brother pulled the raving lunatic off of me and by then another cop was on the scene restoring a semblence of order. She was so gone she was wearing his handcuffs cuffed to a tree far away from us. She made me look like an angel. I played it. He couldn't believe all this was over a naptkin. He was right, it wasn't but it was a security issue. Mine. That made it need to know! For my security he didn't need to know and she was in no condition to tell him!

To this day I can't believe I walked? I believe Billy had something to do with it?
111211121112112122.title: Do  neither throw up?

choices: Brenda asks," Are you forcing me to choose?"
Brenda leaves but doesn't return directly to Billy.  She visits............
1112111211122.content:
After a good night's sleep and her first sip of my morning,"Getsha goin" brew, she said," Before you start on me again, let
me thank you for always being there for me!"

I waited patiently, for a man who knew he wasn't going to like what was coming and was on his third cup of "getcha goin!"

So, I surprised even myself when after she said," After a lot of soul searching and weighing the pluses and minuses of Billy's and my relationship, if he is willing to go to an anger management counsellor with me, I'm going back to Billy." " The reason I'm willing to make this work, if at all possible, is simple." " I love him and I know he loves me." Can you understand this, brother?"

In a calm, serious, controlled voice I answered," No, I don't." "But here is what I want!" "Understand me clearly so there will be no
confusion down the line." " Pack your things, get in the rusty mini-van and go back to the slime you think you love." " I'm getting off this train and I wish you were getting off with me!" "There are other trains going to better places I'd rather ride on." " The next time your train derails I'm going to make sure the engineer enters forced retirement!?" "Now leave, I don't want to see you for awhile." "Yes!" "I mean right now!"
1112111211122.title: Go back to Billy.

choices: Billy puts her in the hospital
11121112111221.content:
Brenda asked, "Are you forcing me to choose?"

There was silence for I refused to answer. I had said my piece. Now, I would wait-and listen. I knew that she would no more back out than I would but I wanted her to.

Both of us were blank-faced as we struggled to pull our emotions up tight.

The silence began to itch in the back of my mind but I kept my figurative fingers at my side.

Finally, she broke the silence,"Okay, Patrick. I'm leaving but know this. Just as it's always been, so my door will remain open. God bless, Pat."

With that she walked around me, heading for the front door. In five minutes she was pulling out. Since there was nothing to pack departure was swift.

I waited on the porch, watching until her SUV was out of sight, waiting for the dust to settle then I turned around and entered my empty house.
11121112111221.title: Brenda asks," Are you forcing me to choose...

choices: Brenda asked me if Billy had come by while she was out?
Rob told me the cops were looking for Billy, Assault & Battery
111211121112211.content:
My word is my word. Our Dad, Brenda's and mine, taught us both not to give it lightly. "Try not to give
it at all!" he reminded us over and over, like a broken record! Before Brenda walked out my door on her way back to Denver, her house and a relationship she believed could be saved, I told her in earnest what was going to happen to Billy if he ever used her as a punching bag again.

I had already told Billy to pretend when he was hitting my sister that he was hitting me. I thought that might make him think a split second and check his punch, breaking the spell or whatever madness overpowers a man's senses making him capable of being a woman beater?

Jesus, she was at my house six days ago! Six days?

My best friend Rob's (he's really a Robbin) sisters, both of them, work at Mercy General, a very large and prestegious hospital located in downtown Denver by the Stadium. Elway's stadium! One is an Orthopedic Surgeon and the other, Annie, the one who called, is an anesthesiologist. She and Brenda went to school together from kindergarten to high school, graduated as seniors. Their lives took seperate professional courses but not their friendship.

Annie called her brother giving him the details of Brenda's injuries so he could deliver the bad news in person to me. Thus, sparing me the emptiness of staring at a wall or putting my fist through it, after hanging up a cold and lifeless telephone. He was with me, riding shotgun in my truck, asleep and snoring after taking a turn at the wheel so I could sleep. The road sign said forty miles.

Billy had no way of knowing that I was in town or that I even knew what he had done.
Brenda was in a coma. The object he had hit her with had caused bleeding inside her cranial cavity and the building pressure had to be released and her brain monitored. Sleep was necessary for healing so they had induced her coma for restoritive purposes, or, at least, Annie had assured Rob this was the case. Rob knew his sister as well as I knew mine and said she would have been an emotional wreck if Brenda's life was hanging in the balance. I believed him, it was easier than the alternative!

We found Billy at my sister's house. The two empty bottles of Mescal overturned, one at his feet and the other by his elbow, explained why he had wet himself, had flammable breath and didn't wake up, or bat an eye, while we were immobilizing him with the duct tape we had brought just for this purpose. His arms taped behind him, his legs taped at ankles and knees and a black stocking knit cap pulled over his head and duct taped around his neck, holding the hat in place but allowing him to breath through the loose knit. I was afraid to duct tape his mouth because I needed him alive for the event I had in store for him. I was going to give him a chance to survive. Admittedly not much of a chance but more than he deserved. I also wanted him to have time to come to terms with why he was where he found himself.

I left Rob at the hospital after we had picked up Billy. My word, my sister, my doing and the worst case scenerio was I get busted for murder and deal it down to second degree manslaughter. Colorado, like Texas doesn't take kindly to men beating on women. They would look down on me for NOT doing something to Billy! Rob didn't need this on his head either!

Billy was awake when we got where I was going. He was begging whoever had him, me, to just tell him what he'd done wrong and no matter what it was or what it took, he would make it right! Just tell him what I wanted! Anything he pleaded! I went to see if everything was how I remembered. He didn't know I wasn't there so he just kept on squirming and begging for some hope that his ticket wasn't going to get punched.

I hadn't been here in ten years. It had belonged to a real mountain man my father had met while he and Ned, my dad's best friend, were deer hunting. Sal Vascusco was the trapper, hunter, gold miner's, mountainman's name. The only reason dad found him is because Sal's dog, well, not a dog, a wolf he'd raised from a cub, made my dad understand that it was urgent and important that he follow Friend. Friend is what Sal had named the wolf. Said it was the only friend he ever had til me and my dad.

Dad was led to Sal who said later he was wishing to die before anyone found out that he had stepped into his own bear trap and couldn't free the spring to open it. He had his bowie knife out and was close to cutting his foot off rather than be found dead in his own trap! He owned four hundred acres around his cabin and the land touched federal forest reserve that was unlimited unowned wilderness. He deeded it to me before he went missing. He told me what he was going to do and did it. He walked into his wilderness and became legend.

No one but us three, Sal, Dad and me had ever been here. Even Brenda and Rob, my best friend, didn't know about this spread and that I owned it free and clear. No lease expiring in ninety-nine years! This is fee simple. Mine for perputuity! Billy was about to become the fourth person to see my property.

After dragging Billy to where I was set up. Still blind with the watch cap covering his eyes, I asked," Do you have any idea who has brought you to this place and why? He hadn't recognized my voice and quickly whined," He had no idea but would I remove the cap so he could see who and ask why?" I cut the cap off with my knife leaving the tape around his neck like a chocker. It took some time for his eyes to adjust to the bright noonday sun but when they did and he saw who his capter was, first his eyes flashed surprize and realization finishing at resignation. It was just like a green light turning to yellow than red. Go, going, slowing down to an abrupt stop!

I explained what was about to happen and what his only chance to live depended on. When he heard there was a chance he could survive my wrath,his entire being seized this hope as if it was a physical, tangible substance you could hold in your hands. I showed him the rope wrapped around, coiled on the spindle with a handle. It was obvious to him that this was the machine used to bring a bucket of water up and out of the well.

He was biting his lip as I told him the water in this well is very cold and is usually somewhere around fifty to seventy feet down. Instead of me just cutting one of your arteries and watching you bleed out for what you've done to my sister on more than one occasion, I'm going to untie you, lower you into the well and into the water. However far that is, is the distance you will have to climb to free yourself from death from drowning or hypothermia, whichever comes first. The man who dug this well said that at the bottom is an underground river that comes to daylight a quarter mile from here. He told me if he ever fell in the well he might try that.

I made a hang mans noose and had him put his foot in it. But, of course, this was after I had him strip down to his birthday suit. He was shaking from fear not cold as I began to slowly lower him into the darkness. Once he was beyond my sight, about twenty-five feet I let go and he plummeted through total darkness, the only light the peephole framing me at the top getting smaller only to completely disappear when he hit and was below the surface of the frigid, Colorado mountain water.

This was my signal to pull the rope which was free of him from the fall, back to the surface. He was crying, pleading with me to keep my word. It WAS my intention to put this extra scare in him but bringing up the rope but I also had another reason. I believe I could climb up the rope to safety. I'm not sure if Billy could or couldn't but I didn't bring him here to escape. He was here to be puinished for the countless abuses, mental and physical, he so nonchalantly ladeled out on someone I would give my life to save, before he died! I yelled down to him," One more minute, Billy! No kidding!"

As I finished the end of his rope, rubbing in nice and deep the last of a gallon can of axel grease, I threw the attached rope in the well! Without a word to Billy, I walked to my truck, took a last look at the land I would be living on sooner than later. Cleaned my hands with lacquer thinner. I hate grease on my steering wheel. Started my truck and pointed her to the hospital anxious, now that I was done and Billy was finished, to see if my sister was back in the land of the living?
111211121112211.title: Billy puts her in the hospital

choices: Steve's brother shows up at the grave
11121112111222.content:
Brenda appreciates her brother's concern, but she's made her decision and is determined to get back to Billy as fast as she can. Thanks to numerous Red Bulls and a handful of pills she bought from a trucker in Whitehorse, she pretty much drives nonstop from Wasilla all the way past Sheridan Wyoming. But now she's fading fast...

"Shit Brenda! Gillette? What the fuck are you doin'? You missed the turn for I-25 South, now you gotta backtrack at least another sixty miles! What the hell is wrong with you girl? And now you're talkin' to yourself again, just like when you and Billy was doin' meth! You better find yourself a place to crash pretty quick girl, you ain't gonna last long enough to make Colorado Springs without some serious sleep!"

Brenda spots the familiar Motel 6 sign near the Skyline Drive exit, a place she stayed a couple weeks in what seems like a lifetime ago. She thinks back on a man who died in a fiery crash not far from here, driving away from her after a fight they had in a local bar. On how a drunken disagreement over things that really didn't matter in the long run had ended his life.

She gets off the highway but instead of taking a left for the motel, she takes a right and heads for the cemetery. She drives into the entrance, parks, and walks to his grave...

"Steve, why the hell did I ever leave you? Billy is the scum of the earth compared to you! I just wish I could go back to that day..."
11121112111222.title: ... She visits a grave.

choices: Does her intention to return to Billy shorten her time in the graveyard?
Will anything develop between Carlton and herself?
111211121112222.content:
....close on her heels but he goes unnoticed by Brenda. Her whole attention is on the grave she's approaching.

In the middle of a circle of ornate monuments sits a plain, white marker. Nothing's on it but a name and a year; Steve Commons, 2008.

Carlton comes up to her side as she's staring at the stone. Her next words went unspoken.

"Yeah, everything of worth died the day you did. I wish I could go back."

Carlton spoke, next to her, and he finished the sentence just as he had always been able to do. "but you can't go back."

"Carl, hello, it's been awhile," she said, using the diminutive name she always had.

"Yes, it has been awhile. I wondered if you would come back."

He took a few steps to one of the monuments and turned to lean against it.

"Bitterness, Carl? Why? I'm the one who left," She lifted her eyes to his and he saw the tears that were trickling down her face.

His hand came up as he stepped forward and stopped. His hand fell away. He would not touch her, at least, not now.
111211121112222.title: Carlton, Steve's brother, enters the graveyard...

choices: I was in luck.  I could hear Billy singing in the shower
When I opened my front door, I wasn't surprised to see who was standing there
1112111211122222.content:
Brenda hadn't missed Carl's 180. He was about to offer her comfort from the weight of the
emotions bursting through her defenses as if they were non-existant! She made no effort to quell
what had taken on the properties of a flash flood but let her sorrow pour out of her with her tears. Carl
had regained himself in the blinking of an eye. He only remembered his hate for me as he was about to
dry my face. The transformation was instantaneous, triggered when we both made eye contact! It was
a role he felt obligated to play, it giving a visable demonstration of the love he had for his brother and directed towards who he felt was responsible.
To me it was as meaningful as a paid mourner at a chineese funeral! I also was certain we would
be friends again, probably more than friends. We were very close for years and he knows I've done nothing
to cause or feed his anger and pain resulting from the premature death of his brother.
Carl doesn't know it yet but to speed up the restoration of our friendship, earlier,I dropped off some film. I needed it developed anyway and Carl is a great photographer. He might even be better in his darkroom. I couldn't think of a better way of getting us back together than him developing my pictures and delivering them to me at my house. Then we'll see what develops between us.
I got in my car. I'd said my final good-bye to a friend I'd loved more than any other man, aside from my
brother, Pat. It was way past the time I should have given Billy his walkin papers! Engine running, I put on a
cassette. It was The Jefferson Airplane, doing,"Takes Off". So I did!
1112111211122222.title: Will anything develop between Carlton and herself?

choices: In the grip of his temper will Billy have to be put down
Will he stop and remember the anger management sessions?
11121112111222221.content:
...singing in the shower.

I brought my bags in and started unpacking. I noted that the shower had stopped after I put away the contents of the largest case. I waited, next to the bed, for him to come in the bedroom while I opened the rest of the suitcases.

He came in the bedroom a minute later with a smile on his face that brightened into a grin when he saw me.

"Hello, Babe," he said. He glanced at the bags."I didn't know-" The grin disappeared. "- you went to your brother, didn't you?"

I could have continued to take the easy way out, could have continued to let myself get beaten, but the recent memories of Pat, Carl and Steve set my resolve. I was starting to think that I didn't have to let myself get beaten without some resistance.

I looked at him, directly, and he tried to hit me. I blocked the swing and kicked him, lightly, in the stomach. He had a bit of expulsion then straightened up and now I could see the fear in his eyes.

I had been here, before; now he would go for a weapon and he ran out of the room but I HAD had it! The training I had taken caused me to strike an easy pose and I waited. In the flash between his departure and his return I wondered if he was still serious about anger management. It didn't appear so but maybe I would have put him down.

I wasn't going to roll out of here as easily as I arrived. I bought this land, and I would work myself to exhaustion to keep it!

The "quiet" was getting too much for me. Maybe for a few weeks but the rest of my life? That was a definite, no no. The people around were decent folk, all ready to help. Yet, I felt left out and didn't really belong here.

To top it all, I was reminiscing, the time with my ex, the glorious moments we shared. All the hate and anger I had within had disappeared it seems. Must be the purity of the air infiltrating my soul!

I am divorced now and no chance of getting together, Then, why am I having all these thoughts? Am I still in love with him? After all what he had done!

The more I tried to brush these thoughts away, the more I recalled the passion, joy, the longing was getting unbearable and oh,all those lovely times together. I miss him so.

I must make up my mind.

choices: I will never be alright, ever again
1112111222.content:
When my palms started to feel as if million ants are pocking my skin, marching into the war against the rest of my body that shook uncontrollably while my boss held me in embrace, trying to keep the pieces of me together, I knew the situation I was in got more serious than I first thought it would be after they called me into her office. She didn't hold me too tight, it was a comfortable hug, the one your mother would offer if she's not thousands of miles away, but I still couldn't breathe between her arms and few whispers she placed in my ear, repeating the same thing all over again; you're going to be alright. I didn't believe her. I couldn't, I felt my brain melting down into my throat when the army of ants invaded my head and committed genocide over my brain cells. My eyes got blurry so I closed them down, trying to escape to some other place where I wasn't surrounded by complete strangers who looked at me as if they never saw someone having a breakdown. Surprisingly unearthly strength, mixed with anger and despair, was boiling in my stomach despite numbness of my head, and spread over my chest, then my arms. I only realized I'm squeezing my boss too tight because she started to tap my back, first gently and then harder until I didn't ease up without letting her go completely still. I think none of us knew what we supposed to do in that moment so we kept holding onto each other until someone figure it out. My brain was stuck in my throat, making me unable to speak. I could only gasp for breath and wait for another part of my body to lose its battle and go numb. She was quiet at this time as well, making slight movements of her head as if she was nodding. I kept my eyes closed so I couldn't see if she was communicating with him or this was just random movement. Five minutes after, she tried to detach herself from me but I was afraid to let her go at this point. Ants now moved from my head to my legs. I won't be able to walk ever again, I thought, so I intertwined my fingers behind her back in case she try to break free. I didn't even know why I did all that. The healthier part of me, part that wasn't attacked by ants, convinced me I will shatter all over the floor if I let her go and I knew he will kick me and call it drama rather than trying to put me back together.

WC: 1147
My whole being was sickly upset. It felt like everything was just a bad dream where I've been chased by the monster, sweating hard while trying to escape its claws all while realizing that I'm running in one place and the monster is just one step away. All I had to do is to wake up but waking up in my case meant I will face another monster. I felt his eyes probing my eyelids, waiting to swallow me whole as soon as I open them. You're going to be alright, I heard my boss's whisper again, and again, and again. She run her fingers gently over my hair, untying it slowly. I remember the feeling of relief when she did it. My heartbeats slowed down with her movement and gasps became longer. I was now breathing the air almost with full lungs. I'm going to let go of you now and I'm gonna call medical center and whoever is on duty to see if they are available for us, she said with her steady voice. My heart started to pump hard in my chests again when she mentioned medical center. I'm not crazy, I just... I.. I can't walk and.. I can't anything, my brain in my throat couldn't produce any sentence that would make sense. It was just stuck there, betraying me. I squeezed my eyes shut and tried to keep my fingers intertwined behind her back but they felt like gummy. With one harder push she detached herself and I was now sitting on the couch all by myself, with my eyes still closed. I saw myself crashing down on the floor even if the couch wasn't too high so the jump can kill me and him, sitting on the chair in the corner, not doing anything about it or anything at all. At this point he knew I put the whole blame on myself, I didn't give any to him, yet he still just sat there with his mocking eyes. Few moments after I heard conversation between the nurse and my boss. Apparently, she said she will come over here rather than have me going there. Ants now moved to my stomach and I curled myself on the couch when they attacked gizzard, causing the feeling of vomiting. Ladies don't vomit in front of bunch of strangers, what do you think they will say about you? I put my hand against my mouth and decided to prevent gush.

Nurse came surprisingly fast. She brought some papers with herself, at least that's the only thing I saw. Like my boss, she too tried to speak with me in calm manner. I didn't know why did they treat me like that, I wasn't violent or anything, I didn't need to calm down. I was just... messed up. When she saw I couldn't even tell her my name she just told me I have to walk down to the medical center so that they can inject valium. Both of them took my hands and got me up from the couch. Since the ants were now in my stomach I could make slow steps toward. I felt his eyes on me and this time I managed to take a look at them. He looked shocked. I felt sorry for he never saw me this way and I felt sad because I knew he will hate me now even more. This is all your fault, no one else's, thoughts fluttered around my head as I dragged my feet.

I felt my brain is slowly going back to my head, my heartbeats slowing down and my eyelids becoming heavy. Ants were finally beat down by meds. I'm sorry, I said to my boss as she was sitting on the edge of my bed. I guess this was the end of my career. She just covered me up and didn't say anything. I wasn't expecting anything more than that, she was just a stranger that happened to be part of all this... charade or whatever normal people call it.
I'll never be alright again.
You will, just look for someone new.
She didn't understand me at all. No one did.
1112111222.title: Look for someone new

11121112222.content:
"I will never be alright. Or at least by their standards. Sure, I may pretend to fit in their little boxes, but there will always be a part of me that walks in the greys of their black and white world, and sometimes I just fly above all their bullshit. When i am on that natural high, i am invincible. Though unfortionely everything must fall at some point, and when I fall gravity pulls me into the pits of hell. But, you are like them. You do not understand a damn thing I am talking about, do you, Mrs. Doctor I-Don't -know-shit?"

"Ok now. I understand you've been through an ordeal, but that is no reason to be insulting. You can call me Dr. Caldwell. And, you might be surprised at what I understand. Now, tell me, why do you think you are here?"

"He left me and I was just a little upset is all. They kept telling me to calm down, but I was calm. Maybe they're the ones who should be in this straight jacket."

I glared at the doctor, resolving that much like Mr. Douche bag, who had paid me a visit no more than ten minutes ago, wouldn't believe me anyways. Besides, the old hag in front of me llooked like she walked out of a 1950's B movie with her blue eyeshadow and beehive. Something about her sent icy chills up my spine.

She flipped through some papers in a manilla folder. "It says here that your husband was murdered."

I turned my head to the side, avoiding eye contact. "Now you're just making shit up."

Mrs. I-Don't -know-shit exhaled loudly and I heard the file slam shut. She let out a sarcastic exhale. "It appears you and I are not going to get along so well." She grabbed my face, forcing me to look at her. "You best get a new attitude, or I may just have to adjust it for you." She poked me between the eyes with her pointer finger.

There was a coldness in her eyes that froze the air in my lungs, and I began to grasp for air in a panic attack.

"Oh, cut the dramatics!" She slapped me hard across the cheek, causing me to fall against the White padded wall. Now huddled on the floor, I stared at her in shock, and she laughed. "I will be back again, and when I do, you will be complient. And, you will not disrespect me. Right?"

Unable to find my words, I bobbed my head for yes. She responded by smiling. "Good girl."

I layed there for what seemed like hours, staring at the heavy door.

111211122221.content:
I lost track of time as I sat, bunched up in the corner of the room. Hugging my knees tightly to my chest, it took me forever to get my breathing back on an even keel. These people were supposed to help me, and instead they had treated me like a piece of shit. As sobs lodged in my throat, I couldn't see a way out of here. They told me I killed my husband, but that can't be right. I'd know if I had. Surely. "No no no no," I repeated over and over until I must have fallen asleep right there, sitting on the floor.

Something knocked my hand, and I woke up. At first, my eyes were too groggy to see.My head throbbed and my mouth felt like it was full of cotton wool. It was down to the drugs. I know. I've been here before.

Peering into the darkness, I couldn't see a thing. I was about to put it down to a nightmare (I mean, who could blame me?) when it happened again. My head shot up, but still I couldn't see anything.

"He—hello? Who's there?" My voice sounded thick and uneven. I waited for an answer, but got nothing. "Hey, who's there? Who just—"

It happened again. A tap on the back of my hand. I clutched it to me and stood, all the time pressing myself against the soft wall. "What's happening? Who's there?" Still nothing. Fear bubbled inside me, rising to my chest and squeezing my lungs.

"Help! Help!" I screamed. "Let me out!"
111211122221.title: Haunted mental institution

choices: Doctor Caldwell Pays her Another Visit
The door opens and nobody is there
1112111222211.content:
Time passes slow when your bound with only your own thoughts to keep you company. It felt as though I was being taunting by something unseen. It seemed as if it was feeding on my fear. The more my body tensed, my heart jumping out of my chest with each beat, I was being toyed with. It felt as if a hand went through my hair, lifting it. Then their was a tap on my shoulder.

"Leave me alone!" I screamed at the invisible touch, hoping to gain strength and push whatever it was away.

I heard keys clanking. Someone was unlocking the door. I didn't know what was worse, experiencing that demented doctor again or whatever was taunting me in this batted room. The door opened and two men in white uniforms walked in. I assumed they were orderlies.

A tall muscular brunette spoke first. "Hello Elizabeth. The doctor has decided you've had enough time to calm down." He pointed to the muscular blonde man next to him. "This is Mike and my name is Jason. We'll be taking you to your room."

"Are you going to take this awful strait jacket off of me?"

Jason's eyes narrowed on me. "Depends. Are you going to behave?"

I smiled. "Oh yes, yes, I promise."

Jason nodded. "Then the answer is yes, but not until you get to your room."

The two men stood on either side of her, dragging her out of the padded room, then through some heavy doors. They reached a long hallway and at the entrance there was a sign that read Maximum Security, monitored 24 hours a day. Mike swiped a card and the doors opened. At the end of the hall, they stopped at a door, swiped the card again, unlocking it.

Mike looked at me. "This will be your home for a while."

I stepped inside the windowless room. There was only a mattress on the floor. "What happened to the rest of the furniture?"

Jason winked and his voice carried a hint of sarcasm. "We wouldn't want you to go and find something to hurt yourself with, now would we."

I nodded. " I understand" I moved my arms forward as much as I could with the restraining jacket. "So, are you going to remove this?"

Jason removed it and I sat on the bed, looking up at the two men. "Thank you!"

Mike looked down at her and smiled slightly. "One of us will be back in a few hours to get you. The doctor would like to speak with you."

I felt the air freeze in my lungs. "D-Doctor Caldwell?"

Both men looked at her in confusion, but Jason spoke. "Who is Doctor Caldwell?"

Mike nudged him and shook his head. Jason looked at him in recognition, obviously knowing something she didn't.

Mike leaned forward. "Doctor Johansson will be calling for you."

"What about Doctor Caldwell? Will I be seeing her again?"

Mike furled his eyebrows and he seemed to be getting annoyed. " I don't know, but you'll be seeing Johansson soon. Until then, get some rest."

Both men turned and left, locking her in the bland room. She realized that she was tired, so she laid on the mattress and drifted off to sleep. She awoke to the door opening.

11121112222111.content:
After what seemed like a long time, I heard steps outside that became louder as they approached the door. The door knob turned and it opened revealing Jason. I smiled at him and he returned a warm smile. For some reason, I had started liking Jason, he was nice to me, even if he thought I was just another loony in the mental institute. Talking about that, why was I there in the first place? I didn't remember having done anything before that could lead me here.

Jason moved aside and another figure entered the room, I supposed it was Doctor Johansson. He was tall, dark brown hair and hazel eyes that looked into mine very deeply. He was about five foot ten inches and had a good body, muscles built, a sturdy frame. He cleared his throat and put on his glasses as he glanced in the file he had.

"Hi Elizabeth. i am Doctor Johansson, I will be your in-charge while you are here. Right now, it's our thirty minute conversation session. If you'd be kind to follow me?" He said kindly and then pointed out of the door, "Ladies first?"

He gave me one of his most charming smile and I got up, automatically, not knowing how my body obeyed his command. This should be interesting.

111211211.content:
I slowly started to climb, unsure of what my fate would be when the ledge my left foot rested upon gave way. The castle
seemed to be laughing at me as it moved further and further away as I plummeted through space towards the water of Kororareka Bay sixty feet below. My sailboat, Shamballa, was anchored directly below the castle and with any luck at all I pray I will miss all sixty-five feet of her deck. Salt water is hard enough to hurt but soft enough to survive. Not so with my teak deck, standing rigging, stainless steel stanchions for railings and bowsprit and bumpkin.
No wuckin furries, mate, I smacked the water so hard it knocked all the wind out of me so I couldn't breath. Did I crack a rib or two? Debree from the hillside avalanched around me and a stone hit me on the head so hard white light replaced the evil staring castle for a couple of minutes until it came back into focus looking more sinister than it had before if that was possible.
I was swimming towards Shamballa when something very large and dark scooped me up and out of the water rising as rapidly as I had fallen, taking me to my horror to the evil castle's entrance. The drawbridge was down and it had the uncanny look of an open mouth with teeth ready to devour this tender young morsel being delivered by what appeared to be, no, is a fire spewing, fully scaled with a forked tail, dragon. This is The Bay of Islands, New Zealand, not a T.R. Tolkien Hobbit adventure in Middle Earth!, for God's sake!
111211211.title: 'Come to me."

111211212.content:
It was midnight before I reached the top of the stairs and entered into a small round room with slits for windows. The full moon created streak of light as it passed through a slit in the stone wall, It fell upon markings on the floor. They were carved runes running in a circle and seemed to glow. I had no idea what they meant and yet the feeling that I should know was strong. The voice was silent now as I gazed around the room. Ceremonial tools were hung on the walls. Knives, feathers, crystal wands, a scythe, a sword, and even a velvet violet hooded cape. Laid out on an ornate wooden table was a goblet, metallic chimes and candles. A bat flew out and startled me . As I waved my hands above my head to shoo it away, a long mirror, hung on the opposite wall, caught my reflection.
I saw myself , yet not who I am now. I closed my eyes and gave my head a shake. I looked again as the voice spoke again,
Remember...

A quill pen and ink beside a scroll appeared in the center of the circle of runes.
111211212.title: Midnight

1112112121.content:
Some wise old man long ago said that a great man would come around one day, maybe beat a few bad guys and save a beleaguered town or two, and when all was said and done he'd become king of an entire land and rule with peace and harmony until he decided to croak of old age. Debates over who the prophecy referred to have been ongoing in the interim, to little avail.

You see, like all good prophecies, it was extremely vague and universal in its details, making it almost impossible to determine whether or not any individual or reign corresponded to the prophecy. Has the great man already lived and died (there have been at least three kings since the prophecy was created who've become kings through a bit of a struggle and then reigned long and happily), or should we continue keeping our eyes open for this Promised One?

No one knows. That doesn't stop them from arguing the matter ad infinitum, or sending some random fellow out on a mission to get some "extended edition" of the prophecy that they think will clear up the matter.

I have the misfortune of being that random fellow.

Three months of hard travel, the expenditure of more money than I'd care to say, and the attention of a band of thugs is all I have to show for my trouble.

The extended prophecy was said to rest in a tower where the wise old man was said to have spent a great deal of his time when he lived. That tower now happens to be in the middle of hostile territory, lorded over by the aforementioned band of thugs. They weren't too happy about me trying to sneak into their domain, so here we are, with me hiding in a thorny thicket and them hacking through the underbrush to find me.

If it wasn't for the fact that I was surrounded, I'd turn tail and leave the mission for some other poor fool to attempt. Since I can't run, the only option is to fight my way through these thugs and see if this whole thing was worth the trouble.

I ready my sword and wait for the nearest thug to get nearer.

***

It's remarkable how quickly I managed to dispatch them. Their reliance on their numbers seems to have failed them in the confines of the forest.

I make my way to the tower and proceed to search for the extended prophecy. It's long and tedious work, searching through the scattered and crumbling papers, and as I leaf through the final books in the uppermost room of the tower, I begin to doubt any such "extended prophecy" exists.

Then I hear something out the tower window. I approach the window and look down to see a growing crowd of people gathering at the base of the tower, streaming in from a nearby town. They were already whooping and shouting, but when they saw me leaning out of the tower window, a wave of cheers broke through the crowd. Several voices rose above the cacophony, calling me "lord" and "our savior."

I couldn't actually be the Promised One.

Could I?
1112112121.title: Prophecy

"Purple!" Tommy yelled as the doctors struggled to contain him, "I see purple!"

The doctor turned and looked at the boy's family through the window. They all wore the same expression of worry. All of except one, that is. A girl, his sister maybe, stared back at the doctor with a sneer. A sneer that was so startlingly evil that the doctor quickly turned away.

"Please Dr, Robby! I see purple! Purple is bad!" Tommy screamed once again. His eyes rolled back into his head and his mouth started to foam. The doctor started barking orders to his staff as Tommy's family started to scream as well. Tommy pulled his arm away from one of the nurses and yanked the doctor down. His frothy, spitty mouth pressed hard against the doctor's ear. His voice was harsh and older. It was the voice of a much older man.

"If you see purple, kill her," Tommy said. He fell back onto the stretcher, unconscious. The doctor turned back to the family and saw the same girl. He knew Tommy spoke about her. Her dress was purple and she looked to dangerous to be allowed.
