11121221112.content:
It was long after dark, he had been sleeping as much as possible for him. His whole body hurt and it was difficult to stay in one position on the hard straw mat. He heard water dripping somewhere into what sounded like a puddle. Then he heard the soft scuff scuff of sandals on the rough stone of the passage outside his tiny cell.

"Hello," she said through the narrow bars of his cell. "I brought you food, I wish there were more, but the guards are the only ones here who get enough to eat."

"What is this place, I remember a boat, and being sick from the rough water. There were two others with me, when the boat capsized trying to come ashore. Have you seen them?"

"No," she whispered holding a finger to her lips, "Someone is always listening."

Under the bars in a small space in the center she pushed a steaming tin bowl under the bars. It was filled about half way with a thin broth with a few vegetables floating in it. There was a cup of some kind of tea and some cooked rice on a little plate. It was definitely less than he burned handling stone blocks.

"Thank you, what ever your name is."

"Leila," She turned to leave, then reached through the bars. In her hand she had the shining disc of a penny from home. She went down the passage the same way she had come.

He squatted on the floor and ate with his fingers. He tipped the bowl and drank every drop of the broth. The rice was gone in three bites. Then he turned his attention to the bitter tea. He drank it all at once and pushed te eating utensils under the bars. He stood holding the bars looking to see if he could see anything.

He became dizzy and the sound of the dripping water took on the proportions of a drum.

Hands over his ears he laid down on the filthy straw mat. Within seconds he lost consciousness.

After a period of dark and dreamless sleep; He heard someone coming down the passage. The drip had mercifully stopped. His head was swimming and he had to urinate. He used the toilet bucket with his back to the bars so if it was Leila he could preserve a tiny shred of decency.

A male guard brought him a cup of water and a fist sized piece of dry hard bread. "Inde'ga Passo'." he grunted making motions of eating rapidly.

The prisoner decided he had better eat in a hurry if he wanted to eat at all. The guard opened the cell door in a few seconds. The bread was still a lump half way to his stomach he desperately needed more water to wash it down.

The guard kept the sharp point of the spear tight against his back.

When they reached the construction site he was shoved roughly into line where he would begin the tedious task of passing stone block after stone block down the line to where the builders were fitting them into a wall.

As the sun rose higher in the sky he could feel the burning rays through his shirt and on his face.

After what seemed like many hours Leila came with a bucket of refreshing water.

"Ike beach guards killed your two friends when they put up a fight. I'm sorry," said Leila. She got him a second drink when the guards were distracted.
11121221112.title: He is locked in a cell alone.  She brings him f...

choices: Rus begins to get the lay of the land hatching a plan for escape.
111212211121.content:
Ten days pass in a never ending chain of stone blocks passed to the builders working on the structure. Aching body, aching head from the searing sun, a hard bread roll choked down every morning and when the day ends only enough food to remind him just how hungry he really is. The brightest spot has been daily visits from Leila bringing water, and
her bringing what pitiful amount that was rationed for him at night. Each night he tried to get her to talk to him, with the same results. She would place her finger over her lips. SHHH They are listening! Then she would leave down the passageway withe same shuffling sound as the day before.

He slept less each night, The amount of the drug in the tea must have been decreased or he was gaining tolerance to the drug in the tea. The guard brought him his stone hard piece of bread and a full cup of water. He let him finish the roll and even poured a little more water into the cup so he did not have a lump half way down.

This morning was different instead of being led to his place in line he was led to a shelter from the sun. There was an old gray haired man sitting in a padded chair. "Do you understand me?" the old man asked in heavily accented Minoan.

The prisoner nodded his head.

"What is your name?" asked the old man.

"Rus,"he answered.

"Do you know where you are?"

Rus shrugged his shoulders.

"Kiriti," said the old man.

The puzzled look an Rus's face prompted the old man to elaborate.

"The Seafarers have captured almost everyone who was not killed in the flood after Thera exploded. Where are you from?"

"Akrotiri," said Rus.

"Where have you been these last twelve years since Thera was destroyed?"

"We fled to the west trying to stay ahead of the poison clouds. I do not know where we landed. There were several storms. I escaped slavery there around two months ago. Two companions and I stole a boat and left trying to reach home."

"There is no home to return to. Even the birds avoid the dead island." The old man shook his head in disbelief.

"If you want to live, you must do what you are told. The Seafarers are terrible and think nothing of killing for sport."

"Rus had seen three men beaten to death at their hands in the last few days."

"Won't they run out of slaves if they keep on killing?"

"No time soon. There are still several cities left on the south coast that were spared from the floods after Thera exploded. The north coast is gone and there are two places the waves rushed over the land cutting Kiriti into three Islands until the water left."

"Can you lay stone?"

"Yes,"said Rus.

"Good, the stone layers get more to eat than those who pass rocks."

"Do you understand post and lintel construction?"

"Small blocks wedge the larger ones in place then smal blocks are placed on top of the lintel to raise the walls.

The old man spoke in a strange tongue to one of the soldiers, who came and led Rus to another man dressed similarly to the old man with whom Rus had talked. When the day was over the crew with whom Rus had been working filed to quarters for twelve. One straw mat was thinner than the others. It was also crawling with lice. Rus was not sure this was better than isolation or not.

When food was brought, it was brought by three women, one of which was Leila. The men squatted on the floor and ate with their fingers. There was twice as much food as Rus had received in isolation. When the meal was finished Leila motioned for Rus to follow. Outside the quarters was a stack of fresh straw.

"Put a fresh layer on your bed," She picked up a bundle of dark green leaves with a strange odor. Put this on top of the old straw before you put new straw on top. It kills lice for awhile."

Rus said, "can we talk now?"

"Perhaps tomorrow," said Leila.

Rus placed the leaves on the straw pallet and laid a four inch pad of new straw on top. That night he slept without the aid of the tea.
111212211121.title: He makes the aquaintence of the others after hj...

111212212.content:
"AAAAAAHHHH!" He screams, tumbling backwards until he hits the ground, then nothingness... darkness... the void.

A second, a minute, an hour, or a day later he awakens and looks at his surroundings, a rocky landscape devoid of life. A dull orange sun in a hazy sky beats down on him with an oppressive heat. The Wall is still there, now looking impossible high, he would never even attempt to scale it now.

He sees a man dressed in black approaching at the same he spots his crumpled body at the base of the Wall. the realization of his death hits him, "Oh my God!" he calls out.

"Care to guess again?" the man in black responds.
111212212.title: His hand slips and he loses his footing.

1112122121.content:
"So you're the Devil?"

"Bingo! Give the man a cigar."

"What are you gonna do now, torture me in a flaming pit for all eternity?"

"No, no, I don't do things like that. Just vicious rumors spread by those guys upstairs to scare the masses. Besides, isn't being stuck down here punishment enough for you?"

"Yeah, it's pretty hot and dusty, not much in the way of scenery. Kinda reminds me of Barstow in August. So how do I get out of here? Can I make a deal with you, like in the stories? "

"No, I only make deals with the living in exchange for their souls. You're dead and you're already here, you've got nothing to bargain with."

"Isn't there any way I can get out?"

"You can try climbing the wall again..."
1112122121.title: The Devil You Know

11121221212.content:
"What do you mean, try climbing the wall again, you say that like I've been here before."

"Well you have, hundreds of times. And every time you try to climb the wall to get out, and every time you fail. Think about it, why were you climbing the wall before you fell in here?"

"Well, I was just... I had to get... hey, I don't remember, OK? It's probably because I was traumatized by the fall."

"All right if that's the case, then what were you doing before you started climbing the wall? And were do you live? Are you married? Where do you work? How old are you? Bet you can't answer any of these."

"You're right, I don't remember anything! But maybe you're lying to me, you are the Devil, a known liar. Maybe this is only the first time I've been here and it's not really that hard to climb out, and I should just try it!"

"That's what you usually say, but be my guest, try climbing it again! But keep in mind I didn't make the wall, the guy upstairs did. And I haven't been able to climb out of here, I tried thousands of times before I finally gave up."
11121221212.title: Hang Out With Satan

111212212121.content:
Wow!

You talk about a light bulb just above your head going off like a bright idea or even
revelation! When it said, " But keep in mind I didn't make the wall, the guy upstairs did. And I haven't been able to climb out of here, I tried thousands of times before I finally gave up."

An idea surfaced. Win or lose, it's worth a shot! Barstow in the summer isn't for amateurs.

When the Father of Lies speaks, listen. Then do and think the opposite of what it has
projected. Don't believe a word it says. It's all a lie! Pretense. suggestion, illusion, subliminal
manipulation, psychology, bad theology.

The key which gave me hope was, " I didn't make the wall, the guy upstairs did."

I started to climb. For all I knew it was my first attempt. Because that's all I knew-so it was.

What wall? All I knew was I had to get the hell out-a- there!

And I did.
111212212121.title: Try Climbing, One More Time

1112122121212.content:
I cut my fingers on the sharp stones as I climbed. I saw that the cracks, fissures, and edges I used for handholds were not natural formations but carved letters. And the letters formed words I did not want to see, the names of those I'd wronged in my life.

The boy I'd bullied in school, who later in life had committed suicide.
The investors I'd cheated at the brokerage, some of them losing their life's savings.
The women I'd had while I was married and the ugly divorce it had caused, where my lawyers had helped me cheat my wife out of what was rightfully hers.
The young man permanently disfigured in the car accident I caused while drinking, and the way I had avoided punishment by bribing the police.

The names went on and on, and the realization of all the evil I had done almost made me give up and cast myself back into the pit. But If I was truly remorseful and repented these sins, could I not be redeemed?

This is all that kept me going until I finally reached the top.
1112122121212.title: Climbing Out

11121221212121.content:
At the top of the wall I found myself before an ornate golden gate, with a bearded man dressed in flowing robes standing behind it. "I see you're back again," he said.

"Again? I replied. How come I don't remember being here before?"

"It's part of your punishment, climbing that wall and suffering, over and over again. If you remembered, you'd give up and not bother trying to climb out, and just staying in Hell is not nearly punishment enough for the likes of you!"

"So I guess there's no way you're gonna let me in, is there."

"Not a chance, buddy."

"But I'm truly remorseful for all I have done, I thought Christianity is all about being forgiven?"

"Yeah, there is that clause, but it only applies to the living. You can beg for forgiveness as late as your deathbed, but once you're dead all bets are off."

"But I never got a chance to repent on my deathbed, I was killed instantly in a car accident!"

"Yeah, well you shouldn't have been texting while driving. "

"Can I appeal to someone? Maybe directly to God?"

"Well, he's kinda busy right now, but I'll see if his son will see you."

St Pete pulls out a cellphone and sends a text. A couple seconds later Jesus appears and I explain my plight. He responds, "Sorry dude, but you were just too evil in life. If I let you in my old man will kill me, and I don't want to go through that again."

"So you're just gonna cast me back into the pit?"
11121221212121.title: The Golden Gate

111212212121212.content:
Jesus scratched his beard and thought for a minute, then said, "I am kinda tired of doing his dirty work, so I guess I'll let Dad decide your fate when he gets back. In the mean time, you can hang out with the O.G.s at Dionysus' place."

"The O.G.s? Who are they?"

"The Old Gods. You know, like Odin, Ares, Vulcan, Rostam, Belenus, the Gods nobody worships anymore. They don't have much to do since most of their followers died off long ago, so a lot of them spend their time playing dominoes at Dionysus' tavern."

"So you're telling me all the old gods and their followers are all here in the same heaven as the Christians?"

"Sure, as well as the Muslims, Hindus, Buddhists, Confucians, you name it. This place was just too big for me, Dad, and the Holy Ghost to keep up, so we consolidated a long time ago, it makes things a lot easier.

"Yeah, I guess that makes sense."

"Dionysus' is right across the courtyard, next to the Olive Garden. Go on in and have a drink while you wait for Dad. Just mind your own business and don't start any arguments with the patrons, those guys play rough. And don't even think about trying to sneak past the courtyard into Heaven."

OK, no problem. Thanks for giving me a break J.C., I won't let you down."

.
111212212121212.title: Last Minute Reprieve

1112122121212122.content:
So I walk into Dionysus', order a beer, and sit down at a corner table. I look around the place and see some Viking warriors, a few people who could be from ancient Greece, and a group of men who look downright prehistoric.

I spot this hot looking woman dressed in furs walking out of the Ladies. She catches me checking her out and saunters over to my table. "You are new here? You would bring me wine?"

"Sure, have a seat. I'm Steve, what's your name?" I ask, as I motion for the waitress.

"I am Samkat, you call me Sam." she says

I catch a conversation between the Vikings at the table behind me. "Wait'll Enkidu shows up, this should be fun." With this they both start laughing.

A minute later a large hairy man walks into the bar and looks around, stares at me and the woman for a second, then storms over to our table. "Shamkat, you would be unfaithful with this weakling?"

"No, Enki, just talking!"

"I know where your talking leads, woman!"

With that he grabs me by the shirt, pulls me to my feet, growls, and takes a swing at me.

I duck and make a run for the door, but a group of Enki's hairy friends catch me. One of them pins my arms back and Enki punches me in the gut.

I see the Vikings getting up from their tables, one of them saying, "By Thor's hammer, that is not a fair fight!" and they join in the fray...
1112122121212122.title: Barroom Brawl at Dionysus' Tavern

choices: Why do you look like that?
11121221212121222.content:
The door slams open and everyone freezes. I see the Vikings backing away in fear, and the primitives raising their hands in front of their faces as if to ward off a blinding light. A deep voice roars out: "GO! ALL OF YOU, NOW! LEAVE THIS MAN IN PEACE!"

The bar room quickly empties. I turn towards the door and find myself face to face with a being who looks just like a cartoon from my childhood. "Casper?" I say, without thinking.

"I'm actually the Holy Ghost or Holy Spirit of your religion, but you can call me Casper if it makes you feel any better."
11121221212121222.title: Saved by the Holy Ghost

choices: We don't have time for that now.
111212212121212221.content:
"Why do you look like that?"

"I appear to every man as they first imagine me to be, the same as the rest of us Deities here. You must have gotten this idea of Casper the Friendly Ghost in your head when they taught you about me in Sunday School. No big deal, it's a pretty common image from someone of your generation."

"then why are the Vikings and the primitives so afraid of you?"

"Their religions are older than yours so they see me as their primary God, striking fear into their hearts."

"But I thought "God the Father, Maker of Heaven and Earth" was the primary God."

"Yeah, that's my boy, he'd like you to believe that, but he gives himself too much credit. I let him get away with it though, though I'm pretty much retired now."

"So you actually are the original Creator, and Jesus is your grandson?"

"Gee you catch on fast, too bad you didn't have enough sense not to text and drive."

"Fair enough, I deserved that, but how come you're a ghost now?"
111212212121212221.title: Why do you look like that?

1112122121212122211.content:
"It's a long story. Let's go next door to the Olive Garden, we can talk about it over dinner. I just love their unlimited salad and breadsticks."

I order the Alfredo and the Ghost gets the Parmigiana. We both order Buds to sip on while we're waiting.

"So how did you go from being the Creator to being a Holy Ghost?"

"Well to start with, I haven't been totally honest with you, I'm not "The Creator", only a God who is the Creator of the Judeo-Christian religion. The original Creator is actually a woman. The Greeks referred to her as Gaia, the Egyptians called her Mut. In the days before written language your ancestors first called her Ahn."

"Really? That's kinda hard to believe."

"No, it's the God's truth, the original "Creator of Heaven and Earth" is a woman. The Venus of Willendorf is one of your earlier representations of her, look it up on Wiki if you don't believe me. Think about it, do men give birth?"

"Yeah, I guess that is logical."

"Since you've taken that so well, there's one more Revelation you might as well be aware of."
1112122121212122211.title: It's a long story.

11121221212121222112.content:
"You know "In the beginning, God created Heaven and Earth?"

"Sure, I learned that in Sunday School when I was a kid!"

"The truth is, in the beginning Man created God."

"I'm surprised to hear that from you, it sounds like something an Atheist would say!"

"No, your philosopher Voltaire got it right when he said "If God did not exist it would be necessary to invent him." When Man first evolved to the point of self awareness there was no God, so Man created Him, or actually Her."

"So who created the Earth then?"

"Whoever created the Universe created the planet you call Earth.

"This is crazy, you mean to tell me you are not the Creator of the Universe?"

"No, truthfully, I am not."

"Then who did create the Universe?"
11121221212121222112.title: The Truth About Creation

111212212121212221122.content:
"I don't know, maybe aliens? All I know is that on your planet once Man evolved to the point of self awareness there was an intense desire to know who created him, so Man Created Ahn, the Earth Mother."

"What do you mean Man created her, was Ahn was just a figment of Man's imagination?"

"Oh no, Man's belief was so strong that she became real! The chanting of her name by thousands of her believers at their fertility rites caused her to come into existence."

"I guess that could be plausible, but then how did you end up here?"

"I was the second God, the God of War, created by the leader of one of Man's larger primitive tribes. He named me Rahr, and he lead his followers into so many successful battles against his foes in my name that eventually I became real."

"But what about Heaven?"
111212212121212221122.title: I Don't Know

1112122121212122211222.content:
"Heaven was created by Man as a place for his Gods to live, and a place for Man to go to if he deserved it after he died."

"So we created this place? That's pretty cool!"

"Yes, the collective consciousness of Man created Heaven shortly after Man created me. It was very useful in motivating believers to fight in support of their tribes. Many religions even now profess that dying in battle for your God is a sure ticket into Heaven."

"OK Casper, assuming I buy all this, you still haven't answered my original question. How did you become the Holy Ghost?
1112122121212122211222.title: Heaven Was Created

choices: Your guess is as good as mine
11121221212121222112221.content:
"As I said, the Earth Goddess and the War God are the two archetypes on which all of Man's other Gods are based, so in a sense all other Gods are Ahn and Rawr's "Children". We have watched in pride as they rose in power among their followers, and in sorrow as some of our favorites faded into the mists of time. Ahn especially is disappointed that the majority of men have chosen to follow primarily the Gods of war and destruction instead of her children."

"I can see where that would be discouraging, but it doesn't explain how you became a ghost."

"Ahn and I are both ghosts, we retired from active duty once man created the other Gods. But we do look over the shoulders of our Children and their followers in spirit, since we are the original archetypes. Thus men see us as "ghosts"."

"OK, that sounds logical, but you still didn't explain who created the Universe?"
11121221212121222112221.title: I Retired

choices: I believe I'll have another beer
I believe we should get going before Yahweh shows up
111212212121212221122212.content:
"When Man created the Gods, he believed the Earth was the center of the Universe. The Sun revolved around the Earth, and the stars were simply the hearth fires of his ancestors who had gone on to the afterlife. Thus we were only the Creators of Heaven and Earth, not Creators of the Universe. We did not question this until Man did."

"What happened then?"

"Faith and Belief were no longer enough, Man started asking How, Were, and When and other such questions. He found answers in Logic and Science. He discovered that the Earth was merely a small planet revolving around an average star in one galaxy in a whole universe of galaxies!"

"What did the Gods think of that?"

"Many of them wanted to wipe Man from the face of the Earth for heresy! But Ahn and I being older and wiser, made them see reason. We explained that since Man now knew more about the creation of the Universe than we did, we should let him tell us who created it!"

"That sounds logical, and it does let you off the hook... Has Man told you more about the creation of the Universe lately?"

"His scientists have made quite a bit of progress in answering the When, Where, and How, but right now they seem to be ignoring the Who and Why of that question."

"So Casper, what do you personally believe?"
111212212121212221122212.title: Your guess is as good as mine

1112122121212122211222121.content:
The Ghost raises his empty glass to the bartender and calls out, "Can I get another Bud Light? And one for Steve here, too."

"Thanks, Casper. So honestly, what do you think? Is there a Supreme God above you guys, a God who created the Universe?"

"I hate to admit it, but I'm pretty much agnostic on that subject. If there is such a God he hasn't made his presence known to me. Maybe he is so powerful that his observations of us would be the same as you observing the activities of insects in your garden?"

"I guess that puts you in the same boat as human agnostics. Those who neither believe nor disbelieve, but choose to wait until after they die to see if God exists."

"Maybe, Steve, but I'm not really sure what happens to human Agnostics after they die. They don't end up here, and Satan says they don't end up with him either. Something to think about... I guess I'll just have to wait and see what happens to me when I die."
1112122121212122211222121.title: I believe I'll have another beer

11121221212121222112221212.content:
"How can God die? I thought God was eternal!"

"That may be what you were taught, Steve, but those are Man's interpretations of his Gods. From what I have observed, the power of the Gods depend on a constant supply of believers who eventually die and end up either here or down below."

"But Casper, you said that even the old Gods have their small corners of Heaven, where they exist with their faithful who died centuries ago."

"This is true, but it is not enough. Have you looked around at this place? Do you realize the upkeep? If there were no more believers Heaven would fold like a house of cards! It would be like Las Vegas if everyone quit gambling, a ghost town!"

"So you're thinking that Man may eventually give up on religion?"

"Maybe in China and parts of Europe, but no, I don't think Man will ever totally give up on religion, especially in the Americas. In the end I believe Man himself will cease to exist. And when that time comes all of his Gods, along with Heaven and Hell, will also fade into the mists of time."

"What's going to kill us, Casper. Global Warming? Plague? "
11121221212121222112221212.title: How can God die?

111212212121212221122212123.content:
"No, you are a resilient species in spite of yourselves. I suspect you will muddle along until the comet Kali appears in 2032 and slams into the Earth, an event that will make the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs look like a cherry bomb."

"But we have Science, we can find a way to deflect it!"

"Yes you could, but Man is no longer interested. Look at the cuts made to your NASA programs along with other basic research. The only investments your leaders are willing to make these days are those they can immediately benefit from."

"But if we knew a comet was coming to kill us, don't you think we'd all rally together and try to come up with a solution?"

"You mean like in that old Bruce Willis movie? A nice idea but no, I don't think so. That comet is going to come at the Earth from the backside of the sun, you'll be blindsided until it's too late. Maybe you could save yourselves If you already had a basic asteroid deflection plan in place. But your leaders are not willing to invest in something like that right now, and will have even less interest once the riots start in 2025."

"Maybe you could send me back and I could warn them? Get them to change their priorities? There's gotta be something I can do, and it would also be in your best interest..."
111212212121212221122212123.title: A Comet

1112122121212122211222121232.content:
"Yes Steve, it would be in my best interest. But Yahweh would never let me get away with sending you back to Earth, you are a dead unredeemed sinner after all. But there is one way you might get back, a "Deal with the Devil", so to speak."

"What are you talking about?"

The Ghost causes a piece of paper and a pen to materialize, hastily writes something on the paper, folds it up and stuffs it into Steve's shirt pocket and says, "Read this when you get back to Hell."

"You're sending me back to Hell? Come on Casper, I thought you and I were buds?"

"Sorry Steve, this is the only way. You have to be cast back into the pits of Hell, and you got to play along, kicking and screaming like you don't wanna go."

"That shouldn't be too hard since Hell really sucks. But how do I get back to Earth after that?"

"There's no time to explain, Yahweh's almost here! Just try to remember to read the note I gave you when you're talking to Satan."

The door of the restaurant bursts open and a burning piece of shrubbery enters, shouting "Cometh with me Steven! For thou are going back to Hell!"
1112122121212122211222121232.title: Steve goes back to Hell

11121221212121222112221212321.content:
The burning bush reaches out with fiery branches and grabs Steve by the arms and drags him towards the abyss.

"No! Don't make me go back there! Give me another chance!"

Jesus, standing at the gate, shrugs his shoulders and says "Sorry Dude, I tried, but Dad says you gotta go. Best of luck down there."

Casper touches Steve on the forehead with his ghostly hand and whispers in his ear, "Remember."

Then Yahweh throws him into the abyss...
11121221212121222112221212321.title: Kicking and Screaming

111212212121212221122212123212.content:
Steve awakens and looks at his surroundings, a rocky landscape devoid of life. A dull orange sun in a hazy sky beats down on him with an oppressive heat. He sees a man dressed in black approaching and calls out to him, "Hey, don't I know you? I feel like I've been here before..."

"Yes Steve, you've been here many times," the man in black responds, "but something seems different this time..."

"Yeah, now I remember, you're the Devil and I'm supposed to make a deal with you! Casper the Holy Ghost wrote something down, Ive got it right here."

Steve pulls the note from his pocket and hands it over. Satan scratches his head, looking worried, as he reads the note. "So he says mankind will be obliterated by a comet, causing the end of Heaven and Hell?"

"That's what Casper told me."

"And I'm supposed to find a way to send you back to Earth to save humanity?"

"That's about the size of it."
111212212121212221122212123212.title: You Again?

choices: Sorry Steve, you're on your own.
1112122121212122211222121232122.content:
"Well today is your lucky day, I just happen to have an elevator specifically for that purpose."

"An elevator to Earth? Hmmm, I suppose you use it to go up there and torment people?"

"Not very often. It's much more convenient to have my minions come down here to meet with me, then send them back up to do my dirty work."

"You mean you have demons riding the elevator?"

"I suppose you could call them demons. Most people just call them Senators, CEOs, Supreme Court Justices, third world dictators, et cetera, you know, the usual greedy bastards. They can cause an awful lot of misery, and they are so easily paid for! Material wealth, a mere snap of the fingers to me, is all they ask."

"Yeah, I kinda figured you had to be behind the way things are these days."

"Well, no time to waste Steve, you'd best get in the elevator and get going."

Steve enters the car, pushes the "up" button, and says "So Satan, when I get back up there, I trust you're gonna give me some help? It is in your best interest in saving humanity too, right?"

Satan replies...
1112122121212122211222121232122.title: Hell on Earth

Steve pulls the aging Chevy into a parking space in the rest stop and shuts it off. Strong winds are rocking the van as they look out across the Texas plains at the flashing lightning and hear the thunder rumble. "I bet those guys are storm chasers, Annie. This sure looks like one that could drop a tornado on us. Maybe we should just get moving and try to outrun it? It looks like the sky is a little lighter in the distance to the west..."

"Yeah, as long as he doesn't run off the road first."

111221.title: Riding the Storm Out

1112211.content:
In January 1999 I stepped out the front door with my son christopher. The sky's were clear and we didnt have a worry in the world. My husband at the time Carl was at work and we was headed to the park. After about an hour I noticed that the clouds were comeing in and it didnt look good. I had to get my three year old home before it started to rain. If I had known that it was going to be worse than that we wouldnt have left the house.
As we were walking back to the house i heard sirens going off. My heart began to race and my son started to cry. All I could think was that a Tornado was comeing and we were still two blocks from the house. I picked him up and started running as fast as I could. I went through other peoples yards and cut through rose bushes but we made it just in time. I sat Christopher down and unlocked the front door as fast as I could.We then raced into the house and slide into the hallway I told him to stay put as I pulled a matress out and through it over him. I layed over the matress hopeing that it would be enough. After a few minutes I heard something that sounded like a train coming straight at us. I layed there praying that nothing would happen, that my son would be safe ,and that it would be over soon. And it was. I got my son and checked him over I then ran to the phone and tried to call my husband and then my parents. Just to come to the realization that the phones were out I then looked out side to see that the houses on either side wasnt just dameged but completly gone. About an hour later my husband showed up scared to death and happy that we were ok.

There were three other tornados that hit the town of beebe that day and over 16 people that were either injured or killed. including a friend of mines six month old baby tornados are scary and we moved within the week
Oh and im right back in tornado valley Go Figure
1112211.title: Tornado

11122111.content:
Due to a major breakdown on my truck, I've been "on vacation" in Needles California for the past week. Nothing much to do while I'm waiting for them to get it fixed so I've been driving my rental car around on the back roads, taking pictures of the desert.

One thing I've noticed is there are a lot of roadside memorials. I stopped to look at one of them, a white cross with only the family surname and the dates 1970-1988. Some 18 year old kid died here and his grieving family put up this memorial.

Back in town, in the grocery store parking lot I saw a memorial decal on the back window of an old Buick. Someone's son, a Hispanic kid, the dates 1992-2007. Later that day I saw another one in the back window of a pickup truck for a little girl who died when she was only 5 years old.

I know some people think roadside crosses or window memorials are tacky, but I think whatever helps you grieve is OK. Losing a child has got to be one of the worst things that can happen to a parent, that bond of love is so strong. To have it broken, their child dead, I can only imagine how horrible that is...

Today I was driving down the same road where I first saw the white cross for the 18 year old. I looked over at it as I drove by. Someone had placed new flowers next to the cross. That child died 23 years ago, and someone had just placed flowers there... That child is still remembered, that's love.
11122111.title: Love

111221111.content:
Life... What's the meaning of it? Why are we here?

Those brought up by parents with strong religious beliefs might say our purpose is to serve God. But if God is all powerful, why does he need mere mortals such as us to serve him? Can't he just snap his fingers or twitch his nose and immediately have whatever he wants?

Others say there is no purpose, Life is just meant to be lived and enjoyed. You better do whatever you want to do now, because once you die that's all there is. But how can anyone be so sure that's all there is? What about all these people who come back from near death experiences and talk about seeing their deceased relatives, and the white light, and the feelings of peace and joy?

Some say our existence is a mere accident, a random byproduct of evolution that allowed sentience to occur on this little blue marble orbiting in just the right location around the Sun. And if that meteor hadn't come along and destroyed the dinosaurs when it did, intelligent life on this planet might well have been saurian instead of simian.

Others are convinced God created the Earth to be in the right place to allow life, and humanity to prosper. It's up to us to make the best of it and become the good stewards of this planet that he intended. And some say if we don't behave we'll be punished for all eternity when we die.

As for me, I'm too busy making a living to worry much about the meaning of life. Maybe there is more to it than the here and now, maybe not. I'm content to try to live my life the best I can, no matter what, if anything, comes next. "Take time to enjoy life, and help others along the way," are the words I try to live by.
111221111.title: Life

111221112.content:
Men can set excellent examples by way of how they lived, then again they can do the same by how they died. A stupid death is an excellent teacher, you can almost hear her saying "Now don't choose to kick the bucket this way..." Two deaths have heavily influenced me and my perspectives in life. One was the death of my father when I was about 13, the other was the death of a friend a couple years later.

My father died from complications of lung cancer, undoubtedly accrued from years of smoking no less than 30 cigarettes a day. That death's lesson was a reinforcement of common sense: don't smoke. But the impact of losing your father to a habit at a young age is quite forceful, and thus the lesson is learned quite well. I never really got to know my father. I was the last child of a second family, and he was always away on business. I surprised my parents by being conceived in their later years, when my mother was actually thinking of having her her fallopian tubes tied up so they could bear no more than three children, one dying from miscarriage. I admired what I knew of my father, and I still remember and am fond of his stories both fictional and otherwise. It was unfair that I had so little time to spend with him and with a complete family that subsequently fell apart without him, all because he fancies a smoke too often.

A good friend with whom I shared a second name committed suicide when he was about 15 years old. He strung himself up using one of the straps of his backpacks the night he got a good scolding from his father. His mother was promptly devastated, and us, his friends from school, were dumbfounded. I remember the wake. His mother was crying. So were some of my other pals. Everyone was quite affected, except me. And I never understood why. I never understood why I didn't feel a thing. I stood there and watched, careful of my expression and my words. I was also there during his funeral. I walked the line that went past his coffin that served as a final goodbye, and upon passing his wooden final resting place I knocked on its side twice, again, feeling nothing. I knew him enough to call him my friend. We shared some ridiculous moments as ludicrous pubescent boys. He hung himself and I didn't even flinch. Perhaps that was my unique reaction to the tragedy, the stupidity. My way of grief expressed by his family and other friends through streaming tears and consoling words. Anyway, the second lesson was taught: don't commit suicide. And was that not more ridiculous than the first?

Don't smoke and don't commit suicide? Seriously?

Thinking about it, these lessons - though quite simple and self-justifying (not to mention self-explanatory) - are some of the simplest lessons people never learn and follow. So in the aftermath of both deaths I suppose I was lucky enough to learn without experiencing firsthand.
111221112.title: Death, an Excellent Teacher

1112211121.content:
I, myself, never wanted this. I mean, sure, dragons and armored knights lining up to fight some evil king of darkness sounds like the plot of some medieval action movie, and one that I would watch, now that I think about it. However, waking up atop some dormant volcanic mountain face to face with some giant bird wasn't the way to start a movie.

I guess they'll never make a movie about me.

I mean, I don't think I did anything. Normal kid, going to school, social life, that sort of thing. I mean, really, what else? Some demon-spawn who practiced magic and was sucked into some movie upon a wrongly spoken spell? Not me. I just woke up here.

I really don't think they'll ever make a movie about me.

Some ancient wizard who understands all and points me to the top of some erupting volcano surrounded by dragon nests and rock spikes and other random dangers? A diamond pendant I must throw in and be randomly teleported back to the real world? Nope. Not for me. I just am here. No quest, nothing. It's no movie I've ever heard of, and it's definitely not a period in history.

Or maybe it is. I mean, maybe there were dragons back then. Truly, how much do we really know? Nothing except what we have experienced. The rest we have taken for truth, but may well be falsified to cover up some ancient revelation or some point in history we don't want to remember.

I'm getting philosophical.

I mean, the natives are fine with me. Most actually aren't knights, thieves, peasants, or wives. All the stereotypes of a movie. I'm not really used to living here, but I don't have much of a choice, do I?

I've always been called reactive.

Personally, I'm not in shock that much any more. I've just accepted it. I'm not very into their culture, though, and sometimes I do things considered taboo back then. I don't exactly know the inbred rules and laws of a community living in a forest.

I guess I'll just have to learn.
1112211121.title: Learn

1112212.content:
And it came to pass, as they still went on, and talked, that, behold, there appeared a chariot of fire, and horses of fire, and parted them both asunder; and Steve and Annie went up by a whirlwind into heaven.

And the wall of the wind therein was like a great ladder, and the top of it reached to heaven: and behold the angels of God, along with a great mass of tree trunks, and a freight train or two, ascended and descended it; all of them singing,

The wind began to switch, the house to pitch, and suddenly the hinges started to unhitch.

Just then, the Witch, to satisfy an itch, went flying on her broomstick thumbing for a hitch.

And Steve and Annie couldn't believe their eyes or credit their ears, so that when the wind failed at last, and the clouds parted, they saw their van had come to rest atop a water tower just inside the Amarillo city limits.

Then looked they at each other, and said,

Verily, it must have been a dream, and in our sleep we drove and parked our van up here, for behold, there is no flipping way it could have happened the way it seemed.

Then summoned they a tow truck, and boy did it cost them a pretty penny to get down off that water tower, and many bad words did pass Steve's lips.

Thus arrived they in Amarillo, as had been foretold by the prophets, and to the Lord they gave thanks, though only grudgingly, for it was Amarillo, and who really wants to end up in Amarillo, amirite?
1112212.title: Amarillo

11123.content:
Wolf Runner was the name she gave the recruiting officer when he came to her door. She knew from the news stories that they didn't care what name you gave or anything else. The only thing that matter to the Recruiters was an individuals willingness to go with them and to leave their life on Earth behind. So when one of them came to her door and ask if she wanted to join the colonist she said yes.

She chose to honor her great grandmother Native American heritage. She chose to leave behind everything, except the Dream Catcher her grandmother had left her. She knew, that even if her brothers or sisters were willing to leave Earth they would pick different names and different heritages to honor. That was the way of her family, always going in different directs and always choosing different paths in life.

The only living person she would miss was her mother, who was living with her youngest brother. His last e-mail requested her to visit at Christmas, but now there would be no visit and no argument. Once she went up to her assigned ship there would be no return to Earth for Christmas or any other holiday. She would send a Happy Holiday greeting.
11123.title: Wolf

111231.content:
Home Sweet Home,
where exactly is it?

To some,
it may be their grandparents' house.

To others,
it may be the home where they grew up.

To me,
my Home Sweet Home is not here on Earth.

It is in the Heavenly mansion of my Father,
in His loving arms, surrounded by Our extended family.

With Him, where it is safe and no harm can come to me.
With Him, where nothing is out of reach.
With Him, where nothing but hope, love, peace, and His Holiness reigns.

This is where my Home Sweet Home is,
and where it will forever be.

1112321.content:
Step. Turn. Weave. Duck.
No, that’s not right, do it again.
Stop looking at him like that. Don’t think about how nice it would be to run your hands over those firm, perfect muscles.
Duck!
Kick, now. Take advantage of his weak left leg. He hurt that yesterday in that bout with Sono. Great, now close. No, dodge, he was faking.
Idiot. See it coming in future! Don’t let him get to you. Take it like a man. Don’t let him see you cry, ever. Get your bag. Take off your gee. No, not here, in the bathroom. Hide in one of the toilets.
Don’t think about him looking at you, judging you. Don’t get your hopes up.
Make sure to listen to music all the way home. It’s dark, so hum under your breath — it keeps the devils away. Remember to feed the neighbors' cat. The old bat is coming home in the morning.
Lie in bed, staring at the ceiling. Wonder whether he can even see you.
Practice writing his name in your diary, in pencil so you can erase it again. Go over your bout, again and again, looking for all the ways you slipped up. Dwell on that bloody arrogant smirk. Remind yourself that he thinks you're useless. A girl. Unworthy to be on the Karate team.
Wake up with the sun. Go through your Kata before breakfast. Look for your center. Balance. Do it again.
Shower. Don’t look in the mirror. Don’t wonder what life would be like if your weren’t a blue eyed white girl with fuzzy witch hair. Don’t waste your time trying to be beautiful. Don't resent the others for being perfect without trying. Just keep moving; keep focused.
Eat before you leave — breakfast is the most important meal of the day. Give your mother a kiss. Notice the way she watches you from the window. Don’t wonder why she looks nothing like you. It doesn’t matter.
Pause by the school gates and breathe. It will be okay.
Try your hardest in class, don’t be discouraged by your inaptitude for Japanese. Push aside your homesickness. You're stuck here, so make the best of it.
Pull out your lunchbox. Whisper a prayer of thanks to your mother for her hard work. Remember — before you gag on the sashimi — there are starving children in Africa who'd love to have so much food. Don’t think too hard about that. Don’t wonder whether your sashimi should be sent airmail to Africa. Ignore the girls at the next table, glancing at you over their shoulders and giggling.
Slow down, heart.
Smile politely.
Don’t ask him what he's doing at your table, you'll sound like an idiot.
Breathe.
Nod.
Listen to him tell you your hair is against regulation. You should cut it off.
Laugh nervously. Hope he doesn’t mean it.
Don’t get too lost in those damn honey brown eyes, staring at you with that bloody secret smile.
1112321.title: Love

JPL Observatory, 10:53 PM, October 25th, 2027


"Professor Farnsworth, we have the first image from the Tycho Brae Orbiting Telescope up on the screen, it's amazing!"

"Yes, Chiyoko, it is. At the distance we are now able to see, we are now looking back in time to the very beginning of the Universe! Those tiny sparks you see are the first stars being born!"

"Professor, what is that dull reddish colored object in the background of the center of the lower left quadrant? I haven't seen anything like that before."

"Hmm, it must be some sort of nebula, or a concentration of cosmic dust."

"There's another one in the upper right quadrant, near the top, it looks very similar, except it appears to be curled over on itself, and the inside is tan colored, and black along the edges. "

"That is most curious. It almost looks like an immense piece of charred paper, and it looks like it has something written on the red part. I can't quite make it out Chiyoko, your eyes are better than mine, can you read it?"

"Professor, I don't understand. It looks like it says M-80?"

11123221.content:
We are tiny specks in the vast universe.
Small, insignificant
Unheard, unseen.
We are tiny specks
Nobody notices us
Nobody cares.

Each tiny speck glows
Spreading its inner light
spreading the energy
Giving out joy, courage.
We are Stardust
We can reach out
By twinkling brightly
We can notice
We can care.

We are tiny specks
Significant, meaningful
Making a whole
That pulsates harmoniously
With all the gladness
That is nature
That is creation.
11123221.title: We are Stardust

111232211.content:
We can notice the traffic closing in,
Yet not the sound of a bird as it sings.
Volume turned up becomes white noise.
From computer games to talking toys.

When will silence return here again,
To stop our minds from going insane.
Will we ever stop, turn it off, let go.
Free our minds, find something we don't yet know.

Look at the world with fresh, clean eyes.
Discover this place glows with azure skies.
Feel excitement at seeing a rainbow,
Against chronic storm clouds, thunder rumbling low.

Do we see our escape from the onslaught?
Of all that we've built, all that we've taught.
Take time to seek for the quiet, the peace.
Originally given to us; for a moment!

Let the noise cease

112121.content:
The sound—a low, continuous groan—came from inside the apartment three doors down from Gustav's. Leaning his right ear against the cold wooden door, the voice was indistinguishable. "Ansel," he whispered and held his breath. The groaning stopped, and he backed away. Why had he stopped? Did it mean he was dead? Or maybe it wasn't Ansel. But whoever it was, they weren't making that noise because they felt well.

Standing in front of the door, he reached his hand to the door, but something stopped him from pushing it open. Then he realised: the door frame was splintered. It looked as though it had been hacked with something like an axe. An axe!

As he backed slowly away, he noticed how the blood led into the apartment. He should call the police, he knew that. But what if this is something to do with me? he thought. It's not like it would be the first time he got himself beat up over his lack of regard for drug territories. That was why he was living in that apartment, after all. He'd had to leave his old life in Fairway because of his dealings. Back then, he had a wife and two kids. He was the perfect family man. That's why no one suspected his other life. Until the day he had three ribs and an arm broken. But all that was in the past. He'd been careful this time around.

"Help me." The voice circled his head, dropping into the periphery of his brain. Ansel. Gustav's body froze, half way between going to help his client and saving his own backside. "Gustav, please."

Leaning his mouth into the crack of the door, Gustav said, "Okay, Ansel. It's me. Are, ahem, are you there alone?"

She gave him an address and he got a cab.
The building was uptown, a posh place.
112322.title: Shaking, scratching, nose and eyes watering he ...

choices: She was already home and answered on the first ring
but could not finish as his arm was

Even he wondered as he returned the pay phone receiver back to it's cradle," IS THE INVITATION INTENDED TO BE HIS DEATH?"

He made up his mind. He then called " the shrink", he had met on the plane. He needed help! She was it.
He dialed........
1123221.title: Is the invitation intended to be his death?

Marty is intercepted before he can get there.

ring.

"Hello?" said a contralto voice at the other end.

"Ma'am?" said Marty. "Marian gave your number to me. Who am I talking to?"

She identified herself as Spring Johnson.

"Spring, could you give a neutral location to me?
11232211.title: She was already home and answered on the first ...
