Spring was the most beautiful women Marty had ever seen.
112322111.content:
After informing Martin she had not only been expecting but deeply hoping he would call.
Spring Johnson assured him it was in his best interest to trust her.

Martin after saying," My friends call me Marty.?" suggested THEY MEET AT A PLACE OF HER CHOOSING.
She gave him the address of her office for the cabbie and told him she was a psychiatrist specializing in patient
drug abuse. She had some methadon for him to take the edge off while they explored options and the paramenters of his addiction.

Then she said," Marty, please come directly to my office. It's private and comfortable and I've been told I am not hard to
look at. Don't stop anywhere when you leave the airport. I have plenty of food and beverages here. It is important that you come straight here.
I'll explain once you have arrived."
112322111.title: They meet at a place of her choosing

11232212.content:
grabbed by a nondescript woman wearing a grey London Fog jacket. "Sylvie? Is that really you? My God, I thought I'd never see you again!"

"We can't talk here, it's not safe! Follow me, Hurry!"

She pushes him towards a 1972 Citroen DS parked at the curb, they get in and speed away as sirens and flashing lights approached from the distance.

"Marty, I see you've been self medicating again, I thought you had more strength than that!"

"But Sylvia, I thought you were dead! And with all the other agents compromised I thought it was only a matter of time before they got me too, so why not go out on a high?"

"But I'm not dead Marty. And neither are you, if you can stop wallowing in self pity and get your head back in the game!"

"OK, Sylvie, but can I at least call my man and score enough to keep me even?"

"No Marty, there's no time. There's a pint of bourbon in the glove box. Have a swig, that should take the edge off. But we gotta find Callie before the others get to him..."
11232212.title: but can't finish as his arm is

113.content:
Out the door and into the alley he sped, already an inch of snow on the ground. Like a hell-hound on the trail of a wandering soul, he moved with a purpose, quick and steady. It won't stop to give him a head start just because he needed to rest. The result of being merely human, he couldn't go on forever, he tired of the chase, he had to regain his strength. The smoking only weakened his lung capacity and made it harder to breathe in this blizzard. The cold will freeze his limbs and cause a furious pain to creep in, slowing him down.

It's amazing how adrenalin keeps the body pushing on when exhausted. He hadn't slept more than a few hours in the last four days. But even three cups of strong coffee won't drive away the mental fatigue that had enveloped his mind. Maybe the end would come swift and painless. It would put him out of his misery.

There was that sound again. It was close. It seemed to track him regardless of where he went or how he got there. Running on pure fear, he quickened his pace, looking for a door to duck into, or an outlet to a well lit street. But the alley was getting darker, almost like it was drawing him into shadow, a place not of this world.

It had to end, there had to be a way out. Then there it was, a door, or what appeared to be, the light searing the darkness and providing an escape. A man stood in the doorway, urgently waving him on, holding open this passage to freedom. This door man yelled: "Get down- Now!"

Cement greeted him with an unkindly slap as a shot rang out, the muzzle flash lighting up the corners of this dead end alley. Something screamed behind him and he heard the sound of the wind rushing past his ears. The man with the gun offered his hand to help him to his feet. In the other was a .44 magnum, a smoking gun that saved his life.
113.title: Smoking Gun

choices: Hooker With a Heart of Gold
1131.content:
Broke down in Little Rock, took almost six hours to get this damn rig back on the road. Been driving for eighteen hours straight now, trying to make up for lost time. Faster than I care to go with this load, but being careful to keep it under-ten-over, sure don't wanna get stoppped for speeding... The boss says I gotta drop this off in LA by 16:00 tomorrow or they'll be hell to pay, and I damn sure don't wanna dissapoint him.

Livin' on Red Bulls and Mickey D's, sleeping in rest stops for three days straight, it ain't much fun. But once I unload and get my payoff I'll be on easy street, at least for a while. Five Gees, fifty hundred dollar bills, and all tax free. A pretty good payoff for less than a week's work, if I do say so myself.

I don't know what's in the trailer, and I don't much care. Once I drop it off I plan on picking up a bottle of Jack Daniel's, booking a room at the nearest Motel 6, then calling the local escort service to see what they got avilable. I'm looking forward to a long deserved rest...
1131.title: Rest at Last!

choices: Talk your way out of this.
Your truck gets a strip search
11311.content:
The sun looks very angry today in the mirror as it rise behind me. The nights seem to go on forever, especially just before sunrise. My eyes grow tired of watching the white lines. Sometimes they cross, and sometimes they zig-zag, but no matter, I keep the rig between them.

Some people say billboards litter the highways, but I like them. They give the mind something else to do, besides counting mile markers. My favorite thing to do, is to look down at the cars that pass me by. People do all kinds of things in there cars; drinking eating, doing drugs, and even having sex. I've seen it all.

The sun is higher now, and no longer glaring at me from the mirror. I didn't notice the state trooper that has probably been tracking me for the last five miles. I check my speed. Still within reason, but I let up anyway, just to give him his respect. There goes his lights. Time to make an unscheduled stop. Some of these guys can be real ball-busters.

The big rig comes to a stop on the shoulder of this barren stretch of highway. I gather all of my necessary papers and wait for him. He's your typical trooper, complete with the smokey-the-bear hat, shiny shin high black boots, and black shades to cover-up his bloodshot eyes.

"Good morning officer."

"You skipped a scale - back about ten miles."

I never even saw it. Perhaps it was the sun blazing in my mirror, or the lack of sleep. Either way, I have just been busted for one of the most serious violations of them all. If I'm lucky, he'll give me a ridiculously huge ticket, if not, he'll make me follow him back to the scale and probably want to inspect my cargo. I wonder what's in there...
11311.title: Busted

113111.content:
"You got some paperwork to show me ma'am?" The trooper grins a toothy smile. "Tough job for a gal. Don't see many female drivers in these parts."

I reach for the file folder with my right hand and with my left, I roll the window down fully. The trooper steps back, removes his shades and eyes me warily.

"You need me to get out or can I just hand you the papers?" I don't have a good feeling about this guy. I didn't miss any scale regardless of the sun and fatigue. I'm tempted to ask to see his badge but decide to keep quiet. For now. My left hand finds its way to the weapon in the door pouch. I flash him a smile of my own. "Officer?"

"Just the papers. You stay put."

I lean out the window to hand over the folder but I smell a stink emanating from him. Whiskey and death.

"Company policy says I need to see your badge and ID before giving over any documents. Is that a problem?" My smile is stuck; my mind considers options and my heart races. Is this the monster I've been eluding?

His face contorts and twists with building rage. He turns away.
113111.title: Not Today

1131112.content:
I watch him in my mirror wondering if I should let go of my weapon and try to go for my radio. Beads of sweat started to form on my forehead and my stomach turned with nausea. I knew that I had to get out of there. Should I risk gunning it now and lose my job. A job that took six months to get. No one really wanted to hire a woman even though they couldn't come right out and say that. There was always some lame excuse that the position was already filled or they will call me back but never do. Just like the officer said, there aren't many female drivers around here. A wave of nausea shot through my body again. I was getting desperate. I needed to go now.

"Sir! Did you hear me? I can't give you these papers without your badge and ID, it's company poli--" I started to repeat, but was interrupted by the horrible sound of metal crashing upon metal. Then an explosion shook my rig.

The trooper took off running, yelling for assistance into his radio. I sat in shock for a moment and then a surge of adrenaline coursed through my veins. I dropped my papers and grabbed the fire extinguisher. Jumping down from my rig I ran towards the back of my trailer. The smokes and flames burned my eyes and lungs. What happened? Were they still alive? I could see part of a car rammed underneath the trailer. My heart sank.
1131112.title: timing is everything

11311122.content:
To late.

Way to late. The car was a classic 64 mustang. The color that was visible by the fire emanating from the trailer and
car burning was caspian blue. It could only be Bill and Beth's. The question I needed an answer to was who was driving the car?

I could see there was a driver. Toast!

I couldn't see a passenger or anyone else in the trailer or vehicle. No one could. The fire was to hot and the bottled gas (butane)
the trailer used hadn't been separated from it's location yet. We all were a safe distance away.

God, I hope it isn't Bill or Beth. Please Lord, let someone have stolen their car................
11311122.title: Too Late

choices: Steal the patrol car and make a run for it
Drive the semi to its destination with the cop locked inside
113112.content:
"Sorry officer, I'm not running overweight, I just didn't see the sign for the scale. If I don't make this shipment on time my boss is gonna kill me!"

"So son, what are ya haulin' ?"

"The bill of lading says it's medical supplies."

"What kinda supplies?"

"To tell you the truth officer, I honestly don't know. The trailer was sealed when I picked it up."

"Well, I bet you got a pair of wire cutters in your tool box. How 'bout you get 'em and step out here and open that trailer up so I can have a look see."

"Yes sir."

My boss gave me a gun, said I shouldn't let nobody open up the trailer, no matter what. But I ain't no cop killer, so I leave the gun where it is under the seat and step outside with my wire cutters. I open up the trailer and the stench of the zoo hits me, then I see the cages. I'm just as surprised as the cop is."

"These ain't no medical supplies, your'e haulin' monkeys! "

"Well officer, maybe they're for medical research?"

"And maybe they're just a smokescreen. Maybe you got drugs hid up there past the cages. I'm gonna go take a look, and you're coming too." The cop says, pointing his gun at me... I don't argue.

We climb up into the trailer and the cop starts looking around with his flashlight. He grabs onto one of the cages and leans over to look behind it. The monkey in the cage bites the cop's fingers and he yells out in pain and drops his gun. Thinking fast, I grab the gun and jump out of the trailer, locking him inside with the monkeys...
113112.title: Your truck gets a strip search

choices: What about a ploughman or a keeper at the zoo?
What about a circus man who lets the people through?
1131121.content:
I go over to the police car, running my hand over the hood. The metal is hot, and I squint as a flash of sunlight off the windshield stabs me in the eye.

This is bound to be fun. I've never been a policeman yet!

Until yesterday, I'd never been a truck driver.

Tinker, tailor, soldier, sailor,
Rich man, poor man, beggar man, thief.

I sing the rhyme quietly to myself as I open the driver's side door. Already I've been a sailor and already I've been a soldier. Certainly I've been a rich man, and just as certainly I've been poor.

But I am, and always have been, and always will be, a thief.

The leather seat squeaks as I slide into the cabin, and I let out a low whistle at all the buttons and switches and displays. I never realized how many controls it takes to run a cop car. I figured you just needed an extra button next to the emergency lights to turn on the sirens.

Or what about a cowboy, policeman, jailer,
Engine driver, or a pirate chief?

I can add policeman to my resume now, I think with a grin as I accelerate slowly back onto the highway, leaving the truck behind. I suppose I've been a jailer of a sort, too. That cop isn't the first person I've left behind, trapped in a trailer, or in a basement, or under a makeshift cairn of stones as I've made off with a new identity.

Speaking of which ...

It's not enough, you see, to steal the patrol car and make a run for it. I run my palms delicately over the steering wheel until I feel a patch of heavy smudge left behind by the cop.

That's good. It means I won't have to search the rest of the cabin to complete the theft.

I keep my eyes firmly on the road as I lean forward to run my tongue over the steering wheel, where the smudge of sweat and body oil and skin flakes is thickest.

His DNA is delicious, and the old, familiar thrill runs through me. My vision blurs, but the highway is straight and empty, and when I emerge on the other side I've only drifted half out of the lane. I steer back to a central course.

I wish I knew how to run the sirens. I wish I had the uniform.

But at least now I have the face. The rest will be easy enough to get if I can only find an address to go with it.

And with the cruiser and the uniform and the face, it will be so easy the next time I want to try for something new!

Oh it's such a lot of things there are
And such a lot to be
That there's always lots of cherries
On my little cherry tree!
1131121.title: Steal the patrol car and make a run for it

choices: Let it go and continue becoming a policeman
11311212.content:
"Where the hell did that come from?" I shout hitting the brakes as an elephant thunders across in front of me. The car slows nicely and spins on a dime with a mere flick of the wheel. Momentarily, I marvel at this and wonder what else it can do. "More importantly, where is it going?"

Some sort of natural instinct, or perhaps my fantasy about being a policeman, takes over as I follow behind the lumbering giant. I look over for button to turn on the siren. Unmarked, I press one that looks promising. There's a low pop and a shadow rises in the rear-view mirror. Trunk release.

No time to stop and close as I scan the center console's array of knobs and switches. But what catches my eye is the radio's microphone.

"An elephant is running down, um . . ." A street sign flashes before the car then quickly disappears beneath it as I swerve back onto the road. "Broadway. I'm in pursuit."

Adrenaline fuels my actions. A hard turn on screeching tires almost slides me into the passenger seat making me wish I'd fastened my seat belt.

"What elephant? Who is this? Where are you on Broadway and which one - avenue or street?" squawks from the dash speaker.

A big gray one stalls in my head as a reply because I'm not sure how to answer the other questions. I'm just a guy who stole a police car after locking the cop in a trailer of monkeys is probably not good either.

The elephant makes a turn into a park through a large gate, plenty big for the car to go through. It'd be easy to follow across the lawn and through the wide-spread trees. A large tent is behind them - a place to switch again? I don't have a uniform, and what will I do if I catch it. And I haven't found the siren and lights switch! Then again, I've always liked the circus.
11311212.title: The circus is in town

11312.content:
She smiled at me, her face breath-takingly beautiful, but her eyes, heart-breakingly sorrowful, betrayed the happiness she faked. Her high-pitched laughs were brittle, sounding almost artificial. But she was too good. Too good at what she did to ever break the facade she had so carefully built.

She was the hot girl standing at the corner. One hand resting on her small hip, or perhaps accidently on purpose stroking her large chest, the other hand sweetly beckoning to men in expensive cars who wore business suits, and had wives and children at home. She knew what they wanted, and they knew she'd give it to them. For the right price though, of course.

I looked back at her, and tried to smile. It felt wrong, as if my muscles had forgotten how to pull and twist my lips into a friendly grin. Her own smile faltered then, her pretty pink mouth curving downward. A deep, fatigued sigh escaped her. "I don't know how much longer I can keep this up......." she confessed, eyes vacantly gazing over my shoulder.

"But you're almost there, just five hundred more dollars, and he'll be safe," I told her, feeling a sense of sudden urgency.

Again she sighed, and slumped against the side of the brick building. "I know, I know.......I just-" Her eyes squeezed shut, a lone tear slid down her sparkly cheek. "What if it doesn't work?" she whispered. "What if it comes back, and he dies? Then all of this.........would have been for nothing."

I shook my head violently. "No, not for nothing! You tried and that's what matters. What if you had done nothing, and he did die? Would you have been to forgive yourself for that?"

A sharp sob met my words. She sank down, holding herself in a ball of fishnet and shiny pleather, tears tracing lines down her face. "I just want him to be ok......."

Her younger brother, still a child, was in the hospital with a brain tumor. He was scheduled for chemotherapy, but no one knew if he would survive in the end. Though her family had long since cut off contact with her, she'd learned the news from a sympathetic aunt. It was this that had driven her to the streets to make money to send to him. Truth be told, I had no idea if what she was doing would actually help, but I couldn't bear to be the one to destroy the last shreds of hope she clung to.


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *

It had been outside a McDonald's that I first met her. I was walking home from my first day of tenth grade. We'd spotted each other at the exact same time - an expression of apprehension on her face, a look of faint shock on mine. I could have sworn several minutes passed before she plastered on a huge grin and walked towards me, sticking her hand out and introducing herself as "Kitten". Somehow, we ended up sitting across from each other in a booth inside the resturant chewing on greasy burgers and salty fries, and slurping large cups of pop.

"So what did you say your name was?" she asked me through a mouthful of soggy beef.

"I never did," I replied.

She looked momentarily perplexed, but then smirked as she leaned over the table and whispered conspiratorially, "I think I'll call you..........Tinkerbell."

I stared at her, unsure if it was a joke, or if she was being serious.

Seeming to sense my discomfort, she patted my arm and reassuringly told me "I'm not teasing. Tink is cool, and you are too, 'cause you bought me lunch!" Her eyes sparkled with mirth.

For the next two weeks, we met at McDonald's, my allowance slowly being drained from my pocket as I continued to treat us both to lunch. Through the course of that time, I found out about her job, her little brother, and her parents. In turn, I told her about my family, my teachers, and the few friends I had. She seemed almost desperately interested in what my life was like. "It sounds a lot better than mine," she'd laughed. But there'd been no humor in her voice, only a deep longing, a wistfulness, that had made my heart feel like it was twisting inside my chest.


* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *


I couldn't bear to be the one to destroy the last shreds of hope she clung to..............

"It worked, Tink........it fucking worked!"

At first, I could only stand there, mouth hanging open stupidly. She grabbed me in as tight a bear hug as her thin arms would allow. "It worked, it worked," she repeated breathlessly.

"Your brother......he's gonna be alright?" I asked, even though I already knew the answer.

"Damn right he is!" she agreed, her teeth bared in a wild grin. She suddenly started laughing, the sound bordering on mania. As quickly as the laughter had begun, it stopped. "You know what this means?" she asked. Before I could say anything, she answered herself. "It means I can leave......"

"Leave where?" I cut in.

"Here........." she waved her arms in a vague gesture.

But I never did learn what she meant by that. She dragged me into McDonald's for a celebratory lunch, for the first time complete with dessert. I could not banish the sense of foreboding that hung in my mind like a miasma. Standing back outside the resturant, she hugged me again, this time gently. When she pulled back, there was a strange look in her eyes that I couldn't decipher. Like usual, I was the one to walk away, but this time, I glanced back after I'd crossed the road. She was gone. It was the last time I saw her since then.

It's been a year, and I find myself sitting in our booth at McDonald's. I've lost count of how many times I mused over her words: "It means I can leave.......here........" What did she really mean? I resign myself to the fact that I will probably never know if she simply left the city, or perhaps the state, or if she was dead, the purpose of her life fulfilled. In the end I suppose it doesn't really matter. It's who she was that struck me so deeply. A hooker with a heart of gold...........who'd have thought?
11312.title: Hooker With a Heart of Gold

113121.content:
Some people say that we write nothing but a lot of propaganda. I say we are artists who paint with words. We may do the Mona Lisa with a spray can, but it is still the Mona Lisa.

It isn't easy making our Glorious Leader look his best day after day. Sure the movie people produce more glamorous footage, but our work is all the greater, considering what we have to work with. Our Glorious Leader is not conventional leading man material. He has that little kink that unkind people are brave enough to call a hunchback and his eyes give the viewer an uneasy feeling. We just have to work that much harder to help viewers to understand his greatness.

All of us in the Promotion of Happiness Department love our work. Malcontents like Theodore don't really count, especially when they get sent to the Camps for Rehabilitation. The rest of us put in extra hours out of relief to have whiners like Theodore gone. Boy is it ever great to be able to get on with our wonderful important work!

I am especially proud of the way the Department spruced up the story of our Glorious Leader's past regarding his Sex Worker sister. Some people might have wanted to give up on finding a way to make that cheerful. There is just nothing like a Sex Worker with a heart of gold to pluck at heartstrings. Having our Glorious Leader's sister working to pay for his chemotherapy was a really nice touch. I don't think we had better put in anything about her time in the Camp for Rehabilitation. Well, maybe we can have a cute starlet show her being deliriously happy learning to better serve the state and living happily ever after, when she becomes an asset to our Society. Yeah. That might work.

It is just so wonderful to work for the Promotion of Happiness Department. I already work twelve hours a day six days a week, doing my part to keep our Perfect Society functioning at its best. If I didn't have to spend so much time commuting, I would, of course, be working at least sixteen hours a day. It is too bad I have to spend so much time doing boring things like eating and sleeping. If I didn't have to do all of that, it could give me even more time to contribute to the Promotion of Happiness Department!

I know that our science department is working away on the problem of losing so much productivity to eating and sleeping needs. Who knows when they might come up with an advance that will give us many more hours to contribute toward keeping our Perfect Society functioning at its best! Words to describe my feelings fail me. I am sure everyone in the Promotion of Happiness Department feels the same way I do.

Please send a copy of this to all staff members and post extras on all bulletin boards. I am so glad to serve our Glorious Leader and our Perfect Society!

P.S. Don't forget that attendance at the Celebration of Happiness Parade this Saturday is mandatory. Don't forget to have a wonderful time and smile a lot for all of the cameras. Big smiles are also mandatory. Have fun. (The last is optional.)
113121.title: Propaganda

1131212.content:
I don't follow the whole Happiness Parade that Saturday. I'm in complete and utter rebellion as I watch the happy people posing perfectly with plastered smiles on their faces. Streamers fall down from the sky and I brush on of the obtrusive objects away from my shoulder. I have plans that I've made in my moment of mayhem.

My eyes scan the backpack I have hidden underneath my arm. I tuck it in tight and walk toward one of the floats that is covered in flowers. This shouldn't do too much damage but just enough to shake things up. I keep pace with the vehicle driving it and look across the sea of people.

A camera is shoved in my face. I push a hand in front of it to block but fail to do so in time. Now they have a picture of me, I'll have to take care of this guy after the fact.

"You know you're supposed to smile," he chastises me. There's some kind of cologne coming from him that smells divine. He has blue eyes and is wearing an even bluer shirt. A tatto adorns his right bicep and peeks out from under his shirt.

"To hell with smiling," I reply. My head tilts back as I take a long draw from my cigarette. The smoke fills my lungs and steadied my nerves. I know once I light the bomb he'll be an unfortunate victim from the fire. Lit by my own cigarette and tossed within the flowery confines.

"I hear that," he replies. The man gives me a cool look up and down. I hesitate with my decision of lighting this whole world on fire. What should I do?
1131212.title: Rebellion

113122.content:
In my attic, I look at the page in front of me.
I found her picture at last.
My chest starts to tighten, making it hard to breathe.
She graduated at the top of her class.
It is a miracle that I was given this as a gift.
Ever since the McDonalds departure,
I think about her and to be with her, I wish.
I wonder if her life is easier now or got harder.
Her curly brown hair would ascent her face.
Her eyes appear to be filled with happiness.
Unless, her brother died, she would feel like a disgrace.
Maybe, I will find her, and she will be mine.
No one else would be able to have her.
Her soft lips on mine would make her divine.
To my despair on the next page were
A picture
With her boyfriend with an engagement ring on her finger.
This yearbook of senior year at her school in Maryland,
It is the book of truth that will never be forgotten.
I closed it and began to sob.
113122.title: Book of Truth

choices: Like kicking a puppy that kicks back
114.content:
Before I asked her anything, I read her notebook. Opened it while she was out of the band room, like a thief, shaky-handed. It was one of those shiny black sketchbooks that art students carry. Her indecipherable handwriting covered the charcoal-smudged pages like vehement red stitches. In between the ragged lines I found tiny pencil sketches. Tiny fragments of people that made my face heat. She had never expected those pencilled ghosts of desire to see the light. I felt like I was opening her skin up, cutting through her muscles and looking inside. It was like the first time I looked at porn, but worse. Her soul wasn't meant for my consumption.
         I never could tell her about how I had violated her privacy while she was away. Maybe that was why it didn't work out between us. I knew her mind because of the notebook. I used my stolen secrets to win her. But when we were alone, those sketches lay between her skin and mine, an invisible sheet that tattooed me with shame.
114.title: Sketches

1142.content:
There are moments when he watches me. I'm not sure if he knows I've noticed his gaze, but it has never once wavered. It's as if those blue eyes see something in me--see something know one else knows. It's as if I'll disappear, or blow up if he's not watching.

Honestly, it could probably be all my fault. I've never once stop him--never once objected to his hard-boiled stare. I know, I know. What in Pete's name is a hard-boiled stare? It's the way he looks at me, those deep piercing blue eyes full of cat-like curiosity and tides of incoming visions of me. He looks at me as if I'm the only one in the room--and I'm sure that sounds hell creepy--but honestly, I boil under his gaze. My soft center hardens slowly and I remember all the anger. I remember all those late nights we spent yelling at each other, awful words and harsh tones, when we were both just frustrated beyond our tired minds. And then there were afternoons where I wanted nothing more that to be in his arms as we lay the abandoned tree-house where we would watch the sun set in an explosion of tangerine and plum. It makes me bitter.

Oh God, he makes me so bitter and resentful, like I'm some woman scorned... and then I remember why he tore us apart, why he changed. I expect many things to change a person, and hell, circumstances matter but it was never supposed to be like this. I was never supposed to act like this; like he was the last person on Earth that mattered. I hate it.

But like I said. There are moments when he watches me, as if he's still in love with me.

It kills me.
1142.title: Hard-boiled

11421.content:
now I lay me down to sleep
but no sleep comes, the hours creep

a thousand worries haunt my bed
I toss and turn inside my head

a clock ticks, I lie awake
just praying for the dawn to break.
11421.title: A Clock Ticks

114212.content:
I stare at the textured ceiling. I trace the edges of the raised patches with my eyes, letting them roam over the bumpy white landscape as they wish. My peripheral vision slowly darkens, and my mind races faster along the shrinking tunnel of light that remains.

A bear presents itself before me, joyful below a cloud specked sky. My eyes travel up a cliff, white, impassable. A dragon swims in the air above, long thin tail streaming behind. I wish I had a dragon. If I had a dragon I would slip onto its red ridged back, and grab on behind its ears before whispering,

"Take me somewhere beautiful," and we would depart. Within minutes we're above the clouds. They are as peaceful from above as they are from below, and I imagine that if I should fall, they would catch me and envelop me, and I would be weightless in the cool fog, swirling around my body, tugging gently at my clothes as if to say, "those don't belong here..."

A car honks outside. The ceiling is once again hard, plain, lifeless.
114212.title: Wide Awake and Dreaming

choices: be who you want to be
1142122.content:
Dear Dad,
I know what you think. Chris plays sports and gets As and Bs. Andy gets straight As. So what went wrong with me?
For the first thirteen years of my life i struggled to come up with an answer for you. I still don't know how to answer that question. All I wonder is, did you ever really pay attention to anything i did?
Remember 6th grade graduation? I got an award for the best improved in art, I thought you would be happy, but you weren't. When I got home you talked about how i should of stood up straighter and not have my shoulders all slumped over. Then you yelled at me cause i slumping at that very moment. Couldn't you see that I did that because i was nervous and uncomfortable. i don't like being in front of large crowds or being yelled at. Not once did you say anything about my art award, which i was once so proud to have gotten.
Oh, and this is a memory i remember while. My report came in 7th grade and i was failing math. Chris had a B in math and Andy a A. What was it you told me "You have two smart brothers, your mom is even smart, and I'm sure as hell no dummy, so why the hell are you so retarded."
Do you realized how much that hurt. Did you see the A in English or the B in history, I was even passing science. I cried myself to sleep that night. It only gets worse and worse from there. You abused me in more way than just those verbal assaults. You know you did and that's why you are where you are now.
I use to wake up wishing I was dead, I didn't know if i could face another day. I believe Chris realized this and that's why he told. We are proud people and like to deal with our problems ourselves, I know how hard it was for him to do what he did.
We move in with Mom, and for once I'm called beautiful and smart. I don't have to worry about what happens late at night or what will happen when that report card gets home. My grades still weren't good, I'm sure that's what you're thinking. I wonder if you noticed that I made the highest grade in history. Did you know that if I hadn't of failed a test on Shakespeare I would of made English Honors. Then there was that time when i spent every waking minute trying to write a book. I threw away so much paper that Chris finally snatched one out the trash and read it. He was amazed and he thought i would be the next best thing. I guess he was wrong.
Many years have passed since we lived with you. I'm 18 now and I have graduated high school. It's funny really, you always figured I'd be the one to drop out and Andy would be the one to graduate. Instead it was the other way around. I didn't get the highest grades in the class, in fact i believe i had some of the lowest. But you know something, that doesn't mean I'm stupid. I'm very smart, but I'm lazy.
I can go on and on but I won't. All I want to let you know is that I'm sorry I didn't meet your high expectations. I'm sorta glad i didn't. I know it may sound wrong but I've learned some stuff about myself through my failures. But the biggest changes in my life I have to give all the credit to my friends, online and off. Maybe you get some credit somewhere, we'll have to see about that.

Your daughter
1142122.title: high expectations

choices: The unspoken beauty of shimmering glass
Love is stupid , as well as blind
11421221.content:
I went back just to look at the broken glass on the pavement. I went back , praying it would rip open the wound and I would feel
something other than numb. I anticipated a moment of surreal confusion before a crushing agony would steal my breath. I was prepared to
feel my very soul bleed.
         I parked across the lot and stared at the light post. The irony of this had not escaped me. I had , in my darkest moment , sought a literal
light. I approached the light , part of me praying for the pain and part of me shying from the absolute terror . Surreal confusion took over , as
I looked over the grass, shimmering as though strewn with diamonds. The pavement was clean of any broken glass. The blood had washed out of
my clothes and my car. The windows had been replaced. I felt no pain , only a furthered detachment from any reality as I stared at the shimmering
grass. This should hurt , this was the place that every dream I had for us ended.
         Time reversed in my head . I was pulling you back in my car , you were tearing the cartilage in my shoulder , telling me I didnt love you
because I wouldnt let you jump. All I could do is beg you to let go , and when I stopped I ran. I loved you with all that I was but in that moment ,
I realized my bestfriend had died. I realized that I couldnt do it anymore and I let you go. Something inside me broke away and I lost meaning of life.
          Its been two years and I still replay it in my head. Its been two years of healing , with kindness and love from another. It was knowing that
I should have answered yes every time you asked me , " Is this abusive?" . Its knowing that the most important promise a man can ever make me from
now to the day I die isnt that he will be faithful , its that he will never hit me or scream at me. Its been two years since I escaped your abuse and since
something inside me broke.
         I went back to look at the broken glass on the pavement. I went back to bury the woman I was.

11421222.content:
What an interesting title. It is very familiar to me as I have been practicing since my youth. In real life I have been who I have wanted to be many times. Different characters in different cities doing different things with different people. Sailor, Merchant Mariner, Commercial Fisherman, Surfer, Restauranteur, College Student, Navigator, Scuba Diver, Building Contractor, Home Inspector, Realitor, Marijuana Grower, Dope Dealer, Prisoner, Boat Owner, Champian High Diver, Life Guard, Parent, Husband, Ordained Minister, Home Owner, Television Actor, Tennis Professional-11 courts, Radio Broadcastor, Newspaper Reporter, Surgical Technician, Soda Jerk, Convention Mgr-Hilton, Paper-Boy, Sky Diver, Yogi, Bible Scholar, Published Author, Artist, Draft Dodger, Baseball Coach, Competitive Swimmer.
BE WHO YOU WANT TO BE-today, tomorrow and yesteday was my motto to live by. Well today I'm not Daddy's dumb daughter who was voted by the family the least likely to succeed at anything except staring off into the distance, feminine hygiene, watching grass grow, remembering my address, getting pregnant, putting my underwear on, using adjectives in my sentences, waking up, keeping a job, flushing the toilet and breathing.
Today I'm Bold Marlin Spike, the baddest Pirate to ever sail the Spanish Main! I am cruel, wicked, mean, bad, and nasty! I have my way with the very Proud and Wealthy, Beautiful, Aristocratic Spainards! Not the men but their wives and concubines! Then they walk the planck! Begging for Mercy where there isn't any! Enough, It is time to set sail!
BOLD Marlin Spike said to his crew:

“Up with the skull and cross bones
And down with the blue!

Up with the Black Boy!

All men to show,

Over the water

And off let us go!”



A man-of-war he hailed us:

“Come under my lee!”

“See you damned,” said Captain Spike
“For I'd rather sink at sea ,





---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----





In the blue water

Far out and free,

Cruising down on the shore

By the coast of Barbary.”



We met the Flying Dutchman,

By midnight he came,

His hull was of hell fire,

His sails were all o' flame;

Fire on the main-top,

Fire on the bow,

Fire on the gun-deck,

Fire down below!



Four-and-twenty dead men,

Those were the crew,

The devil on the bowsprit

Fiddling as she flew.





---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----





We gave her a broadside

Right in the dip,

Just like a candle,

Out went the ship.



We met a gallant vessel

Sailing on the sea ,


For mercy, she did plea;

But the mercy we gave her

We sunk her in the sea ;

Cruising down on the shore

By the coast of Barbary,



Four-and-twenty Spaniards,

Mighty men of rank,

With their golden ladies

Had to walk the plank,





---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----





Over the gunwale

Into the sea ,

Cruising down on the shore,

By the coast of Barbary.



Oh devil take the captain!

And devil take the ship!

And devil take the cargo!

And devil take the trip!

And devil take the bo'su'n!

And devil take his call!

And devil take the doctor!

And devil take 'em all!



Over the quarter,

Over the sail,

Into the water,

Dead as a rusty nail





---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----





Slung like a biscuit,

Hot as a coal,

Where the sharks take the body,

But the devil takes the soul!



Then spoke Sad Sam of Jersey, “As we've heard

A mermaid or an albatrose is the same bird,

But of a different feather, so a pirate,

And slaver, is all one for prisoners of Mother England's guards cannon fodder,

For pirates kill and plunder all they catch,

And slavers at the same are just their match."

There ain't no special difference (it was said

That Sam himself well knew the Guinea trade,

And half-way to the devil had sent his soul

By running into Cuba “sacks of coal”)—

And then he sang to us right merrily

﻿﻿A slaver's song, not written by me.
11421222.title: be who you want to be

11422.content: It's the moments were happy I wish I could capture. I could have an image that would bring back the memories after the darkness sinks in. However, I don't. I can't go back in time to when love was beautiful and blooming. The past is stuck unmoving in my mind. As time goes on the memories fade, or are overcast by the shadows of now. One image is all I ask for, one Polaroid picture that could convey feelings. I need one picture that could convey all our hopes and desires. I need one picture that could capture the light giddiness we felt. I need one picture that could show our love in that instant. I need only one picture to remember how we fell into a deep and unyielding war that was the most wonderful thing in the world, but also the most heartbreaking. One last picture so I remember all that I was.
11422.title: Polaroid

11423.content:
She knows I have been watching her. I see her look at me, and then she turns away, She still feels pain from that time. We were younger then, and so much has changed.

It was one of those times of youth when life was grand, and all of the possibilities of the waiting world were open to us. I've learned since then that whenever nature lifts you up high, it's only because you will have more impact when nature decides to let go, and you crash to the ground. The problem was that I took her along on the crash.

It was about the money, so many things like this are, but she thought it was about her. Her father had plenty of money, and I wanted a piece of it. I had told her that I loved her. We spent a couple of months doing wedding plans. She did a lot of girly things. When I spoke with her father, he was glad to see his girl so happy, and even offered a position in his company. Everything was going well. That is, until she found out about the secret that I felt no one would ever uncover.
11423.title: bus stop

114231.content:
In that moment Jayson painfully understood how fickle life could be. All it took was a millisecond for his world to shatter into a million pieces.

They had been laughing, and he had been pondering the thought of how lucky he was to have such a handsome and loving man next to him in the car. His man was shining light on old memories they had created together, memories he relished dearly. Silly memories like how they first met.

They had both mysteriously gone to the same amusement park alone, pulled by the same desire of adventure and thrill. They had stood at opposite gates waiting anxiously for their turn on the roller coaster. Once seated down and strapped down, they both had confessed it would be their first roller coaster ride in both of their lives. They both chuckled nervously at the slim chance they encountered themselves in as the ride began. Fifteen seconds later, the roller coaster stopped. Half the carts were facing down the first big hill, theirs at the cusp of plunging down with them. The intercom system had shouted for patience as there happened to be a malfunction.

So there they both found themselves, in another almost-impossible situation, trying not to freak out. His roller coaster buddy kept mumbling that only one in twenty-four million people died in roller coaster rides. Even though those statistic should have comforted him, all Jayson could think at that moment was that his day so far had been one of crazy chance and that one in twenty-four was looking awfully alluring. The man next to him glanced at him once, saw how horrified he was, took his hand in his, and said it would all be ok with a reassuring smile. A few seconds later the ride continued without a hiccup and Jayson took comfort on the stranger's hand the whole ride, maybe squeezing a bit too hard at times. Once it ended, Jayson realized he was still clutching the man's hand and let go with a sheeppish grin and few shades of red in his face. Like the marvelous man he was, the stranger only smiled and introduced himself.

Now their story ended at another impossible chance as he laid on the grass, ten feet away from his smoldering car. He had only glanced away for less than a second to tell the man he loved how much he meant to him. But he laid there, unable to make a sound as he saw the same hand that had comforted him, under the wreckage of what once was his car. Jayson was scared as hell, and now there was no man to tell him it would all be ok.
114231.title: Under the Wreckage

1143.content:
Time moved on and I got in to deep for there to be something between us other than right. Even if it was only
my conscience building something that could be small to her but was gathering momentum and larger than life to me. It had to be seen by both of us.
You understand? Secrets, large or small, when they are personal and involve no one else but you and a friend can be shared. If not, it's a good way to find out the value of friendship. Not to purposely put friendship to a test for it does that quite well by it's very nature, but somethings must be brought forward and looked at, together. They can be the glue that defines one or the other and sometimes both.
I was hoping this wasn't a deal breaker but I had to put it out there because I couldn't carry it anymore. It was getting heavier and it was distracting me from what I considered to be more important things to focus on. In hindsight I'm glad I spilled the beans when I did. The timing couldn't have been any better.
Since we had been going together for over a year and felt comfortable with the ups and downs of each others natures, I was shocked but pleased at the fire that, I guess was there but lying dormant until activated! Well I activated it! It was LIKE KICKING A PUPPY THAT KICKS BACK!
She went and got the sketchbook and made me describe my feelings about what I was looking at. Each and every one of the sketches I had to describe in detail. Here's the puppy kicking back. There were many more pages I hadn't seen because they weren't written or drawn on back then. She had me take my time and review her new sketches and read her comments as she had me describe what I felt about what I was seeing. In the course of us going over her sketchbook honestly and together we learned a lot more about each other and our particular and unique to ourselves, way of looking at the world we are surrounded by.
We've been married now thirty years. I wanted a woman to ride the river with. This I got when I kicked a puppy and it kicked me back-harder!
1143.title: Like kicking a puppy that kicks back

Alert my experience years ago, and after many years experience married to this wonderful, yet challenging love of my life, I realize now how lucky I am and why and how I should continue to do whatever possible to keep my best friend and life companion happy, healthy, and madly in love with me. This is a partnership which I have grown to appreciate and hope to have for a very, very long time. Sure there have been monsters in this relationship tying to upset the balance of things, but really, when it's this important and precious, it is worth investing everything I/we have into our relationship.

So now I am researching what to do for my next written work, and she my partner is deciding how she is going to create her masterpiece which will be displayed at the next art show. Hum, what if we combine forces and work together on both of these projects, wouldn't it be wonderful.

Perhaps we'll have a lot of fun with her illustrating the mule and cart I tell about in my novel, or maybe we can figure out what monster is leaking in the barn that the family dog keeps barking at day or night, or the trip from Canada to Mexico that the retired couple have always wanted to take may be of interest to both of us. Well, at least there are choices and then again, I wonder what the retired couple will look like according to my partners illustration? Much to think about and consider, so I guess it's time to consult with Nancy and see what she thinks. This is going to be quite an adventure in imagination and mystery.
11432.title: It's a long ride from Canada to Mexico on a mule

11433.content: We have no secrets. We didn't want to bring children into this cruel world. I'm fine with just the two of us but we have stayed here in this apartment for thirty years. I had to get out somehow. I went to the travel agency down the block and brought home every brochure they had. When she got home I had them stuck on every wall, scattered across the tables, even some on the floor. She looked at me and said "Do I have to get out the sketch book again?" "Hear me out." I quickly reply. "We need a vacation. I don't care how long or where to. You pick. I did this for you." She looked at me skepticly . Then started looking at each brochure. It took her a month to go through the states. Another month to go through Africa. I was going crazy. Was she ever going to pick or was she going to make my life a living hell again. I should have never have brought this up. We were fine. Thirty years and no kicking the dog. I must be opening up old wounds of some kind. What kind of hell would we go through now. Then her voice, barely a whisper, "New Zealand." My head jerks up "Did you just say New Zealand?" "Yes" She walks out of the room.
11433.title: New Zealand?

...of my thoughts.

I watched her leave the room not even her shoes making a sound!

"Why was she so quiet?" I thought. I had expected her to make a scene like she had every other time. Something was wrong and I went after her.

choices: Honey, I chose New Zealand because
Unusual weather. Detoured to Sydney, Australia
114332.content:
Why? What does she, me or any of our friends know about New Zealand? Floored by her decision I grabbed
four brochures about traveling in New Zealand and retired to what my wife calls my library, the bathroom.

When I exited forty-five minutes later, I could barely walk. My buttocks had fallen asleep and the pins and needles
there and in my legs when the circulation was returning, was so painful it was all I could do not to cry out.

I had learned a lot. New Zealand is a country not an island state of Australia as Tasmania is. Australians (aussies, pronounced ozzies) are fiercely competitive against New Zealanders (called Kiwis-after a beach living small king-fisher).

New Zealand is consists of three islands, narrow and about the length of California, made up of a population of about
three and a half million people. Apparently the indigenous people found in N. Zed when the first Scottish settlers arrived, the Maoris(Polynesians), had eaten the indigenous people they found when they arrived, the Morioris(Polynesians}.

The Maori name for New Zealand is The Land of the Long White Cloud.

The furthest one can get from the ocean in New Zealand is fifty-five miles. They have more boats per person than any other country in the world which helps explain their dominance in international sailing competitions.

Anything and everything that can be done on and with the water is available in N. Zed. The South Island has tremendous snow skiing. It also has volcanic activity for viewing and exploration. It has many world renown hiking trails, day and overnight, with and without guides.

Kiwis get along with Americans but do have a tongue-in-cheek type of humor and will, "Have ya on", but all in good fun.

I love the ocean but my wife feels like salt and sand are out to get her. She didn't swim in the ocean before she saw the movie, Jaws. But after the movie she hates to even fly over the ocean! So Why New Zealand?

The only way I'm going to find out why she chose New Zealand is to come right out and ask her.
114332.title: Why?

choices: Does she tell him that the only experience in the wild, blue yonder ended...
Does she tell him something so completely off-track that it floors him.
1143321.content:
...it was a different place, as far from civilization as I could go without going wild. Going wild is not what you want and I know it. Do you still want to hesitate?"

She looked me in the face in silence for 5 minutes, and I suspected that the gears were still turning inside her skull. She opened her mouth and closed it then took a deep breath and started to talk.
1143321.title: "Honey, I chose New Zealand because...

11433212.content:
"After all we've been through I suppose you deserve the truth. The real reason I chose New Zealand is I because need to see my daughter."

"Daughter? Daughter? What are you talking about?"

"I got pregnant when I was sixteen. A couple from our church adopted the baby. They moved to New Zealand to support a Maori Mission. So that's where my daughter is."

"How come you never told me this?"

"I was a pretty wild teenager, promiscuous, drugs, the whole bit. Getting pregnant changed me. I decided to clean up my act so I could have a healthy baby. When I met you a few years later I didn't want to tell you about my "sordid past", I thought you would leave me if you knew.

"I suppose you're right, we were still quite young when we first met, I'm not sure how I would have reacted. But you could have told me later, after we were married."

"I guess I thought it was easier to just try to pretend it never happened. But then a couple years ago my daughter tracked me down somehow, and we've been in touch on Facebook ever since. And now she really needs my help because she's...
11433212.title: Why She Really Chose New Zealand

114332121.content:
suffering from Malaria.

Four days with a temperature of 104 degrees plus. Ice packed and alcohol bathed! Thank God N. Zed is a country of sailors very familiar with the many and varied degrees that one can contact the four major types of malaria. And, how each can be treated.

Her temperature has dropped and the sisters have assured me that the possibility of brain damage is miniscule.
The pill regimen is large but because Papua New Guinea is almost touching Australia, a first world country, and it having knowledge of this particular disease, I trust that my daughter's health is in good hands.

Our plane leaves in two hours. My wife is flying with me. I love her. Do I love my new daughter?
114332121.title: In a Hospital in Auckland

1143321211.content:
It was at the candy machine in the hospital hallway the name for our son came to me

I had been staring off into space, fatigued after holding my wife's hand for fifteen hours while
she was laboring to birth our new son. Thank God she did the hard part! I couldn't have.

Standing there experiencing a daydream about our daughter Robyn's malaria she had contracted when but a baby and how well she had been treated by her Australian doctor at the hospital in New Zealand, a light clicked on inside my befuddled mind.

It seemed to make perfect sense but how would it go over with, not just my wife but everyone else? The World?

My name is Robbin. Coincidentally (or not), I married a Kiwi in Australia named Robin. Since there were already two Robbins, it felt right to name our daughter Robyn. People thought this a novelty. What would people think when they came across a family where everyone's name was Robbin?

My wife agreed and we named our son, Robben.

The name of our sailboat is Robin's Nest.

The family that crewed their boat named, "Robin's nest," have the same first name but spelled differently.

Their spellings are; Robbin, the father, Robin, the mother, Robyn, the daughter and Robben, the son.

Can you imagine the ramifications, even confusion this has caused enduring the myriad of daily encounters with the public that we may take for granted but do make up the fabric of our lives?

How would you respond to a phone call on your land line when the caller asked," Is Robbin there"?
1143321211.title: Her name is Robyn.  His name is Robben.

114332122.content:
Homeless.

" Oh honey, I wish you would have told me. What do you want to do?"

"I'm not sure yet, but I love you more than you can imagine, just for you being you.
I sent her money and with it, my recommendation that she get off the street and that I
would be coming to help in any way that I could."

"Are you ready for a trip to New Zealand?" "To meet our daughter?" Try and stop me
Robbin!" "It is a long flight but I am loving you more for your understanding and trust in me
that I was as ignorant to this addition to our family as you." You use the word "our". like she is ours."

Not anyone I've ever met, male or female, could adjust to leaving the U.S. to find, introduce and
acquaint themselves with a total stranger. The stranger happened to be my daughter and will become a person with
a mother and a father. This American mother accepting her husband's daughter, unconditionally as her daughter, by the law of liberty
in love.

Some people call this new kind of family, the Iroquois kinship system. Other people call it Calabash. The Hawaiian kinship system.

My wife and I, with our daughter call it, Another dull day in paradise. What do you call it?
114332122.title: Homeless

115.content:
The day our family got our first television set remains in my memory as one of the highlights of my childhood. It was 1953 and I was in the third grade. I had watched television at my aunt's house a few times when we visited her over the summer. Of course, we had to watch what she and my uncle wanted to watch.

My best friend's family had a television and they would invite us over to watch sometimes. The adults would sit on the couch and us kids would sit on the floor. We watched whatever they chose to watch. We were just glad to be able to see a television. Usually one night a week is all Dad would allow. The whole family went together; my mom, my dad, my little brother, and me.

But now we were to have our own television set. We could watch what we wanted to watch. As Dad and a neighbor carried the big box into the house, I was so excited I jumped up and down. I knew this would change my life. Now I could talk to the other kids at school about what we watched on TV. That would be geat.

Television opened up an entire new world to me. I would rush home from school to watch "The Howdy Doody Show" and then "Ozzie and Harriet." Saturday mornings there were back-to-back cartoons. I was in heaven. I grew up with Annette and Spin and Marty on the Mickey Mouse Club and learned to dance with all the kids on Dance Party. Yes, television certainly enhanced my life. Then color television came along...a miracle.
115.title: The Television

1151.content:
"I can't believe you still hold a grudge against me for that. It's been years."

"It's not a grudge, it's hurt. I was hurt."

"But it was a joke! Just a joke! You're a spoilsport."

"Yeah, yeah, all very well for you to say. You weren't the one that had to walk out of an expensive restaurant because your so-called best friend had offered to treat you and then didn't show. It was so embarrassing, I had to count coins to figure if I had enough to eat anything in that place. I didn't, of course. And I had told you when you phoned that I knew you were April Fooling me. You wasted an hour of my time phoning again and again pestering me to please turn up, it was real. You know, they even held the table for us, didn't give it to other customers. I can't believe you'd do that to a restaurant, book a table and then ditch them. I don't call that a joke, I call it a mean trick."

"Look, don't get all heated up. That was years ago."

"And you're about to do it again. Well, this time, I'm not falling for it."

"Please, please. It's the only day I'm in town. I promise it's real this time. Would I do something like that to you?"

"You would, that's just the point. You already have."

"But that was way back in college! Look, I'd drop in at your house, but I have this meeting here and you know the traffic. Please, please. I'll make it up to you. This is really a fancy-schmancy joint. Bet you haven't even seen it yet."

"I haven't. It's way beyond my means. And I'm not stepping in there on your invitation, least of all on April Fools' Day."

"Look, please, please. Check with the hotel, okay? I'm booked in for tonight. I'm staying here till I catch the early morning flight tomorrow. They'll give you my room number and everything, and tell you I've really booked a table in their fancy restaurant."

"Why am I getting a sense of deja-vu? Thanks, but no thanks."

*Slams the phone and ignores it when it rings again.*
1151.title: April Fool's Day

choices: We both couldn't stop laughing for
She slapped me,saying," How could you
11511.content:
I called the hotel and they confirmed that my dear old college friend really had a room and had booked a table for two. I decided to go for it, regardless that today's date was April 1ST and my memories of her ill treatment of me on the Fool's day many years ago, I placed into the Sea of Forgetfulness.

It took but an hour and a half for those old college memories to return to the surface into the Sea of Remembrance.

I sipped (nurtured) one glass of house white.wine waiting and waiting for my friend to show. Having looked at the menu I caught myself falling into the past. I was counting the coins I had in my purse to see if I could afford anything on the menu in case my college girl friend had gotten into an accident or something bad had happened that could cause this very uncomfortable delay.

Deja vue. She got me again. I was counting coins and whatever paper I had wandering about in my purse to see if I might purchase another glass of an extremely unrememberable Zinfandel when a very handsome but serious man approached my table of one and asked if he could join me for a moment.

My thought was how well she has thought this years April Fools Joke out, so I humored this actor
saying, "Be my guest."

I was only half listening when he announced who he was and what he did for a living. I was looking everywhere around the room within my vision for my friend, knowing she was watching me from some obscure hiding place to witness my reactions to her machinations.

I was pulled from my seach by the words, "died an hour ago when the car she was a passenger in was hit head on by a drunken..." "What are yy-o-o-uu ssa---" I didn't quite get out as I slipped into unconsciousness!

I woke up in a hospital. I had been driven there in an ambulance as the shock of hearing of my friends death, the very friend I was to have dinner with at her posh hotel's restaurant, my brain starved of oxygen when the detective crudely informed me of her demise, I passed out.

Her tears were real as she apologized, begging for forgiveness, holding my head off the pillows with both of her hands behind my head laced together. In the midst of her groveling to save our friendship, her promising to never do anything like this again, she having witnessed everything she had put me through. I. with perfect timing, tone, eye contact, intensity and a half smile, said, "April Fools."
11511.title: Count Coins

11512.content:
Who does that guy think he is anyhow that I should just drop everything and come running at his beck and call? Well thanks, but no thanks! I pick up the phone but slam it down without answering it. He must think Im still that starry eyed freshman ... The phone rings again but at the same time there is a knock at the door. Great, one quiet evening at home without drama, is that too much to ask? I guess it is.

"OK, OK.. I’m coming." I looked through the peep hole in the door to see the guy that sits in the cubical opposite to mine at the office. He's not a bad guy, not the best looking man I've ever met but a great sense of humor and isn’t afraid to pick up the check at lunch time. I opened the door and he walked right in. "What?" was all I could muster as I just let myself fall into my worn in spot on the couch.

"You forgot didn’t you, I knew you would". He pauses still staring at me before saying "aren’t you going to answer the phone"?

"No” He just continued to point at the phone. "OK, look... just pick it up..." he picked it up, "... now put it down" he put it down “now, unplug it" he unplugs it.”Great job, now what is it that I forgot?

"The mandatory staff party on the company yacht this evening at 8:00... Its 7:30." My new best friend taps on his watch repeatedly while starring at me under his raised eyebrows. This guy must be bucking for supervisor, I thought to myself.
“Great”.
“You still have time, just go throw something on. No one will notice if we are a few minutes late”.
It was important that I didn’t miss this opportunity. There would be a lot of big names at that party and my career could use all the help it could get at this point. “Yeah, Yeah, thanks, give me five minutes”.
11512.title: Thanks, But No Thanks

11513.content:
"Hey, Mike," said Roger, "remember that roommate we had back in college who always wore a football helmet around the house?"

"Yeah." I nodded. "Bono. He drank so much he didn't wanna bang his head if he fell."

"Bono?" asked Melinda, "you guys were roommates with Bono??"

"No, no," we answered simultaneously.

"Not the U-2 guy" I went on, "we just called him Bono. I don't even remember his real name now."

"Jeremy, I think," said Roger. "Or Gerard."

After a couple of seconds' silence, Roger seemed to remember he'd brought up Bono in the first place. "Ran into him yesterday. Man, he's gotten heavy. If he's not three hundred pounds, he's darn close."

I nodded. Twenty years of beer will tend to pack on the pounds. "What's he doing now??"

"He's a janitor. Couple kids in high school. His teeth look like they're about to rot out of his head." Roger shook his head. "Must not have been to a dentist, like, ever.

"Did he finish college?" said Melinda.

"Nah," I told her. "Dropped out after a couple terms. He kept on living with us though, for another six months."

Roger stood up. "Who wants another beer??"
11513.title: The Roommate

1153.content:
It was the year of 1960. It was the year that me and my classmates had been waiting, the big event of the month of July of 1960, The Seniors Prom. Girls all over the school had been seen hanging around in small " packs " waiting to be invited to go to the prom. They all we're waiting to be invited by the more handsome students, the football players. Not the person i was. Although being 6.6 feet of height, it made me a gentle giant, not an athlete, so I would stay late in the library working on reports, studying and even reading for pure pleasure. Not what you would call a lady's man. But I wasn't the only one. My best friend, Frederic, or Fred for short, was always there with me. He was the comedy guy, the class-clown, and, nominated the funniest guy in school three times in three straight years. He wanted to become a T.V. Star, and have is own show. He was the best to talk too. But also, a girl from my year who also used to hang out in the library after school. She didn't talk much, she looked shy and further more, bullied by the cheerleaders. One night, I got feed up, so i made a plan that didn't involved violence to help her. One night, when she was being picked on again, my plan went into effect. I knocked over a book from a top shelve from the other side of it and quickly made my way down the ladder to continue my plan. When one of the cheerleaders when t check on who has dropped the book, nobody was there. Then it happened. Two snakes came out of the bottom of the shelves heading towards the cheerleaders. They ran off the library screaming that it was snake infested. But it turned out to be me and Fred pulling the so called snakes ,made of wood with gaps to slitter across the floor, with nylon strings at the end. The girl came to us and thanked us, to which Fred pointed that i was the true hero, he was simply the sidekick. her name was Rosanne, and in that moment i asked her to go to the prom with me. She accepted, blushing like the fading sun of a summer evening.
The day of the prom came, and i picked her up at her place. She lived on the same street that the school was, so we came on foot, but that didn't matter. She was gorgeous like a rose that had just bloomed. It was a magical night. Even Fred had gotten a date for the prom. She also dreamed to be a T.V star, just like Fred, and also was the first who found Fred's Charming side. It was the best night ever for the two couples, and it seemed that it would go on forever and ever.
1153.title: The Prom

I desperately wanted to get out of my home with it's jail-like atmosphere. My reproductive units (Mutha and Fadar) were the wardens who tried to keep me under lock and key. Like siamese twins conjoined at the head (sharing the same brain), they were magicians with batons. "SWISH" went the batons and my computer and cell phone vanished. Another "SWISH" and there went my car. The only way to escape their Alcatraz was to get pregnant and guilt Fred into marrying me. Then Fred would mortgage his life to buy me my own home! 11533.content:
I had two wedding days, but the one that sticks out for me is my first one. the guy I married was, and still is, mentally ill. He is paranoid schizophrenic. I knew that BEFORE the wedding , but still married him anyway. He wanted to keep his illness a secret from everyone, but my best friend had his number. She was the one who schooled me in mental illness. Just like he asked, I didn't tell my family. I met his family, which consisted of his mother, who nwas also ill, his younger siblings, and his nephew.

         Looking back on that wedding, April 4, 1992, my nerves weere on edge, I couldn't eat, and my mother took over everything. My parents did put money toward the wedding, but she crossed very clear boundaries. My ex-husband didn't have a car, and I don't drive. It was pretty disheartening to ride in the car as a newly married couple with the bride's parents. My ex had a strange look on his face. This was a first marriage for me; it was his second. At his insistence, we married in a non denominational church. I was born and raised Catholic. He was Methodist. It seemed the only thing that I made a decision on was my outfit.

         The reception was held at a nearby hotel. My best friend was my matron of honor. She also sang at the ceremony. Everything regarding the reception was almost cancelled due to my mother's controlling behavior. I did have the absolute best DJ in our area. We nate, danced, laughed, and had a great time. We were staying at the hotel. Due to a trivia game that was played earlier nin the week, we stayed for the weekend. My parents stayed until Monday because they had to take us to get important documents made. So that was our honeymoon.

          The morning after the wedding, my ex asked me if I wanted to stay married. I was shocked at the question. I asked him if he was sorry he married me. He didn't answer. We had a separation for seventeen months. By this time we had a car. It was used. The reason for the separation was due to the fact that he abused me physically. After we got back together, there were almost daily fighting. During one of these, I asked him why he didn't speak up when the minister saide "Does anyone have just cause why these two should not marry. His reply was that he didn't want to hurt me.

         We were married for five years. We didn't have any children. I have seen nor heard from him in fifteen years. I remarried twelve years and have one son. There have been problems, and I wanted to get a divorce but will stay married until my son turns eighteen. I am better off single.
11533.title: The Wedding Day

12.content:
The flag in the middle of the sixth hole
flutters in the wind, and
the one-story houses surrounding
the golf course sprawl like bush dwellers
wearing green skirts. A footloose golfer
gone wild moves with fluid
contortionist movements, deep squats,
lunges, hinging limbs, and fiercely rotating joints.
as if dancing to sixties rock, moaning
bluesy vocals. A second one runs after
a wayward golf ball jumping over barriers
My neighbor to the right walks
her Labrador Retriever, the dog in need
of attention from the Dog Whisperer.
My neighbor to the left barbecues something;
the scent of beef sizzling
crashes into my nostrils, as I watch
from my bedroom window,
and I recall another place, another window,
from which I saw you leave
like a shadow, trudging through
an ice-crusted layer of snow
without an apology.
12.title: From my Bedroom Window

121.content:
Since then I’ve been wondering why you left.
Part of that is simply ego, I know,
who can even think about leaving someone like me?
But part of it, the biggest part, is pain
confusion, a scrambling after reasons
that even though they might not make much sense
at least provide something to steady myself with.
My life these days is a rolling deck on a stormtossed sea.
Out my window now I see a ship
moving slowly across the bay
I hear children laughing somewhere below me
but their sweet sounds are drowned out
by the forlorn, incongruent sound
of foghorns.
That, and not the laughter
is the current sound of my soul.
121.title: foghorns

12113.content:
As Steve Miller once said, "Time keeps on ticking into the future." Insightful words to ponder, since none of us are getting any younger. Mick Jagger said in song "Time is on my side," but truly time is NOT on our side. None of us will live forever.

Time marches on... Boys and girls become young women and men, promising eternal devotion in their passion. Cyndi Lauper said, "If you're lost you can look and you will find me, time after time. If you fall I will catch you I'll be waiting, time after time." A nice ideal, but one that doesn't hold true for the 49% of marriages that end in divorce. Friends become lovers, then fathers and mothers, and passions can fade over time...

Time sneaks up on you. One morning you take a good hard look in the mirror and realize you're no longer young. You're older, "Shorter of breath and one day closer to death." as Roger Waters put it. So you may as well try your best to enjoy each remaining day, until the final picture fades and darkness turns to grey.
