She releases herself from the straps and chains her chanting of her spell was too strong for the men to fight.
She uses the heavy chain that they had bound her with to hit one of the men in the head, knocking him down with blood oozing from the corner of his eye. she uses it again on the other two men and she sees near her a large board she picks it up and hits the men with it and then she takes off running out of the room. She don't know where she is she just knows she was being held in a large house somewhere. She rushes to find the front door and when she does...
123312.title: she escapes

choices: I am you in a few minutes
12332.content:
Stretched out on the long, leather chair, Devon watched as the doctor sitting away from him began to jot down something on the paper in front of him. Little did he know, it wasn’t hard for Devon to find out what it was that he was writing. Devon was…different in a way that gave him the abilities and powers that normal humans don’t have and with this new body, he was sure he wouldn’t have trouble attracting food. He watched the mans expression as he finished the sentence, reading off his thoughts, waiting for the moment.. to Waiting for this game to come to an end. The tag on the doctors shirt read, Terrance but his face read fear and that is what Devon enjoyed the most.

“It started about two weeks ago, the voices I mean, not the killing.” Devon began, still concentrated on the mans thoughts, “It comes and goes, telling me to do things that I know are bad but I’m forced to do them anyway. I turn into this monster. I’ve killed innocent people, slaughtered the ones that got in the way and united the ones that I call my best.”

“Are these voices telling you to kill these people, Devon?”

“I see there faces replay in my mind sometimes, the horrified expression of their eyes as I ram my deformed hand through there skull and take what I must have. It clams me, reassuring that it will all end soon. But how soon?”

“Devon, I’m not here to judge you, I’m here to help. These voices, are they telling you to kill these people?” He sat up straight in the chair, eyes fixed on Devon, not wanting to hear the answer but in need of it. He reached toward his back, where he kept his cell phone. In the position that Devon was in, he wouldn’t see him calling the front desk and having the sheriff paged in. If his life was in danger, he wanted the backup. He flipped the phone open and slowly dialed, muffling out the sound of the tones.

“You people are all the same.” Devon sighed as he got up from the chair. He turned toward Terrance and smiled. His eyes shot back with an unnatural color.

“Devon?”

“You see, I’ve been following you around for some time now and the more you talk, the more you seem to piss me off. ” Devon stood like a mad man, the skin of the body he took over turned pale and clammy. His eyes glowed with the desire to kill, he stared.

The phone flew out of Terrance’s hand, slamming against the brick of the wall with the force to break it into tiny pieces. He could hear the locks on the doors turn tight. The glass inside the windows crack and spring tiny vibrations. Terrance jumped up from the chair in fear.

“What are you?” his voice trembled as he looked for a way out.

“I am you in a few minutes.” he snarled and slowly approached, taking in the sweet sensation of a job well done.
12332.title: Straps Tighten

123321.content:
Eric closed his eyes and visualized himself on stage playing guitar with the band in front of the full arena. "I am you in a few minutes," he thought. Just then, there was a knock at his dressing room door. He had been 'relaxing' for the past twenty minutes, so the room was kind of messy. He shouted, "Be there in a minute."

"You better be, you creep," a female voice yelled back. It was Paz the drummer. This was their first world tour, and she didn't want Eric to be too out of it to play Madison Square Garden that night. He washed his face quickly before opening the door for Paz.

Paz came in and gave Eric a huge hug. "Oh sweetie, I can't believe we're playing HERE! tonight. We've dreamt of this night for a decade. Play that solo, man. Play it loud."

Eric shook his head. He couldn't stop thinking about what Juan said.
123321.title: I am you in a few minutes

choices: What are you going to do about it?
123322.content:
"It's a job well done," he said, shrugging his shoulders. He had a certain indifference about him as he turned his back dismissively.
"And?" Jake asked, impatience knitting his brow. "Do you want me back tomorrow? He started to feel the pent up frustration between his shoulders, that were already hurting form the days labour. His normally olive skin had darkened to a deep honey colour and it glistened with sweat. "Look ... I need a job, but if you can't give me a straight answer, I'll have to look elsewhere."
Jake watched as the man he called 'boss' turned to face him, a self-satisfied smirk lighting his features.
"Is that some sort of ultimatum?" Beads of perspiration laced the smaller man's upper lip, and his sandy comb over was no protection for a poorly disguised bald spot. He became pensive, clasping his stubbled chin. His eyes were watery-blue chips of ice - lacking all compassion. "I'm the only one that gives ultimatums around here, and for the record, an ex-con doesn't have that many options." He loosened the tie at his throat, revealing pasty flesh, flecked with struggling hairs. "Turn up tomorrow and we'll see what we can do." He chuckled, collecting his clipboard from the makeshift ledge of bricks the colour of gun-metal. "You're not going anywhere ... are you?"
Jake felt it in every inch of his being. That old friend residing beneath his skin, squeezing his heart with a cruel fist; inducing him to violence. He wanted to grab the pompous weasel in front of him by the neck; damage him - the urge so strong that his blunt nails broke the rough skin of his palms. His gums ached - that always happened when he clenched his teeth too hard.
He stared at a broken brick perched precariously on the heap - he could feel its rough texture in his hand - it felt good. The possibility soothed him. "No, I'm not going anywhere."
123322.title: A job well done

choices: Snow falls gently on the man's cheek
as the life slowly drains out of him.
1233222.content:
It was a cold winter morning, the kind that leaves the busiest man wondering why he should even get up in the morning, as the cold deters anyone from getting anything important done. As a man got up, slapping his alarm clock to make it end that unbearable noise it always makes, he looks outside the window. What a dreary day. Getting up, he quickly stripped down and brushed himself off before excusing himself to the bathroom to take a quick shower and brush his teeth. Exiting, he goes over to his dresser and puts on his usual suit and slacks. Oh what a dreary day.
         Leaving his house, now complete with jacket and umbrella, snow falls down rather rapidly and hard. Kids are heard in the distance, playing and frolicking as kids do, and the man turns around to shut the door. Fumbling with his keys, he finally manages to find the right one. He then begins his walk to work, he still can't bring himself to use that car, it holds too many good memories, and too many bad surface at its touch as well. His boots crunching on the snow as he goes.
         About ten minutes or so later, the man comes upon a concerned old woman. She looks him up and down and shakes her head. "Why do you walk when you own a car? Why do you insist on living in such a broken down apartment when you could move into the building he lived in, the one you walk to every day to care for?" His reply is a simple sigh and shrug. He then forces a smile and continues walking down his way, the woman staring at him until the snow completely masks his distant form.
         Arriving upon the now rusted gates, he withdraws another key, flashy and fancy. At one time, the gates may have been just as nice, but alas, that is not so much the case anymore. Time takes a toll on everything - as the man knows more than anyone. Before he pushes it open, a man comes up. "Listen, you're always going up here to take care of the place, but why not sell it and buy a better place for yourself instead of stretching out your inheritance from him? Maybe a job could ease your mind." The man looks at the concerned stranger, but just shakes his head no. He couldn't bear to see it fall into anyone else's hands, be tainted by their presence. He moves on.
         Walking up the long path to the abandoned mansion, a few dog houses, barely visible due to the snow, lay in a neat little row. Names are ettched into them, but time as also effected them, and they're impossible to make out unless one is close up. The man remembers how each day his friend would release these dogs, be it onto an anarchist, a girl scout, and once or twice, the man himself. He sighs, remembering such things pains his heart.
         Before he opens the door to the house, a sole tear runs down his cheek. As the door opens with a foowsh, a grand painting of his friend is seen. The man smiles again, and whispers the word "Sir", before collapsing into a heap.
1233222.title: Release the hounds!

124.content:
A half written letter
It doesn't begin or end
So I don't know why you
said what you did
There, in the middle.

I don't know if you started
out angry and
wrote till you were calm or
was it the other way around?
I have only the middle
of a letter
you only half wrote.

I read it again
I assume it is addressed
to me
but how
can I be sure?
If you meant it for someone else
I shouldn't be reading
it at all.

But I've read it
My eyes have seen
My soul has heard
I think.
But I'll never know
I'll never know for whom
or why
because I have only the middle
of a letter you half-wrote.
124.title: a half-written letter

1241.content: So, why did I pick this useless thing up in the first place? I mean, it doesn't begin or end. It just makes my mind wander madly in search of the reason I ended up with this non-sensical letter in my hand to begin with. How dare you leave it out on the desk like that. You know how I am. You know I can't leave something like that un-read. Not when it's scratchy script is fully visible, belly up on that desk of yours and with you acting all suspicious as of late. You had to of wanted me to find it. You wrote it for me, didn't you? You wanted me to be confused - to ask you what it meant. You hoped that when you got home from your little jaunt I'd be standing in the doorway with "that" look on my face and you'd get to say, "What?" all innocent like when all the while you would know exactly what. You've done it before, but this time - this letter has stirred up a hornet's nest in my mind and the stinging little bits refuse to settle. I sure hope you wrote this for me because if you didn't you're going to have some explaining to do. Wait - you're coming up the driveway! Do I really want to get into it today? What if I just ignore it and act like nothing's going on, like I didn't read that letter? You'd know I read it. You'd know I got all worked up while you were gone, was bursting to find out the truth behind those words and... I can't ignore that little bit of letter you left out for me. It has to be for me. You love me. You married me. Shouldn't I relax a little and let you do what you do without butting in? But is that bit of text scrawled on that piece of paper a cry for help? You wanted to be found out?
1241.title: It doesn't begin or end

12411.content:
"Oh no," I groaned as the first droplets spattered my shirt. "It would decide to rain on the day I walk home." After a few minutes, the drizzle turned into a downpour and I was left running through the rain, completely soaked. "At least I'm not wearing white," I mumbled. I could barely see through the relentless drops. As I turned a corner, I bashed into someone coming the other way. "Oh, sorry!" I yelled over the sounds of pounding rain and rumbling thunder.
"That's ok!" a man's voice shouted back, "Are you alright?"
"I'm fine! Thanks! Are you?"
"Fine! Well, nice meeting you!" he laughed.
"You too!" I laughed too. This was ridiculous. As I turned to continue on my way, the man shouted after me, "Hey, I never got your name!"
"Anna!"
"Carl! Hey, Anna, why don't we duck into this coffee shop and wait out the rain together?"
I hesitated. He was a complete stranger. I hadn't even been able to really see his face. Oh, what the heck?
"That's fine with me!" We rushed down to the coffee shop door where he held it open as I ducked inside. Oh, it was warm and smelled deliciously of coffee and pastry.
"Do you have any towels for two soaked travelers?" Carl hollered to the bored-looking barista.
"Sure," the kid grunted and tossed a few small bar towels to us. After we had dried off a little, Carl and I ordered drinks and seated ourselves in a cozy nook near the fire. Through the window we could see the water still beating the sidewalk with a passion. I sipped my steaming coffee contentedly as I studied Carl. "What a strange way to meet a man," I thought. He was tall, a little chubby and baby-faced, but still pretty cute. He had thick, wavy blond hair and deep, blue eyes. No movie star material, but not too bad for a stranger on the street.
"So," he began, "Other than your name and your tendency to bump into strangers while walking, I don't know much about you. Let's start with the basics. Where did you grow up?"
I laughed and began to tell him about myself. As we talked, I felt myself warming up to this charming stranger. He was witty and funny and, I soon found out, loved children and was very kind. He was a pediatrician at the local hospital and lived alone with his Siamese cat in a little apartment downtown. Before I realized how much time had passed, Carl looked out the window and announced that the rain had stopped.
"Well, my lady, may I escort you home now that the sun has been allowed to shine once again?"
"I would love that."
A few minutes later, we reached my apartment and stood in front of it rather awkwardly. I waited for him to say something.
"Well, Anna, this has truly been a delightful, albeit wet, afternoon. We should do it again sometime. Perhaps excluding the part where we get soaked," he grinned.
"I agree," I giggled and handed him my number.
"And that's my cue to leave you, my lady. It's been a pleasure." He bowed and danced away whistling "I'm Singing in the Rain".
I sighed and wondered if I'd ever have such a lovely rainy day again.
12411.title: Rain

124111.content:
My next rainy day was ominous. I set out for my father's cabin in the mountains after work on Friday. My old Ford needed a tune-up, but I was confident I could make the 250 mile trip safely. I needed solitude in order to write an article on Mediteranean cuisine that I had over-optimistically promised would be completed by the beginning of the next week. My father's cabin met my needs. High up in the Appalachians in West Virginia, remote and without cell phone coverage, peace and quiet. My first mistake.

Three miles from the cabin the deluge descended, a horrifying storm, wind howling, blinding rain. Suddenly a car came around a corner and I panicked. Mistake number two. My old Ford slid off the road and lodged against a tree. Miraculously unhurt, I scrambled out of the car and squinted through the torrent. The other car was gone. My car was mired, and I knew there was no hope of regaining the road.

In this remote area I despaired of another car coming. I decided to trudge on to the cabin. Mistake number three. My clothes were soaked within the first hundred yards. My luggage weighed me down, and then the rain turned to sleet and snow. For the first time in my life I feared I might die in this wilderness. Push on, don't give up. Keep going I exhorted my exhausted body. Twice I fell, and the second time I dropped my suitcase. Clinging to my laptop in its waterproof bag, I saw the cabin up ahead. I cried out in relief.

Then I saw the motorcycles outside the cabin.
124111.title: Mistakes

1241111.content:
Bill Jenkins looked out the window. "Christ!', he said. It's snowing all over our bikes." The other three men jumped from the table and joined him.

"Better get them in the barn," Hal said. They rushed for their coats and hurried out the door. Brushing off the wet snow, they dragged their motorcycles to the old barn. Inside they dried off the machines.

"Shit, now we're stuck up here," Ed complained. "We might be here for a week."

As they trudged through the thickening snow, Bill stopped. "Did you here that? I think someone is out there. I heard someone call out."

"No one knew we were going to be here," Bob McGee said with the same apprehension they all felt.

"Let's split up and see if there's more than one of them," Bill ordered. The men took out their guns and separated trying to outflank the intruders.

"Help. Help me please," came the cry.

Bill thought the voice was familiar. "Janine! Is that you?"

"Bill? I'm freezing and I can't move."

Bill hollered, "It's ok guys. It's my sister, and she needs help."

The men all put their guns away and rushed to the frozen young woman. Bill picked her up and carried her into the cabin. She hugged him, and said feebly, "I thought I would die out there." She looked warily at the others. "Who are these men, and what are you doing here, Bill?"

Hal had retrieved the carrying bag with Janine's laptop. He opened it, noting it appeared to be dry. He looked at the other men. If Janine had Internet access, they had a problem. Arnie needed at least a day before he could finish his part of the project. They needed to be isolated until then. They all looked at Bill as he covered the sleeping Janine with a blanket.

What are we going to do with her was the unspoken question.
1241111.title: Motorcyclists

12411112.content:
The snow is so beautiful between December and February, most years. There have been a couple years lately that have been very disappointing.

One year it was so cold the snow didn’t fall very often and the accumulation was very sparse. That winter I felt cheated and it was hard to believe winter had been there.

Another year the snow comes and then the snow melts before the next snow storm. That winter left me with a strange feeling.

I enjoyed this past winter because the snow came and it stayed, and we had several snow storms. It was just right.
12411112.title: The snow melts

1241112.content:
There I stood, deciding whether to search out my candy thief or to let him go. Living in an orphanage was like a free for all and. I knew that, at least I thought so. That's why I had hidden the candy in the back of my dressing closet, away from hungry hands. How anyone found it, puzzled me.

After mulling the idea that whoever stole my candy needed it more than me and ridiculing the idea in my head, I headed out in search for the culprit. Today I was feeling territorial. I had a few suspects in mind. First i excluded all the girls, because my closet was in the boys' bathroom and girls were strictly chastised for entering. Then I excluded all the boys I had some kind of friendship with. That left no more than 4 boys. All these fell under the 'naughty' category. I excluded one from the group under the fact that if he was the culprit, I couldn't do anything about it because he was twice as big as me. This meaning he could easily beat me to a pulp. That left 3 boys and I decided to play a little game of trap the mouse.

When our caretakers shouted it was time to turn in for the night and we all went to change into our pajamas, I made an exuberant motion of stashing something behind my clothes. I made sure to be the last out of the bathroom, watching the 3 suspects closely. They all saw my act but pretended they didnt. I caught on quickly.

As soon as lights went off in the orphanage I sneaked out into the bathroom and hid in a closet adjacent to mine. There was a perfect peephole and I waited patiently. No more than 5 minutes passed before my candy thief opened my closet and dug behind my clothes. Arte finding nothing I looked around the room and left with a curse. I saw his face clearly. My mission accomplished I headed to bed.

The next day I confronted the boy and demanded he tell me I did it. The more he refused, the angrier I got. Why would he steal my candy from my dresser? Did he not know that candy was a piece of happiness in a place like an orphanage? Finally my anger boiled and we entangled into a fistfight. I punched and I cried and I yelled all my frustration at this boy, blaming him for the place I was caged in. It took 3 caretakers to separate us and by then I was throwing a tantrum.

In the end, only I got punished and was sent to my room for the rest of the day. I spent it crying at the unfairness of it all. The orphanage took me away from my family, took me away from living a free life. They took my wings and clipped them, and as if that wasn't enough, they built a caged and trapped me in there. A parakeet in a cage full of eagles. The orphanage was supposed to be a doorway into a better world and I had waited 3 years to enter it. I was beginning to lose hope. All I wanted in life was to matter.

It was almost bedtime and I had refused to eat dinner, punishing myself for something that really wasn't my fault, when one of the caretakers entered my room.

"I have good news," she said. I replied, "Go away." But she stared at me with a perplexed expression and informed me I was adopted before she left. I was left alone to piece myself together until the new finally sunk.

I was adopted. I was going to get out of this prison. No more candy thiefs, no more cages, and no more eagles.

It was good news indeed.
1241112.title: Good news

124112.content:
I love chocolate. There are those that don’t like it, but I don’t know of anyone. I buy enough chocolate to give myself and my husband the amount we crave. Its smooth creamy feeling in my mouth is like no other feeling and taste I have experienced.

I like to get a box of Whitman or some other chocolates with centers of different textures and flavors. My favorite has been discontinued. They are the jelly fillings. They were so good.

When I was a teen I enjoyed Brach’s bridge mix. I used to be able to eat mint patties but the mint makes my heart race since I am older. Reece’s peanut butter cups are nice. They are very rich, and they satisfy the taste quickly.

Chocolate milk and hot chocolate are the greatest drinks around. I also love chocolate in my coffee. Only one thing about chocolate I don’t like, and that is it keeps me awake at night if I eat it very late in the evening.
124112.title: Chocolate

12412.content:
Shivering with this seeping cold
I watch the daylight fade
Feeling the sunshine slip away
Seeing this world God made
Alive with sombre sadness
I know all lives will end
Staring out across the ocean
I think of the world I tend
My quiet house with the apple tree
In a world inside my head
Where the skies are always bright
And no loved ones are dead
Sitting in this hollow
Nestled somewhere deep inside
I watch the daylight fade away
Taken by Night's black tide.
12412.title: Sunshine

124121.content:
So this, my children, is the end of your story’s beginning. The passing of my mother into the darkness of oblivion coincides with the passing of my brother and I through the darkness of night, into our new lives, and, consequently, passing our father into the echoing madness that had been hovering at the edge of his broken mind for years like ravenous wolves remaining just out of the firelight. Then the careless traveler allowed the protecting heat and flame to dwindle to dead ashes and smoldering embers, no more comforting than the hollow howl haunting his limping footsteps.
         Note, children that I said this was only the end of the beginning, as each and every generation is the beginning of another, and their end heralds that beginning and the passing on of tradition from ancestor to descendant. We must continue on and delve far deeper into the fresh memories of the past to uncover what the future may hold for you all.
         Dearest children, listen well and remember the words that are your Legacy, for it is both yours and mine to bear for all of eternity.
124121.title: Echoes of madness

1241211.content:
You're awful quiet tonight, Calvin. What's the matter, you miss your mama?

That not it, Lester. I guess I just ain't used to the killing... I though being a Ranger would be like being a policeman in the old days, where you'd arrest the bad guys and put them in jail, then they'd get a trial and be sentenced for their crimes.

Yeah,that kinda bothered me when I first joined up too, Cal. You just gotta get used to it. The three men we hanged were dangerous! They damned well deserved what they got! They killed a law abiding man and his wife, then kidnapped the ten year old daughter and raped her. Lucky we caught them before they killed her too!

Still, I'd feel better if we gave 'em some kinda trial, Les. The youngest guy was only seventeen, said he didn't have nothing to do with killing them folks, and he didn't rape the girl, neither!

These are dangerous times we live in, Cal. We don't have policemen or jails anymore, you know that. It's our responsibility to be judge, jury, and executioner, you read the instructions when you took the Ranger Oath. That kid may have been telling the truth, or he may have been lying. Maybe he didn't kill them folks or rape the girl, but either way he didn't do anything to try to stop it, neither! So he's guilty by association, for being part of the gang that did it. As Rangers it's our job to get rid of dirt bags like that, it's for the good of society. End of story.

Yeah, I guess you're right, Lester... Coyotes sure are howling pretty loud tonight, think I'll put some more wood on the fire, make sure they don't get too close.

You know, I think those might be wolves, Cal. Hear those howls? They're a lot deeper than coyotes...

You may be right Les. I heard wolves been making a comeback, ever since the plague. And judging by what I've seen recently I do believe it is true...
1241211.title: Wolves and Firelight

12412111.content:
We been riding since just after sunup Les, waddya say we make camp here for the night?

"I thought you'd want to press on more, Cal. You're the one who wanted us to patrol this stretch of road so we could stop by and see how your folks are doing."

"That's true, I was concerned when I left, my dad was feeling poorly. But we are still a good two days out, anyway you look at it. No sense in pushing the horses any harder than we have to."

"OK by me Cal, this place is as good as any. Looks like there's a branch down the bottom of the hill, why don't you take the canteens and go get us some water while I set up camp..."

Cal is down at the creek filling the canteens when he hears a gunshot, then a voice calls out, "Don't move, Ranger!"

He looks around, realizes the gunman has Lester pinned down.

"How does it feel Ranger, knowing someone is gonna kill you in cold blood just like you did my boy!"

"Mister, I don't know who you are, but the only men I killed were in the line of duty!"

Cal gets an idea of where the gunman is by his voice, decides to see if he can quietly circle around. He ends up on a small hill, looking through laurel bushes down at the gunman.

"Say your prayers, Ranger, it's time for you to die!" the gunman calls out as he takes aim at Lester...
12412111.title: Keeping the Wolves at Bay

124121111.content:
Cal takes aim and fires at the gunman, hitting him square in the back below his left shoulder at the same time as the gunman fires and hits Lester in the chest. Cal runs down the hill to Lester, as he lies there bleeding.

"Les, I'm here, you're gonna be all right! Just let me get some bandages."

"No Cal, I'm dying...." he gasps, blood dripping from his mouth. "Take care of yourself... and remember what we talked about..."

"Sure Les, but you're gonna be OK, I can get help! Please don't leave me!"

Cal looks down but Lester has stopped breathing and he knows he is gone...
124121111.title: Cold Blooded Killer

1241211111.content:
Dear diary,

This is the funeral of a friend-
the funeral of you-
and my desperate hoping that your ashes
will love me later.

This is the only way I thought of-
to send you out of this world
of leaking ink and broken lead
dog-eared corners and winded poems-
Fire.

I built it myself-
small bundle of dried leaves,
under a layer of sticks.
and lastly you- after the desiccated, brittle
kindling of your pyre had fanned
into bright and lilting dancers-
who then spent the twilight
tossing armfuls
of our old words to the moon.
1241211111.title: Funeral for a Friend

12412111112.content:
The purpose of this 5K run
is a universal one

Find a cure for breast cancer
destroy it for good

It is a long distance
but many people participate

I do not know how they do it
but feel no envy towards them

Watch from the sidelines
to catch all the action

Almost there my friends
just run one more mile

You have almost made it
hang in there and be strong

Completion is a success
good job everybody

I will see you
at next year's race
12412111112.title: Run one more mile

1241211112.content:
Cal sits slumped in the dirt next to the body of his friend sobbing for quite a while, then as daylight starts to fade he realizes he has to take action. He looks over at his deceased friend.

"Les, I guess there's not much left to do but honor your wishes now. I remember how we talked about what we'd want done if one of us were to get killed on the trail. I wanted to be buried beneath the tallest tree you could find, so you could tell my momma where I was in case she wanted to come find my grave. And you wanted to be cremated so your spirit could soar up in the clouds and find the soul of your Cherokee wife that got killed by them raiders. Looks like you got out of the digging. I better go get some more wood, make sure it's a hot enough fire to get the job done right..."

Carl watches Lester burn, adding more wood as the night goes on. Eventually the body is consumed, and as the fire burns down low Cal manages to get a little sleep. He awakes when the sun is already up and starts to strike camp. He looks over and sees a turkey vulture circling above the hill, realizes it's coming for the body of the man who killed his friend.

Cal looks up at the sky and speaks, talking to his departed friend. "Les, I know the Code says any outlaw who kills a Ranger deserves to have his body hanged in the nearest tree with a sign around his neck listing his crime, but I'm not sure if my heart's in it..."
1241211112.title: Cleansing Fire

12412111121.content:
As he approaches, Cal sees one of the vultures has landed and is pecking at the body. He chases the bird away and looks down at the dead man. He's thin, dressed in shabby clothes. He searches the body and finds a couple silver coins, which he pockets. He looks in the man's backpack, finds a bag with a piece of jerky and some stale bread in it, and a threadbare flannel shirt. he stuffs these into his own pack.

Cal looks the dead man in the eye. "Mister, judging by what you said before you killed my partner I'm gonna guess you're the daddy of that boy we just hanged outside of Sylva. I aint got no kids, but if I were to have one someday and he ended up like your son, I suppose I might want to kill the Ranger who hanged him... Code says I ought to string up your dead body and leave it for the turkey vultures on account of what you did, but I think there's been enough violence done here."

Cal pulls a camp shovel out of his pack and digs a shallow grave, drags the body over and pushes it in. He shovels the dirt back in on top. He picks up a couple dead tree branches and uses strips of cloth torn from the man's flannel shirt to lash them together in a rudimentary cross that he puts at the head of the grave. "Don't know if you were a Christian, but at least if any of your kin comes looking they might find your grave."
12412111121.title: Respect the Dead

124121111211.content:
Cal has been walking for two days since he buried the stranger. The bread and jerky are long gone, and he hasn't had any luck finding game. He's hungry, but hunger is not a stranger to him. He can't be more than a day or two from home now. He can live off water until then if he needs to...

"Lester, you'd like my dad. He's a good hunter, and he's real mechanical minded. He even got electricity working in our house so we could run some of the stuff from the old days! And my mom, she's a real good cook..."

"I know what you'd say about now, Les; "Cal, what the hell are you doing talking to me, I'm dead?" and I realize that. But I'm all alone here! I got nobody to talk to, you were like the older brother I never had. It helps me to think that when I talk, maybe from up there somewhere you might be listening..."

Cal continues walking. In the distance he spots smoke along the riverbank. He walks a little closer and he sees what appears to be a woman squatting by a campfire, with a man lying on the ground next to her. He approaches cautiously, not knowing if anyone else is around.

"Hold it right there mister!" a voice calls out from behind.

Cal turns around quickly and sees a young woman, she's pointing a loaded crossbow straight at his chest...
.
124121111211.title: The Road to Teresita

1241211112112.content:
Cal drops his rifle and puts his hands up. "OK miss, I don't mean you no harm, an honorable man."

Isabel keeps the crossbow pointed at him. "I haven't met an honorable man in my life yet, so you'll excuse me if I don't take you at your word."

"But I'm a Ranger, see? Here's my badge."

"Any man can pin a star on himself, that don't prove he's got character... What are you doing out here sneaking up on our camp?"

"My partner got killed a few days ago, and I'm low on food. I was on my way to see my mom and dad, gonna visit them and get some provisions before heading back to the Ranger Station in Bryson City to get reassigned. I spotted your campfire and thought I'd check to make sure you weren't bandits invading our territory."

"OK, sounds like a good story, but from the looks of you I'm guessing you were drawn to our campfire more by the prospects of a free meal than by the chance to fight bandits."

Cal blushes. He tries to think of a clever response but finds himself at a loss for words. "My name's Cal." he says, thinking at least he can introduce himself.

"I'm Isabel. Now turn around and walk on ahead of me to the fire and we'll see what the others think of you before I let my guard down..."
1241211112112.title: Introductions

12412111121121.content:
"Callie? Is that really you?"

"Ma?"

Cal rushes over to greet his mother, they embrace. He looks her in the eye, then looks down at the wounded man lying by the campfire. "What are you doing out her with Uncle Lance, Ma? And where's Dad?"

"Never mind that now Callie, look at you! Been gone a year, I hardly recognize ya! My little boy is a man now!"

She hugs him again.

Cal's face reddens at his mother's words as he looks over at Isabel.

"Thanks Ma, but it seems like you're trying to avoid my questions. Where's Dad? And why are you out here with Uncle Lance? And how did he get injured?"

Kaylin explains how they were attacked by the robbers, and how Isabel saved them.

"OK Ma, but that doesn't explain why you were on the trail with Uncle Lance to begin with."

"Well Callie, I hate to tell you this, but your father is dead..."

"No! He can't be dead! This is a bad joke, right?"

"No Callie, he passed away shortly after you left. That cough he had turned into something worse."

Cal breaks down and cries. Kaylin holds him while recovers from the shock.

"So after Dad died you were on your way to stay with Uncle Lance and Aunt Susan when the bandits attacked..."

"Yeah Callie, but there's a little more to the story... I'm married to Lance now."

"Married? Is Aunt Susan dead now too?"

"No, she's fine... It's just that Lance and me joined the Mormons, they can have more than one wife, you know."

"Knowing you I'm guessing this was your idea, right Ma? Does Aunt Susan approve of this? Does she even know about it?"

Kaylin turns away, not wanting to look Cal in the eye.

"How could you do this, Ma? I'm not sure I even want to know you right now..."

Cal pushes her away, turns and walks away.

"In these times a widow has to look out for herself, Callie, I was just doing what seemed best!" Kaylin calls after him.

Kay starts crying and Isabel approaches her, puts her hand on Kaylin's shoulder. "It's all right, he just needs some time... Do you want me to go talk to him?"

"OK, if you think it will help," Kay replies...
12412111121121.title: Family Reunion

124121111211211.content:
Cal is sitting on a rock on the edge of the river, staring at the rushing waters. He hears Isabel approaching, but doesn't turn to face her.

"Cal? Are you OK?"

"How would you feel if you just found out your dad was dead and your mom was trying to steal your uncle away from his family as a replacement!"

"I don't know Cal, my mom and dad are both dead, killed by those robbers."

Cal turns around to face her. "Sorry Isabel, I didn't know."

He reaches out and puts his hand on her shoulder to comfort her but she pushes him away and takes a step back. "Back off, I don't need your sympathy. My father wasn't much better than the men who killed him. His main talents were making corn whiskey and drinking it with Mom, then taking advantage of me when she was passed out."

"My God Isabel, it must have been horrible to live like that!"

"Lets just say I didn't cry when those men killed him... I did cry when they killed Mom. She wasn't a mean person, just weak. I think living with Dad all those years musta wore her down... "

"I'm sorry Isabel," Cal says.

He reaches out to put his arm around her again to try to to console her, and again she pushes him away. "Just leave me alone, Cal. I know you mean well, but when a man puts his arm around a woman he usually has more than friendship in mind, and right now I ain't interested in such ideas. Besides, I'm here to try to get you to make peace with your mom."

"But don't you think it's wrong what she did, pushing my uncle to marry her like that?"

"Talking with your mom the last couple days, I get the idea she probably would have married Lance instead of your dad to start with, if he had the courage to ask for her first. And as far as the plural marriage idea goes, there are more honest single women than men around these days, so the Mormon revival kinda makes sense in that respect."

"But Uncle Lance already has a wife and kids! Do you think Aunt Susan is really going to accept the idea of sharing her husband with my mom?"

"That's not for us to worry about. Your mom is a survivor, she did what she did to take care of herself when she was all alone after your father died, and I don't blame her. Now it'll be up to her and Susan to work things out, assuming your uncle survives..."
124121111211211.title: Aid and Comfort

1241211112112111.content:
Lance and Isabel approach the campfire just as the sun is going down. Kaylin looks up, but doesn't say a word. Lance is awake now, sitting next to Kay, sipping water from a canteen. He puts the water down and speaks softly. " Sorry Callie, I know this all must be pretty upsetting to you."

"Don't cal me Callie! Only Mom calls me Callie, and don't expect me to call you Dad now neither!"

"All right,.. I'll just call you Cal and you can just call me Lance from now on... man to man, fair enough?"

"OK Lance, I can live with that... Think you'll be recovered enough to make the trip back to our house in the morning?"

"Don't be pushing the man, he just got shot! He might need another day of rest before moving," Kaylin says.

"It ain't that safe on the trails, Mom. Besides, we'd be better off at home where Lance can get some proper rest and some good food."

"Your son's right, Kay. it ain't safe out here. And it's not that many miles back, I should be all right. I think if we leave in the morning we should make it back long before sunset, even if we don't push it. And I sure could use a home cooked meal."

"You're not the only one," Isabel says. "But I think Callie needs it the most of all of us. He's looking pretty thin, Kay, looks like's he's gone too long without a good woman's cooking. I'll help you out in the kitchen when we get back, let's see if we can fatten these men folk up."

Kaylin and Lance laugh with good nature at Isabel's remarks. Cal reddens a little at first, then decides to take it in stride and laughs along with them.
1241211112112111.title: Making Peace

12412111121121112.content:
Joel remembered his father's words. "I'm going after the men who hanged your brother. I'm not gonna let them get away with killing him like that! If I ain't back in a week, you go over to Riverton and tell Aunt Mae what I done, and ask if you can stay with her. Those Rangers are dangerous men, so don't you even think of coming after me. If I don't make it back, I gotta know at least one of my boys is still alive to carry on."

Joel remembered forcing himself not to cry as he hugged his father goodbye, that was over a week ago.

His decision to disobey was not made lightly but he knew he could not go to Riverton, knowing his father was somewhere out on the trail and he might be able to help him.

Joel was only fifteen, but he was strong of body and mind. Once he decided on a course of action, God help anyone who got in his way.

After several days of tracking Joel came upon the campsite. His blood ran cold when he saw the grave, with the cross of dead branches tied together with cloth from his father's favorite old flannel shirt. He pulled the cairn rocks off of the top of the grave and started digging away the earth with his hands, fearing what he would find but knowing he must finish digging.

Joel's eyes were blinded with tears as he brushed the dirt from his dead father's face. He wiped the tears from his eyes with the back of his sleeve as the rage began to build in him. "I'll get them Daddy! Those bastard Rangers that killed you and Billy are gonna be sorry for what they done!"
12412111121121112.title: An Unwelcome Surprise

124121111211211122.content:
Joel pushed the dirt back over his father's body and put the rocks back on top to discourage animals from digging into the grave, forcing back tears as anger welled up inside. "I'll get them bastards, Daddy," he muttered over the grave as a final farewell, then he turned toward the trail.

Cal's tracks weren't hard to find since he wasn't trying to hide them. Once Joel knew he was on the right path he started to run. He saw there was only one set of tracks, this was encouraging. Maybe his dad had managed to kill the other Ranger before he was killed? At any rate Joel would only be facing one man, so his odds were better than he originally thought. But as the afternoon wore on and he began to tire, he figured he would not be likely to catch up with the man before dark, no matter how hard he ran.

He was getting hungry too, so Joel decided to make camp and find some supper. He spotted a squirrel eating seeds from a pine cone near the base of a tree. He slowly pulled a throwing knife from the sheath attached to his belt and with a quick flick of the wrist sent it flying. It pegged the rodent square in the chest.

The squirrel was still alive when Joel approached. he pulled the knife from it and used it to quickly slit its throat to put it out of its misery. "Sorry buddy, but I gotta eat," he said as he did this.

A short time later Joel had a fire going, and the skinned animal roasting on a stick. Not long after that he was curled up in his bedroll next to the dying embers, belly full, dreaming of exacting revenge on the man who killed his father...
124121111211211122.title: Running Wild

124121111212.content:
"I'm grateful you came back to check up on me Lance, I spent too many nights alone since you left."

"I've missed you too, Kaylin, glad to see you're doing OK. I bagged a turkey on the trail and dressed him out just before I got here. Not a very big one, but should be a pretty good meal for the two of us. You want to help me pluck him?"

"No, I can handle tha myself, I'll put some water on to boil. Been a long time since I had any fresh meat around here, I sure do appreciate it. I got a tub of water drawn for my bath but you look like you need it more than me. Why don't you go wash the trail dust off yourself while I get this bird ready for the oven...."

A short time later Kaylin knocks on the bathroom door, then enters, carrying a steaming pot: "I brought some hot water to warm your bath Lance, hope you don't mind."

"No, I guess not, ain't like you never seen me naked before. Although the cold water doesn't do me justice... Kay, I can't help noticing that you don't look any different that you did when I left. I guess the baby didn't take?"

"No, sorry to say it didn't. But now that you're here we can always try again. Maybe a few times extra, just to be sure."

"I don't know, Kay, Spence has been gone quite a while now. By the time you had the baby, folks would know it wasn't his."

"I was thinking about that too, Lance, and I got a plan. You go ahead and finish your bath while I tend to dinner. Later on I'll tell you all about it..."
124121111212.title: Daddy's Gone Hunting

1241211112122.content:
"...So this Joe Smith, he's a preacher, calls himself a prophet. Says he's a descendant of the man who founded the original Mormon church a couple hundred years ago. He came through here last week preaching and he left me these pamphlets. Said him and his followers were setting up camp in the old Union School building, and anyone interested in joining his church should come on down. I think we should check it out."

"Kaylin, you know I ain't never been much into listening to no preachers. I believe in the Creator and in honoring him by living my life the best I can, but I just can't see myself hanging around with a bunch of holy rollers in some old school building. You never were much of a church goer either, from what I can recollect. So why are you so interested in this now?"

"Here's the thing, Lance. In his religion a man is allowed to have more than one wife, hell, it's even expected of him! So all we gotta do is go down there and agree to join the church and then he can marry us. We don't have to hang around after that if we don't want to."

"I don't know Kay, I'm not so sure Susan would approve of me having a second wife."

"It says in one of these pamphlets that the man is supposed to be the head of his household, and his wives are obedient to him. Susan couldn't really argue with your decision to take a second wife if it was part of your new religion."

"Well I'm not so sure about this idea, Kay, I gotta think about it."

"It's getting kinda late, Lance. why don't we just go to bed. You can sleep on it and then decide what you want to do in the morning..."
1241211112122.title: The Followers of Joe Smith

12412111121221.content:
"I sure am glad you agreed to go and let that Mormon preacher marry us, Lance."

"I must admit you were pretty convincing last night about the benefits of having a second wife, Kaylin."

"Well, Momma told me if I found a man who was a good provider and I wanted him to stick around, I shouldn't be shy about using what God gave me to make sure he started the day with a smile on his face..."

"Well, far be it from me to disagree with your momma. Say, we've been walking quite a while now, let's stop and have our lunch. There's a nice shady spot down by that riverbank."

"OK Lance, maybe we can go for a swim after that."

Suddenly a rifle shot rings out and Lance falls to the ground. Kay screams!

Two ragged looking men approach. One of them points a gun at her and calls out, "Don't move, woman, or you'll end up like your man! Darrell, check their packs, see if they got anything good."

Darrell rifles through their belongings, pulls out the bread and meat Kaylin had packed for lunch and takes a bite. "It's some pretty good ham Hiram, you want some?"

"Maybe later, I think I want some of her first."

Hiram grabs Kaylin and pushes her to the ground, tearing at her clothes while she struggles. He pulls out a knife and holds it to her cheek. "It'd be best if you didn't fight me woman, I'd hate to have to cut your pretty face."

Kay is looking up at the man, hate and fear in her eyes, then she hears a faint whirring sound. Suddenly Hiram is gagging, coughing blood, and pulling at the shaft of an arrow that is stuck through his neck.

Darrell stands up, looks at his friend in shock. "What the hell is..."

But he get doesn't finish what he is saying, he falls to the ground with an arrow in his chest.
12412111121221.title: Take Me to the River

124121111212211.content:
Saved is a curious word; there are so many things it can refer to. I once saved an egg out to make pancakes for breakfast the next morning. If I hadn’t it would have been eaten.

Money is the most saved item around and also the most spent. People are saved from different things. Some are said to be saved from themselves. This is a good thing because if they weren’t saved from themselves they could have been ruined finically, physically, spiritually or mentally.

There are programs to save the whales, and wildlife preserves have saved many different species of anamils from perishing. Time has been saved by taking short cuts. Face has been saved by telling the truth.

There are so many ways for stuff to be saved that saved turns out to be a pretty general term.
124121111212211.title: Saved!

1241211112122112.content:
I'm really starting to think I gotta do a better job handling my anger issues, it might be the death of me yet.
Literally.

I finally decided I had enough. Enough of my boss always bitching at me for coming in late and not keeping the shelves stocked with the right plumbing supplies, like anybody cares. Enough of my lame-ass girlfriend Diane always expecting me to spend my money to take her out to dinner or buy her stuff. Half the time she don't even put out, always got a headache or some bullshit.

So I had a few drinks and walked into work and told my boss to go fuck himself, then stopped at the Denny's where Diane works to tell her the same. One last stop at my crappy apartment to throw my clothes and anything worth keeping into the back of my Caravan and I'm on the road again. Thank God Almighty I'm free at last! Time to crack open a beer!

I was on my way to Vegas but when I got to Barstow I thought maybe I'd take the 40 instead and head over to Havasu, look up this girl I used to know. But I had a few beers too many to even make it to Needles, so I got off the highway somewhere near Ludlow and hit the dirt roads looking for a place to camp.

I wake up in the back of the van not knowing where the hell I am. I look out the window and all I see is sand. I get out to take a piss and realize the gravity of my situation.

I'm at the end of a dead end dirt road, no civilization in sight, I must've drove for miles before I stopped. The van is buried up to the axles in soft sand, I guess I spun the wheels for a while when I got stuck last night before I passed out.

I read someplace where people who aren't prepared can die in the desert heat in less than a day. All I got for supplies is the fries at the bottom of the McDonald's bag and a can of warm beer.

I'm already thirsty, and the day is just starting...
1241211112122112.title: Sand

124121111212212.content:
Kaylin struggles to get to her feet as a girl dressed in ragged clothes and carrying a crossbow approaches. She's maybe sixteen or seventeen, and has a long scar on her cheek. "Are you all right?" she asks.

"I think so," Kay replies, somewhat in shock from recent events. "Lance!" she calls out, remembering what happened as she rushes over to where he is lying. The girl follows her. "He's still breathing!" Kay says.

"He's lost some blood, but it looks like the bullet went clean through. If we wash out the wound real good and get it bandaged he should be OK," the girl says.

The two work on patching Lance up. "Thanks for saving us, I don't know what would have happened if you didn't show up. My name's Kaylin, what's yours?"

"I'm Isabel, and I have a pretty good idea of what would have happened if I hadn't got here in time. These two bastards ambushed us a while back, killed my father and kept me and my mom chained up like dogs while they used us for their pleasure. My mom lasted about a week, then they decided she wasn't any more good so they killed her. Not long after that, when they were away hunting I managed to pick the padlock on the chain around my neck and make my escape. I found an abandoned cabin up on the ridge and stayed there while I healed up. I found the crossbow in the cabin, decided I'd see if I could track these two dirtbags down and serve them some justice. Lucky for you I did."

"God, that must have been awful!" Kay says.

The man with arrow in his throat starts moaning, apparently he's not dead. Isabel walks over to him, kicks him in the side so he rolls face up. She puts her foot on his chest. He looks up at her, fear in his eyes, while gasping for breath. "Did ya miss me, Hiram? Anything I can do to help you out here? What's that? You want me to get this arrow out of your throat?"

Isabel steps on his head and pulls the arrow from his neck as he moans in pain and loses consciousness. "Sorry, Hiram, looks like I accidentally cut your jugular vein with the arrow. I suppose I could put a tourniquet around your neck but I don't expect that would help you any. Oh well, at least it's not a total loss. I managed to save my arrow," she says, walking back towards Kaylin and leaving him to die...
124121111212212.title: Isabel

1241212.content:
First of all, to really understand how things got to be the way they are, you have to go way back.

You mean like to the Stone Age?

No, farther back than that?

Dinosaurs?

No, even further.

The primordial ooze?

Nope, but you're getting closer.

The Big Bang?

Yeah, that's where it all began.

So what does the Big Bang have to do with it?

You see, elegant as it seems, there was one minor flaw in the creation of the elements of the universe. Some theorize it was a cosmic accident. Others who believe in a Creator, say it's God's Monkey Wrench, a Divine Practical Joke just waiting to unfold.

Well, it doesn't seem very funny to me. And we'd probably all be better off if we hadn't discovered it. Ignorance is bliss, you know.

I agree, but it's too late for that now...
1241212.title: Back to the Beginning

12412121.content:
I agree and truly believe that ignorance is bliss. Just think about it. When we're kids in the past back then, we used to be so carefree and not worry about facing life. We just play around naively and not think about complications in life, yet we're having fun and the time of our life. It's great to be knowledgeable and understanding, but when we free our mind from troubles and worries, our burden will feel so much lighter than before. It's like putting down a heavy knapsack. Just imagine how relieved you are when you finally can put down that weighty burden and rest your sore back. It works similarly like that.

When we know too much, especially unnecessary information, our brain would feel tired and stressed. We tend to constantly worry about test results, jobs, updating your online status, whether your videos has gain views. And even waiting for your boyfriend/girlfriend to text you back. If we learn to stop thinking about them, we would definitely feel better. Just try it someday.
12412121.title: Ignorance is Bliss

12412122.content:
Doctor Forrester, what first gave you the idea something unusual was happening?

It was the dogs, the attacks. News articles becoming much more frequent about them, always the younger dogs, as if each generation were being born more feral than the last. Then the disaster in Pamplona last July gave me the idea that this might not be confined to canines, other domesticated animals were being affected as well. That's when I had my genetics team start looking into bovines as well.

Is this a virus or some type of pathogen? Is it something that could spread to people?

We're not sure yet what the cause is, but it doesn't appear to be viral. We're not sure if humans are being affected at this time, we'll have more for the press once we've done further research.

Doctor Forrester, what about the reports that globally decreasing test scores of primary school students may be an indicator that humans are already being affected?

We feel it's too early to comment on that right now. Thank you for your time, no further questions please.
12412122.title: God's Monkey Wrench

124122.content:
If thoughts could kill we'd all be dead
Hung by the noose formed in our heads
We love and laugh but sometimes we hate
Just one instance would be too late..

The deed would be done
With regrets on the run
Sprinting rampant knowing the truth
I wonder what son of man could outlive youth.

Even a pastor has dark thoughts in mind
But he keeps them controlled (most of the time)
Imagine the congregation drop dead in the pews
What holy punishment would he then have due?

Guns would be just as uselss as knives
There would be extinction of all kinds of fights!
A married couple really wouldn't have a chance
Condemned by one thought to no longer last

The warlords and criminals would all drop dead
Imagine the cost for a price on your head!
The police would be useless as well as deep graves
Corpses would fill the streets or become zombified slaves

With the price of one thought
Much havoc could be wrought
No tears to be shed
For all would end by an idea in a head
124122.title: If thoughts could kill

12413.content:
I walk in the house and there you are with "that" look, leaning on the wall with a piece of paper in your hand.

I toss my keys on the table, put down my bag and walk to you as though all is well. Kiss on the cheek, "Hey," keep walking.

"Hey?"

"Yeah, hey." as I open the refrigerator looking for a snack or drink, something to occupy my mouth for next 5 to 60 minutes.

You sigh, shoulders slumped, hair disheveled, drop the paper on the table and go to the back of the house.

I spoon out my yogurt, adding cinnamon, nutmeg, honey thinking why me? Why did I get married? Why do I like the rush of going behind your back?

As I sit down at the table with the container of yogurt, I know none of this is new. I've never been satisfied. Not with you, not with anyone. It's not that I don't love you, I do, more than anyone else. And I know this can't be replaced, YOU can't be replaced.

Mail sprawled on the table, you clearly wanting attention from the bedroom, opening and closing God knows what so that I know something is on your mind.

I scrape the bowl leaving thinner white lines in the black bowl. Right about the time the bowl is looking black again you come out and place a large stack of letters of the table beside me.

"Just a reminder," you say as you stomp away to the bedroom again.
12413.title: Why me?

124131.content:
Reminiscences from a time long ago.
We were on the lookout for suitable tree branches for making catapults with. It had become a bit of a craze with all of us and we were forever arguing about who's was best. What you had to do first was spot a suitable branch, it had to have a nice thick stem and two forks growing in equal thickness to each other but slightly thinner than the shaft, quite simply we looked for a nicely symmetrical letter Y. Once the desired candidate had been selected we climbed the tree and hacked the entire limb off using an old axe that Cliff had relieved from his father a few weeks before and that we kept hidden in a plastic bag that went in a hole in the ground, all very clandestine.

We would then drag the branch from the woods to Steve's garage, his father was a great bloke and his garage was chock-a -block with wood working tools and he was always in either the garage or the garden because he was building a boat in his spare time, (I'm going to talk about the boat later, I bet you can't wait) and he would gladly help us to saw the branch to the right size. I was always a bit jealous of the relationship Steve had with his father. He was an only child and was clearly doted on. He loved showing the three of us how to do stuff and it was he who had shown us how to make the catapults, not the chopping down of tree's bit you understand,

Once it was cut to size and stripped of bark we would chuck them on one of the bonfires for a few minutes to dry them out and then we would buy a yard of quarter inch cat elastic from Gentries the sports shop and cut notches in the top of the two forks, cut the elastic in half then force one end of each piece of the elastic into the notched ends then bind them together with a wire that we had stolen from an electrical shop in Bexleyheath. The other ends of the elastic were then attached to a square of leather using more wire. When Steve's dad had made the first one he had bought a piece of leather especially for the job. Cliff and me didn't have such luxuries, no we just cut the tongues out of our shoes, they were perfect for the job.

So we're back in the woods and we had come across this tree that was about 30 feet tall but very thin, it had loads of spindly branches on it , nothing suitable for us, but Cliff had decided to try and climb it, he had only got about half way when the tree started to bow, he was only about seven stone wet but even his weight was to much for the puny tree, suddenly it bowed right over and brought Cliff back to within a couple of feet of the ground, when he let go he more or less just stepped off, but the tree whipped back upright a lightening speed. If anyone had been in it's way they would most certainly of been killed, but I think all of us had the exact same thought at the exact same time.

We immediately set to work, the mission was to strip the whole tree of all it's branches, this took us hours, I still to this day can't believe that we were so dedicated to one tiny bit of mischief. We took it in turns to shimmy up the tree hacking off all the limbs as we went. We had to return to finish the job the next day because it had got to dark to continue and it was a bit scary in those woods after dark.
So it was Sunday afternoon when finally the last branch had been removed and the top ten feet cut off, so basically what we were left with was a 20 foot pole, have you worked out where I'm going with this yet, no? Then I'll continue. We were almost ready we went back into the street and collected half a dozen milk bottles off some random doorsteps and a sledge hammer from Cliff's and a massive steel spike that was about three feet long and had stood against the wall in my garage, it had been there for so long that no one knew how it got there or what it was originally for. But finally we had found a use for it.

15 minutes later and we rendezvoused back at the pole. We hammered the spike into the soft ground with the sledge hammer, that was the hardest part of all Cliff had insisted on doing this because the hammer was his, but the trouble was the bloody hammer was almost as big as him and he could hardly swing it and when he did manage to lift it above his head the weight of it dragged him over, but eventually between us we got it hammered in so that there was about six inches sticking out of the ground. Next I climbed the pole until it bent over enough for the other two to grab it, then with all three of us hanging onto the end we secured it with a length of rope to the spike in the ground.

Great! It was finally ready. We stuck one of the milk bottles onto the end of the pole and stood back to admire our weekends work. I think that if it hadn't taken so long to get to this point we might have had second thoughts about doing this, but we had come to far to turn back now.

Using the axe I chopped through the rope, it went in one because it was under so much strain already I suppose.

I think that we all thought that the bottle would probably fly straight up into the air and we would get loads of fun doing this over and over again. What actually happened was that the milk bottle got launched up into the stratosphere, we didn't even see it leave the end of the tree, It couldn't possibly have stayed within the woods. We didn't see it leave and it wouldn't of been possible to see it land because it must have flow across Iron Mill Lane over the school on the other side of the road and carried on into town

Of course we did what we always did when we came face to face with our own stupidity, we ran.
We legged it out of the woods and went home. We stayed out of those woods for at least a couple of weeks, and when we did venture back in all our handy work had been removed. The old boy must have come across it and he had cut down the stripped tree and pulled up the spike. I think we were secretly pleased, all the evidence was gone and there had been no reports on the news about anyone being killed by a mysterious flying milk bottle, so we had got away with it.

Years later, when Cliff and I would be in the pub our REMINICENCES always included that story, and the more he drank the further that bottle went.
124131.title: Reminiscences

124132.content:
Watching you retreat back into the bedroom, I sigh in frustration knowing that there is no way I can avoid this confrontation. The stack of letters sprawled across the table are a silent reminder of when things were so much better between us.

Where did it start going wrong? I ask myself in resignation.

But really, I already know the answer to that question. It started going wrong shortly after we married. The day I woke up to discover that no matter how much I loved you it wasn't enough. The chase, the capture, the infatuation was all gone now. Married with no challenge left except to survive each and every day without the thrill of the pursuit. Those letters, penned during our courtship, were mute testimony to what was now lost. No longer did my stomach tingle when I thought of seeing you. No longer did my pulse race and my body ache for the need of you. Long hours spent writing of my love, my need, my absolute adoration of you -- all done now.

Sighing, I stood up. I can hear you weeping softly behind the door. I know I have to face this, to explain to you why this was happening to us, to you, to me.
124132.title: Transgressions

1241321.content:
He walks into the room, that familiar resigned look on his face. His eyes are glazed. He doesn't care. And the half-written letter still burns in my heart.

How did it go so wrong?

"Listen, Alya" he begins. How are you going to explain this letter to me, Sean? Are you going to say that you were writing love poems to yourself?
"You know I love you.." I know you don't. It was a long time ago, the truth that you are speaking now. A long time ago when your eyes shone when you spoke to me. I know every heartbeat of yours, Sean, haven't you realized that by now? The way you shrug your shoulders when you want to avoid a confrontation, the way you run your hand through your hair when you are frustrated. The way you look away when you don't really mean what you say..

"...but it was a long time ago, Alya", he was saying. Yes it was a long time ago. Do you remember those moonlit summer nights, when we lay together in the terrace, in each other's arms, looking at the stars? Do you remember the hours we spent staring into each other's eyes? How much we used to talk then, Sean, even when there were no words left to say.

I close my eyes as he goes on, trying to live those moments again. Trying to feel his hands on my hands, trying to look at him as he was then, long long ago.

"Listen to me, Alya", he says, and his voice is tired, far away. It is with her I know. She, with her blonde hair and fair skin. Yes I know Sean. I can hear your voice when you talk to her on the phone at night, for hours, and oh, the agony it causes me! To hear you laugh, the way you laughed for me so long ago! To hear the affection in your voice, that you swore would be for me and me alone! Do you know how many nights I have spent burning underneath the covers, while you chatted with your friend?

"Alya", he pleads again, and tries to pull me towards him. But his touch is cold. So will be mine...

"Alya, what is it you are holding behind your back?"

The blade of the kitchen knife doesn't feel sharp enough, but it will have to do...
1241321.title: Confrontation

A love that was untouchable, that would last for eternity, forged in heaven by God himself sacred and holy. You are a Judas, who's lies fall like posion wine from your lips. I swear as I stand before you now never again will I allow you to cheapen our Love. Alya raised the knife she had hidden and plunged it deep..Sean was frozen, unable to fathom what had just happened...

1242.content:
The other way around
I went for a walk
Just to be with myself
And to read your letter
For my spirit to relive.

I savor your letter
Amidst beautiful sky
Amidst multicolored flowers
Amidst beautiful trees with hues of gold
Blinding yellows laced with orange and reds.

I read softly, slowly, with nothing on my mind
This walk was for you, my love
Butterflies floating around
Setting the tone
For a lighthearted glow
To enter my heart.

The other way around
As I walk softly
I read your letter
A true thing of beauty.

A glimmer turn my awareness
and point me
in a direction to notice the things
that are usually obscured
from the motion of my mind
the motion of the day
that shades my heart
and dulls my soul.

Truly, I felt my soul

The other way around
With a half smile
The one that is present
Without trying.
That easy soft one
From the spirit
That causes the heart to glow
And is attractive to others
I breathe deeply
Asking for God's direction.

I feel and see what is there...
I am filled with all things
I am graced with all these creations
Playing off each other
In perfect harmony.

I walk...softly...slowly...

To my destiny.
1242.title: The other way around

12421.content:
"Tell me how you are going to your destiny?"

I'm taken aback by this last question, not one I expected to hear at a job interview. But it has been a while since I had to look for a job, and I'd heard it was now common for interviewers to ask questions unrelated to job skills to "get a feel for your character". And the clumsy construction of the question could be explained by the fact that my interviewer's native language was Chinese, as was true of many new business owners these days...

America, once at the top of the heap, was slowly sliding into third world status. Our failing education system, along with high unemployment and unaffordable healthcare, had been driving the middle class down to poverty levels for some time now.

The Chinese saw this, and being good businessmen, started building factories here to exploit the new cheap American labor. How the tides had turned from when I was young. Kids graduating high school with basic skills barely above what used to be expected in grammar school were now more than happy to take a low paying job with no benefits at the local plastic factory. Me, at my age, I was competing against them for one of those jobs.

I thought I was set, put in thirty years at a major aerospace company before I retired. Then, five years later, my pension disappeared and the company declared bankruptcy, a victim of the "2012 Credit Crisis" and subsequent stock market crash.

"Tell me how you are going to your destiny?" he asks me again.

I guess I better answer the man if I want a chance at getting this job.

"Sir, I am going calmly, quietly, and respectfully to my destiny," I reply.

"Excellent, I have confidence you will be a good worker. You may start next week on night shift..."
12421.title: "Tell me how you are going to your destiny?"

124211.content:
Jesus, I feel like a greeter at WalMarts!
How long can I last? I know I made the right choice, the only choice.
Let's see. Life or death? What would you choose? See what I mean. We all choose life unless death would be preferable to what we were made to do to survive. Even then, some people have done horrific things to others to make it through some very bad situations, I have become a janitor.
I was an aerospace engineer who loved his work for so many years and retired at a comfortable age, having raised children to maturity with good family values, schooling and grandchildren.
So what now?

Borders are changing. Nothing different than what has happened from the beginning of recorded history.
I studied all that but thought America might last forever, forgetting that Rome had a good four hundred years!
All society is in flux. Why did I forget that China and her population would eventually awaken. again. And then?

I am on the NIGHT SHIFT and studying Mandarin. I wish I wouldn't have talked my daughter into speaking
Spanish as her second language. If she spoke one of the many orient dialects maybe she would be in China instead of Mexico? Oh well. I'm glad I'm alive. I am excited to see what happens next!
124211.title: Night Shift

12422.content:
Since my early childhood I have often stood looking through my window, dreaming of doing brave deeds and making a difference to the world. My problem is that I am timid. I do, however, have one saving grace. Although unable for the life of me to stand up to someone acting the bully towards me, I have always managed to be protective towards someone smaller than myself.

My Grandmother was witness to one of these episodes.

She said to me, "This was how you are making your destiny. This is your strength."
12422.title: How you are making your destiny?

124222.content:
"The Dead Don't Die," was the headline on CNN NewsPulse when it first started happening. The comments from posters were predictable, the usual blaming of global warming, Democratic conspiracy, and the second coming of Jesus. I wasn't too concerned, at least the Dead were peaceful, not like the bloodthirsty brain-eating monsters in the movies.

The Dead didn't cause any trouble. They mostly just sat around on benches in neighborhood parks, conversing with each other in low whispers.
Police stopped enforcing loitering laws against them when they realized the Dead didn't care if you put them in jail. They had infinite patience, they would just sit there until you released them. In the meantime your jail would absorb the odors of decay, and the other inmates would soon be contacting their lawyers and the ACLU, filing lawsuits against the city for inhumane treatment or cruel and unusual punishment.

When asked, the Dead allowed themselves to be examined extensively by the doctors of the CDC. They could not determine a physical cause for the condition, or a reason these people were still ambulatory or able to think and carry on conversation, they had no pulse, they did not breathe, and had no need of food or drink.

Great men of science and religious philosophers questioned them, asking why they thought this had happened to them. Was Man evolving beyond death? Was this part of God's plan? The answers they got were noncommittal, disinterested. "The Dead do not concern themselves with such things," was a typical response.

I didn't understand, this was such an amazing new development, unprecedented in history! How could they be so apathetic about their condition?

Then this morning I woke up dead, I imagine it was a heart attack in my sleep. I wasn't sure at first so I checked my pulse, couldn't feel anything. Slipped the cuff of my BP monitor over my arm and pushed the button just to make sure, got a zero over zero reading. That's not too healthy.

Oh well, I guess that's it then. No sense hanging around the house, I think I'll take a walk down to the park and see who's around...
124222.title: Don't Die

1242311.content:
Which path, dark or light?
An almost absurd question,
for what has the light ever done for me?

The more I reached for it,
the more unattainable it became
until I was left a damnable mess
tormented by an elusive dream.

I've walked among the murky shadows for so long
that they've become home to me, and
there is a certain comfort in that--
at least I'm where I belong, wanted.

There is an honesty in the dark,
no promises of a bright future, but a gift
of tolerance and acceptance, and from it
a power I never knew I possessed.

I read somewhere that "light thinks it travels faster,"
but it arrives only to find that darkness was there first.
We were conceived in darkness,
and to the dark we shall return--eventually.

Until then, I shall embrace the darkness within me
and reach not for the stars
but for the vast deep that envelopes them
and allows them to play.
1242311.title: Which path, dark or light?
