125132.content:
A flash. Another mortar lights the sky, showering debris over us as we stand, your snarling face cast into shadow. Do I still know you? In this pause in time, I wonder - but there is no answer to be found in the depths of your eyes, blackened as they are by the night. Behind me, the wall weakens as the moments pass; in every second there is a growing sense of decay that threatens to swamp both of us. Fluid leaks from my shoulder, the quaking earth tearing at the knife you thrust so hard it cracked the wall. Like the colours of war it seeps everywhere, painting your hand a savage crimson as it gently grasps my throat. Out there, in the land we loved so well, the antiquated lives of thousands are lost with such ease as still others advance, driven by a strange fury that sees all reduced to dust. With bated breath I stand, pinned to the wall, well aware that the gun in your hand is pointed solely at the culprit. Me.

What did I do to you that warranted this? Somewhere in the back of my mind, the chant begins anew, but the time for words is long past - these allegations that hold me here in thrall can never be resolved... there is no hope left to set the truth in motion.
The wall shudders angrily, freeing me from the constrains of the knife. Your grasp tightens ever so carefully, those darkened eyes never leaving mine as around us the world dies. Even as you pull the trigger, love blooms within me as I remember. The end this may be, but I know who you once were. That is enough to sate the souls of all.

Surprise, like a fleeing deer, splashes across you face as the empty chamber clicks. An expression, no doubt, mirrored by my own - but what did I expect to see? Sorrow consuming your soul even as you destroy me? Or something less; the primal anger that drove the knife home? Instead I find misery, chasing away the shock. The gun falls, the hand slips away. A silvery tear escapes your eyes, now shown for the hazel they are, as the blinding light of an aircraft's searchlight sweeps the plain. The choking love inside my chest swells and leaves me breathless, seeing you illuminated by brightness, like my own angel sent to set me free. With careless joy I pull the knife away, the pain merely a momentary blight on my mind; eyes trained on yours. The wall creaks threateningly, but we know we've reached the end at last. The knife clatters as it hits the rubble, but the sound is nothing compared to the rhythm of you heart as we embrace, crying as though at a funeral. Our funeral, but strangely our union as well, for in this second I know there is no greater love than that I feel for you.

A second explosion, greater than the first mortar, rocks the ground on which we stand, and the wall renders all the love in the world useless as it falls.
125132.title: Sorrow consuming your soul even as you destroy me

choices: The beach is pleasant on a sunny day.
Why don't we throw a party.
1252.content:
Today is the day, where it will happen.

Today is the day that shapes the future.

Looking out my window I spot a buzzing swarm of bees.

Are they in any way significant?? Will they shape my future in any way??

I do not know, but somehow I've got the feeling that I'll find out.

I feel drawn towards the window, and I'm almost tempted to opening it, but I decline. I'm simply not ready. Not yet. Perhaps not ever.

But still....it would be interesting to see, if this swarm of mean-spirited insects in any way could change the way life takes me.

But are they mean-spirited, or have we just misunderstood, what they're doing. Maybe bee-stings were supposed to be pleasant. Maybe bee-stings weren't supposed to hurt. Maybe bee-stings were even supposed to do us good.

Somehow the significance of bee-stings could have been twisted by some sort of insignificant happening. Is that possible??

Yet again I have to conclude: I do not know.

For my whole life I've dreamt about opening my window to see, what happens, if a swarm of bees pass by.

Yes, I'm going to do it. I'll skip all intentions of living the safe life. I simply have to know, if they'll harm me, or if they'll just pass by, ignoring the possibility.

I open my window and the bees simply pass by. None of them found my office worth entering.

Perhaps someone else will want to come in here...
1252.title: fulfilling a lifelong dream

The chickens were getting ready to roost. The head rooster was giving the hens a boost. Up into the tree they would go one by one, then off to slumber dreaming about a lot of fun. As the rooster helped the hens one by one, the spiders thought about how to have their fun. They scurried around and never did frown. Some even wanted to journey into town. Go for it the head spider said, while we put all the young ones straight to bed. So off the group went to town, there was no time to monkey around.

As they passed a tree on their way they noticed a strange thing happening which they couldn't help but notice. The tree looked colorful and bright, even in this evening day light. Was this a christmas tree they wondered, then the idea thundered. it was colored with chickens they discovered so they changed their plans hoping some to recover.

As they stealthily climbed the tree, the rooster alarmed the hens. Flapping their wings and jumping for they lives, they flapped to the ground as adrenaline drives. Running for safety they cackled and squawked, while the rooster fought to save one hen who seemed apparently lost.

The spiders ganged up on this little her, then...

"Little spider, what would you like to make for the party?"

"I wanna have cookies and juice and maybe cupcakes!"

"Alright, but since it's your party you have to help make them."

"Alright Mama. I'll help you make it."

Mama spider began gathering the baking tools, and Little spider carried them to the kitchen. Then Mama spider got the recipe book and opened it.

"Cricket chip cookies," She read out loud, "First, we need five crickets. Can you get me five crickets, Little spider?"

"Yes Mama." He did.

"Can you get me some flour, Little spider?"

"Yes Mama." He did that too.

"Can you get me a little bit of egg, Little spider?"

"Yes Mama." He did that as well.

"Mama, may I stir it?" Little spider asked.

"Yes, you may. All we need is a little bit of sugar first, and then I'll let you stir it."

As I buttoned my levis while moving to the sink to wash my hands, I hollered at
Dick to see if he had managed to get the card table down from the Attic? Looking in the mirror,the face looking back at me seemed as puzzled as I was. Without my beard and ponytail I looked high school age, still wet behind the ears, definately
going to get carded!
What the hell was I thinking? When I was younger it would have been tequila to the black hole. Waking up two or three days later, where only God knew, while looking for clues through eyes so red if I kept them open, I would bleed to death. Stumbling to a mirror and sink, multi-tasking. Vomitting in the basin, looking up feeling I was AWOL from myself when the reflection returning my gaze was a total stranger. Someone else had cut my hair and shaved not only my beard but my eyebrows also!
If I had have crossed paths with the Barber of Seville, that day, it was a killin matter. Today, I would thank him for doing me one of the biggest favors anyone has ever done. That reflection, my reflection had an effect on me that to this day I still have not totally come to terms with. The force from that mirror death experience was comparable to being struck by lightening! In the twinkling of two bloodshot eyes I was a changed man. I didn't find out who I was till the next day when I found my wallet where the dog that had chewed it to pulp had almost finished burying it, planning a snack for a time to be announced. The miracle was the only piece that survived the action of Buster's hydrolic compactor with shredder and in pretty good nick considering was my driver's licence. Thank God it had a picture. I saw instantly why I hadn't recognized me! I had hair past my shoulder blades and a full beard, like Moses not Charlie Manson.
That was it for me. I was in Utah, two states from where the party started. My car was gone. I was only now beginning to fill in the missing pieces of the John Doe puzzle. I had no money and no friends and Big John Henry, the steel drivin
man, was laying track for the Union Pacific Railroad in my freakin head.
I've never been drunk since that horrific Houdidi (a disappearing act)! I can't even say the word, uuurgh, you know. What made me errased. Once I got my identity back, I found I also had friends in Utah and plenty of money in the bank.
Dick, who should have the table down by now, and I went to college together. Mark isn't here yet, it's early but he and the three girls that are coming at seven are alumnus also. 12531122.content:
There was mud, and cold. It was a country lane - a real country lane; no tarmac to be seen for at least a mile in any direction. Rocks jutted out of the dirt here and there, worn smooth by the tramping of hiking boots.

Jonathan stood in the glare of the headligh from the Police 4 by 4 parked close by, his breath as gouts of steam in the night air.

'Where's his clothes?' he asked.

'Dunno,' said Pete, crouched near the corpse and examining the dead man's muddy feet.

'Thought I saw a sock as we were driving up here, maybe he was leaving them like a trail of breadcrumbs or something. What's that round his wrist; a watch?'

'Don't think so,' replied Pete, prodding at the item with a ballpoint pen, 'looks like one of them medical bracelets you wear if your, like, diabetic or some such.'

Pete stood and stretched. Nearby, several more officers erected Police tape. Jonathan sauntered back to the 4 by 4 and looked that the odds and ends they'd bagged: a Banana (bruised), some sort of small bone with a piece of string tied around it and 16 Pencils.

The body had been found by a National Trust employee about a hour and a half ago. A fresh set of tire tracks led off the dirt track and across a nearby field towards woodland some half a mile away. There were no serious looking wounds on the body, although both of the eyes were bloodshot and congealed blood drew a hard red line across the side of the head originating from one of the ears.

All of the pencils were brand new with the exception of one, which was missing the lead and needed re-sharpening.
12531122.title: tire tracks

My Mother asked if I could give her a ride to Wal-Marts. She doesn't
drive, these days. It gives us an excuse to hang out with each other without
distraction. We're using Wal-Mart as a duck blind.
While people watching in the entryway I spotted something unusual. ( wal-Mart is unusual ) The greeter must have been just shy of eighty, still standing straight up and exhibiting the booming voice of an orator. He was discussing a sign hanging towards the parked cars in the entryway which was plain to see, you had to look for it though.
Curious, I repositioned closer to see and hear what was being talked about?
The sign was about the same size as an exit sign at a local movie house but the letters were askew or wrong. Here is their position. K-now Exit.
The person the greeter was speaking with had asked him what the sign meant?
I couldn't believe my ears when he with a strait face that it is the first of the new signs they are breaking in slowly so as not to shock the public when the transfer is complete. He went on to say that This sign had been converted. It used to say K-Mart Exit. The head office likes Now better then the archaic Mart. Mart being
redundant Now is replacing Mart. This is an exit sign. It will say K-Now Exit. The K-Mart signs outside and elsewhere will say K-Now now. They say this is good market sense. So from now on, K-Now, now.
She left satisfyed. Another asked," What is the meaning of that sign"? He explained she would be seeing a lot more hanging soon. The head office has done sturies and because of the hypen between the capital K and Now, it draws peoples attention to the word know and it places an impression in people's minds,
lmprints like a branding iron does to a cow, so in an emergency, they are herded to the exits robotically, they have been programed to already subliminaly to their locations through out every store. Your Safety first.
I went from this old greeter is a full blown looney to struck dumb. He was having fun and so was I. He did two more spins on the K-Now Exit sign before my mom finished her shopping and yanked me out of the store by my ear like I was
eight years old again! I wanted to see all the greeter had.
His next to last spoof was he convinced a shopper that the company that had made the sign mis spelled No! They were sorry and were working on the problem as we speak. In the meantime we still need our customers to know this K-now is No. When they really know K-Now is No, They'll know there's no exit. Did I make myself clear?
He saved the best for last when he explained that all the greeters in times of an emergency directed customer panic traffic. To stop panic and people being crushed by the weight of the people behind them all trying to squeeze through the same door at the same time. This sign, K-Now Exit, is a vertible life guard ring at your favorite pool. I am the life guard at the door. I look in people's eyes directly and when it is determined that it is safe, I say," K Now Exit." Brings tears to my eyes when I think of the human lives that will be saved! Happy shopping!
125312.title: K-now Exit

choices: Allison answers the question ( you fill in this blank)
Dale discovers a Biblical secret hidden all these years in plain sight
12532.content:
My name is Allison on the outside. I was ten yesterday but know I am far older than that. How do I know this or where did this thought possibly originate?
My brother Dale and I used to speak of infinite possibillities before he was sent to a private school as I was also, here. Dale and I knew we were different. Not just from our parents and our relatives but also from the friends that we made as we started meeting and making them from kindergarten on. They didn't see or question ideas, the world, as seen through our eyes. The only way Dale and I came to this understanding was by us questioning and answering each other as curious children. This curiousity seemed to be lacking or of no importance to most adults and if not in them than even more rare in their children?
Dale is older than me by two minutes. He calls himself, " The Ancient One"! We, when we were younger, came up with a conceptualization that we were at least two beings. We both had an outward self and an INNER self. We weren't sure if there were more but we were sure that not just us but everyone had these two characters within and without. We figured the inner self couldn't lie to itself because it knew the truth or what stood in for it. But the outer self could tell a teacher or a mom or dad a fib. A white lie! A fabrication or a shuffle the deck of cards imaginitory, inventive and extremely creative lie to protect knuckles or butt from corporal punishment that existed before the days of political correctness!
So while my brother and I were discussing stars in the sky, the Sun and Moon, time and distance and light, and capital God, our friends were breaking into houses, stealing coins out of the church money basket and spending no time wondering if their life would have any signifigance or be meaningful to anyone but themselves?
Dale and I know the reason we are in private school. Our combined inner self was far to hard for our parents and friends to bare. Thinkers think. Their questions strike home. When shallow people aren't shallow but have chosen the path of least resistance they can't hear a Noam Chomski, Alan Watts, Aldous Huxley, Hermanne Hesse, or even their own conscience?
Dale and I are fourteen now. He just sent me a letter with a great insight. Thought provoking. " Allison, isn't it interesting when your inner self asks a question and your outer self handily answers?" "I believe when this comes about the two that were seperate are now one." "Can you see this?" Your brother in Spirit and Blood, Dale
12532.title: inner

13.content:
I'm not sure what she's seeking
but she waits
there on the side of
a deserted road.

"No one comes,
no one goes," I tell her.
She smiles up at me
there's a gap where
her front teeth should be.

"No one comes ..."
I repeat, and she whispers
"I know. And no one goes."

"Then why
do you wait here? For what?"

"I don't know," she says, softly.

"Come along then," I'm
brusque now, impatient.

"I don't know now.
But I will when
it happens."
And she won't move.

She waits
there on the side of
a deserted road.

And my heart waits
with her.
13.title: On the Side of a Deserted Road

choices: Night comes on that deserted road
131.content:
Let her be, I think to myself as I walk away, down that deserted road. My chest has grown cold, my soul already misses my heart. I glanced back at her, her toothless daze sees me and she smiles. Sanity didn"t come out today, and the gods were having a wonderful time in our earthly playground. She is hunted, and everything that is hunted eventually is caught. The devil in sheep's clothing.

I know the unknown. See the shadows move. Heard the moans of those who hunger. Look and seen the eyes of darkness stare into me. She cannot fathom what she will be when she is caught, what fate has written for her. Let her be, I think, my heart in her hands, on that deserted road.
131.title: My heart waits with her

1311.content:
We lost ourselves somewhere on this journey. The darkness settled, silence falling slowly between us as we listened to the night sounds that sent shivers down our backs. Slowly, our fingers unwound, our eyes so focused on fighting to see around us that we don't notice. So focused on our fears that we forget we aren't alone.

Hands fall away, your warmth leaves my side. I turn to you, struggling to see you as you fade from me. A sharp pain seems to go through me when I realize, I can't feel you. The moonless night crowds even closer to me and I clutch at myself, frantic, desperate.

"Where are you?" I scream into the night. The crickets still, then resume.

I stand alone in the darkness, shivering, feeling the emptiness, the pain. I cannot move, left to hold onto anything of you that I can. Even if all I have of you is your loss...
1311.title: Night comes on that deserted road

choices: I Never Thought To See Her Again
13111.content:
Because Night has come - a cold, harsh mistress that envelopes me in her arms. I cannot feel my heart anymore, as I left it long ago on this road. I cannot feel my hands or my feet, cannot move as Night holds me close to her bosom.

In the cricket song, I hear another sound. Dragging, wet, clomping through the darkness. A stench assaults me such that I hold my breath against the intrusion. I find my hands again, and hold them over my mouth.

What Slayer has Night brought me to trouble me? Is not the loss of my heart, of my love, enough to satisfy her?

The sounds and smells move away from me. I wait to breath deeply. I wait to see if Night wishes me worse.

I do not have to wait long.
13111.title: Slayer

choices: Is my beloved returning to me?
131111.content:
Even within the grip of the Mistress of The Darkness, I felt more protected, then I do now, just a short time later. The wind begins to kick up around me, swirling to twist itself around me, and hold me captive too.

Upon the eerie sound of the twisting mass of cold, moist air, I hear what sounds to me, like a song. I struggle to hear the intimate words of the frightening song, meant only for me. It begins as a chant like whisper, the steadily grows in volume.

Is it a warning or a threat? I now hear it as clear as day. It sings to me that "Death Walks Among Us". I try to understand the rest of the lyrics, but they die away, as suddenly as they came to me. I shiver, and hope I will live to see the light of day.
131111.title: Death Walks Among Us

Different wish, now. I wish for this ball to disappear. Forever.

choices: "Would you be an outlaw for my love?"
131121.content:
The autumn of 1985 he drove his Trans Am all over town, Big Star and Richard Thompson in constant rotation on his tape deck. He listened to "Thirteen" and "Did She Jump Was She Pushed" about one million times. He drove past the streetside bar, Bunce's, and past the army surpulus store. He always ended up on the ridge, standing beside the shopping center and watching the highway. He couldn't break away.
         He was scared to turn on the radio. The one time he did, they were playing the Replacements and he slammed his fist into the buttons until "Androgynous" died. He didn't want to think about it, but when the melancholy piano part hit his ears he saw them back on the roof on that June night. Michael singing along with the record player, head back, white teeth flashing, hair falling in his face in clear, scissor-edged strands. It was in black and white. It was never going away.
         The summer had been sweaty, hotter than any other he could remember. When you said the word "heat" in that humid air it shaped itself softly between your lips and the sound of the thing was the whole of the thing. When you said "heat" you thought of the brush of Michael's arm against yours and the swinging bassline of "Spirit in the Night" coming from the house next door, and then tried not to. It was October now. Richard Thompson's doom was easier to bear than the sweetness of Alex Chilton's love song, or Bruce Springsteen's aching howl.
131121.title: Thirteen

131122.content: I wait for him to come out. He has a board and some pieces with him. He set up the board and then we play. It a game of chess and I am winning. At least I hope I win at the end. You never can tell in a game of chess. Some times the checkmates come before you know it.

13113.content:
Two hours before midnight,
The shadows before me are ghostlike.
Alone,
All alone,
Lonely as a cloud
I can hear the silence shout.
'Only when it is dark enough can you see the stars'
But these blurs I perceive on the skies are scars,
Of memories broken,
Of a love unspoken,
Of the bloodshed of children
Screaming veangance from the tomb-bed.
Where are you when I call?
Would you fold your hands when I fall?
Nightfalls in heaven.
10PM
Is two hours too late to pretend.
13113.title: 10 PM

131131.content:
Have you read 'Paradise Lost'?
Dug deep into the details of the consequences?
Enslaved by lethal repercussions,
The race of man is haunted by Nemesis.
Cupid's bow is broken.
And the deluge are the tears of his eyes.
A bigger gamble than a game of dice.
Night has fallen on our Eden.
Darkness veils the portals of heaven.
Here we stand on our deserted road
Retracing our step in mental strides
Love got a travelling bag and hit the road.
Now we face each other agony tearing our hearts,
'Cause we forgot how to say NO.
We numbed our souls
By the compromise of silence,
Our parting is a product of blindness.
We called it even-steven
This nightfall in heaven.
131131.title: Nightfall in heaven

1311311.content:
Still on that road,
Still in the rain.
Still deserted - I feel the toll.
Still the nightfall will explain.I see affection dimly,
Like staring through a frosted window.
Still trying in vain to interprete the dream,
To pre-empt the oracle,
To reach a new beginning;
A utopic pinnacle.
The ghosts of childhood
Arise, a cloud of warriors
And invent a chasm between us two,
A forcefield of passion separates us;
I seek a love unknown,
And you a fiery affection.
Two unreconciled strivings
In the hurricane of our passionate conniving.
Climax has arrived at its resolution.
Time is frozen,
A notion of honor
To our passionately loveless coven.
Still our love remains fallow,
Our pasts, still on that road.
1311311.title: Still on that road

13113111.content:
"Good to hear your voice again, Steve! What's it been, two years?"

"Probably closer to three, Doc."

"If I remember correctly, back then you were planning on taking an early retirement option in a few years to get away from your stressful job, leaving the city for a simpler life in the country. You bought an old farm house you were going to restore, plant a big garden to grow your own vegetables."

"Yeah, that's right, and I finally did it, left work and moved there two months ago."

"So let me guess, you're having a little trouble adjusting."

"Yeah. I guess after working the same place for thirty years, much as I couldn't wait to leave, I really feel kinda lost now. I know we have a lot of work to do on this house, but some days I get up and I just can't do anything. And on other days I feel this intense anxiety, wondering if I wouldn't have been better off working a couple more years, especially when I see what's happening with my 401K investments with this latest market crash."

"Steve, do you remember the exercises on developing a personal philosophy we did in our sessions a few years ago? See if you can pick something from that to draw strength from."

"Yeah, I know what you're thinking. The one where I was complaining about someone I knew who didn't have a strong sense of personal responsibility. I was bragging about how that was one of my strengths. Always accepting the consequences for my decisions right or wrong, taking action and moving on."

"There you go Steve, problem solved!"

"Yeah, right. I love your sarcasm Doc, I really do."

"OK Steve, but seriously, maybe the realization that it's not always easy practice what you preach will allow you have more empathy towards others. Life may be teaching you a lesson here. And you know deep down you do have the ability to adjust and move on, you've done it before."

"Yeah Doc, I suppose you're right."

"And I know you've refused them before Steve, but I can give you a prescription for some antidepressants to help you adjust..."
13113111.title: Lost

13113112.content:
"Somewhere on a desert highway, she rides a Harley-Davidson, her long blonde hair flyin` in the wind...
She`s been runnin` half her life, the chrome and steel she rides, colliding with the very air she breathes..."
Neil Young - "Unknown Legend"

"So, what's a nice guy like you doin' in a place like this?"

"I was on my way to my sister's place in Florida, see if she could help me find work. My bike broke down and I can't afford to fix it. My credit card's maxed out, got no job, so here I am! You guys need a breakfast cook? Just temporary, you know, just need to make a few bucks so I can get parts to fix my ride..."

"I don't know, I'm just a waitress here, you'll have to talk to the boss. He's gone for the day, though. He'll be back to open up the place around six tomorrow morning..."

"You know anywhere around here where I can set up camp until I can get back on the road? I got a tent and sleeping bag with my bike..."

"Ain't no campgrounds around here, just cactus and dirt... hmmm....do you know how to fix a swamp cooler, or a leaky roof on a double-wide?"

"Ma'am, you are looking at the finest mobile home repairman in the western United States!"

"Well, then I guess I can make you a deal. You can set up camp in my yard in exchange for repairs, and I might throw in a couple free meals, if you do good work..."

"Lady, my customers are always satisfied!"

"Listen, buddy, I ain't interested in hookin' up with no road trash, this is strictly business. You fix my place, you get a place to stay, nothing more. You try anything else, I got friends in this town that'll make you regret it, understand?"

"OK, lady, I got it, you got a deal. But you can't blame me for trying. You ain't bad lookin' for a woman your age, and I'm guessing you've seen near as much of life as I have..."
13113112.title: Deserted

1311312.content:
Something destroying me.
Clawing its way out.
Self-consuming apathy,
Manifesting in self-doubt.

I want to let it all go;
I want to not care.
I want to be nothing,
Never expected to be there.

“Give it up”
So tempting
“Just give up”
Close to accepting

The only real way out
I know
Would be the end;
A fatal blow.

I am so very tired,
So much effort spent.
To the soft lovely voice,
I may soon relent.

Something destroying me.
Clawing from within.
Self-consuming apathy.
Let the letting begin.
1311312.title: Destroying Me

13113121.content:
The ocean
My comfort
Never do I want
For support

Her kind voice
Sung me to sleep
When I lacked human arms
In which I could weep.

Always a constant
But constantly in change
Our close kinship
Perhaps preordained.

I strive to be like her
Beautiful and strong
But perhaps simply on her waves
Is where I belong.

This her wish for me,
I take up and sail
My love for her
The only thing to prevail.

Such a bond
Built of admiration and respect
Is more than most
Do expect.

Never understanding
Never comprehending
How such a thing could really “Care”
But I assure you, friend, for me she’s always been there.
13113121.title: By Sea

131131211.content:
I don’t remember how I got here but I know I like it. We’re in a field and the trees are bursting with their best fall colors. Picking up a leaf that held a bright red color, I show her and she was delighted.
“Oh how pretty!” She gushes as she takes it from me it from me. Folding it neatly into her wallet she puts it in her back pocket.
I know I blush as she takes my hand in hers, hers far colder but soft and gentle. We talk of nothing because what subject could really matter when we’re both so lost in this happiness?
The sun begins to set on us, silly orb knowing that she can light my day better than it could ever hope to try. But in its absence she grows a bit chilled, the autumn air only holding its warm breeze in sunlight. But neither of us bother considering that we should head back, that would be a waste of an evening, so I slip off my sweater without a sound and wrap it around her. She looks cute in gray even though she doesn’t like it.
We come to a ridge overlooking the field we were just in with a glorious view of the stars and she sits down, pulling me down beside her. Leaning into me, I can’t see her face but I know almost certainly that she’s smiling. I wrap my arms around her.
She whispers, as if not to disturb the peace and pure zen that surrounds us, that she loves me. Was I growing a bit cold before that? It matters not, I’m filled with a warmth I’d never known before her.
I hold her close to me, my only wish to never let her go. I’m struck, however, by the fact that I must. With an almost inhuman certainty I know that our time is painfully finite. I don’t know why but I cry soundlessly, silent tears finding their ways over my cheeks to sprinkle her gorgeous blonde hair. “I love you too, Mari.” It will only come as a whisper.
She can tell there’s something wrong in my voice; that I’m upset so she leans away slightly to look me in the eye. And as her blue eyes meet mine I know what’s wrong. Only in my dreams would things feel so perfect. The world won’t let us be like this.
I have to tell her however I can, even if it’s only a dream, “I’ll always love you Mari. Please never forget that.”
I can feel reality coming back as she becomes less and less subsistent in my arms.
I wake alone, tears covering my face, with nothing but the music I’m listening to for company.
The snow outside spins happily, mocking me. It’s covered over all of our bright red leaves.
131131211.title: Pretty Red Leaves

1311312111.content:
Her dark hair was laid neatly around her peaceful face, her delicate hands, so often joined with my own, were folded elegantly over her lap. Her eyes were closed and her chest... Still... It was a lovely service.
But I was filled with disgust and anguish regardless. She looked all wrong, my beautiful Olivia. her hair as never neat, not even for church. In fact, it was usually full of braids, or some other decoration. Her face was never, ever, peaceful. She usually ranged from fury without rival to the inquisitive look of a million questions. My favorite was her look of pure, unbridled joy. And her hands... They belonged fiddeling with something of writing or... Interlaced with my own...
Regardless, I spoke at the ceremony. Her mother cringed, never quite approving and now she lacked any reason to pretend otherwise. I sat through the other speakers, as it ran through my head how much better I knew her than them. I'd seen each and every one of them distance themselves as she deteriorated. They did anything to get away and save themselves the heartbreak. But not me. As I reflected, my mind naturally went back to the evening I found out. I looked up at the dried little sprig I'd brought her laying in her casket. She would've liked that.

-------------------------

It was months ago, late spring I think. We were out for a walk because all the trees were heavy with their beautiful little blossoms she loved so much.She lead me to the park and we sat by our tree, the one that still bares our initials, holding each other in bliss.
But something was bothering her, I could feel the tension in her skin. I finally nudged her and kissed her on the top of the head. "What's wrong lovey?"
She sighed deeply and I felt her push back against me, looking for comfort. "I'm sick Kate." She stated simply. The statement hung heavily on the air. On some level, I could tell that it was something serious, I just wouldn't admit it to myself. I simply assumed she had a cold and everything would be just fine. I still feel so bloody stupid.
"Well then lets get you home hun, why on earth did you decide to come on a walk with me?" I laughed quietly and moved to help her up before she put her hand on my arm, finally catching my eye. I saw the tears in her eyes and my heart sank into my feet.
"No, not that kind of sick baby..." She pulled me back down to her and buried her head in my chest. I could feel the spots of moisture through my shirt. "I needed to see the blossoms with you again this year because I may not be around for them next year." Her voice was still so flat and acceptant. It terrified me.
Tears pricked at my own eyes as I struggled for composure. She needed my strength, and I'm thankful that I maintained the presence of mind to realize that. She told me the specifics, what it was exactly, how it worked... She's apparently inherited it from her father, who'd died five years earlier.
Once she'd told me the lot, I just held her, my breathing forced into a steady rhythmic pace to comfort her but I wanted so badly to just break down. I wanted to scream. I wanted god himself to present himself to me and explain exactly how he justified taking my everything away from me like this. I cursed the world because without her it would become the very picture of empty, sad oblivion.
But my anger wasn't what she needed. Her life hadn't been easy but I resolved in that moment, even if it killed me, that I would make what she had left amazing. I tilted her chin to look up at me and I kissed her forehead gently. I'd done it a million times and the sensation was so much... More... When I realized that I had a finite time remaining.
"No more of this, beautiful. No more crying." I took her now cold, still hand in mine and held it tight. "I promise to cry plenty for the both of us when the time comes but what's the point of the time you have left if you spend it sad?"
I wiped her face and showed her my makeup-darkened hand. "I mean look at this. Do you want to be remembered as a mess?" I forced a mocking grin, hoping it was at least close to my usual standard of teasing expressions. I kissed her deeply and it was a comfort to feel her lips form a smile against mine.
"You're right, I'm sorry." she hugged me tightly and I felt her reign in her own sadness to calm herself. She put her hands in mine, where they so clearly belonged and pulled me to standing.
She didn't say a word as she lead me to the clearing. She didn't have to. We had so many memories, and even if we weren't going to be making anymore, I knew exactly what we were doing. For year now, we'd always, at least once, danced under the spring blossoms, savoring their beauty and each other. It began slowly, both of us holding the other, each moving to the internal music that we shared by some miracle. Thankfully, there was no thought. There was no future, there was no past. There was only this momentary feeling, our wholeness found together, our consuming love.
Slowly though, we sped up, each caught up in the power our bond gave us. The pastel flowers became a blur behind her face as we began to spin, laughing and smiling. Her hair was freckled with the fallen petals and I swear for all the world that she'd never been more beautiful to me than in that moment. It was most likely that smile. She'd truly forgotten, in that moment anyway. It was that look of joy I mentioned. That look I willy probibly spend the rest of my life missing.
Dizzy and breathless, we collapsed, falling against some tall grass. A content glow hung around us and she was entirely free of her tension. I held her tight to me, savoring the way she felt in my arms, so full of life, and she smell of her hair. But I felt it come back to her, slowly, like a heavy cloud and there was nothing I could do about it.
"Kate?" She looked up at me, thankfully free of tears.
"Yes Olive?" I kissed her forehead again, trying my damnedest to ignore the stormcloud that still hung.
She smiled at the use of her nickname but it looked bittersweet. "I understand if you want to bail out." Her voice was soft but sure.
I was speechless for a moment, my mind blank. "You're crazy," I finally managed. "Olivia- I love you with all that I am. And every day you have left on this earth, I intend to spend with you. Whether that means tomorrow or fifty years from now, I'll be there." I kissed her again "You're my whole world baby."
She simply nodded and buried her head in my chest again.

------

It's been a few months since then. I watched her become frail and I kept her spirits up as best I could. Thankfully, there were more good days than bad. She never saw a day without smiling, I made sure of that.
But the day came eventually. I'd held out hope right up until that point, in the hospital, holding her hand... That now so still hand... Five days ago. But it's ok baby. You can't come see the blossoms with me next year but at least a handful will go with you, ours forever.
I'm still waiting for that explaination god. Because what I wouldn't give to have that dance back. Just one more time.
1311312111.title: Spring (A Dying Spring)

1311312112.title: Dream

131131212.content:
My life sucks, big time.

I know I shouldn't complain, I make good money for what I do.
I'm a mail clerk for a big aerospace company in southern California.

But it sucks that I'm forty years old and I've never been laid, and I still live in a condo with my mother.
And it sucks that I'm a woman...

If I were a lesbian or a man I'd at least have a chance, looks aren't as important. A hard-working plain-looking man or a dyke with a few bucks in the bank wouldn't have any trouble finding a halfway decent woman.

But an ugly straight woman is screwed...

My momma wasn't no looker, and from what she's told me my dad weren't no prince charming neither.
The guys at work walk past me in the hall and avoid looking at me like I was some homeless street person.

The only one who looks at me and smiles is the fat cross-eyed second-shift Mexican security guard who gets into work when I'm leaving. I could chase him, he might be my only chance. We could eventually get married and have some kids even uglier than me!

My life sucks...
131131212.title: Abhorrence

13113122.content:
By night I feel them swarm around
But by day not even a sound.

Their presence heavy in the air,
Trap me with an evil glare.

I beg for mercy as I lay
In bed, closed eyes to God I pray.

"Please protect my soul tonight.
Relieve me of this awful fright."

To sleep, I fall for final rest.
My spirit on a renewed quest.

May I be guided to the light,
For peace, I will find by night.
13113122.title: By Night

131131222.content:
"What the ..." Ernie didn't know whether he'd spoken aloud or not. How could he, with those drums beating out from the speakers?? Speakers that hadn't been there the last time he visited Tiny's Tavern. He caught his breath as his eyes adjusted to the dimness and he glanced at the stage. A woman wearing a pink bikini with fringe around the bottom half gyrated enthusiastically, if not in tempo with the "music."

He slid onto his usual stool at the end of the bar. At least <i>that</i> hadn't changed. Tiny's Tavern only had six tables. Men sat at four of them, in parties of two to five. Ernie recognized a couple of them. He waved, but their eyes were glued to the stage. A fourth table was occupied by a young couple sitting very close together. Ernie squinted, then looked away. The girl was giving her companion a hand job!

"Heya, stranger, where ya been?" Tiny yelled from behind the bar. Tiny didn't like being called Tiny, but Ernie figured the regulars were doing him a favor - His real name was Ambrose.

Ernie turned. "Tiny, what's going on here? I go away for two weeks and come back to ... <i>This</i>." He raised his voice to make sure the barman heard.

"Ya like it?? I went into hock to buy this stereo and hire the girls, but it's working, and <b>quickly</b>."

"Tiny, this is all wrong. You had a decent neighborhood tavern here where we we could drop in and shoot the bull. Now the only thing I'd like to shoot is that amp."

"I'm here alone till I can hire another bartender," said Tiny. "You wanna beer or not."

"Yeah, yeah." Ernie shoved a tenner across the bar.

Tiny brought a draft then ran off to fill a pitcher for three men who were obviously enjoying themselves hugely. One of them yelled an explicit suggestion at the dancer. She must have heard him, even over the music, but didn't react.

Ernie sipped his beer sadly. Why did everything have to change?? Maybe he was just getting old. This wasn't his scene, but what could he do?? It was the only tavern within walking distance, and he sure wouldn't risk driving after a few beers. What to do?? Join in the spirit of the new Tiny's or do his drinking at home, where he'd slowly turn into a bitter, lonely old alcoholic??
131131222.title: Quickly

1311321.content:
"...every time I hear a growl I'll know the tiger's on the prowl, and I'll be really safe, you know, the elephant he told me so..."

1311321.title: Speak to Me

13113212.content:
I'm falling. Falling from the black, midnight sky. There is lightning all around me, but it doesn't hit me. Why? Is the monster, that bug eyed, evil, grim reaper whom I can't seem to face properly, toying with me? Am I dead or not? Give me an answer!

But everything goes dark for a few minutes after I feel my body, bumping very hard into something.

The next thing, I feel, is a warm, soothing hand on my forehead, which occasionally dabs small amounts of cold water on it. Very slowly, I start to regain consciousness again. Then, my vision becomes less blurry as well. I can see the contours of a person. The width of the head, I can make out now, tells me that there is a lot of long hair. Long, brown hair without curls. I look at it for a few seconds, during which I notice the intensity of the total silence that is painted on a beautiful canvas of stars.

"The desert is one of the best places to look at stars, you know?", the person whose soft hand is still on my forehead says.

I lift my head up a little, tilt it forward and have a look around. It seems to be true. I am in a desert, and the person with the long, brown, non-curly hair on their head seems to be a girl who is solicitously crouching on her knees to watch over me. She brushes my forehead again and dabs some more water on it.

"Where are we?", I ask, while I wonder, if this is the same girl as before.

"I don't know." She replies. "But I am still holding your heart."

"It feels like, I have been asleep for a very long time." I say.

The girl chuckles.

"I dreamt about angels... I dreamt about being a rock star... But for the life of me, I can't figure out why?", I continue.

"Does it matter?", the girl asks.

"Well, no... Or yes, I guess. I mean, dreams are just a reflection of our subconscious mind. They are just situations and circumstances that we wish could happen in real life... Except for nightmares, of course. But then again, how do we differentiate dream and nightmares? How do we know, when a dream stops and a nightmare starts?", I say, pondering my thoughts out loud to the girl. "And when you add alcohol or drugs to the mix, as I am sure, we must have done tonight, since we ended up here, the dreams and nightmares become even more vivid, or does that just happen to reality, while the sleep gets disturbed? I mean, I know that alcohol lowers the quality of sleep, but tonight seems to have been so much worse than that."

I pause for a minute. Total silence.

"Yeah...", the girls suddenly says. "...Looks like our minds have been quite obscured by clouds tonight."

"What does that mean?", I ask her.

"I don't know...", she responds. "... Just that you sometimes can't see your own existence amongst all the clutter of distractions in the world. And then you kinda forget to search your emotions to know, how you feel about yourself."

"Hm, I guess you're right." I stipulate. "You know, what the ironic thing is, though?"

"No."

"Out here there are no distractions from life. From our own existence. Yet, out here, death is most likely awaiting us. But of course, not before the monster of the universe lets us experience some of the good old pain and suffering, because instant death is too kind of a way out."

"That's dark." She says, a bit shocked. "But hey, at least we aren't alone after all."

She runs her hand through my hair, as if she was petting me. I counter by sitting up straight and putting my arms around her to keep her warm from cold desert air.

We just sit like that for a few minutes, until I notice a couple of branches and a rock on the ground.

"You know? We could try to light a fire with that." I suggest. "Would be nice to do something to keep busy at least, until the monster gets us. What do you say?"

"Well, it's just as good as waiting for a vehicle to show up on that road." She nods mockingly at the deserted road behind us. "Whether it is a lonely Land Rover or a crazy Lamborghini owner who has confused themselves into this part of the world, both scenarios sound equally unlikely to happen."
13113212.title: Obscured by Clouds

Behind him someone dropped to there knees and began to gag. Zander Nox ignored them, his eyes searching the horizon.
"Zander, the chances that she still alive....its..."
"I told her i would come back! I PROMISED!" the stress of the last few hours were catching up to him.
He looked around again, his movements reminding the group of a crazed beast. He spotted it, a golden sphere of light. With amazing speed to took off, jumping over mounds of bodies.

She leaned, doubled over, never to her swords. She had long since lost the use of her eyes, but she could still hear the approach of her enemy. She mustered the little energy she had left and garbed her swords. She twirled around trusted the swords forward. They were tugged from hands, causing her to lose her balance. She stumbled forward, but she refuse to go down without a fight. She summoned the magic that the dragons had taught her, careful not to draw from the golden sphere, and prepared for her last assault.
Saiya! Its me, Saiya!" his voice was like the raising sun in this eternal land of darkness. She had fought for the last twelve hours so that she could hear that voice.

Zander caught Saiya as she fell. He didn't need to have a healer to know that he was to late.
"I'm sorry! So sorry. I tried.." his words were choked off as tears streamed down his face, "Please don't leave me! I can't lose anyone else!"
He jumped a little as her hand touched onto his cheek.
"You would of never lost anyone if it wasn't for me. I killed Zinder and Riku gave her life for me. The Nox family only dies around me."
"You fool, i stopped blaming you for those a long time ago. I love you Saiya, I've always have."
Saiya faintly smiled. She didn't have long. She was barely aware of the rest of the group arriving.
"Blake, is there anything you can do?!!"
Saiya felt the warmth of her brother's healing magic, she felt it center around her eyes. "All i can do is let her see you one last time."
Saiya looked up into a face she knew so well. A pale face, thin face framed by straight black hair. Eyes that glowed red with the cruse of demons. A face she would miss. For the frist time in many years she felt tears fall from her eyes.
"Zander..."
HIs face had been turned away, looking at Blake with a pleading look. As he looked at her she let out a small gasp. There was a change.
"Zander, your eyes..their blue?"
Zander couldn't help but laugh. Smiling through his tears he kissed her forehead.
"Marcus discover, before he died, that love conquers any cruse."

131132212.title: Smiling through tears

1311322122.content:
"No," he whimpered. The sinking feeling in his chest made it feel as though he were hurtling through a sinkhole, the quagmire encasing his body in a tomb of mud. "No...." Without hesitation, he cradled her in his arms, trying to recall a time when she had lived, when she had been his childhood confidante, his youthful lover, his beloved wife, the mother of his young children. '"Had been"? "Was"?' he pondered, only crossing his mind for a moment. Then, after its fleeting, light tap, he resolved, 'Is. She is.'
         She lay still, empty emerald eyes staring upwards into oblivion. Taking her slender hands, he pressed each blessed finger to his lips. Nothing. The guilt was overwhelming as he studied each of her stunning features, and a lump rose in his throat. The eyes, so deep a green, had lost their enchanting, lively sparkle, the joie de vivre that had brightened his own life every time she lifted her clear voice in song, or even whispered in his ear with the brogue accent indicative of her previous home. Touching her creamy skin, he instantly missed the soft, rosy glow emanating from her cheeks and the broad spread of her full lips as they turned up at the edges, revealing perfectly white teeth. The silky, raven black hair did not sway temptingly about the soft lightness of her pleasant face; it was marred by the dark, crustily dried blood spreading out from her neck and head. No sweet dimples dotted her face. Even her pert nose seemed pinched at the edges, a disturbingly pink froth bubbling on her dry lips.
         Absolutely nothing.
         “M-my God.”
         The tears burning his throat let loose as a moaning sob escaped his lips. Tentatively, he touched her lips first with his fingers and then with his own, hoping for a response, for soft, giggling laughter or her slender fingers running through his hair. Nothing. Cold guilt icily coated his insides while the hot grief streaked down his face, but there was no answer, no response, no life left in her dear body.
         “Goodbye,” she seemed to whisper as he tightened his arms about her, venturing to lay a final kiss of farewell on her dead lips. “Goodbye, darling.”
         Burying his face into her graceful neck, the gentle scent of roses, ruined by the metallic odor of blood, brought the proceedings full-circle. Gone. She really was gone. Nothing.
         And so he wept.
1311322122.title: Death's Embrace

13123.content:
She lie awake in bed, staring at the clock radio. 1:15 and still no sign of him, he'd be coming home drunk again...

A few minutes later she heard him fumbling with the lock. The door opened and slammed shut as she hurried towards the kitchen.
"Where's my supper, Bitch!" he hollered.

"I'm sorry Billy, I had to put it in the fridge so it wouldn't spoil. I can heat it up for you if you..."

"Shut up! Just shut the fuck up! You know I expect my supper waiting for me when I get home!"

"But Billy, I didn't know when you'd be..."

"I've had enough of your shit, Gloria! Give me one good reason I shouldn't just kill you right now!"

"Billy please! Put the gun away! Sit down and relax, I'll get you a beer then I'll fix your dinner,OK?"

Billy staggered over to his favorite recliner and sat down, still holding the gun, while Gloria hurried into the kitchen to get his beer.

"Here you go Billy, ice cold just how you like it."

"Alright Gloria, but don't think you're gonna get away that easy, I'm still gonna have to punish you for not respectin' me. Now go fix my dinner, Bitch!"

Gloria thought about what was ahead for her as she warmed up his dinner. The beatings had gotten worse, and now he was threatening her with a gun. Was it possible he might actually kill her the next time?

A few minutes later Gloria walked back into the living room. Billy was snoring loudly, lying back in his chair, the gun had fallen to the floor.

She walked back into the kitchen and put on her rubber dish gloves, then walked back into the living room.

She picked the gun and pointed it to the side of his head and pulled the trigger. Billy grunted softly in his sleep, then stopped breathing.

She placed the gun in his hand, his finger around the trigger, then walked back into the kitchen.

She washed the gloves carefully, then placed them in the basin with the cleaning supplies under the sink

She dried her hands on the dish towel, then dialed 911.
13123.title: She decided not to wait and find out

131231.content:
Everyday during summer, Randy's mom would drop us off at the public library to read books and pick us up a few hours later. He asked me to come along. No way, I told him. I'm not going to spend my summer reading boring books when I can have my own adventures. But he told me we would leave the library as soon as his mom drove off and explore the area.

I was really excited. I wasn't allowed to play far from my house. The chance to explore the city center was too good to be true. My mom was happy that Randy was being a good influence on me and agreed to let me go along.

That day, we decided to explore an abandoned building right behind the library. The entrances were boarded up but even the boards were old so we just kicked them in and walked around. The first floor was one large open space so we went up the stairs to the second floor.

We stood in a dark corridor that seemed to have no end. I was a little scared, and I think Randy was too, because neither one of us moved nor looked at each other. If I looked at him, I'd have to start walking or he'll make fun of me, so I bent down pretending I was tying my shoes.

"Hurry up," I heard him say. I could tell from the tone of his voice that hurrying up was the last thing he wanted me to do. "Cole..."

"Yeah, alright! Hold your horses."

"Cole...I think there's something here," he whispered. My heart stopped the moment I heard those words. I was afraid to lift my head but I quickly shot up and looked around. Randy was frozen in place. I couldn't see anything, but what was that noise? Where is it coming from? I turned around to go back down the stairs.

The next sound I head was a scream that still haunts my dreams to this day. I knew it was coming from Randy. I looked back. A dark figure stood looking over me. I couldn't see him properly but his smell was pungent. He took a step towards me, and I could hear his heavy breathing.

"Cole! Run!" In a moment of panic, I ran towards Randy instead of escaping down the stairs. We tried to run around the man but he just stood there like a tree, blocking the exit.

"Push him Cole!" Randy yelled. I didn't want to, but I didn't have time to think. I put all my strength into my two arms and pushed the man down the stairs. He took a tumble, his large, dirty coat flying over his head.

He hit the bottom with a loud thud. We ran down behind him, stopping only for a second to look at his body as we flashed past him to the bottom of the stairs and out the building.

The strange angle at which his neck was snapped is burned into my eyelids.

------------

We waited in silence on the stairs outside the library for a lifetime. When Randy's mom finally appeared, we got into the car and sat silently. His mom chattered on, asking us about what books we read, and something about ice-cream? I don't know, all I could think about was how we were getting away with murder.
131231.title: Getting Away With Murder

132111.content:
I think it's pretty safe to say that you haven't lived until you've heard a gymful of high school kids singing "Don't Stop Believin'".
         What? You don't believe me?
         Picture yourself in your local Elks Lodge-- sprung floor, disco ball, institutional plastic tables lined up along the sides, lights down. Picture it a late August evening, muggy, the windows open. They'd be letting in the sound of crickets and ice-cream trucks if anyone could hear anything over Neal Schon's guitar and the howled singing. It's 'That Seventies Dance', so you're wearing thrift-store bellbottoms, which chafe a little, but you don't care, because you've been swept into the middle of the floor, your compatriots swirling around you as you all sing along, rising and falling with your overdramatic gestures.
         Nobody's mocking it. There's a quasi-religious fervor to it-- tribal rite of a Friday night. You all, wild struggling you things that you are, know that you'll need it. You're already living just to find emotion, or living in spite of the ridiculous emotions your generate. You want to know that you'll always, always have it-- the fever that draws you into the middle of the swarm, the wave rising toward the disco ball, falling-dancing clumsy against other sweaty bodies.
          You're probably wrong. The world of streetlights and loner-lover-losers walking under them in glamour doesn't exist. But you need to tell yourself that it does. Otherwise, why grow up?
         You promise, then, as the harmony soars and your cracking voices follow in dissonant desperation, that you'll hold onto that feeling. Regardless of the cost. And you're sure that years later you'll give anything for another dance, another rapture like this.
132111.title: Don't Stop Believing

1321112.content:
We are difficult to categorize, him and I-- we have run the gamut from childhood antagonists to middle-schoolers just learning to flirt to enemies to what we are now. And it's what we are now that confuses so many: they think Man + Woman only ever means one thing, as fixed a fact as 2 + 2. It's widely assumed that we are together-- when I touch his wrist like that and whisper in his ear, what else can it mean? Little do they know that I'm whispering an in-joke to him. Teachers have assumed that we are together, asking friends discreetly (but not discreetly enough) behind our backs. One one memorable occasion, a classmate even asked him if we were having sex, having mistaken intimacy born of many years for physical intimacy. We really laughed at that one, albeit in an uncomfortable way.

         We're friends. If this were a romantic comedy or a sitcom, we'd get together, after our years of swearing up and down that we weren't. But this is real life--we are what we are, complementary angles fitting together to make a whole, opposite and equal. Partners in crime, a dream team. We love each other, and we make each other whole. But it's sad that no one today believes me when I say that if we were boyfriend and girlfriend, we wouldn't be as close.
1321112.title: Complementary Angles

13221.content:
Every day, Sam sits on the bench. The same bench; the only one adjacent to the green grass. Some days, Sam would bring a book with him, sitting down to read a chapter or two. Other days, he wouldn't bring a book at all, instead choosing to preoccupy himself in his own thoughts and feelings. A young boy's thoughts and feelings about the world; the plants, the animals and the sky. God's plan. Sam believes God created everything for one single purpose - to accommodate his creations, and to make them contented. So they wouldn't leave.

Sam doesn't see how human beings fit in this world. Violence, pride, evil, corruption, ignorance, lust: the modern set of sins that every man, woman and child had committed at one time or another. Every person who passes him by as he sits on his bench; they are not fit enough to trample on God's earth. God's ground.

Sometimes, Sam wishes he could leave. Leave, forever. Is suicide a sin?
13221.title: Every Day

132212.content:
Every time this thought, this foul vapor, appears in his head, Sam watches blankly as tourists and vendors and men and women in newly-cleaned and coffee-stained shirts and blouses tread the dirt path in front of him. Rarely do they pass without some sort of buzz. Children with fluttering flags and denim hats grabbing at their mothers' jeans and asking when they could eat. Joggers sweating in the heat and chill of the morning. A woman with her hair in a bun speaking about agriculture subsidies, a man talking to a woman about dinner reservations.

They don't even know, he thinks to himself, his tongue bitter with self-inflicted venom. Or, they don't even care.

That venom is his status quo. Not his favorite taste - he regards any taste as dull, and any effort to choose anything as his favorite as far too much of a resignation to this self-destructive society. But that venom, that disdain for external life, is the lifeblood of his illusions.

Still, he resigns to going home. That, he figures, is inevitable. But there is no point in pursuing something better, for finding something worthwhile in the cold, materialist, dull Gomorrah under this bleak sun. He has fallen into the routine of traveling here, so he might as well go back to that dingy brick building where he stayed in Rosslyn, Virginia. He stands up, and begins to walk to the subway station a few hundred paces away. He ducks his head and looks to the hazy sky to avoid eye contact until he grasps the impure escalator handrail that carries him down to the train.

"I am so glad the wind finally stopped! I thought the roof was going to blow away!"

"I wasn't worried. This old place is pretty solid, probably just knocked a few shingles off. You want something to drink?"

"Yes please, do you have any wine?"

"I got some of Merlot. Probably isn't up to your standards, but considering the circumstances..."

I pour the wine, she takes a sip and comments, "That's pretty good, better than I'd have expected from you."

"Got it on sale at Bev-Mo, gotta have something on hand for those young chicks you think I'm trying to seduce," I reply.

"Oh, come on Rick! I caught you red handed with that waitress! In our bed, no less!"

"Like I told you she meant nothing to me, it was just sex! I mean, you weren't interested anymore anyways. You were so preoccupied with your work at the firm, coming home late and tired, you always pushed me away whenever I tried to get close ... Men are different than women, sex is more of a physical need!"

"I suppose you're right, at least in your mind, but I just don't think I can get over it... So, did you finally sign the papers?"

"Yeah, they're right here... Are you sure this is what you want?"

1331111.title: Trustworthy

13311112.content:
The lights flashed from the start of the path on the red carpet to the end as Destiny exited the limousine. "Oh, hey hun!" she listlessly said to random fans, although it appeared as though she was excited to see them. She was, after all, an actress. An A-lister at that.

I had only taken her one year to reach stardom. Her "tragic" history and apparent triumph over it are accountable for much of this, since she'd only done two movies, one single, and one guest role on a sitcom. Yet here she was tonight, at one of the most prestigious events for actors and singers, with a nomination for "Best New Artist" and "Breakthrough Actress." Producers were already fighting over her to produce her biography, and she was only 24!

However, even now most people knew her biography. She and her twin Dorothy were born to Ian and Gina Engle, a famous politician. Gina kicked Ian and the twins out when they were only four and remarried her second husband. Since then, Destiny and Dorothy had been excommunicated, from the famous bloodline of their mother, and their five older siblings would in the future rule the city without acknowledging the twins. Gina once told the press that marrying Ian (husband 3) was a mistake and regretted ever doing so. Ian was forced to raise them, and he tried his best, though they struggled. At age 13, Ian married Zelda Elfman, his former step-daughter and half sister of Destiny. For the next two years, the twins were generally ignored. Then Zelda murdered Ian and got away with it. She was pregnant with his son when Ian died, but she never allowed Destiny or Dorothy to see him again, since they accused her of murder (which was not a lie). The young teens were left to finish raising themselves. According to common knowledge of the public and the press, life was pretty much a struggle for the girls until age twenty, when they both fell in love. At 22, Destiny married Gustavo Belmonte, and one year later started her career in acting and music.

However, tonight, everybody was wondering why Gustavo wasn't accompanying Destiny. "I heard they had an argument." "Is he cheating?" "Is she cheating?" "Maybe he's just sick." "No famous couple ever lasts." Destiny chose to ignore all of these rumors that she heard from the crowd.

After all, Destiny Belmonte was the only one there who knew the real story. There were problems. Gustavo could no longer cope with the problems resulting from Destiny's new fame and had finally threatened to tell the paparazzi about Ignacio. Destiny tried to level with him to keep it secret, saying that it's the only way she knows due to her unfortunate upbringing and lack of a mother. She would say that never had a mother, and turned out fine. She completely ignored the psychologically abused little girl that she had been and still was, ignoring her lack of strong emotion for anything other than the spotlight, which Gustavo had once given her. She even threatened to leave Gustavo if he spilled about Ignacio. She loved both Gustavo and Ignacio, but couldn't bear damage her reputation. Not yet, at least. And so there she walked alone.

Across town, in a mansion of a gated community was Gustavo, hoping to save his marriage. He wished that he could return to Zephyr Park where his friends and brother were, but this was the life that Destiny had chose for him and Ignacio. He went to check on one and a half year old Ignacio. He looked at his son and tears fell from Gustavo onto the babies gentle cheek. Gustavo bent down into the crib and kissed his forehead. However, this was not the kiss Ignacio wanted. Ignacio, who bared a striking resemblance to Ian Engle, was the secret baby boy who was waiting for the kiss of his mother, a kiss that he had never ever felt before.
13311112.title: Waiting For The Kiss

133111121.content:
They slide me from the gurney onto the operating table. Classic rock is playing for my surgery, an old Pink Floyd song. As the anesthetic takes hold I feel totally relaxed, all my worries and cares fading away... "...there is no pain you are receding...a distant ship smoke on the horizon..."

The words the nurse speaks start to penetrate through the fog. "Are you OK? Sorry if we were a little rough, but you were really thrashing around quite a bit when you were coming out of the anesthesia."

Her assistant is holding tightly onto my left arm. "Sorry," I manage to mumble, calm now, only vaguely aware of my previous actions.

The assistant releases my arm and fades from my view. "We're going to take you back to your room now," she says...

Thinking back, I had a similar reactions many years ago when coming out of a previous surgery. "We had to hold you down, we were afraid you might hurt yourself," they told me after I woke up. At that time I was in a pretty dark place in my life. Not so much now, but I must admit I still do peer into the abyss now and then.

So I'm trying to think: What's up with my fighting in the recovery room? Why am I struggling as I regain consciousness?

Some might say it's a perfectly normal reaction, fighting your way back to life after being experiencing the "near death" state of anesthesia.

But I have to wonder: Was I fighting to come back, or fighting to stay gone?
133111121.title: Searching Through the Scars

1331111211.content:
Comfortably Numb. Its how she wished she had stayed. If she had just keep her distance then she wouldn't of had this problem.
"You aren't seriously mad about it, are you?" he asked.
She kept her face blank as she choose not to answer. Was she mad? Hell yes, but she was more depressed. For the last 3 months she tried to be the friend she could be, tried to get him to change his mind. Three months! All she did in those three months was cause herself more problems. She let herself get to close, care to much about this one person.
"Your mad. Don't be mad, be glad." he said.
"Ha, that won't ever happen." she said as her bad mood quickly grew.
"Sorry for making this decision. Sorry for wanting to be at peace."
She sighed and stood up. She was surprised no one could hear the sound of heart shattering and falling to pieces to the floor.
"Before I go I'll give them hell." he said not really paying attention to what she was doing.
"Well, then i guess that's that. Its been nice knowing you." She turned and walked at the door. Moving ever faster as she felt the tears about to come. How could she have been so stupid.
He sat at the table for a minute, a stun expression on his face, then he got up and ran after her.
"Just like that?" he asked as caught up with her.
"what?" she asked, quickly wiping her face.
"Your gonna say bye, just like that?"
"I don't know what else to do."
She was in love with him. He didn't want her. All he wanted to do was join the army, with his main intent being to get shoot and killed. What else could she do? For the five years she known him, that had been his plan. At first she keep her distance, but then she got depressed and he was there. Even though they were both single, he was trying to get back with his ex. What place did she have in his life.
"i'm your friend, I'll always be here if you need me" she said
She walked away then, feeling a heaviness upon her. Why couldn't she remember how to be comfortably numb. How to be his friend, yet not care so much. As she got home, she couldn't hold it anymore. She sank to the floor and cried. Maybe if she had just told him how she felt, but that wouldn't of worked. It seemed she was forever to be left alone, watching her friends and loved one leaving one at a time.

My mind had been sucked inside the clock and the noise was like a hammer as the hours passed. Shattered dreams melting before me and turning to sulpher to burn like a tattoo on my brain. Never letting me forget what had happened in the past... I had tried in vain to forget but inside the room all I could see and hear was the clock, every second was like a millstone dragging me into some abyss. I found myself in a tunnel being swept along by murky water. There was nothing to grab or hold onto. Time was speeding along as I was pulled towards what could be a light. Where was it taking me?
