133112222.content:
"Wake-up!" I heard the voices speaking in the distance. "I didn't think we would bring him back from that one. May want to lower the voltage next time."

I struggled to open my eyes, still hearing echos of the clock ringing in my eardrums. The bright light stinging like daggers as I opened my eyes, "Where are you taking me? " I shouted to the voices. My vision slowly adjusting to the brightness of my surroundings. Tears were running down my cheeks as I struggled to focus. I tried to raise my hand to wipe them, but found I was restrained.

"It will only get worse next time if you resist, we will have you in recovery soon." Said a deep gravely voice.

I could feel the warmth of the blankets around my body as I was wheeled down the long corridor. "Where am I? What's happening?" My head felt as if it were on fire.

"We're taking you to the west wing. We have a special room waiting for souls like yours." I turned my head towards the sound. The stern voice came from beneath the black hood of a man pushing my gurney down the hall.

"Souls like mine? Am I dead?" I began to fight against my restricted movement. The blankets were wrapped tightly around my body. The more I moved the tighter they became.

"You could only wish. We are taking you to the safe room, again. Same place we always take you after your cleansing."

"Why am I here?" Things were becoming hazy and I could feel myself drifting off.

"Must we go through this every time? You entered our safe-house and judgment has been made. The elders have read your soul and passed sentence."

They made a sharp turn into a brightly lit white room. The hooded figures pushed the bed up against the wall. "What's the sentence?" I asked. The pain of my burning skull - slipping me slowly back into unconsciousness,

"Eternity"

Please let this be a dream. I whispered.

The tick-tock of a clock grew louder.
133112222.title: Safe house

choices: Relinquish life on earth for everlasting love in Heaven
1331122223.content:
Suddenly I was wheeled into what was referred to as The White Room. The brightness of the light was intolerable and I squinted instinctively. At a distance I noticed two bearded figures. One looked old and wise and had wise but loving eyes. The second was younger, also with a kind, loving imposition, but he had a questioning expression on his brow.

"What the," I stammered, "is this it , my day of reckoning?".

"Yes!", said the younger. "We do not have you here to judge you though. WE welcome you to eternal life- if you accept our welcome."

"Well, I thought this was it; I've had it, not worthy of eternal life in Heaven."

The younger God reached forward and took my hand in his. "What do you want? Would you prefer to be reincarnated into life on earth or are you ready to dwell in the everlasting spirit realm with peace, love and harmony in your midst?".

I pondered the options, What about about all I'll miss out on? What about all the grudges and revenges I'm still to exercise? And, how about the girl I just met?
1331122223.title: The white room

1331123.content:
Unending Corridors in a complex maze
causing the controlling mind to phase
keeping eyes on my shoe while in this haze
so I don't freak with claustrophobic craze.

So much like a dream I had one night
running through tunnels in terror and fright
corridors with doorways to my left and right
none would open, so I followed the light
1331123.title: Unending Corridors

1332.content:
It's been hot and dry for the past two weeks, and the last rain was in mid March. Fire season is coming, it's in the air. Hot, dusty, with the faint scent of dying pine beetle infested trees...

Annie left me years ago, after our two boys were old enough to get out on their own, I guess she got tired of my ways. Me stayin' out late most nights drinking and playing cards with my buddies at the casino, while she sat up and worried if I was gonna get arrested again, or gamble away the rent money.

I eventually realized I couldn't keep on going the way I was. I knew the guys at the casino were only my friends as long as I was losing money to them. One night I finally scored big, hit a progressive jackpot with an honest-to-God-royal-flush. I tipped the dealer a couple hundred, cashed in damn near twenty grand and walked out, determined never to go back. But I knew to make it work I'd have to leave town...

The one good thing I did in life was manage to keep my job as a machinist for Boeing for 35 years, which qualified me for an early pension. So I turned in my notice and went looking for a place to start over.

I was driving around up in Big Bear looking at foreclosures when I saw this little log cabin for sale that looked like it might be in my price range . I called the number and made an appointment to meet with the agent.

The place needed a lot of work so I was able to get it pretty cheap. But I'm good with my hands, I knew I'd have no problem fixing it up, and it would give me something to do since I wasn't working any more.

So two weeks later I move in, and two months later after fixing the place up I'm bored. I'm talking to one of my neighbors and he mentions how he's a volunteer fireman, so I go down to the next meeting with him to check it out. It seems like something I can do, I started working out again so I'm in pretty good shape for my age.

I pass the test and join up, and after being called in and fighting my first fire a couple months later, I'm hooked. The adrenaline rush of battling the flames, and that feeling you get after successfully putting down a big fire. After quitting work I really missed the sense of accomplishment you get from a job well done, and this is a way to get it back.

I don't sleep as well as I used to when I was younger. So when I wake up and see the glow out my window and it seems like it's too early for sunrise. I look at the clock and it says 3:20 and I realize it isn't the sun. The phone rings and I pick it up to answer. Looks like it's time to go to work...
1332.title: Fire from the East

13322.content:
It was his hands I hated. Where did he even come from? But it was the hands. He could fix anything; he play anything. He drove the women in town wild, not that they wouldn't have gone over for any new bull's swagger, but then he shot pool with those hands, he tipped his hat with the long fingers, his motioned Old Bell over for another beer and the rest of us sitting there like chumps, dirt on us from fields, our own palms black as sin with worked over skin. And him sitting at the last stool at the end of the bar doing coin tricks, throwing dice, gesticulating like a madman as the women went crazy and the firehouse plugs drooled. So it was his hands I hated, and the hatred only grew the more I saw of him. And the more I thought that a man with clever hands like that gets them clever because he has no real work to do, and then he comes to a new town like mine and trigs up all the women, including the brat in the bar who twice now has almost been mine, and a fire gets out in some ramshackle nowheresville ranchhand's rusted tin shed, and he busts it up and is the new hero?

And the brat goes home with him, and Old Bell the next nights gives him free drinks, and his name gets in the paper, and oh how all the women keep swooning, and the dirt just piling up under my nails, and somebody even buys him a dog to layabout his godsforsaken house sniffing at passing farts. And when I go up to talk to him about the brat situation, he acting like he's never met me, never passed by me every day in the fields for the last three weeks, the sun beating up the back of my neck? And a grimace flickers over his face when we shake. He looks down at my cracked knuckles and frowns. And cracks his own and a wide, beaming smile busts out of his unseamed face.

So I did it. I did do it. I am that firebug, doing everything anybody said I did. And more. Did the big one, that one that burned so hot men halfway across the county went soft with fear? and the hand-man's pool boiled in his backyard? and his gift dog became a wasted cinder in the wind? You bet that was me, and I got more intent where I found that. Better believe it. Fair is fair, after all, and I earned what I earned, and nobody's going to take it.
13322.title: Fire Bug

choices: At this late date can you turn that around?
133221.content:
though, is it fair?

After all, has anyone struck at you in the same way?

And suppose they did. Where's the justice you claim you deserve?

The truth? The truth is that you don't deserve a break. You haven't earned it.
133221.title: Fair is Fair. Consider what you're doing...

133222.content: Fire is beautiful. It bends and twists, always glowing and always shining. It brings light and warmth and safety from the bitter cold. It is savage. It burns unrelenting all in its path. Fire heals, for great life grows out of the ashes of its destruction. Fire is many things, but above all fire is fire. It is unique and triumphant and something of its own. It cannot be compared to anything else on this Earth, and perhaps beyond it. The next time you stare into its flickering flames, remember why it stands as the symbol of so many years.
133222.title: Fire is Fire

choices: Meanwhile, in a small apartment on the edge of town...
13323.content:
They drag me out of the cell at sunrise, and march me in irons into the courtyard. There's a chill in the damp early morning air, but within a few hours it will be unbearably hot. I'm not sure I'll be around to feel it...

As an idealistic journalism major fresh out of college, Somalia seemed like the perfect place to go. I joined the Red Cross as a way to get in. I figured once I was there I could jump ship and get to know the locals, interview them, take some pictures and notes about how poverty and the breakdown of society had led them to their actions.

I could write a book about their plight and make enough money to pay off my school loans, and maybe make a name for myself as a writer in the process. I could see the cover of the book already, a grainy photo of a couple of skinny black kids standing on the bow of a speedboat, holding their AK-47's, the title "Pirates!" in jagged red type above the picture. I thought my forture would be made!

I thought wrong...

Within a week I was "arrested" as an American spy and thrown into a cell, presumably by the man who hired the local kids to hijack the ships. I try to talk to my captors: "I'm not a spy! Don't you realize he's taking advantage of you? He's keeping most of the ransom money while your people take all the risks!"

"Mister Arale said you are an American spy, and you will try to say things to turn us against him. And even if your words are true, what does it matter? There are no jobs here, no way other than the ships to make money. He pays us enough to put food on the table for our families, what more can we expect in these times?"

In the courtyard, my leg irons are fastened to a post in fron of a wall pock marked with bullet holes. I know I'm screwed, but in a perverse kinda way I gotta admire Arale's traditional approach to dealing with people like me.

"Do you have a last request?" the guard asks.

"Yeah, how about forgetting this whole thing and letting me go?"

"You are a funny man, Mister American, I have not heard that one before. But no, you cannot go. Would you like a cigarette?" he asks, offering me a lighted Benson.

"Sure, why not?" I say.

I quit freshman year, but I guess it doesn't matter now. I take a deep drag off the smoke, cough a little as the nicotene buzz hits me.

"Would you like a blindfold?"

"No thanks, I want to see it coming," I say with false bravado, as I try to keep my legs from shaking.

"As you wish."

The guard steps to the side and calls out to the riflemen: "READY!"... "AIM!"...
13323.title: "FIRE!"

133231.content:
The path of a bullet is different for every shot. Sometimes it hits the target, sometimes it doesn't. My shot always finds its way.

Living in this crazy world has taught me many lessons over the years. One, always be prepared; two, never trust another; three, survive for as long as you can. As a professional assasin, my job has caused many lives to perish over the years. Why, you ask, become an assassin? You go along with your talents in life.

Like many others, my troubling childhood brought about my ways. Killing never seems to be a problem, and so my life goes on.

The latest objective was a woman from New York. A entrepenuer, she took some risks that paid off. This apparently angered her competators enough to wish for her demise. That is where I come in.

I set up on a roof top, across from her home. The morning meal she was eating was sure to be her last. My longshot sniper would create a quick ending to her blissful life.

After a half an hour, she came out into the daylight. Immediately, I was thunderstruck. I had heard rumors about this feeling, called love, that others recived, that I never had. She was the most gorgious creature that ever walked the earth.

My target had just become...my target.
133231.title: The path of a bullet

1332311.content:
April awoke from a very pleasant dream and stared at the clock on her nightstand. It was 10:30. Still groggy, she crawled out of bed and made her way to the bathroom. While brushing her teeth, she realized that today was Saturday. She didn't have to work. After a warm shower,she dressed in a red tank top, white shorts, and sandals. Even though she was off today, there waas still a lot to do to get ready for the dinner party.

         After brewing a pot of tea, April sat down and made a grocery list. Looking at its length and her wallet, she hoped she had enough to get everything. She grabbed her purse, keys, and phone and went to Pinkney's Marke. April filled her cart and hit a lot of sales. While in the produce section, she was examining the heads of lettuce. When she placed one back on the pile, a chain reaction of falling head occurred. She tried to stop the onslaught, but to no avail. She was preoccupied with cleaning up her mess when a hand grabbed the same head she was going after.

         Straightening up, ,April was shocked to see who Her helper was. It was the guy in her dream. He had light brown hair, deep blue eyes. a heart shaped face. When they stood up, he was taller than her. He wore a pink polo shirt that was tucked into tan pants. Regaining her composure, April thanked him. He looked in her cart and noticed its items. He commented that she must feed an army.She smiled and told him about the dinner. She couldn't keep her eyes off of him.

         They exchanged names and numbers. before he asked her out for a date. Waiting patiently for a response, April told him to call her. She would answer him then. All she could think of was that love at first sight is true.

         What should she do? Invute him to the party? Or invite him tto dinner at a later date?
1332311.title: Love at first sight.

choices: Convince her to stay and talk
13323111.content:
He is upstairs, focused on the computer screen in front of him; his desk is covered with french textbooks and worksheets. Mumbling the foreign words under his breath, he leans back. Memorizing has never been easy for him. Still, he has a test tomorrow on the topic of musique. From behind the closed doors, he could hear the shouts and bouts of laughter as his roommates and friends play Super Smash Bros . Instead of enjoying the Sunday night festivities, he's stuck in the bedroom at 11:00 pm, straining to keep his mind on the vocabulary at hand instead of how useless it'll be in the future.

A shy knock interrupted his wandering thoughts.

"Can I come in?" A familiar voice inquires.

"Well, I don't see why not. This studying is going nowhere."

"Awh, Nickolai!" A girl approaches, hugging him, "You can do it!"

He smiles and enjoys the quick shock of the smooth skin on her arm.

"But, before you dive back in, a party downstairs is missing a key component."

Nickolai smiles. She pulls him up and he pulls her into an embrace, whispering in her ear, "and you're missing my key component."

She pushes him and giggles.

"Let's go play a few rounds, loser."
13323111.title: Invite him to party

choices: Shawn arrived at 6:30, April wanted to show him her house.
Shawn called her at four and asked her if after dinner she would enjoy a moonlig
13323112.content:
When the phone rang, April had forgotten about mr. love ar first sight, not forgotten
moved to the left a little so she could focus on the food, the people and the games being played at the party. Not party games but the teasing that adults who have known each other for a lifetime do. Mostly harmless heckling but sometimes it can get a little over the top as they all have trigger mechanisms and a lot know a lot about a lot. She answered and it was Bond, James Bond, not Roger but the real deal, Sean.
Coincidentally, his name was Shawn, spelled differently but so what? And (how did you guess) she made a fool of herself, tongue-tied, vocabularlyless, armpits raining, shaking, hot flashes and the real betrayal that demanded attention, the warm glow humming or vibrating like a guitar string changing her breathing and staying centered in her loins. She hadn't felt anything like this ever! It took every bit of her concentration, will power and focus to not say, "Shawn are you doing anything right now?" She came to and realized she had just said to him what she was trying not to say! Was she losing her mind? Thank God he said he had an early meering in the morning and declined! Close one,. Phew! He suggested Dinner tomorrow at seven and asked her favorite food or restaurant here in the City? Without any hesitation she said McDonalds. He laughingly said he had something a little better in mind than McDonalds? Not where they sell Big Mac's silly. I'll show you. It's a-aI'll surprise you. It's casual elegance so we can look good but be comfortable. He said, sounds grear It's a date. A date it is she saidas her voice cracked. God was it hot in here? Good night, good night. She was trembling with something she had put to sleep after Tim had shattered her trust in herself men, society and the milkmans cat. Whoa girl, reign these feelings in or you won't even make it through dinner. She fell asleep immediately and did not remember dreaming . She could handle it. Or could she?
13323112.title: Invite him for dinner later

choices: Fear and Panic, a cold drenching sweat
1333.content:
Louise found she could not take her eyes off the body. A dead black boy in a ditch a common occurance during this year of 66' when the civil rights movement was at its full peak.

"But its a man, who has red blood like I do." She thought, "He is a human being. who could do this sort of thing."

She cast a glance at her husband, who had literally drug her away from the sight.

"Get in the damn car!" He snarled, glancing to the surroundings. He thought he heard a noise, what sounded like a yawn behind a tree and a flash of white.

"But its a boy, a human like us."

"This stinks of the clan Louise." He said, "If they know we know they murdered a n*****. our life won't be worth a plug nickle either."

"But..." Louise said, "Maybe we should bury him. its not right to leave him like that."

"Hell no. Get in here." He snarled pullnig her arm as he started the car and he punched the accelerator to the floor making the tires squeal as the car sped off.

Louise peered in the mirror as men, clad in white sheets walked silently to where the boy lay, and a several gunshots rang out.

"Oh my god." Louise thought, realization setting in, "They already know!"
1333.title: A heavy yawn

choices: Sandwichs on the Espalande in San Antonio
13331.content:
As far as I could tell no bullets had hit my GTO! Had a bullet mad contact I might have been forced to get my
12 gauge out of the trunk and make those white sheets as red as a muslim women's bed on her wedding night!
I wasn't quite sure who I loved more my Silver Gto with trips or my wife who trips on acid and trips over things. She tripped over that boys body, that's how we found it.
There was a truck trying to catch me but it was a six cylander flat head probably top speed was fifty-five or sixty with overdrive, maybe seventy but not up any incline. Louise asked if I thought they knew where we were staying? I told her of course not but knew they did because of the car.
Didn't matter! Not even going back to get our gear. I'll call tomorrow and have them pack it up and send it to my nephew at his desk. Lieutentant Carter Graves Lapd. I was tired of visiting my sister and her red neck husband anyway and we definately had worn out our welcome in Tuscogee, Alabama.
If I could talk my wife into driving a bit, I would love to drive non-stop through Louisianna and Texas. Spend a couple of days in Taos, New Mexico with human beings. These crackers were a little to close to succeeding from the Union again or maybe they never did come back in? If I heard, " The South is going to rise again", one more time I am thinking about setting fire to their crops like Lee did so the Yankees had nothing to eat! God, I'm glad the South isn't in California! It's hard to believe that that much hate could be passed on from generation to generation with no grounds to back it up. It's hate for hates sake. They feel united or stronger having an agreed upon common enemy. Did the men who shot into an already murdered black childs body feel What? Gives me the shivers! Louise, you feel like driving for awhile?
13331.title: Car Chase

133311.content:
I was asleep when Louise pulled into a TRUCK STOP IN HUSTON that was larger than quite a few cities we had passed through. I only realized this when after slapping me hard enough to leave her handprint in my beard, I woke up from a dark, deep, narcotized sleep that only those who have driven in infinity on the open road and when sleep overtakes isn't really sleep but an uncomfortable sweaty type of limbo or purgutory! An in-between, never-never land where dreams are the labraia tar pits! You are a slow moving dinosaur that is sinking while escaping and with a brain that doesn't know the difference between living or not living? Doesn't care.
I'd never seen so many eighteen wheelers in one place before. It reminded me of when I was tuna fishing off Midway in the northern Pacific. We were in the pile (albacore ). There were over two hundred tuna boats in the middle of the Pacific Ocean going around like we were all cruising the major boulevard in any city U.S.A. It was a small moving city on the water, thousands of miles from anywhere but the tiny Island of Midway which is itself in the middle of no where! It was like that for four days and nights until the tuna dispersed. Then we dispersed to go out and find them again.
This place wasn't about fish. This was about petrol, sleep, a good meal, a hooker, a shower, comradrie and a clean book. They only let you be on the road so many miles and hours these days. No more truckers whites, cross tops, speed and Ocean to Ocean mom-stop! Those days are long gone along with route 66!
Here is what I did not expect to find and was glad Louise was taking a shower. A guy invited me to his table. I was leary and didn't like his looks but that's never stopped me before from hearing someone's spiel. He bought me a cup of coffee and came quickly to the point. His point. He placed a card on the table in front of me and asked if I'd heard of the Klan? I responded," The Ku Klux Klan?" He said," That's the one".
Louise and I had just seen a young black kid shot by people just like this guy. We found his body and they fired into his already dead body again and thought that was funny! I'm 6'3" with a full beard. I looked into this sweaty, beady eyed, red necked cackers face as I tore up his card, just halves and said, " I hope you aren't asking me to join"? "What if I was"? his s sounded like a zzzz. "Well, if you are asking me to be a member of the Ku Klux Klan, I'd have to decline", I said continuing, "Do you want to know why?" "Naw"' he said making it sound like what a dog does to a bone! "Ya'll come around sooner or later". I started laughing! Could not help myself. I thought his head was going to explode it was beet red and getting larger if that were possible. This of course made me laugh even harder, The entire restaurant was looking as he got up and waddled out the door into the blazing lights and sounds of trucks in perpetual motion. I managed a, " Ya'll come back now y'hear", in my best Beverly Hillbilly imatation! He never looked back.
It relieved a lot of pressure Louise and I had been feeling but had been keeping a tight rein on our emotions. We had seen hate for no reason which is worse than madness because it can wear the appearance of sanity and reasonableness. I was glad she didn't witness the confrontation but she did enjoy it vicariously. She asked me only once if I thought we might be followed and I said emphatically no. But if we were what could they possibly drive that could keep up with my GTO with trips?
133311.title: Truck stop in Huston

13332.content:
Louise turned to face the road that was coming at her fast. She said, "God help us all." She slumped on the door as her husband hung a left down a red dirt road. He rolled up in the yard and hid the car behind the house. They entered through the unlocked back door. She knows it's going to be a long night so she makes coffee as Earl goes for his shotgun and pistol. They sit at the table sipping, waiting. For what they don't really know. Life as they know it to either go on or end.
Midnight marched down upon them with a heavy striking hand. Louise woke with a start at Earl shaking her awake. "Get up, it's time." They peer by the dusty curtain at the cross burning in their front yard under the Magnolia tree. The hooded men descend on the house walking in a line carrying clubs and shotguns. A tall brusque man wallops the door. "Open up. Don't make things hard on yourself." Lousie cowers in a corner with the pistol as her husband shoves the door open. He levels the gun in the hood's face. "Now Earl, don't play dirty, boy. We know what you and the misses saw. We're here to have a cup of coffee and talk about it."
Earl spits at the man's feet. The man sneers and enters with a raised club. That's when Earl gives him both hammers. Louise screams as her husband falls to the floor and the rest enter.
13332.title: Midnight cross burning

13333.content:
In terror, the man sat up immediately, soaked in a cold, drenching sweat and chest heaving. His bleary eyes nervously flitted around the room, panic feeding his dream to make it seem as real as if he were again a child. Blurred, dreamlike vestiges of twisted, grotesque shadows painted their distortedly misshapen forms across the widely contrasting structure and continuity of the monolith that were the cold, gray walls boxing him in. Until a large, trembling hand flew to relight the waxy candle stub on the night table, those nightmarish horrors remained a fragmented connection between the not-yet-forgotten past and the present day, a link forged irrevocably by the unforgivable physical and psychological tortures he still felt.
         The ominous shadows evaporated in the sudden light, shrinking back into the dark nothingness from which they dared to approach the wary, uneasy sleeper. Bare walls of dull limestone coldly greeted his unfocused, shocked eyes, as did the sparsely spread furniture. Ornate designs on the chair and legs of his oaken writing table glinted in the dim, orangey glow, as did the woody leaves and earthy, curling vines of his ceiling-length wardrobe and bookshelf, filled with leather-bound volumes in his personal collection, too precious to remain either in study or library. Forest green bed curtains framed this picture, obscuring the other sights, but he knew of the three doors: one leading to the corridor, one leading to his personal washroom, and the third leading to the his wife‘s chambers, adjacent to his own apartments.
         He lay his head back down and pressed his eyes with the heels of his palms.
         ‘…it was simply a nightmare. Why do dark demons of the past haunt my footsteps, in wakefulness and in sleep?’ The questions rang in his mind like the peals of mourning death knells from the silvery-sweet bells hidden in the lofty spires of the not-so-distant monastery. Just the thought of the cold place brought back less-than-fond memories of the time he had spent there as a child and the years previous to that--the somewhat happier days before the end of life as he had known it.
         ‘Have I not suffered yet enough?’
         It had been nearly two decades—a long time to pass, but nowhere near long enough in his time-aged eyes. For his were the eyes that had seen more than enough death and horror to last a lifetime; the eyes that had watched so many ruthless, unjustified murders; the eyes that had shed far too many tears for too many dear, loved ones in his time on this earth. His were the eyes that spoke of the dark places in the man‘s past, of the black things that so many had buried and refused to mention; his eyes spoke of the deceit and the treachery and the tortures through which he had come; his eyes spoke of a troubled soul hidden deep within.
         He briefly shuddered at the waves of cold rolling down his tall spine, feeling the goose pimples collecting on the warm flesh and the fine hairs stand up on edge in response to the familiar fiend: fear. It played on his mind like the cool shadows cast by the orangey-red glow of a heated blaze. All too real was the horror of those frightful days in his childhood and still all too fresh in his grief-numbed mind for the cycle of human emotions to thoroughly and naturally run their course. The gruesome past lurked in those shadows, waiting to grab him in icy claws of darkness and to remind him why he had survived. It burned as a black beacon in his mind, the overwhelming dark consuming what little light still shined in the bleak coolness.
         Now, as the man stared up at the ceiling's flickering shadows, he could do nothing but remember and cower helplessly in fear at the unwelcome memories flooding his mind and overwhelming his swimming vision.
13333.title: Fear and Panic, a cold drenching sweat

133331.content:
'Do you have these kinds of thoughts often?' he asked, raising one brow with practiced interest.
I noted the way he doodled in his journal and tried to hide his smirk that was begging to get out. 'Mm ... define often,' I said, shifting in my chair. He simply stared and I felt the old frustration coming in waves. I blew the air through my gums, rotating my neck. It cracked, making me wince - boy, did I hate these damn questions. 'I wouldn't say often,' I said with a weak smile, 'maybe ... I don't know - once, twice a week. But it's not all the time or anything; I'm not crazy.'
The old familiar prickle coursed over my skin and it felt like someone had popped me into an oven. I willed my heart to beat a little slower. Not only did I feel like a bug beneath a microscope under his gaze, but the fine golden hair at the throat of his shirt was messing with my concentration.
A hundred dollars a session, just so I could see that face; those tanned pianist's fingers curled around that clipboard. Huh, maybe I really was a nut; straight jacket material. Yes, he had a knack of making me sweat, in the most delightful way, and I couldn't stay away. Most of my issues were sorted, but it was easy enough to create more, and if he ever suspected that I was telling a tall one, he never let on. I wouldn't let on for a hundred dollars a go, either.
'What about re-living those childhood memories?' He asked with appropriate concern. He crossed his leg and I examined the length of his thigh, defined against the sinfully soft fabric of his pants. His loafers almost gleamed in the light and I pondered over an estimated price tag. My guess would have to be well in the hundreds ...
'Christine?' The lulling tone of his voice broke through my thoughts.
' ... Oh, sorry.' I tucked a stray piece of hair behind my ear and wished for a mirror, or some lipstick, perhaps a splash of perfume. 'The memories,' I said, struggling to remember my own lies. 'I'm still having the flashbacks,' I paused, clearing my throat, 'but they're less frequent now.' I traced the outline of the pink rose on my skirt and forced my self to meet his eyes. I could feel the colour flare to my cheeks and had no means of concealing it. Without thinking about it I plastered my palms to my face, the cold skin a contrast to the heat I found there.
A small grin decorated his face, just enough to show the impeccable row of teeth behind his smile. 'Can I get you a glass of cold water? He asked. 'Then we'll talk more about those flashbacks.'
133331.title: Childhood Memories

133332.content:
Ma never told us about him. We'd lived our lives as normal people and carried on like a normal family. I always proudly told people that I was the oldest of a family of all girls. Only now do I know that I have lived practically my entire life as a lie.
         I only recently found out that I have an older brother.
         Ma said that I knew him when I was very little, and she had hoped I was too small to remember him. My sisters were, but I guess I wasn't. I still remember watching him sit on the couch, eating cereal from one of our little plastic bowls. I always thought that he was weird because he put bananas in his cereal. Now that I'm older, I like to, too.
         I'd asked Ma about him before, but her excuses never added up. Age five, he was the bogeyman; eight, he was my cousin; ten, he was a ghost. The last excuse she gave me before finally telling the truth was that he was her godson. Only, I'd seen pictures of Ma's godson before--he was Samoan, and the person I remember had the palest skin in the world, hazel eyes, and short, blonde hair.
         Ma finally surrendered and told me he was my half brother. She made me promise not to tell, because my sisters were too little to remember him and she didn't even want us to know about him. He'd been messed up since he was a kid and got into some bad stuff like gangs and drugs and all that. It was to protect us, she said, because we were good people, because she didn't want us falling into bad stuff like he did. But he only got so messed up because he got kidnapped when he was real little.
         Obviously, he was found, but the damage was already done. He couldn't cope with it, Ma said, and the only way he could recover was by acting out. So, as soon as he was old enough, Ma kicked him out of the house.
         I wasn't sure what to think, so I guess I'm still getting over the shock of it all. I'm an aunt, but my both my nephew and my niece live out-of-state. They might not even know each other because they were adopted into different homes and they're only half-siblings, too. They probably don't know that they have aunts, either. Does he know, though? Does he know how his little half-sisters are? Does he even know what each of us does? Ma keeps in touch with him, so does she tell him how everyone in the family's doing, or does she just keep in touch to know how much bail money he needs or makes sure he isn't offed by a drug lord or rival gang?
         Would Ma even have told me I have a brother if I hadn't found out first?
133332.title: Familial Secrets

1333321.content:
"Where the hell is he!?"
"He's not home!" I yelled through the torn fly screen. "He's gone out ... and he won't be back for a while." I didn't know if that were even true, but I wanted the hostile stranger gone. He stood beside the rusting hulk of my father's 'vintage' car; legs spread commando style, eyes squinted at the rising sun.
"That big brother o' yours owes me five hundred bucks, and I aint leavin' till I see some of it."
I surveyed him from my hiding spot, my heart beating like a wounded sparrow's. He was terrifying. A tree trunk of a man with impossibly large hands - hands that were clenched around a heavy piece of timber.
I realised that it was doubling as a weapon, and the corroded nails extruding from its tip seemed all the more terrifying.
Snorting, he wiped his arm across his wide nose and spat a wad of phlegm at the thirsty earth. He scuffed the ground impatiently and dust billowed around his legs. He was an angry bull, and I, the red flag.
Inching the door back I tested the lock. Still jammed. "Damn it," I hissed.
Dad was no handy man. He always said, "We're not under threat of invasion, possum." His idea of a joke -- well, this would teach him ...
"What about your old man, little girl ... he home?"
I needed to sit down. I was supposed to be in bed; resting. How could I rest when I had Steven Roberts to deal with - the biggest loser in school. He should have been expelled a long time ago, but when your uncle is the principal, you reap the benefits. If he got kept back again he would need a retirement plan.
"... I ... he's sleeping right now. We don't wake him when he's sleeping," I warned. The tremor in my voice was as transparent as my nightgown - that I was all too aware of.
He laughed, a noisy gurgle that split the silence.
I could smell my toast burning from the kitchen, but couldn't leave my post unattended. "But, I'll tell him you were here."
"How 'bout I tell him myself, sweetie pie? Why don't you show your neighbour some country hospitality?"
1333321.title: Big Brother

13333211.content:
My mind is a seething maelstrom of Viperidae, cobras, scorpions, and blue octopi. My mental pets have names. There's Bitterness, Hatred, and Self-Pity. Of course, Despair is king of the menagerie; his influence extends to every nook and cranny of my psyche.

My personal favorite is Jealousy. My green-eyed companion stands at attention whenever I see a person better than me in any way. In any way:

>> More/better material possessions
>> Better looking
>> Better health
>> Athletic ability
>> Self-confident
>> Romantic relationship
>> More intelligent
>> Courage
>> Happier (Includes pretty much every human alive.)

Yeah, my friend Hatred helps out Jealously. Between the pair, they amp up my frustration, my blood pressure, my isolation. Seven billion people on earth. Haven't met 'em all, but I bet I'd hate 'em every bit as much as the ones I have met.

There is nothing so horrible I wouldn't wish it on those who have wronged me. I fantasize I'll get cancer. Once I know I don't have much time left, I'll obtain a gun, an ax, whatever tool I need, and take care of business. Hey, I don't wanna kill anybody. I want 'em to suffer. Smash a couple of knees. Every time my enemy thinks about running down to the court for a few sets of tennis, he'll remember what he did to me. Or gouge out his eyes. Every morning when he gropes for his white cane, he'll think of me.

And I'm a coward. Never take a risk. Never take a chance on improving myself. Every morning when I wake up, I ask myself, “Is this the day I'll find the courage to kill myself??” And the answer is always No. I would give anything – I mean ANYTHING – for the guts to end the misery.

Yes, there are a few – Very few – Human beings worse off than I am. Every time I see one, I gloat and pat myself on the back for my superiority. If I'm not able to urinate on such a person physically, I look for a chance to do so figuratively. Extend a hand, offer to help someone less fortunate?? Dream on!

Not pretty, but it's me.
13333211.title: Bubba's Manifesto.

133332112.content:
A wise man who is filled with love advises the menaced soul:

"Living in the past is the biggest mistake, because doing so will eternally, day by day, give you reasons to love all the serpents or demons that control you and you will exercise their evil intent. There is a great need to choose to live in a state of love, ever grateful for what you have; ever rejoicing for the blessings that you and others have, and ever expectant of the good tidings that you pray for, or wish for, from this day on."

Miserable soul hears these words and phrases of love and gulps out loud. "Me. You expect me to change 100% right now?".

He shakes his head defiantly.

The wise man responds, " The choice is yours, as every second of every day you are living out the reality of your life as set only by you."

Miserable soul gasps in surprise.
133332112.title: Look To The Future

choices: The idea frightened him and yet...
It is too hard to change
1333321123.content:
Totally confused, Miserable Soul looked at the wiseman and could not figure out why he was not judging him, only giving him a doorway.
One part of his mind screamed:" What??What??" Deep inrritation mounted to anger for a reason he did not know. "don't listen!"

But it was a bit late! Some higher part of his being, above the demons that ruled him, rose up in potency and asked with a bit of alarm: "You mean I have choice?? I am creating my reality??"

He bowed his head and shook it. "You mean to say I am choosing to be in this unhappy state of mind that keeps splitting off?"

'Yes", and you can even fire the demons who keep you in this prison.! You hired them at some time to keep you safe, or the same or in line with everyone else. You are sensitive to all the psychic junk of the collective thought so you can always ask a thought or feeling.
"Who does this belong to and send it away?" The Dark heaviness is not really you, and as long as you believe it's lies and follies, it controls you. And you are letting it." The wiseman drank his tea.

Bubba the Miserable soul struggled with this bit of enlightenment as his demons were sparring not to lose their power.
He could tell them to leave? They had been his companions for so long. What would he be without them? The idea frightened him and yet....

The wise man watched him, sensing the struggle. "yes, what would it be like to be space and choice?"
1333321123.title: Totally confused

13333211232.content:
The wise man patiently nodded his head and said, "Yes, Budda, this type of change is always difficult and it may even seem impossible; but, considering that it all depends on your choice, only you can change it".

Bubba shook his head vehemently again, not quite grasping the advice.

"How can I change anything if this green thing continually reminds me to be envious or jealous, while this red thing keeps reminding me that I hate anyone who has it better than me?", barked Bubba.

The wise man smiled and said, "You need to remind them of your new status; one of love and joy, peace and harmony with all humankind".

Bubba slammed his hand on the counter and, ........
13333211232.title: It is too hard to change

134.content:
And mine...

But to try and shorten this very necessary step given her, given all of us at some point, approaches a breach of what the masters have intended. She will stay. Perhaps a very long time. Longer than anyone in the know would have patience for. She will wander down the embankment over and over. To the car which sits, crumpled, upside down by the ditch. She will lay down beside it and gaze at the driver, still inside, face caked with blood.

It will take some time to recognize that it is her. At first she will be horrified. She may run away. But there is no help for her. No one's coming. In time, she'll return again. She'll be sad. And then reflective. Eventually, she will be able to accept her own passing and then, and only then, will she be at peace in this afterlife. No one goes until they are made ready, for there is no enlightenment gained through easy transition. She will be able to shoulder the next responsibility assigned her by the masters and one day, all souls willing, she will join them.
134.title: No one goes

1341.content: She waits... But why? cannot she look behind to all she was taught, know, deep within her, hear her soul cry. There is no peace. Afterlife yes, but can their be true peace when one is dead. Would her soul want to open its eyes, not knowing what it will see? Step into the grace of a false truth. To come to know that all the time she lived she was dead, and afterlife is a lie of her mortal body. That body that now lies before her, cold, putrid in its beauty. Laughter echoes, a sick mockery, peace.. is this what she prayed for?
1341.title: At  Peace in This Afterlife

13411.content: It turned out to be all lies. All the stories she had heard as a child were all lies. She stood there looking at her corpse realizing that the reaper stood behind her. Why did they do this to me? She wondered as the reaper clenched his bony hand on her wrist. She turned and followed knowing that her time had come. Looking back at her corpse, she knew the time would come for her to have her revenge. A glimmer of hope filled her spirit as she looked through the portal.
13411.title: Lies

choices: Go to Heaven, or an Acceptable Substitute
Go to Hell, Do Not Pass Go, Do Not Collect $200
13412.content:
"I don't want to start any blasphemous rumours but I think that God's got a sick sense of humour, and when I die, I expect to find Him laughing." - Depeche Mode

"Why are you laughing at me? Are you taking some kind of sadistic pleasure in my death? I thought God was supposed to be loving and kind, the "Good Shepherd" watching over his flock. I was a faithful believer, I donated a full ten percent of my wages to my church! What's the deal, were you asleep at the switch? Taking a bathroom break when I wrecked that car? Why didn't you save me?"

"Sorry, I didn't mean to laugh, but so many of you just don't get it. The Founding Fathers of your country, Tom Jefferson, Ben Franklin, Ethan Allen, they all understood. Sure I'm the Creator, the "Giver of Life", but I also gave you free will. What happens after you are born is out of my control, and that includes your death. There is no such thing as "Divine Intervention", it's a myth handed down through the ages by some men trying to make sense out of the randomness of life and death. To paraphrase Julie Gold's lyrics, I'm watching over Creation, but only from a distance."

"So what happens to me now? Do I get my reward for living a righteous life, or was that a scam too?"
13412.title: That Mockery from Above

choices: Hell: A really awful, terrible, scary place
Hell: It's really not that bad, once you get used to it.
134122.content:
"Do you know why I cast Satan into the pit of Hell?"

"Yeah, they taught us that in Sunday School. He was arrogant and proud, wouldn't bow down before you or something like that. "

"You're pretty arrogant yourself. Instead of being in awe of my presence, you're making your snarky little comments and acting like Heaven is something you're entitled to!"

"Wait a minute, I didn't mean it! I'm sorry! I'm really sorry!"

"You're not sorry you disrespected Me, you're just sorry for yourself because now you're going to be punished. Jesus! Bring me the basket!"

Jesus walks into view, dragging a large wicker basket with a long rope tied to the handle.

"Hang the basket over the edge of that cloud!"

Jesus complains "Oh Dad, do I have to? The basket is heavy, and the rope hurts the holes in my hands!"

"Don't be such a baby, Jesus. Just do it! And you! get in the basket! Now! Or I'll fry you with a lightning bolt!"

"OK! OK! I'm going!"

As Jesus starts lowering the basket he calls out "Sorry about this, but Dad's old school. He doesn't tolerate anyone dissin' Him. If it was me, I'd probably just turn the other cheek..."
134122.title: Go to Hell, Do Not Pass Go, Do Not Collect $200

1341221.content:
So here it is. Hell. It isn't the flaming pit of fire you expected. You appear to be sitting at a funeral next to a really really fat man in an ill fitting sweaty suit who keeps blowing off. The smaell is awful. Like sulpher. To your left sits your grandma, but she won't look at you. In front, next to your coffin a middle aged man is talking about God. Looking around, the room is a cold sterile office with desks and chairs piled up against the walls and flickering fleurescant lighting that is giving you a headache.

This isn't what you wanted your funeral to be like! You wanted a big party with fun songs that you liked! The man at the front concludes and introduces the next speaker. It's your hated next door neighbour and he's drunk again.He stumbles into your coffin and starts to rap.

"When me look back at 'er life
Me look back at 'er life
Me regret that she not get it on wit' me
Me 'av sausage that go to waste now
In me bedroom! WOOP!
In me bat'room! WOOP WOOP!
In de club! Woop Yeah!..."

So this is hell.
"Excuse me," says your maths teacher from school leaning over your shoulder, "could you fill out these forms so that we can give you your admittance forms?"

"Such a disappointment whispers your grandma."

"Me bone her in de loo"

More sulpher.
1341221.title: Let's Go To Hell.... Hey

choices: Now that I know his plan, ditch him. And tell the Devil "my" plan!
1341222.content:
I get into the basket, and He walks away, still holding the rope. Still turned around, He lets go. I hold on to the sides of the basket as the wind rushes up at me. I hurl over the side of the basket, but as I am falling, most of it lands on me. "Great!" I mutter.

I glance over the edge of the basket. I am headed straight towards something red and yellow. I close my eyes and try to pray, but the words won't come out. In my head, I hear "You had your chance. You did not believe, and so you are to be punished!"

All of the sudden, time seems to stop. My basket softly lands on the flames, then, just dumps me out. I get up, but it's gone.


A few days later


I go to the cooling area to replace my foot bandages. Hell: It's really not that bad, once you get used to it. Sure, we all have blisters all over our skin, but many of my friends are here. Guess they weren't as good as I thought they were.

I found this one guy I didn't know before. His name is Cain. He is "the" Cain. From the Bible! So cool! So anyway, Cain and I got to talking. He thinks that he can find away to get us out of here. He thinks that since the final days aren't upon us yet, we can help the Antichrist defeat Jesus. All I have to do is do some chanting, and we will get the power of the angels. Cain says that his reward will be being Lucifer's second in command.
1341222.title: Hell: It's really not that bad, once you ge...

choices: The voices she hears are within
13413.content: Her body convulsing, tears streaming her face. If only she hand listened. Her toes frozen, huddled into the curve of the cave, there is no sound but her weeping. She's listening now, listening for the advice, her heart singing for the right answer. She rolls onto her side, salt water tears falling and mixing with the cold ground as she drifts off to sleep. She awakes to the sound of voices, soft, feminine voices. They sing to her like chimes in the wind. "Get up child." the voices say. "Follow us child." "Come with us child." so she follows. Listening intently, feverishly scurrying to the voices, but what lies beyond? Are the voices just in her head? Or is there some divine power calling to her?
13413.title: Fear

1342.content:
Trust me, JD, anyone in the know would love to get their hands on this. It's got government conspiracy, talking snakes, and the ending is really kick ass! It'd be perfect for our next movie!

So where did you dig this one up?

On line, believe it or not!

Oh, I believe it, Larry, I believe it...

Hear me out, JD, I found this story on a site called Writing.com. The guy's not published, an amateur, I made him a tentative offer of ten grand cash to rewrite it as a screenplay, pending your approval of course.

That's well within our budget, at least... go on, tell me more...

The story is about this average guy who runs away to Joshua Tree to get away from a plague...

Hold it Larry, average guys are boring, passe. How about if we have the lead character be a woman? Maybe a hot bisexual woman, something to make it interesting. And I hate the desert, let's have her run away to say, Maui. I'd rather film in Maui than the desert wouldn't you?

Sure JD, I'll ask him to rewrite it. Anyway, he meets this woman from his past, she's with her son, her husband got the plague and killed her other son, so he rescues them and...

Does he have sex with her?

No JD, like I said, she's with her son, and her other son just got killed, I'm sure she'd be in no mood to...

Well, we gotta change that. Lose the kid, too messy. Our lead is a bisexual woman now, got it? Let's have her meet an old girlfriend, we can flash back to their adventurous college days, have them pick it up from there... not show too much, just enough, gotta keep the PG 13, you know... Hey Larry, why don't you text this guy, tell him my ideas, make sure he's willing rewrite it like we want it before we spend any more time on this.

Sure, JD, I'm on it.

(Larry texts the writer, waits for his answer)

He doesn't like your ideas, JD, he says it will ruin the story. Says he's got artistic integrity.

Artistic integrity, that's rich! Tell him we'll double his fee, give him twenty grand to write it how we want it.

(Larry texts the writer, waits for his answer)

He says he doesn't like it but he'll do it, JD.

I knew he would, Larry. All writers are whores, you just have to find their price...
1342.title: Anyone in the Know

choices: Janis wants to stay at the Haleakala look out
Wow, it looks like a crater on the moon

attention and only infects a type or types of people the 1% or neo-coms (facists) feel are detrimental to the betterment of the greater good(them), this is the place to be.
Willy Nelson and Kris Kristofferson live here so maybe it won't get hit to hard. Willy is older than Maui and Kris is a Rhodes Scholar who wrote Bobby Magee and let Janis Joplin sing it. old college girlfriend, talk story and maybe she and I will dance the light Haleakala. Hike the trail that runs through The House of the Sun. An extinct volcanoe at 10,000 feet. Together

13421.title: Hawaiian Adventure

134212.content:
I wish I could wander the beach at Waikiki. Not when it’s daylight and the beach is crowded with tourists - I already pass ten thousand strangers to and from work every day. I'd go in the dead of night, when the moon is coming over the horizon, fresh off the boat from Paris, Dubai, and Sydney. I’ll stand there a moment as the pockmarked sand turns to silver in the light, and the footsteps from all those damn tourists will look just like craters on the moon.
Give me that one moment, and maybe a drink with a little umbrella, and I’ll be satisfied when beach security charges in to drag me away, and toss me in a drunk tank with the rest of the tourists.
134212.title: Wow, it looks like a crater on the moon

13422.content:

A bit of a fluke,
With an ending so cheesy,
It'd make anyone puke,

So I went on my way,
For the "Hollywood Dream"-
It took a few days,
Not all that extreme,

At first, it was fine,
The climate was sunny,
The dream would be mine,
Along with much money-

But where am I now?
Drifting along,
Wondering how

Defeated at last,

That I'll forget my sad past,

As one that's degraded,

To live a "Hollywood Dream".
13422.title: Hollywood Dream

134222.content:
You know the last thing I would ever do is bitch. And I'm aware this is not the proper place to gripe and complain,

That being said, I am sick of these Interactive Stories here at Writing.Com. (With, of course, the obvious exception of this one, "Write Baton.") When I logged in a few minutes ago, the entire first page of Interactive Stories was nothing but diapers and weight gain.

Whatever happened to writers who want to tell stories?? Who want to appeal to adults?? Who hope for honest and serious feedback from like minded writers??

Every so often, I get an e-mail from Writing.Com saying, "You haven't used your account in two weeks." Or two months or whatever. Well, you're bleeping right I haven't used my account. You think I want to log in so I can read nonsense about characters from a video game I never heard of??

I could go on, but you get the idea. and you're probably not much interested anyway.

Happy Halloween.
134222.title: The Last Thing I Would Ever Do ...

1343.content:
She had the glue on her lap. It had leaked out of the tube, but it was still useful. The glass pieces were strewn about her on a napkin on the passenger seat of the little purple sportscar she'd inherited from her dead mother. Using the glue, she will join them together, these pieces of broken glass. The glass was coming apart anyway. Not that it was a special glass, but it had been used by everyone in her family to drink beer from, so it was only fitting that she be fitting the pieces back together again. When she finished gluing the pieces together, she set the reformed glass mug on the dashboard in front of her and closed her eyes to contemplate the next few minutes in her life.

Little did she know that there was an eighteen-wheeler bearing down on her from just around the corner. Her little sportscar was sitting on the shoulder in a shady spot along this winding road she had always driven. The trucker's brakes had failed at his last stop, but he didn't know that yet. As he rounded the sharp curve, he spotted that purple car and turned his wheel, but the curve was too sharp. He plowed into the back of her and sent her flying up and over an embankment, ending her life.

In the afterlife, she was surprised to find herself standing just beside her fun little car and wondering how its bumpers had gotten crushed in like that. The air around her was still, which was surprising, because, the last thing she recalled was that it was about to rain.
1343.title: She Will Join Them

13431.content:
As she gazed out of the window into the grey, stormy sky, she knew it was about to rain. With a huge sigh of frustration she pulled on her coat, wrapping it tightly around her petite frame before leaving her eleventh story flat. She meandered the stairs, her heels clicking on the tiled, empty stairwell as the dim lights flickered uneasily.

Finally she made it to the ground floor and the familiar lobby adorned with expensive looking carpet and upholstery, but she knew it was fake. Stepping outside the huge glass fronted building she popped up her umberella as she felt the first spots of rain falling from the sky. She held it close to her head, not wanting her hair to be spoilt but unfortunate weather. She trotted along the pavement, passing people on either side. A man walked by, his eyes following her as he walked. Her eyes watched him, saw his physique, his luminescent green eyes. She knew it was him.
13431.title: It was about to rain.

134311.content:
She knew it was him - and was both right and wrong with that feeling. Detective Adrian Gorge had been politically outmaneuvered before. Rural routine was forced upon him, while his big city 'pals' ensured he would not be in the way of their ambitions. He had faced it like a man. He simply did his job as best as he could. Modern technology allowed to stay in contact with friends and family, that was, since the traditional divorce, his friend Jack Daniels and his family Razorback the Cat. Occasionally spiced-up by paying a visit to Michelle, who once per fortnight performed the willing mate to him.

Adrian had been in the area for a while now. He had even read the secondary sources, one even suggesting it was all for a porn screenplay. No, one does not go to College and succeed as a detective by falling prey to false leads and red herrings. A malevolent atmosphere could be felt by all who did not fearfully shun away. This morning he had spoken with the one Police Psychologist in the vicinity. Abandoned cars, even expensive ones PLUS several missing persons, repeated arrests of people seemingly influenced by drugs. Something was amiss and obviously that something was a someone damn skilled in using the little failures of everyday-life people as a camouflage for more sinister deeds.

Yet for now it was a routine part of the job. half a mile ago he had arrested a suspect under suspicion of illegal trespassing and stalking. With the only housing in the area being this one house he would soon know, if the suspect belonged here properly, or if he would have to haul him into a prison cell for the night. Adrian's finger pressed the button of the doorbell and he awaited a response.



Where will this story go next? Your choices are below...
134311.title: She knew it was him.

1343111.content:
Well, sorts of. With heavy clouds darkening the sky and the few lights already turned bright it took Detective Gorge a moment to estimate this building project properly. 'Must be one of those alternate design fancies by the richer ones.' came the thought to him.

The main building had eleven visible levels, ground level inclusive. Besides that were compact buildings, one obviously a small diner, one a repair-service and one an outdoor-shop. In the twilight of early evening it was hard to imagine, what kind of thought was behind this isle of modernity in the middle of a forest.

“Hello?” came a voice from the communication panel at the main door.

Detective Gorge gently moved his suspect into position and answered the machine.

“Ma'am, I am Detective Adrian Gorge, I must speak with you. Please come down here.”

Adrian felt that smart. Entering an unknown building, full of unknown persons, while already having a suspect to be tagged along was risky and henceforth to be avoided by the book.

That was, what he found lacking in TV detectives. Like with soldiers the manuals for members of the police task forces were designed as a fallback. A safeguard versus the human-factor which could endanger any officer or detective while criminals roamed around or lurked. Of course being smarter than the books was a known and unspoken competition among detectives, yet in the real profession those were men and women willing to face the tougher truism of life. On TV it were mostly immature and unstable egomaniacs, mockeries of any honest work, who worried only about their fame, fans and quotes.

The door opened and a woman, estimate in her twenties, smiled shyly at him.

“Detective Gorge?”

“Yes, Ma'am. Please tell me, if you know the man besides me.”

The woman looked at the suspect, recognition clearly in her eyes. “Jacob, you really made it here!”

Before the Detective could react the woman, obviously overjoyed, had catapulted herself into the hugging arms of the stranger.

The stranger still looked absent to Adrian, yet finally started to talk.

“Viola, I promised. Just ran out of luck, half the way in the forest my medication stopped working.”

“The new laws, I had nearly forgotten.” Viola seemed concerned. Turning to the detective she added:

“Jacob's heart. By law he could not bring foreign medication along.”

“We get this solved, I already have a supply in my atelier, don't worry.”

Adrian sensed no contradictions and nothing overtly suspicious. Artists were among those people who could easily be mistaken for drug-crazed or lunatics occasionally.

Jacob turned towards the Detective.

“Detective Gorge, the diner offers a free meal to all public servants. Its an old tradition we hold to. Why do we not handle our affairs and meet there to talk in lets say... ten minutes?”

Now Gorge knew this was a tourist. Criminals would be happy with getting away while most citizens always surprised themselves with some kind of etiquette or sense of duty when meeting police detectives.

Because of his extra training course in public relations he answered:

“Yes, that is a fine offer. Thanks. I really could take a break and I would enjoy some coffee.”


Where will this story go next? Your choices are below...
1343111.title: Romeo comes Home.

choices: Jacob arrives after Adrian ate his veggy-ham with eggs...
13431111.content:
Detective Gorge entered the Diner on his day full of surprises and met the next one. "Coffee!" The thought shot through his head so fast, that he did not even realize he articulated it as well. Yes, coffee. Not something with caffeine, Adrian smelled the purest aroma of coffee since his last visit with Aunt Gena. The old lady was iron in her enforcement of one ritually held family discussion per month.

Aunt Gena tended to be even more rigorous with her insistence, that a good coffee and a homemade cake based in fresh ingredients were absolute musts for any civilized family of decent income! Adrian had already grown up with fast-food and sugared cakes from the cool-boxes of countless supermarkets. Yet on her good side Aunt Gena really made cakes of a fine though antiquated taste and her coffee, innumerable the nights at work within which he had longed for one cup of her elite-coffee.

"It was not the cheap crap which came like a punch to the stomach." Adrian thought. No, coffee with Aunt Gena had meant still mineral water was heated to flow through the powdered beans which were prepared just minutes before usage. "They must breath a moment, boy." was what his aunt tended to say.

Adrian was far from ignorant. He was no homely type either. Already back in high-school had he realized, that his family was exceptionally normal. No child-abuse, no frequent beatings, no crack-smoking parents or anything else from the media. Banally adapted...

Norma Hows eyes fell upon her newest customer, just as he reacted to the aromatic smell of her secret brew. She had always loved to be a caretaker for the wandering folks. When her youngest daughter was killed in a car-accident, she even had found comfort in her self-chosen role. Norma was the patron, provider of some food and drink, as well as the local elder, provider of a mother's touch and wisdom on occasion.

The new customer was obviously one of the big city folks and clearly a Police Detective. Before she had seen the badge at his belt she had already known. The way they walk, hold themselves and watch around telltales of certain professions. This was an upright and forthcoming young man, she could sense that her eyes gathered the proper clues.

Patron she was she had readied a cup of her legendary coffee and even unleashed her professional smile. Either the throat-quencher or the heart-warmer would surely score.

And so they did. Adrian had finished his proverbial inner monologue just in time to see Norma, smiling a broad smile born of honesty, approach him with a steaming cup of coffee on her little tray. Holy Chorus, he felt like touched by an angel that moment.



I now pass the writer's baton, as I contributed my parts.


On the contributor's request, I edited a word in this addition. --Joy

13432.content:
riding on the wind
chasing clouds before dawn
her fun little car zips through time
trial, crisis, enlightenment and damnation

here above the earth
everything laid out below
jigsaw puzzle farms, fields, mountains and meadows
she rides her fun little car toward heaven
or maybe hell

something happened somewhere back there
where, she's not certain, there somewhere
far below, between a mountain and a stream
a gurgling mountain choir
singing eternal hymns

time passes, and yet
where there is no time how can time pass
through this cloudy dawn sky
brisk air, moist with snowflakes
melting as they touch her cheek

forward or backward, never sideways
her fun little car carries her onward
sailing through life after death
life despite death
perhaps life without death

she remembers it then
the air horn blaring like gabriel's trumpet
calling her home, carrying her forward
past the embankment, and into the sky

flying here among the clouds
she supposes she must have died

13432.title: Her fun little car

134322.content:
It dawns on her suddenly, catching her unaware. One moment she is admiring the view of the Earth far below as she sails among dawn clouds, tinged with pink, snowflakes melting as they touch her cheek, and then the thought pops into head without warning. Such an interesting little thought. Before it registers, as it hangs there on the edge of consciousness, she plays with it, a kitten toying with a string, and such a lovely string it is. Then she lets it land, that odd, pretty little thought, opening in her consciousness like a flower. She supposes she must have died, and then she wonders what comes next.

She is still sitting in the leather seat of her purple sports car, her hands on the steering wheel, her radio so low she can barely make it out, some silly talk show she never really pays attention to. As if on cue, Ganesha faces her. Her car glides to a stop just short of his great purple trunk.

"Why are you here? I'm not a Hindu or a Brahman or whatever it is they call themselves these days."

Ganesha shrugs. The question is too ordinary to bother answering.

"Heaven, hell, or a fresh start?"

Puzzled, she frowns.

"I don't understand. You're not St. Peter, nor God, nor Jesus. What authority do you have to ask me such a thing?"

Ganesha shrugs again, then waits patiently for her answer. It kind of annoys her, the shrugging.

Once more he asks, "Heaven, hell, or a fresh start?"
134322.title: She Supposes She Must Have Died

choices: Hell is being born in suburbia
Hell is being born in a war zone
Hell is a lake of fire and brimstone
1343222.content:
She knows all about heaven. After all, she grew up in a Christian home, went to church every Sunday her whole life long. Under the guidance of a morning radio show, she worked her way through the entire Bible, not once, but twice. While she would never claim to be a theologian, she has a pretty good grasp of what heaven promises.

Ganesha puzzles her. He waits patiently for her answer, but the size and shape of him intimidates her. Like most people, she didn't spend much time thinking about death or the afterlife. She was far too busy living. Still, if she had, she never would have pictured the colorful Ganesha, not blue, not purple, something in between the two, and decked from head to tail to the end of his trunk in jewels, gold, silver, and all sorts of shiny adornment.

"Heaven sounds awfully nice, at least from what I've been told. A fresh start in this life sounds interesting, too. I've heard though that you can't really start fresh because every life is wound in among too many other lives and those lives have a vote on what you do through the choices they make for themselves. Tell me about hell. Is it really fire and brimstone and eternal punishment.

Ganesha shrugs again, but answers, "I wouldn't know. I've never been there. It's quite a popular choice, though. Less popular than either of the other two, mind, but popular enough to surprise those who fear it most of all."

"Can I change my mind if I don't like it?"

This time Ganesha doesn't shrug. It almost seems like he smiles.

"There is but one thing I know: every choice is permanent but no choice is eternal."

That gets her attention. It defies everything she has ever been taught. Then again, sitting in her car listening to a radio talk show host babbling about politics and taxes, while being quizzed by the Hindu god of death is also nothing like she's been taught. Death is turning out to be full of surprises.

"No choice is eternal, eh? Okay. Let me try hell."

"As you wish..."
1343222.title: Hell

13432222.content:
thunder born of man rolls across the horizon
cowering beneath a hidden stone wall
her mouth filled with rags torn from her dress
hiding her screams from armed patrols
death surrounds her, but here and now
her child demands to join the world

timing each breath between contractions
taught to do so by women who never knew lamaze
she screams, pushes, feeling the child tear loose
into the arms of her waiting daughter
still a child herself, but waiting, holding out her arms
wondering if her mother will die

hell is being born in a war zone, the girl decides
as the baby comes sliding into her arms
she pulls away the remaining placenta
cuts the cord with her only knife
hoping the flame cleaned the blade
enough to save her mother

carefully, she splashes the screaming child with water
washes away the blood and gore and afterbirth
her mother so quiet she fears she has died
but follows each step the way she was taught
save the baby first, her mother had said
no matter what happens to me

she discovers she has a sister
after wrapping her sister in her last clean shirt
praying soldiers have not heard the screams
she lays the baby on her mother's chest
relieved to notice the rise and fall of steady breathing
the baby finds the nipple, quieted by the need to suckle

hell is being born in a war zone
she tells herself again
watching her new sister
drawing life from their mother's breast

The old lion paces its cage quite pensively as the toothless maw gapes widely, in a slow yawn, even as the ever growing crowd mingle upon the zoo's closing day, the swishes of a tawny tail evident. It had spent 20 years inside the enclosure that was its home, mulling on old memories it recalls its days as a young cub, bright-eyed and ready to explore the world which seemed so big at the time. Alas, now it was wondering if it would remain in its familiar surroundings or else explore wider pastures. Then with a sleepy flick, it closes its wavering eyes.

The lion sleeps tonight.

13432222312.content:
The old Lion slept in pockets as the night dragged into morning. She knew that today her fate would be decided. Would she be taken to new and better pastures to roamand be content for however many days she had left or was she goong to be slaughtered and made into dog food. Her heart trembled as she lay, caged, worn out and wishing that she was like the humans who had over the years come to see her in her prime. The children in wonderment and the old nodding their head and telling tales of the war and meeting Lions face to face in the jungle.

She felt her spirit rising above the cage that hed been her home for the past twenty years and as she looked down could see the the wardens looking at her limp body.

"The old girl's gone... worn out and probably too weary to be moved."

She gasped and felt a shock like electrisity go through her body. When she woke up, she had no recolection that her former life had been that of a lioness.

"Sheila! You fell asleep on that garden chair. I hope you havn't got sunburn honey."

Sheila stretched and yawned, her mouth now full of beautiful white teeth. Her blonde hair flowing down her back like a Lion's main.

"I hate to disturb my sleeping beauty." her husband James tapped the glass on his watch and beckoned her to make haste.

"We have a bout twenty minutes to get to the school and pick your two cubs up, you know the twin son and daughter that we made together eleven years ago. Daniel has football tonight and Ariel has Ballet. Come on my sleepy head, I know you stayed up last night finishing your book."
As the couple drove off to collect the siblings, James asked again.as Sheila looked in the wing mirrer thinking, is this real? Am i a human now? Whaw! How amazing is this.

"Well," he paused to listen. "Did you finishe it?"

"Yes, i will let you read it later honey. She glanced at the handsome man driving beside her.

"Mmm." she murmered.

Arriving at the school the couple got out and walked towards the playground. Sheila looked at a man who was pacing up and down as if in a hurry, she glanced again and screwed he face. I know him from somewhere she thought, then almost falling over one of the children running to get to the man.

"Watch what your doing honey," James remarked. "You almost fell there. Oh, here they are!" he said.

"What do you mean why? Isn't it bloody obvious?"
"Not to me."
"Well wake the fucking hell up, mate. You're not accomplishing anything by standing around with your finger up your arse."

"You're not listening, asshole. This isn't a holiday. You've got a job to do. You do the job. Then you can worry about why you did it."
"I don't want to do anything unless there's a reason."
"This isn't about what you want. I'm telling you there's a fucking reason."
"That's not good enough."
"Look. Either go back there and finish what you started, or I'm going to send your arse downtown. You're not gonna like that."

"It's a hell of a lot worse."

John opened his eyes, slowly. There was a rhythmic noise in his ear. He looked over. A heart monitor?
Someone shifted beside him.
"Where am I...?" he said, and found his throat was raw and sore.
"Recovery," the person said. A nurse. "You just came out of surgery, honey. It's normal to feel a little out of it."
"I had the weirdest dream. God was there. And he was British."
"Oh that's funny. Odd though, most people don't dream under anaesthetic."
"Huh."

1351.content:
The sun feels good on my skin, Sunshine on my shoulders... that was a song once, wasn't it? I can't seem to remember who wrote it though... Its been so long since I've felt the sun, it seems like years since it's been here... here in this beautiful little spot. I had a dog once who had a spot on his back, I named him Rocky... I wonder why I never spotted this place before?

Such a short walk, and yet so different, so peaceful here! Give peace a chance, that's what I say! Beautiful trees and flowers and birds... like lillies of the field and sparrows in the air! There is someone above the clouds who takes care of them all! Someone once told me who it was, but I seem to have forgotten... Perhaps a celestial gardener?

Such a beatiful place, I'd like to stay here forever, but I feel like it's time to leave. I'm so confused, I wish someone would let me know, should I stay or should I go? Go where? Somewhere... over a rainbow! Where white birds fly from a golden cage. It's a Beautiful Day....


"Hey Billy, have you seen your grandfather?"

"OK Mom. I bet he's at the park again, he always ends up there."

13511.content:
Yes, that's right. Instead of thinking of things lost, think of things found.
Extend that - things, people, values, blessings. Don't count what is lost, count what is found.
If you dwell on the lost, you'll lose more - you'll lose your peace of mind.
Instead, think of what you have already and everything new you've gained today. Heard a new joke? Tasted a new dish? Felt a raindrop? Saw a flower bloom? Called an old friend, or made a new one? Smile. Laugh! Be happy! Think of things found!

They go home, hand in hand, everything between them, easy. Or so it seems at first. Muddled brains never seem to help the situation and once I start to realize this is not where I am supposed to be... things are not so easy.

My name is Marcel. I am supposed to live here. But who is this Billy? Are we really related? We don't look anything alike. Unease skitters up my spine and I know I must leave. But where do I go? This is my home.... of that I am almost certain.... but not so fully certain. If I go, then where? Who will help me?
