1352.content:
Between the hours of night and day
Shades of the prison house came to play.
The contents of my nightmare
Would petrify the staunchest square.
Blood on the sun
From the kingdom
Of childhood
Guess some were born to lose!
Visualize a mother's pain
As the bullet rips through
The marrow of her babe,
Tearing consciousness away from him
And him from the seed of an unfinished dream.
How do you spare laughter
In the wake of murderous disaster?
My song will translate commotion to unawakened earth,
And give instruction in the recital of a dirge.
For the lords rise early to feast
And the overlords' tyranny increaseth.
They multiply sin
By the invention of iniquity:
Products of negative creativity,
Blinded to the heat of infant tears,
Communicators of hard stares.
We the slaves of society,
The youth is the enemy
Of everything good.
And even though we struggle to stay true,
Hypocrisy reeks of a deaf attitude.
It's been this way
Since a spade's been a spade
And there aint a sign
That things will ever change.
Can we play down the tragedy?
Picture a prototype parody of justice
Up from your high horses.
Night falls on the pulse of our sorrow,
We fall like a sparrow.
We bleed
At the mercy of those who lead.
How do you build a future
That you killed moments ago?
If the head kills the breast-nurtured
Then who shows the way to go?
Terror illustrates individual odyssey.
This anaesthetic mind control provokes my fantasy!
1352.title: Mind control

13521.content:
The breath hitched for a moment, stuck in in his throat. His fist tightened around the grass beside him. Fingers brushed the hair out of his eyes, being sure to be gentle. Despite the pain that radiated through his body, he allowed a small smile to graze his features.

"Never guessed this was how I'd go." The fingers that had moved to his hair froze.

"You aren't going anywhere." He could tell in his brother's voice that he didn't believe his words.

"Wouldn't be so bad if I did." He said before another breath caught in his throat. He arched his back against the pain. There was no way out of this one, he was going to die. Both horses were gone, taken by the same man who had shot him. They couldn't get back, not until he was dead anyways.

"Stop it...don't talk like that. Ya know I need you." He reached from the younger boy's hand and squeezed.

"No ya don't...I...did what...I was born...to do." It was getting harder to talk. The sun would stay up to meet his death.

"No you haven't. All you've done is deal with me." The kid wasn't getting it. He didn't care that he'd been an almost designated caretaker. True, he sometimes groaned about it, but nothing gave him better pleasure than knowing that his brother was safe and happy.

"James...don't be...an idiot." He felt the kid stiffen momentarily before letting out a chuckle.

"Not an idiot Christopher, just don't wanna see you die."

"You'll under....understand oneday, kid...when your old...and gray."

"What that everyday you had to put up with me, had to deal with Ma and Pa using you to deal with all the labor. Don't see what the point was."

"What I was born to do." His breath was getting shallower, his body growing numb. The heat of the day was doing nothing to warm him. It was almost time.

"What do you mean, Chris?" There was sorrow and confusion mixed in his voice. Christopher smiled as he opened his eyes and looked up at his brother.

"I was born to lose...for you." The last of his life left his body, leaving James by himself, feeling like Christopher hadn't been the only one to lose.
13521.title: Born to lose

135212.content:
I sit in the chair,
rocking him to sleep.
Our souls intertwined;
his hand on my breast as he suckles.

I sit in the chair
reading a book about turtles.
His eyes light up as he repeats
the words while holding my hand and heart.

I sit in the chair

A disorderly stack of blocks

I sit in the chair
watching him sleep.
The fever gaining strength
while his body weakens.

I sit in the chair

Trying to focus on the love
instead of the loss as tears fall.

1352121.title: Creating Chaos

13521211.content:
I watch the wild shadows run from the light. They go to extraordinary lengths to avoid it. Leaping over stones, snaking through the undergrowth. I watch the wild shadows and I wonder: did that used to be me? Before my taming, was I this belly crawling creature that shivers and hides from sunlight, moonlight, starlight, and the lights made by men?

I was taught a better way. A learned man of the arcane arts showed me. There are millions of nooks and crannies: under feet, inside ears, between hairs, inside clothes, in the wrinkles and dimples of fleshy folds, and most importantly, within the body itself.

I live where the light will never reach: in the esophagus, under the skull, twisting along veins and arteries.

I watch the wild shadows. My feelings for them are ambivalent.
13521211.title: Light the shadow's fear

135212111.content:
I don't remember too much about what it was like before the hard times. I was kinda young when it all happened. Never even went to a school, like some of the older kids I know did.

Just little fragments I remember. Going to this church, a man in a black suit standing up in front and telling us all things like pray for peace or love our brothers. I didn't like my brother much then, he was older and he always picked on me. I wish he was still alive now...

Then after that we'd stop at this place where we got chicken and mashed potatoes, and we brought it over to share with my grandparents. They were really old, like maybe sixty. They're long gone now.

After "the shit came down," as my dad put it, we left our house and started walking. I remember it was always really cold and then most of the plants and trees died, which was kinda OK, because once they dried out you could burn them to keep warm...
135212111.title: Tomorrow

1352121112.content:
Life on the Road.


Dreams fade as we look into the cloudless sky.
Memories of a life that was turmoil, despair our rain.
Cracks decorate the endless road as we each walk alone.
Mainkind has all but ended, a stigma of a leaderless fall.
The world has ended, life on the road, has begun.
1352121112.title: Life on the Road

13521211121.content:
Oh the sun it burns so bright
with an ethereal never-ending light
It lights a spark in the darkness
and yet it is but one among so many
13521211121.title: Insignificant Sun-

135212112.content:
"Yesterday, all my troubles seemed so far away...
Now it looks as though they're here to stay, oh I believe in yesterday..."
- Paul McCartney

It's kinda surprising how adaptable people are, how much we try to pretend everything is still normal as conditions slowly deteriorate.

I guess it's the old lobster in the pot theory. You know, if you put a lobster in a cold pot of water and turn on the stove, the water warms slowly enough to where the lobster doesn't realize he's getting cooked until it's too late.

Someone told me they do this because if you throw a live lobster into a pot of water that's already boiling, you can hear it scream before it dies. (I don't believe it, but I'm not going to boil a lobster to find out.)

At any rate, it seems like only yesterday when the whole swine flu thing was just another big non-event, like the bird flu, or terrorists on airplanes after 9-11. Then there started to be more people dying.

But the news just kept on saying there was no cause for alarm. Just wash your hands, keep you kids home if they get a fever, the usual BS.

Then a woman at work told me her friend's daughter had died. She had no previous health issues, just a normal twelve year old kid. Then she got the flu. Fever, chills, vomiting, the usual. Then she got a nosebleed. Then she started bleeding from the eyes, and coughing up blood. And then she died.

But there was nothing about it on the news...

As soon as I heard that, I knew things weren't right and it was time to get the hell out of Dodge. I told my boss I wasn't feeling well so I could leave. (Since nearly half the department was out sick by then, he didn't think I was faking it.)

I stopped at Albertson's on the way home to stock up on supplies before heading for the cabin. Got a little fresh fruit and meat, and a couple two pound blocks of cheese. But the rest was purely survival stuff, no refrigeration needed if the power went out. Salt, pepper, canned corn, peas, pears, tuna, spam, sacks of rice, dried beans, flour, sugar, coffee, and a couple bottles of whiskey (for medicinal purposes, of course).

Traffic was pretty light going out of the city, I don't think anyone realized what was happening yet.

Just outside of Joshua Tree a guy standing next to a pickup tuck flagged me down: "Mister, my wife's really sick, can you help me out?"

I looked at the man, blood was starting to drip from his eyes...
135212112.title: Yesterday

1352121121.content:
My first thought was to step on the gas and get the hell away from these plague carriers. But although I'm no longer much of a churchgoer, I still believe in Christian charity, so I had to stop and see what I could do. Besides, I was thinking I might be immune to this pig flu anyway, being as I'm over fifty.

"She's just lying there hardly breathing. Do you know anything about medicine?" he asked.

I pulled out my cell, punched in 911 and hit "Send" as we walked over to the truck: "You have reached 911. All our operators are busy. Please be prepared to explain the nature of your emergency..."

I punched "End". The way this thing is spreading, I wasn't surprised. I imagine the hospitals and EMTs are pretty much overwhelmed by now. It looks like we're on our own.

I looked down at the woman stretched across the bench seat. She had dried blood beneath her eyes, but they were now leaking a translucent yellow liquid. She was staring catatonic-like, shallow panting breath. Looked to me like she was about ready die.

The man looked at me like he still thought I could do something for his wife, but I'd pretty much done all I could by dialing 911. Not wanting to disappoint, I reached out and put my hand on her forehead to maybe check for a fever or something. In hindsight, it was a stupid move.

The woman hissed at me like a snake, reached up real quick and grabbed onto my arm with a grip like a linebacker. Before I knew what was happening she bit a big chunk out of my right bicep!

I screamed in pain and jumped back, pushing her away, started running for my truck. The guy came running after me shouting "She didn't mean it! She's sick! You gotta help us!"

I slammed and locked the door, turned the key and put the pedal to the metal. II believe in helping people as long as they don't cross the line. And biting a chunk out of my arm is way over that line.
1352121121.title: Aid And Comfort

13521211211.content:
So I'm trying to make it to my cabin but my arm is bleeding pretty bad. I pull over next to a little cafe where I usually stop to eat when I'm up in JT, maybe someone there can help. Looks like the place is deserted though, then I remember they're closed on Wednesdays. Just my luck.

I get out of the truck and rummage around in back, find the Jim Beam and a clean t-shirt. I rip a piece off the shirt to make a bandage, take a healthy pull off the bottle to ease the pain, pour some of the whiskey on my arm to kill the germs, then bandage it.

Just as I'm getting back into my truck I hear a woman's voice, "Steve? Is that you? You gotta help us!"

I turn around, It's Jenny, from the cafe, and she's got one of her boys in tow, he's crying. Her clothes are torn, she's looking kinda shell shocked, something bad must've happened. "You gotta help us! Billie's gone crazy! He killed little Clayton! Bit his throat out!" She breaks down and collapses into my arms, sobbing.

I hold her for a minute then grab her by the shoulders, push her back a little and look into her eyes. "We gotta get out of here, go to my cabin, we'll be safe there."

She is sobbing uncontrollably. Struggling, she won't move as I try to get her into the truck. I look down at Trevor standing next to her, he's stopped crying, he's looking to me for direction. "Hey Trev, I need you to be the man in the family here, just for a little while, OK? can you help me out?"

He pauses for a second, then says "Come on woman, get in the truck! we gotta go!" sounding just like Billie.

She looks at him and smiles a little, they both get in the truck.
13521211211.title: Zombie Apocalypse

135212112111.content:
THE LONG AND WINDING ROAD

"I think we'd better rest here in this valley under the trees, it will be dark soon",

Bob puts his bag pack down and helps Terry with hers. After setting up camp, they sip the hot tea and munch their dinner - bananas, rice and dried beef. Directly in front of them is a long and winding road ahead.

Darkness soon creeps in and covers the whole valley with a blanket. The only light that one can see is the glow of their campfire. Bob throws more branches into the fire before turning to Terry.

" Let me look at your foot"

Gently, he massages her aching feet sore from walking the whole day. I wonder why nobody seems to travel on this road but assuringly he smiles at her,

" Don't worry, there will be lots of trucks coming by tomorrow"

They tuck themselves in their tent, zipping up their sleeping bags, soon snoring, oblivious to the beastly cannibals creeping towards them under the cover of night. The cannibals are starving.
135212112111.title: The Long and Winding Road

1352121121111.content:
What was he doing here?! He'll only get killed!

I resisted the temptation to try and signal to him, silently of course. It was probably too late anyway. This is how I justified it to myself, every time. There was nothing I could have done, it was inevitable, I'd have only made it worse. Yeah, the especially the latter. Any form of conflict requires confidence. Confidence in your ability and in yourself. I mean, generally I could handle any old spiky, slime encrusted abherration, but I needed to plan, prepare, make sure all the odds were stacked in my favour.

I heard him calling, jeering, taunting at the creature. Probably waving whatever weapon he had around, building up his bravado. I don't think he heard the sound of tentacle on rafter, the sound off hoof on concrete floor.

This wasn't your average, drop-on-head beastie. This one had style. Which made it worse.

The calls stopped abruptly. Oh no, he wasn't dead yet, he had just seen it, glistening and oozing in its all its glory.

The came the long scream, and a chain of noises too disgusting to repeat. Then, quietly, what we like to call the "munching" started. In jobs like this, black humour was the only kind available.

I counted to ten, and emerged from a shadow, and stepped into the light of the warehouse proper. Good, It had its back to me, I think...

A bone snapped, covering the sound of the pilot flame coming on. I grinned, well, at least the guy would get a proper cremation... did I just think that? I had been working here far too long.
1352121121111.title: The long scream

choices: Feel Like I'm Fixin' to Die
1352121121112.content:
We take the right on Park Blvd and head for my cabin. Jenny's still pretty shaken up, but getting better. Unfortunately I'm getting worse...

Getting kinda dizzy, maybe I lost more blood than I though from the bite? No, that's not it, my arm didn't bleed that much before I got the bandage on. Suddenly the headache hits me like a bolt of lightning, I can hardly see where I'm going as I pull the truck over to the side of the road.

"What's going on Steve?" Jenny asks.

"Got this mind-splitting headache!" I say, rubbing my eyes.

My hands come away wet, and I look down as see they are covered with blood. "Oh shit!"

I jump out of the truck, Jenny hollers "Steve? What that matter!" and gets out, approaching me.

"Don't touch me, I'm infected! Get back in the truck!"

I open up the camper shell and grab my backpack, tuck in the Ruger and a bottle of whiskey.

"Take the truck, you and Trevor get out of here! We're only a couple blocks from the turnoff for Desert Shadows, you know the way to my place from there."

"Steve, I can't leave you here!"

"Go Jenny! I know this old medicine man who lives near a spring about a mile back from here. If anyone can heal me, he can. And if he can't and I show up at the cabin looking like an extra from 28 Days Later, there's a shotgun in the kitchen closet, don't be afraid to use it."

"Steve! I can't!" Jenny says, crying.

"Jenny, you gotta be strong! For Trevor! You can do it, I'll be OK, I gotta go!"

"Come on Mom, I'm scared!" Trevor calls from the truck.

She gets back in the truck and they pull away as I head up the trail...
1352121121112.title: The Blinding Light

13521211211122.content:
I hadn't told Jenny a complete lie. There was an old medicine man who used to live in a cabin next to a spring that you could reach by walking this trail, but the cabin was more like five miles away. And I'd last seen Johnny Red Hawk twenty years ago, he had to be pushing eighty then, so it wasn't likely he'd still be around if I managed to make it there.

No, I had another plan in mind when I left the truck. I'd hike as far up the trail as I could make it before nightfall. Then I'd set up camp, build a little fire, drink enough whiskey to get a good buzz on, then put a bullet in my head before this disease turned me into a blood-thirsty zombie.

But as they say, God laughs at our plans...
13521211211122.title: Feel Like I'm Fixin' to Die

135212112111221.content:
I guess I have more energy and daylight than I thought, because I'm able to reach the cabin. But I am right about my other assumption, Johnny Red Hawk is long gone.

The cabin is empty, local scavengers had taken anything of value, but it is undamaged. (Too far away from civilization to be a target of vandals.)

I throw down my pack, drink the last of the water from my canteen, and collapse, exhausted from the hike and the sickness that is slowly taking hold of me. But after resting a while I feel a little better, so I decide to go out and collect some firewood before it gets dark.

I take three steps out the door when I hear a familiar hiss and I find myself staring down a red diamondback. A big sucker, gotta be almost five foot.

I try to back away but it's too late. The snake hits me just above my right knee and I fall to ground, writhing in pain. Eventually I manage to crawl back into the cabin. I pull the bottle of whiskey from my pack. (I remember reading somewhere that whiskey counteracts snakebite, and even if it doesn't at least it kills the pain.)

A few minutes later I'm sitting on the floor, my head swimming from sickness, venom, and alcohol, when the snake slithers past me. It coils itself up in a corner on the other side of the cabin, staring at me with it's cold reptilian eyes...
135212112111221.title: Snakebit

1352121121112211.content:
"I should get my gun and shoot you, but your bite might be doing me a favor. Your poison will probably kill me soon enough, save me the trouble of shooting myself," I say to the snake.

"My venom won't kill you, but your "antidote" might, unless you drink enough water to flush the poison out of your system."

"Hah, I'm hallucinating a talking snake! And even if I believe you are speaking to me, I got no water left in my canteen... Either way, I guess it's time for me to die."

"Not if I can help it! I'll get you some water, just give me a minute."

With that the snake starts to shed his skin, in the process turning into Johnny Red Hawk.

"Now I know I'm tripping, no way this is really happening!" I say.

Johnny walks out of the cabin with my empty canteen and returns a few minutes later. "Drink as much as you can," he says, handing me the filled canteen.

I gulp down several mouthfuls of the cool water, draining half the canteen, then look over at Johnny. "You really are here! What the hell's up with that?"

"I think the Great Spirit decided I wasn't done yet, so he brought me back."

"Come on Johnny, you told me you never believed in all that metaphysical shit. You used to laugh at me when I was into Castaneda back in the 70's!"

"Well Steve, I learned a valuable lesson after I died. I doesn't matter what I believe about the Great Spirit, It only matters what He believes."

"So why did you bite me, Johnny! That hurt like hell!"

"The poison will kill the sickness in your blood if you are strong enough to survive. No magic, just science."

Johnny reaches up into the rafters of the cabin and pulls down an old wool blanket. He shakes the dust out of it and hands it to me. "The desert is cold at night. I don't want you to die of hypothermia, all my work here would go to waste!"

I take the blanket and stumble to an old cot in the corner of the cabin and lie down. I say "Thanks Johnnie."

I look back to where he was standing, but he is gone....
1352121121112211.title: Revelation

13521211211122111.content:
I wake slowly, my head fuzzy, pounding, thinking "God, what a nightmare! Zombies, snakes, I must have done some serious drinking last night. Gonna be late for work again, the boss will kill me!"

I open my eyes and the fog slowly lifts, I realize it was no dream. I'm lying on a half broken cot in Johnny Red Hawk's old cabin, looking down at a pool of my congealed vomit on the floor. My leg hurts like hell, but at least I'm alive, and I feel the sickness is gone now.

I sit up on the edge of the cot until the dizziness passes and try to stand. My right leg is throbbing from the snake bite, it won't bear my full weight. I pull one of the rails from the cot to use as a makeshift crutch and hobble across the cabin to my backpack and canteen, weak with hunger and thirst.

I drink the remaining water from the canteen, dig around in my backpack and pull out an old trail mix granola bar and wolf it down. As my strength is returning I decide to do something about the snake bite. I tear a strip from the blanket to use as a bandage and soak it with the remaining whiskey to sterilize it, then wrap it around my leg. It'll have to do until I can get proper medical care.

I grab my backpack and canteen and hobble out the door. The sun is high in the sky, and it's getting hot. I look at my watch to check the time and realize a day and a half have gone by, I must have slept damn near forty hours! Gotta try to make it to my cabin before nightfall, make sure Jenny and Trevor are all right.

I stop at the spring and splash cool water on my face, it's great to be alive! I fill my canteen, drink most of the water down and fill it again. I Take off my t-shirt and soak it in the spring, wring most of the water out and put it back on. That should keep me cool for a while.

Slowly making my my way down the trail I almost walk right into the snake again, he's sunning himself on a flat rock. I stop dead in my tracks. The snake stares right at me, bobs his head as if nodding to me in recognition, then slithers away, disappearing into the rocks.

"Thanks, Johnny," I say, still not sure if what I experienced last night was real or a fever dream.

I keep on walking, best as I can...
13521211211122111.title: Rise and Shine!

135212112111221111.content:
"You listen to me, Trevor. I'm gonna walk in the tool shed and shut the door, then I want you to put the lock on and lock me in, just like we lock the bikes in our shed at home."

"I don't want to, Mommy!"

"You gotta do this, Trevor! Do you see my eyes? Do you remember how crazy Daddy got after his eyes started bleeding? I can feel it starting, you have to lock me up so I don't hurt you!"

"But I'll be all alone!"

"After you lock me in, you go get help. You walk to Miss Brenna Red Hawk's place, you remember her. She's right down the hill in that first house on the left. She'll be able to help, but you gotta get going!"

"OK, Mom," Trevor says, as he locks the door.

From inside Jenny calls out "I love you Trevor, I'll always love you. Now hurry!"

"Love you too Mommy!" he says, then takes off running.
135212112111221111.title: Meanwhile, Back at Steve's Cabin...

1352121121112211112.content:
The heat and lack of food is making me dizzy. Been walking for over two hours, I should have been back to the main road by now. I must have drifted off the trail somewhere. Sun's getting pretty low in the sky, looks like I won't make it back to my cabin tonight. Hope Jenny & the boy are OK...

In the distance I spot a small cabin. As I get closer I can see the place is surrounded by the rusted remains of times gone by. Old metal and neon hotel signs, vintage gas pumps, and some crumbling junk cars that were already old long before I was born. I know where I am now, Ben Walker's place, Jenny's father.

I walk up and knock on the door and call out: "Mister Walker, you in there?"

No answer.

I remember Jenny telling me since her mom died, her dad spent a lot of time camping in the desert, "prospecting". He'd come back with old salvaged objects, and rocks and crystals that he'd make a few bucks selling to the kids that ran the gift shop down the hill. Guess he must be out there somewhere now.

I don't know him all that well, just met him a few times years ago when I was seeing Jenny. But I'm pretty sure he'd forgive me for breaking in, considering my circumstances.

Most folks out here hide a key somewhere. I look under the doormat, not there, too obvious. I check above the door sill, no luck. Then I look underneath the potted plans near the door and find the key underneath the one on the left.

I let myself in and immediately run to the sink to gulp down some water. Then I look for something to eat. I find a can of Spam and some bread, make myself a couple sandwiches that I wolf down with another large glass of water. Then I lie down on the couch to rest...
1352121121112211112.title: Rusted Relics

13521211211122111122.content:
"Get up off my couch, whoever you are!"

The harsh words awaken me, I roll over and open my eyes. It's Ben Walker, and he's pointing a shotgun straight at me.

"Ben, it's me! Steve Andrews!"

"Stevie? You look like hell boy, I thought you was some vagrant that broke into my cabin. What happened to your arm? And your leg?"

"I got bit on the arm by some lady who gave me the plague, and bit on the leg by a snake that cured me, it's a long story."

"I heard something about the sickness on the radio, saying it's making people crazy. Have you seen Jennie or Billie and the boys? I hope they're all right..."

"You'd better sit down Ben, and you might want to get yourself something to drink."

I explain what happened with Jennie, I can see Ben holding back the tears when he hears that his youngest grandson is dead. We sit there in silence for a few minutes, then Ben finishes his whiskey, stands up and says "We'd best get going..."
13521211211122111122.title: Wake up with a Gun

135212112111221111222.content:
Why did I let you lock me in this shed! I should have gone with you, gone for help. My poor son, all alone now...

But at least you're still alive, not like your brother Billy... Billy, can you hear me? Are you up there with the angels?

Billy, my head is killing me! My eyes are bleeding, could you go get your mommy some Tylenol?

Billy, I always loved you best... Such a sweet kid, not like your brother! Trevor was always too smart for his own good, always sassing back. I shoulda beat his ass, Billie! I shoulda beat him with a broomstick, just like your daddy beats me! And now he's locked me in this tool shed with no food and one lousy bottle of water!

I can't drink the water Billie! It burns my throat! I need blood! sweet, salty, warm BLOOD!

Jennie pounds her fists and claws at the locked door, screaming.

AAAAAH! TREVOR! Are you OUT THERE? LET ME OUTTA HERE! I swear to God, when I get out I'm gonna BEAT YOU and BITE YOU and YOU'RE GONNA BE SORRY!
135212112111221111222.title: Jennie Insane

1352121121112211112221.content:
"...headaches, light sensitivity, and bleeding from the eyes. If you or anyone you know is displaying these symptoms, please call 1-760-555-3242. Help will be dispatched from the 29 Palms Marine Corps Medical center. You and your family will be escorted to the quarantine area for your own safety, and the safety of others... This is a public service announcement from radio station KXCM. Due to a medical emergency situation the communities of Morongo Valley, Yucca Valley, Joshua Tree, and Twentynine Palms are under a temporary curfew until further notice. Do not attempt to leave the area, all highways have been blockaded by military police. Please remain indoors, and do not allow any strangers into your home, or anyone displaying the following symptoms..."

Brenda turns off the radio, muttering to herself, "Well, Ken, it looks like they've really gone and done it this time... Wish you hadn't gone off and got yourself killed in Iraq, I really could use a man around here right now," she says, looking at his framed picture on the wall.

There's a frantic knock on the door: "Miss Brenda, it's me, Trevor! Please let me in! My mom is really sick, you gotta help!"
1352121121112211112221.title: Quarantine

13521211211122111122211.content:
Brenda hesitates. She looks over at the picture and says, "I hear you Ken, I know that boy could very well be contagious and cause my death. But if I didn't help him I'd be killing my own humanity." Then she says "Come on in Trevor, the door's open!"

The boy bursts in and says "You gotta help my mom, she's really sick! She had me lock her in Mister Andrew's tool shed!"

"Trevor, don't get to close to me, OK? You might be contagious, you know what is?"

"Sure, It's like when one of the kids in school gets a cold and I end up getting it from them."

"If I get too close to you and end up getting sick, I won't be able to help you."

The phone rings and Brenda picks it up. "Hello."

"Brenda? This is Betty from down the street."

"Oh Hi Betty, are you all right?"

"Not really. George is pretty sick, his eyes are bleeding and he's pretty agitated. I gave him a sleeping pill to calm him down. And now I have this terrible headache. I called the number on the radio a while ago, they're sending someone out to take us to quarantine. I wanted to ask if you could... hold on a second, there's someone at the door..."

Betty puts the phone down on the table and answers the door. Brenda listens in on the phone and can hear her conversation. "I'm so glad you boys made it here this quick. And I those surgical masks are a good idea, I wish I had worn one when my husband first got sick."

A muffled voice says "And where is your husband now, Mrs Palmer?"

"He's lying down right over there on the sofa."

Another muffled voice says "Don't get too close to him John, looks like he's a stage three. And the woman, her eyes are starting to bleed. Looks like we'll have to sanitize this place."

Betty's voice: "What are you doing with that gun?" followed by the sound of a scream and machine gun fire, then silence.

Brenda, horrified, hangs up the phone. She walks over to the window and looks over at her neighbor's house, sees two soldiers in a Humvee driving away.

Trevor calls from the kitchen, "Miss Brenda? There's a man on the radio that says if you have sick people you can call a number and he'll put them in a corateen to help them! Maybe we should call him about Mom!"

"No Trevor, I think we'd better try to help Mom on our own."

Brenda walks over to a closet, opens the door and pulls out a Ruger Mini-14 and a couple 30 round clips. She looks over at the picture on the wall, "Glad you left me this for self defense, Ken. Never thought I'd need it. Wish me luck.."

"Miss Brenda, why you got that gun?"

"There might be bad people who want to hurt us out there, Trevor. We have to protect ourselves. Now lets go help your mom..."
13521211211122111122211.title: Open the Door

135212112111221111222111.content:
"Miss Brenda, how come we're going this way? The road is shorter, it goes right to Mister Andrew's house!"

"We're going to sneak up the wash to get there, so nobody sees us. You know how sometimes if you're really still you can see coyotes hiding, moving from one bush to the next, stalking prey? We're gonna be like that. We don't want anyone to see us, in case they are bad people. Can you be real quiet, Trevor?"

"Sure, Miss Brenda, I'll be quiet like a coyote."

They hear the sound of a truck approaching and duck behind a creosote bush until it passes.

"That looked like Mister Andrews in that pickup truck!"

"Maybe it was, Trevor. We'll know soon enough."

After walking a little further they hear another vehicle and they hide once again.

Brenda looks out from behind the bush as Humvee drives up the road in the same direction as the pickup...
135212112111221111222111.title: Quiet, Like Coyotes

1352121121112211112221111.content:
"... address is one fifteen Desert Shadows Road. Neighbors reported loud screaming, possibly a stage three. Approach with caution."

"Roger."

John slows the Humvee as he takes the corner, looks over at his partner.

"Should be the last house on the left. Ready for another one, Matt?"
1352121121112211112221111.title: Help on the Way?

13521211211122111122211111.content:
We pull up in front of the cabin and park behind my truck. We walk up to the cabin, the door is locked. I unlock it and we enter, calling out "Jennie? Trevor? Anyone home?" No answer.

"Where do you think they went, Steve?" Ben asks.

"I don't really know," I say, looking over uneasily at a half-eaten sandwich and a glass of soda on the kitchen table.

Then we hear banging and screaming coming from outside, and we rush out the back door. The noise is coming from the tool shed. Ben recognizes the voice screaming voice. "Jennie! Hold on girl, we'll get you out!"

"Daddy? Is that you? Why did you lock me in here! AAAAHHHH!"

"Open the door and let her out, Steve!"

"Ben, she's not herself, she's infected! If I let her out she'll probably bite us! We'll have to restrain her, can you go back and get that rope from your truck?"

Ben walks to his truck and I walk back in the house and get my gun. We meet up back outside.

"Give me the rope, Ben. You take the gun."

"What for?"

"I'll unlock the door and try to restrain her, you stand back. Jennie's probably gonna fight like hell. If I can't hold her down, you might have to shoot."

"I can't kill my daughter!"

"Just shoot her in the leg to stop her, if you have to. You can't let her bite you, you'll get infected. I should be immune."
13521211211122111122211111.title: Daddy? Is That You?

135212112111221111222111111.content:
I open the door and Jennie rushes out, screaming. I knock her to the ground, she's thrashing around, she bites deep into my shoulder. I manage to get he pinned, face down, and I'm preparing to tie her up when I hear a harsh voice behind me call out: "Old man, drop the gun! And you sir, step away from the infected woman!"

I look up and see two soldiers, one with a gun pointed at me, the other has disarmed Ben. I freeze...
135212112111221111222111111.title: All Hell Breaks Loose

1352121121112211112221111111.content:
Brenda and Trevor creep up out of the wash behind Steve's place, hear the commotion going on. She looks over at the boy and holds her finger to her lips. Trevor whispers, "Quiet, like coyotes,right?" She nods in reply.

They sneak up and crouch behind the Humvee. Brenda feels a bad headache coming on, leans forward, rubbing her eyes. She pulls her hands away and stares in horror, seeing the blood on her fingers, knowing what it means.

Meanwhile Trevor has been watching what is going down in front of the tool shed. When he sees the soldiers draw their guns he runs toward them, yelling at the top of his lungs "LEAVE MY MOM ALONE!"

One of the soldiers clubs the kid with the butt of his rifle, knocking him unconscious. He looks over at the other soldier and says "Maybe we should just waste the lot of 'em, Matt. They're probably all infected anyways."

Brenda looks up in time to see what's happened and the rage starts to build in her. She jumps out from behind the Humvee, point her gun at the soldiers and yells "DROP YOUR WEAPONS!"

The soldiers turn and fire at her, she instantly shoots back. In the hail of machine gun bullets they all fall down...
1352121121112211112221111111.title: Leave My Mom Alone!

13521211211122111122211111111.content:
I wrestle and hog-tie Jennie with the rope, and step back out of biting range. She's rolling and thrashing in the dirt, but at least she can't hurt herself or anyone else now. I call over to Ben, "Are you all right?"

"I'm OK Steve, we'd better check on the others."

We look at the soldiers, they're both obviously dead.

We walk over to Brenda Redhawk. She's bleeding badly, gasping for breath, calling out incoherently "Ken ... I told you that damn gun wouldn't do me no good ... ... don't you worry 'bout me honey... I'll be along shortly... got some business to attend to first... "

I look down and see her blue eyes turn a dull gray, and I know she's gone.

I hear a faint rustling sound and I look down and see a rattlesnake slither from the right leg of her cutoff jeans, glistening as if it's just shed it's skin. The snake stops and looks up at me for a couple seconds with it's gray eyes and dark slit pupils, then slithers away...
13521211211122111122211111111.title: Life From Death

135212112111221111222111111111.content:
"Aaaah! Help me!" one of the soldiers cries out. We thought they were both dead, looks like one of them is still alive.

We hurry over to see what we can do. He's got bullet wounds in his gut and his right leg, the leg wound is bleeding quite badly. I take off my shirt and tear a strip off and tie it tightly around his leg above the wound, but it's still bleeding. I pick a stick up off the ground and use it to twist the bandage tight, the bleeding stops. I say to Ben, "How's Jenny doing, is she OK?"

He looks over towards her, jumps up and shouts "Fuckin' snake just bit her!" and he reaches for the soldier's gun.

"Let the snake be!" I call out, stopping him from shooting, "The bite mighta just saved her life!"

"I hurry over to Jenny, she's unconscious. The snake is still there, staring at me. I look back at the snake and say "Thanks, Brenda, I appreciate the help... And if you're looking to visit your grandpa before you move on, he's probably up near his old place."

The snake flicks it's tongue at me, turns and slithers into the wash, heading back towards Johnny Red Hawk's cabin...
135212112111221111222111111111.title: Snakebit II

1352121121112211112221111111112.content:
I look over at Ben, he's helping Trevor up, the boy is a little unsteady. "I'll take him inside and have him lie down, then come back and help with the others," he says, " we'd best get them out of this heat."

I untie Jenny, she's still unconscious. I pick her up under the arms and and start to half carry-half drag her toward the cabin. Ben comes out and helps me bring her the rest of the way. We lay her down on the bed in my room and go back outside to see to the soldier.

He's still unconscious, but the tourniquet has stopped the bleeding. Ben and I carry him into the cabin and put him on the couch.

Trevor is up, he walks over to see what we are doing. "Is he going to die?" he asks , looking at the soldier.

"I don't think so," I reply.

"Where's my mom?" he asks. "Is she OK?"

"She's in my room. Can you help us, find some washcloths and a basin of cold water?"

"OK Mister Andrews, I'll help," he says, as he hurries towards the kitchen.

Jenny is burning with fever from the sickness and the snake bite. Ben takes one of the washcloths from Trevor, squeezes most of the water from it and places it on her forehead. "Your'e gonna be all right," he says to her...
1352121121112211112221111111112.title: A Time for Healing

13521211211122111122211111111121.content:
With Ben and Trevor watching over Jenny, I walk back into the living room to check on the soldier. He's still unconscious, but his breathing is normal. I loosen the tourniquet to let the blood flow back into his leg. The bandage seems to be stopping the bleeding on it's own now, a good sign. I don't feel all that kindly towards this kid but still, I'd hate to see him lose his leg.

The soldier stirs, opens his eyes and looks at me. "I didn't... want... to kill them," he says.

"I know, just following orders, right?" I say somewhat sarcastically, remembering hearing those words spoken by an aging German vet in a documentary, when questioned about his role in the Holocaust.

The kid nods his head, looking ashamed. I don't say anything, just trying to get past the fact that him and his buddy had killed Brenda, and were considering killing the rest of us... Then I try to put myself in his shoes. If I was half my age, serving in the military, expected to follow orders, scared of being infected with an incurable virus, what would I have done?

I walk out to the kitchen to get a glass of water and bring it back for the soldier. He sits up enough to drink, wincing in pain, then lies back down. "My father... can help... phone?" he says.

I hand him my cell, he punches in a number, hits "send", and then loses consciousness. I take the phone from him and hold it to my ear. It rings a couple times, then a man picks up and says "Matt?"...
13521211211122111122211111111121.title: The Soldier's Story

135212112111221111222111111111211.content:
"No sir, this isn't Matt. My name's Steve Andrews, your son's been injured, we need help..."

Matt's father tells me he's in Medical Corps out at the Marine base. I explain our situation, and how we figured out that rattlesnake poison kills the virus. He thanks me and hangs up to call for help.

I check the soldier, he's unconscious, but breathing OK. I walk into the bedroom to check on Jenny, she's awake and talking to Trevor. "I really could use some ice cream, how about you?" she says.

I walk over to the bed and hold her hand. "Glad to see you're back with the living," I say. "Trevor, there's some Cherry Garcia in the freezer, why don't you go get a couple bowls."

A few minutes later I hear the whir of helicopter blades, and a chopper lands in the back yard...
135212112111221111222111111111211.title: Help on the Way

1352121121112211112221111111112112.content:
Three Months Later...

The kitchen phone rings, I call out to Jennie, "I got it!" and I answer it, "Hello."

"Steve? It's me, Sandra, Brenda's sister."

"Hey Sandy, long time no hear! How've you been?"

"Just great Steve, been sober eighteen months now..."

"Good for you, Sandy, glad to hear it! So what's up?"

"Well, I got Brenda's ashes after the funeral, you know."

"Yeah, that's what I heard."

"I promised her years ago if I outlived her I'd scatter her ashes in the desert, where she could be with our ancestors. And tonight is a full moon so I thought it would be a good time to do it, and I was wondering if you and Jennie would like to be present?"

"Sure Sandy, we'd be honored! Would it be OK if we brought Trevor with us?"

"I was going to ask but I didn't know if it would be upsetting to the boy, considering the way she died."

"I appreciate your concern Sandy, but Trevor is not your typical twelve year old. Brenda would probably say he has an "Old Soul". I'm sure he'd want to be there."

"All right Steve, you think you all can you make it here before nightfall?"

"Sure Sandy, no problem, we'll see you soon."
1352121121112211112221111111112112.title: The Desert Winds

13521211211122111122211111111121121.content:
"Sorry these winds have kicked up tonight, made it pretty chilly. You guys OK with this?"

"Sure Sandy, we can handle a little cold after all we've been through," Jennie says.

"Is Miss Brenda going home to Heaven tonight?" Trevor asks.

"I believe she is Trevor," Jennie says.

We stand there in the back yard of Sandy's cabin, looking west, facing empty desert and Joshua trees. She pulls a a Marlboro from her pocket and puts it in her mouth, cups the end with her left hand as she lights it.

She exhales a puff of smoke to the North and says, "To the cold winter, a time for contemplation of our lives..."
Then she turns East, breathes a puff of smoke and says "To the rising sun, who brings us each new day.

Then Sandy turns again, breathing another puff and says "To the warm south wind, bringing us the bounty of springtime."
Then she turns again, inhales, breathes out another puff and says "To the West, the land of the spirits. Please accept my sister into your world."

With that she opens the lid on the container and empties it. The wind blows strongly westward, scattering Brenda's ashes across the desert in the cold night air...
13521211211122111122211111111121121.title: A Celebration of Life

13521212.content:
"I will ask you for an answer one final time, sir - yea or nay?"

Shame and fear rage within my breast, nearly squeezing the very breath from me. What answer shall I give? There can be but one answer, and I despise myself for allowing even a moment's thought before proclaiming, "Yes! Yes, I know Him!"

But the consequences! To answer, "Yea" is to immediately suffer public embarrassment and humiliation, loss of all prestige. Far worse are the broad hints at unimaginable, unspeakable horrors that attend such a confession; how dull I am, how little I understand.

Of a sudden comes to me unbidden Polonius' admonition - "This above all: to thine own self be true..." What is true, then? Only that I am His child as surely as if by blood descent. All that I am hangs from this fact. I open my mouth to answer.

Alas, before I loved Him - but not before He loved me - I was a coward, and a coward I remain: "No, I do not."

It is the ultimate betrayal. The horrors are mine; I fear I shall forever be brother to Judas and Peter.
13521212.title: The ultimate betrayal

1352122.content:
Here at your bedside, watching you gradually drift away, I feel hollow. Sixteen long, numbing years of running and all it has culminated to is this dull waiting, standing at the side of one I've learnt to hate so well... you. Your shallow breathing is the only human sound echoing in this claustrophobic space; the hum of your life support systems nearly conceals the labor of your lungs, but I listen for it, and so it I hear. Somewhere in this hospital, a long time ago, my adopted Grandma was trying her hardest to go quickly, and with a heavy heart I recall those heart-wrenching days of sorrow. Unlike you, she was loved, so completely that even now the gap remains, weighing down my thoughts like the lies you spun so well, but as I watch you die so slowly, I see the logic behind her accelerated death. Should I cry? Laugh? Open the scars I hold inside my head, and recall what you did to me all those years ago? I wish I could bleed, as slowly and painfully as your dying gasps, but I know the mere scratches would linger long after the relief had worn off. Besides, some promises must be kept, and I promised I'd bleed no more. Not on the outside anyway. Your wizened feature swim in and out of focus, and I realize I'm crying. How embarrassing, I think as I hastily dry my useless tears.

After all you've done, I still love you. Resentment rises strong within me as I consider this bitter prospect. How can I love the man who was supposed to protect me; who was meant to be my Father, but who tore my life in two? You hurt me, for heaven's sake. And here I am, sobbing and weak, at your deathbed. {b]I should dance smile maniacally; sever the frail threads that keep you here. But somehow, I can't. Salty blood erupts suddenly in my mouth, and I remember I was biting my lip when I entered the room. "Looks like you're a little tense, girl" I mutter to myself, laughing softly at my sour misery. Such sweet, acidic irony. The 'victim' watching the perpetrator succumb to one of his most dominant fears. But why fear dying, Daddy? You didn't mind when it was my siblings and I on the line, losing our childhood to your perverted ways. You didn't mind when it was my mum who had to pick up the shattered pieces of our lives and fit them back together into something remotely whole. And you didn't mind that because of you, I can't trust anyone without being scared that they'll be just like you. Now I'm in the mood to end your worthless life, but I know my pity hurts you more than death itself. Seeing the fear in your clouded gray eyes, knowing you know how long I've waited for you to die, I grin, unnerving the nurse who comes in to check on your vitals. "Good to see you, Miss" she quavers, preparing to leave, but a sound from my father makes her turn round. Eyes wide, she sees the lines on the screen spike, and calls for backup.

Looking at the defeat resonating from your eyes, I think I've won. As I leave, I whisper one final word to the dying sadist: Goodbye...
1352122.title: I Should Dance

13522.content:
Oh, the hypocrisy of some men!
Those who teach one way, but do another.
Are we the child who
Hears his teacher say.
"Never drink alcohol!"
Yet, the next day on the beach,
He sees his teacher with a bottle of beer in his hand.
Or are we the teacher himself?
Choose your own path...
Liar or Lied to?
13522.title: Hypocrisy

135221.content:
I know that I may be a hypocrite
Tell my students not to drink alcohol
Yet drinking it myself.
Why am I doing it?
I am an adult, and I do what I want.
Am I worried about the universe punishing me for my hypocrisy?
Hell, no!
If my students saw me
And complained to me about how low of a person I am,
What would I say?
I don't give a damn!
As I get in my car
And drive home,
Will I be punished or get away with it?
135221.title: Liar

choices: If I could write a play, it would be about...
13523.content:
I am wandering through a huge warehouse. There are large pipes and ducts overhead, painted an industrial grey. I have no idea why I am here. I feel no sense of urgency to leave, but I am looking for a way out.

I turn a corner and see a large metal door with a hand printed paper sign that says "SHOW TONIGHT".
I open the door and enter a large auditorium with a stage. The auditorium has a cement floor with no seats. People are sitting on lawn chairs and blankets, watching the show. It's some type of comedy, a man and two women bantering.

A woman on my left waves and calls out to me "Grab a chair and come over here!"

I sit next to her and she introduces herself, her name is Charlene. I ask her "What's the show about?"

She says "They're all short plays, and we all take turns acting in them. I'm up next, we're doing a three act drama. You'll have time to think about what kind of play you want to do before your turn."

" I don't think I can write a play, even a short one."

"Don't worry, just get to know some of the people here during intermission, you'll find be able to get a few of them to help put together something."

The audience laughs as the comedy ends, the players take their bows.

Charlene stands up and says "Wish me luck!" as she walks towards the stage.

The alarm rings and I wake up.
13523.title: Unfinished Dream

135231.content:
"I'm sick and tired of living in this crowded little flat, Will! Sharing our room with the children is getting old! We need a place to call our own!"

"A house! A house! My kingdom for a house! Is that all you can think of, Annie! I'm working on a new play right now, I need to concentrate!"

"Oh yes, mustn't disturb the mighty Shakespeare when he's writing. But if you ask me, you should be getting more for your work. After all, the Pay's the thing!"

"I have tried asking the owner of the Globe for a bigger cut of the gate, but he hasn't been very accommodating."

"Well I just heard that a man who is a great admirer of yours, a mister Francis Bacon, recently moved in upstairs. You should go up and introduce yourself, perhaps he can help you out."

"Very well Annie, I shall go see him straight away. Do you know which apartment he is in?"

"I think it's 2B, or maybe 2C. I'm not really sure."

"Ah yes, 2B or not 2B, that is the question..."
135231.title: With Apologies to the Bard

choices: My first meeting with Sir Francis Bacon
Why I found no help for my playwriting with the Viscount.
1352311.content:
"Oh, god's teeth, Will! Can you never stop playing with words! Just go and see this Francis Bacon!"
"I'm off to debase myself for money like a penitent to a common shylock!"I expected Annie to berate me further, so I slammed the door loudly in case she did she did.
As I ascended the creaking staircase to the second floor, I considered what I had heard about the Sir Francis Bacon. He was Ist Viscount of St. Albans and had influence at Grey's Inn. Perhaps I could learn something from this philosopher, essayist and scientist after all.
I put on my most haughty face as I knocked on the door of 2C. An elderly man in the garb of a Jew, answered the door hesitantly.
"Can you tell me, sir, which apartment is the home of Sir Francis Bacon?
"Ah yes, he resides in 2B."
Thanking him I went across the hall, put on my haughty face once more and knocked. I could feel the resident of 2C watching me. This was a true character for the stage or my name wasn't William Shakespeare.
I made note in my head as the door opened.
1352311.title: All the World 's a Stage...

choices: Years later in the garden of my Manor I recall the wisdom of an honourable man
13523111.content:
Normally having the nerve of an ally cat I lifted my now quivering hand and knocked on Sir Frances' door.
"Enter" A quiet and educated voice called.

On entering the room with high ceiling and ornate cornice, my eyes fell on an elderly man of decent posture sitting at a large desk by the window. The desk was filled with papers, books and measuring instruments of unusual shapes. He was writing with a quill and on exquisite parchment.

On the right, a wall of books with a curtain dressing a door in the middle, the curtain was pulled back with a knotted silk cord revealing a large bedroom and I could see a carved bed with eloquent covers draping over the sheet and pillow sham.This man is of nobility and wealth, I thought as my normally lubricated mouth dried up and my tongue stuck to the cleft of my mouth.

The marble fireplace on the left of me was cluttered with more books and papers and above on the wall, a portrait of Sir Francis in his youth.

"Sit on that chair where I can see you." He pointed to a large armchair bound in worn leather and I sat down.
"What is the purpose of your visit." he said putting his pen by the inkwell on his desk.

"I---I was wondering if--
"To be ignorant of cause is to be frustrated in action. Speak clearly young man! What is your reason to come here. Is it advice you seek."
"Yes s Sir, I require to ask of your knowledge and ask what would be the best way that I can combine my career at the Globe and earn a wage to keep a roof and my wife."

" A wise person should have money in their head, not in their heart. Now go and report to me on Monday at ten and I might have some thing that you can pursue to keep your roof and your wife while your vanity will have to be in your shortest time. A man has to follow his heart and also keep wisdom in his eyes. Good day."

I passed the man in 2C who was still holding his door ajar, I nodded and descended the small stairs to my rooms.
13523111.title: My first meeting with Sir Francis Bacon

1352312.content:
There was a strange knocking at the door of Mr. Bacons house. He opened the door and saw Shakespeare standing there.
"Oh, William, Sir, do come in! I am a great admirer of your work! Though this be madness, I can't believe you are really here! How lovely, come in, come in!"
1352312.title: Though this be Madness...

1353.content:
"Just stay calm" the voice screamed in my head
It's not everyday you rise from the dead.
Look around and clear your mind
Insanity is normal you may find
Displaying your madness may do you harm
So just stay calm,Jut stay calm
1353.title: Just Stay Calm

13531.content:
Last thing I remembered was leaving the club with a couple grand in my pocket, got pretty healthy playing. But I had a few too many drinks at the table, got hit in the parking lot by some scumbag looking for an easy mark. I knew I was dying, saw the white light, saw my dead relatives calling, but I wasn't quite ready for all that "eternal bliss" shit.

I thought quick about how I won this big pot a couple weeks ago from this foreign guy, I think he was from Romania. He said if I let him keep a couple hundred he would give me the secret to eternal life. I figured it was a scam but what the hell, I already won more than twice that from him so I agreed.

He said if I shouted out "Eu va trai vesnic" at the moment of my death I would not die, but live forever. So this seemed like the perfect time to see if he was lying. Just as I was fading away I yelled "Eu va trai vesnic!" as loud as I could and to my amazement it actually worked!

So now that I'm "undead", what do I do?
13531.title: Poker

135311.content:
I get up and brush the dirt off my pants and figure what the hell, might as well go back in the casino and see if I can find the dirtbag who killed me. I take a look at myself in my Caddie's side view mirror. The half-dried blood on my face is not very appealing.

My girlfriend Genie is a clean freak, she's always using those little hand wipes and fortunately she left a couple packs of them in the glove compartment. I clean the blood off my face with the wipes and comb my hair to cover the gash in my temple, which is no longer bleeding. (I guess that's one advantage to not having a heartbeat.)

I walk back into the club and look around, no sign of the guy who killed me. But I do spot my old buddy Leo at one of the tables. He's got a stack of chips in front of him and he owes me a few bucks. I sit down next to him. "Hey Leo, looks like you can finally pay me back after all these years!" I joke.

He pushes three hundred in chips over to me and says "Here ya go Frankie, sorry it took so long."

"Yeah, so long you forgot it was five hundred?"

"Oh yeah, right." Leo says nervously, as pushes over another two hundred.

"Hey buddy, no problem, I understand. If you're not cheating you're not trying, right?"

"Uh, yeah, sure Frankie... Hey, I gotta go, got something to do with the wife... Good luck, OK?"

"OK Leo, see ya later." I say as he leaves.

I start thinking. I wonder what's up with Leo? We go way back, no way he should be so edgy, maybe he knows something about who whacked me?

The dealer looks at me and says "Are you here to play cards or daydream?"

I ante up and he starts dealing.
135311.title: Play Cards

135312.content:
What's that saying? Life's too short to whatever? I got time, so I'm gonna get revenge, not just on the scumbag that almost killed me, but everybody who's ever crossed me. I made my list. First off, the guy who beat the shit out of me two years ago outside the bar in Atlanta. What a creep. I need some cash first. Benny has a game tonight. He always invites some pigeons. After I take those chumps for a few thou, I'll be off.

I went back to my dump and took a shot of rotgut and slept until six that evening. I got to Benny's at eight. He let me in and winked. "Hey Rocco, we got some fish ready to fry, if you know what I mean." I looked into the living room where three doofuses were sitting at the poker table.

"Where'd you find those assholes?"

"I let them take me for a few hundred the other day, and told them another game was tonight. Don't look too confident, ya know, don't scare 'em away."

We played and Benny and I cleaned those suckers out. They didn't know what hit 'em.

Benny invited them back for next week, but they just shook their heads. Benny and I cracked up. We made about two thou a piece. Now I got some bread.
135312.title: Get Revenge

1353122.content:
When I got to Atlanta I found the bar where that scumbag had beat me up was now a homeless shelter. A toothless guy sat in the doorway.

"You need a hot meal, Mister, or a place to lay your head? You've come to the right place. C'mon in."

He gestured for me to enter. I hesitated, then thought what the hell, I didn't have anything better to do. I went inside. The entryway was a bare white room, with two closed doors. No one was about, and neither door had a sign. "Which door?" I asked, turning to the toothless guy. He just shrugged his shoulders and grinned at me, making me think about Jack-o-lanterns from Halloweens of my childhood. I turned back to the doors. The one on the right was black, the one on the left, red. The black or the red, which should I choose? Strangely indecisive, I approached the black one and put my ear against it. Nothing. Going to the red door it suddenly swung open, and the toothless guy I had just been talking to emerged. What is this, I thought, some kind of nightmare?

I grabbed his shoulder. "Hey, how'd you get in there?". He shrugged my hand off his shoulder and again turned that disturbing Jack-o-Lantern grin on me. Repelled, I let go of him and headed for the black door. Reaching down I grabbed the knob and twisted. The door slowly creaked open.

God, how I wish I had chosen the other one, the red door.
1353122.title: Big surprise

choices: Does he try to shut that door?
Does anything come out of that darkness?
13531221.content: ...was more blackness, blackness that seemed to move. Seemed? It was moving! I could see the current! That was spooky enough.
13531221.title: Behind the black door...

13532.content:
I told him I didn't drink. "Real ale," he kept saying. I got the impression that he was so drunk he didn't know what he was drinking. I asked the barmaid for a cola. With the glass of cola in my hand I caught the eye of the ale man and said "Real ale, nothing better my friend, this one's on me."

He drank the glass of cola and as he just managed to get the empty glass on the bar he said, "Real ale!"

This was the second time Mark had asked me to meet him in a pub. Next time it would be my choice where to meet and it definitely would not be at a pub. Real ale my foot!
13532.title: real ale

choices: Ding-Dong, Yes?  Have you read The Awake or The Watchtower lately?
Ding-Dong, Yes? We're from the Church of the Latter Day Saints, do
135321.content:
Who is this illusive Mark and why the cat and mouse?
We aren't dealing in state secrets, why can't we meet in a house?
No drugs, no guns, no counterfiet money like Ray-gun and Ollie North And they did their business at the White House, not the 19th hole at a public golf course.

I was handed a folded piece of paper, a voice whispered," I was paid to give you this " ! It said, you'll see a mark IN THE PARK after dark. Then our business is through.Finished.
That's all fine and dandy but now I was pissed off. It was then I heard from the shadows what sounded like a deliberate cough!
I shouted, Mark, Mark, is that you, I could not stop my laugh!
We heard the sound of running feet breaking branches in their path.

I never did figure anything out, it's a mystery to this day?
There probably is a mark in the park. Do you feel like a lark in the dark?
No way!

Bill, we've been here a week working this bogus case, did you happen to
notice the people knocking on doors all through this neighborhood? What were they
selling? Life insurance? The competition must be rough or someone is in someone
elses backyard! Did you see the sparks?
135321.title: In the park

choices: You read only the Watchtower and it scares you
1353211.content:
I couldn't believe it when from out of a fog, a deep fog I heard, answered and responded to my door-bell with my voice to a question that normally I don't answer or participate with in any way!
It all went like this. DING-DONG. YES? HAVE YOU READ THE awake or the watchtower? "Why yes I have," I answered and gently closed the door.
1353211.title: Ding-Dong, Yes?  Have you read The Awake or The...

13532112.content:
Allow me to clarify what scares me about the Watchtower.. Have you ever seen one? What is a Watch Tower? The implications are that a very large structure has been built and has a commanding view over it's surroundings. This tower is filled with watchers witnessing human behavior going on below them. Everyone is below the watchers because the Watch Tower the Witnesses constructed is higher than other structures and the watchers must be above what is below or they couldn't know about maintaining altitude. Rene Dumal finished writing his very small ( LARGE) novelette, Mt Analogue, just before his death. . Rene pointed out the importance of climbing higher up the face of Mt. Analogue in such a way it has stayed with me all these years as a beacon, a lighthouse , a cairn. leading the way, revealing dangerous, life threatening obstacles on the path towards wisdom, enlightenment, which is to say, God intoxication!
Rene simply said " A man who has climbed a mountain knows what is on top of the mountain and what is in the valleys below. But until one has climbed the mountain, that one can only know the valleys "
I'm babbling. Now, there was a Tower. Watch Towers don't scare me. Watching from Towers would. The Watchers in the towers do scare me and the yardsticks they use to measure what is above and below.is spooky!. Not the stick itself but how many Towers filled with watchers with different ideas of what is above and what is below are watching?
13532112.title: You read only the Watchtower and it scares you

135322.content:
There is no such thing I reminded myself but I knew I had to get as close as I could. I still didn't have a clue who this Mark guy was and who he'd been talking to. A PRIVATE MEETING had been arranged, Yea right, this is what I mean, there is no such thing when more than two are aware of a meeting being. The word secret itself is an oxymoron. Just to say the word negates the possibillity of it being a secret? If one person knows something, it hasn't been confirmed! If two people know that something and only two it's not a secret! Not because two people can't keep a secret but because two people know. If I know something you know it's not a secret.But it can be according to Noah! (Webster)
A secret is something kept hidden from others or known only to oneself,, or to a few.
Joy, when I find out who this Mark guy is I'll let you know, then, it won't be a secret! Here he comes, I think? Hell's bells, I don't know what he looks like. I don't know why we're meeting. The only thing I'm sure of is a private meeting.
"Hey you, Are you Mark?" I asked "Whose askin?" the maybe Mark asked me. "Marlin", I answered with what I thought was just enough emphasis to give me the upper hand? "No", he answered, "my names Luke", And he moved off down the line.
Five minutes that seemed like a lifetime when you aren't just bored and you're surly not afraid but feel like you are so far out on a branch that it must break and you don't know what's below you because it is very dark outside. Did you hear that twig break? It was as loud as an illegal mexican m-80, one eithth of a stick of dynamite, water-proof fuse. If it goes off in your hand, so do a few fingers.
"Mark, is that you?" I asked in the direction of the twig breaking? "Whose askin?" the maybe Mark asked me. This time I changed my response to make myself seem in control and a little mysterious and softly whispered, " Marliiiiin Sssppiiiiikeeee". "No", he answered,"my name is Matthew" And I could hear his sandals slap as his footsteps receded into the irrelevant distance.
Time was becoming my enemy. Even though I have had extensive training by the best from Langley, all the way down to Mr. Rodger's neighborhood, this kind of an assignment isn't for amateurs. The very best will tell you if you have the security clearance that nerves at night make one uptight the only fighting is your imagination delighting in what is not there. Do you see that flashlight?
"Mark, is that you?" I asked in the direction the flashlight was coming from swinging back and forth making shadows
on shadows and everything in movement black and white! "Whose askin?" the maybe Mark asked me. "Marlin" I answered stacato! I'd had enough of this cat and mouse and my nerves were drawn as tight as Andre Agassi's cat gut tennis strings! "No", he answered. "My names John, and sometimes I'm referred to as beloved". " Who are you looking for friend, if you don't mind me asking?" "Maybe I can help you". " Why thank you, John, by Jesus thats awful kind of you! Would you happen to know a Mark? I'm sorry I don't know his last name but we've been trying to meet and haven't been able to coordinate our combined efforts so that our physical bodies could get close enough to speak with each other." "As a matter of fact I know Mark and Jesus too!" "They're right behind you, as we speak" "Marlin, is your middle name Philip?" " Why yes John it is" "How did you know to ask that?" " I'd like to say Spiritual discernment but can't!" " Your're the reason we are all here, Philip!" "Your meeting isn't with Mark although it is in a way, It's with Jesus and us. He's asking you to join us and our quest. To join him and become something more than you were. It's a bit tricky and He explains it much better than I . I never get tired of listening to him and questions are welcome. His answers can be a bit etherical but they grow on you as time goes by or they don't". " Let me introduce you to God's Son, Jesus, the Messiah> Jesus Marlin Philip, Marlin the Messiah!"
Wow, I thought he would be larger than life. I can see why the Pharisees had a problem> Of course I didn't say this out loud but he heard me anyway!
135322.title: A private meeting

13533.title: lunar landing

135331.content:
I've been waiting in this desert for an eternity. I've tried countless times to reach him, each time a different scenario within a different dream. Dreaming is the only way I can reach him. If I am to bring him to my embrace before the dark comes to claim him for good, I must find out what will resonate within his subconscious. My heart breaks when I dwell too long on the idea of never having him for my own. I look down at his beautiful face, his heavy black lashes lapping at his cheeks like the waters of a serene ocean as he dreams. His hair is gold and cornsilk and starlight. For a moment, my throat flutters and I don't think I can resist kissing his full lips. Then I remember what happens if I touch him physically.

So I tried first to frighten him. From the little I know of human nature, nightmares seem to have the greatest effect on heightening the senses. Fight or flight I think they call it? Anyway, my strategy of hunter (me) stalking out her prey (him) didn't seem to get very far. I only succeeded in stoking my own desire for him, I found myself longing to capture him and treat him as my prey. The human subconscious is a mysterious and personal thing, apparently his psyche went somewhere hidden and wasn't ready to be caught just yet. Perhaps his curiosity was stronger than his fear.

My role as siren was just as unsuccessful. I tried to seduce him, to break his heart in order to wake him so I could give him mine. This only resulted in stirring melancholy, which is not exactly an emotion known for inciting action.

The nuance of comedy can sometimes have an invigorating effect on the human condition, so I dug deeper within to anticipate his sense of humor. Turns out he had an Uncle with an insatiable appetite for practical jokes. Particularly if my love was the target and was preferably under the age of fourteen. I didn't have time to rifle through them all, so I used the first I found. It was something about attempting to get the poor boy to stick his hand into a tank full of piranhas in order to retrieve a ring belonging to his uncle's "boss" that he had somehow managed to lose down there. I found myself detesting this Uncle, and I resolved to claim vengeance upon him for his dishonesty. For a moment I thought this was the one that had done the trick, for he moaned and rolled his head toward me. I thought he was going to open his eyes and I eagerly anticipated the focus of his gaze. Instead he muttered something about speaking to God. At least we were making a little progress, maybe somewhere deep in that dark well inside his head he was beginning to comprehend.

This was the point at which he began to moan fitfully. He tossed and turned on the dune. Panic sat heavily on my chest and I found it difficult to breathe. My time was running out. "Just stay calm!" I screamed into the wind, entreating it to stop howling around me, but found my pleading in vain. The wind answered mockingly, informing me that I would never be able to barter my immortality for a mortal life lived with this man. This man whom I loved more than all the wonders I had seen and all the lovers I had taken in my 3,000 years combined.

We were so close! I could feel his mind reaching for mine. "NO! I screamed to the dead, heavy sky. Dark figures surrounded us. Tears fell from my cheeks, making indentations in the sand as they turned to ice. All I could do was look at his face and weep. "Can I at least hold him?" I pleaded. The forms were silent but I knew the answer. It was forbidden.

His precious form began to fade. I could see the outline of his beautiful body in the sand as he slipped away from me. I knew I'd never see his perfect face or swim the deep ocean of his mind again. The tallest figure stepped forward, looming over me as I sat curled in the sand. I drew my knees to my forehead to hide my icy tears but I know he could see my sobbing. My wings heaved too heavily along my back to hide this. I looked sternly into his black face. "I hate you, I said evenly. And I promise next time it will be you sobbing alone in the sand, begging me for mercy."
135331.title: desert  dream

135332.content:
Gwen: The desert is unforgiving. People always talk about the heat but there is a terrible cold here. And I want to let it out. It's inside me. I can feel it. Everyone wants to be special. The people to mourn their monsters are weak and don't understand what it could be. What they could be. I do. I do understand and I can feel the hunger inside of me. I can feel it and I relish it. I bathe in it until it consumes me. A predator. A vicious beast that doesn't care what prey, why or where but only about control. We're all looking for a modicum of control, are we not? Do you want to see my monster? I would love to show it to you. Well?

(the hostage sits in silence. Gwen grabs his chin and twists his head to look her square in the eyes. He grunts in pain.)

Gwen: (smiling maliciously) This was not your fantasy, was it? Am I wearing what you'd hoped? Is being a spy all you'd dreamed it would be?

(Gwen takes out a knife and the hostage screams in his gag, squirming in his restraints.)

Gwen: I'm quite the artist you know. My family always said so. Why don't I take off your gag so that you can add some music to my art? Before we begin our painting, is there anything you would like to tell me? (Leaning in) I must admit, I really hope that there isn't, because I really want to...(sticking the knife in him just enough to make him bleed.) ...paint.

Hostage: Please.

Gwen: (frowning) You disappoint me. You only speak to beg? What is this? You just don't want me to show you my art, do you?

Hostage: No. Please, anything.

Gwen: Anything?
