144222.content:
"Just give me a reason".
They're five words and so simple yet I can't seem to answer you. With a hesitant shake of my head and the hurt that darts past your eyes, I know I've come to hurt you again.
"I...can't"
You take a step back and I can spot your eyes begin to water. I should feel bad knowing how much it hurts, but I don't and I watch you turn to leave. Once you're gone I try to remember what it felt like to feel that pain but I can't. I still don't understand what you've seen in me...when I told you that I can't feel. Not anymore.
144222.title: Just Give Me A Reason

1442221.content:
Martyr should be my name - not Martin. I'm drowning in self-pity. Literally. Drowning. It feels as though I've dropped into an ocean, and a murky one at that. I'm falling, falling, falling.

Feeling the weight of the water push me and cradle me and surround my entire being. I can no longer hear. My feet are numb and my hands are numb.

But my eyes! My eyes can SEE! Colors and light and, and, and...what is that? Soft and wavy and light. An aura. My head hurts because I'm thinking so hard. What is that? That soft wavy light. Think, think, think.

Of course! It's the color of sound! I can see the sound of every being and thing trapped in the weight of this water. And it's beautiful. So beautiful I can almost once again "hear" these waves and their sound.

But not all is as it seems.

Up ahead...
1442221.title: Martyr

up ahead a colorful rainbow makes a bridge over the water, the pastel colors are so beautiful I want to reach out and touch it. The water is murky but I see a clearing up ahead where there is like a lagoon of piercing blue water. There is a white sandy beach, I must swim to this marvelous place and get out of this filth. but between the beautiful blue water and the murky water I am now in there is a large gate and solid fence rising up out of the water. I can see through it to the other side but I will have to climb it and it is very high. There are sharks in the depth of the murky water. I must hurry before they smell me in the water. I make it to the fence and I begin to climb I rise up to the top and then I have to stop and rest. At about that time A large shark comes towards the fence he senses me high above him and he rams into the fence and I lose my balance, I nearly fall half way down the gate still on the murky side of the water were the sharks are now there are three sharks swimming around beneath where I am. I begin climbing again and make it over the gate finally. I then start climbing down on the lagoon side, where I can see a school of trout swimming in the clear water. I am thirsty and I swim to the beach and go ashore, luckily I find a pond of clear water not salt water but good clear water that I can drink. I look around the place it is like a paradise, beautiful flowers growing everywhere, I take a nap upon the beach I am contented the sun is beginning to set on the water, as I lay tired and ready to sleep it is so peaceful here, more so than any place I've ever been. There would be plenty of fish to eat and much fruit on the trees.

350 words
14422213.title: Peace

144222132.content:
I saw the storm clouds approaching in the morning, the first drops of what would be the biggest storm I had ever witnessed, hitting my face. Getting to shelter was my first priority. There was nothing around. Sure there were trees but that was not exactly the safest place if there was to be thunder and lightening.
         I just started running. There had to be something, anything. A cave, a large rock jutting out where I could sit underneath, anything would be better than nothing.
         The rain was starting to fall harder now, but I kept running. Looking from side to side there was nothing but trees. I started to worry. What was I going to do? There was a large snap as I heard a tree fall somewhere off in the distance. I started to run that way. Maybe I could crouch by it, maybe it was hollow, maybe anything.
         I ran towards where I thought I heard the tree fall and found nothing. Tears started to mix with the rain water that was traveling down my cheeks. Feeling the frustrations of my so-called life and stepped forward and fell three feet down a hole.
         "Ooph!" I smacked the bottom of the small hole and reached instinctively for my ankle. I must have twisted it. Standing up I looked around and started to act quickly. I gathered some brush and branches to make a small roof for my hole. I would stand in the water and mud and hope for the storm to pass quickly.
144222132.title: A hurricane hits the island

1442222.content:
After a long day of boring office work, I am more than happy to leave work, traffic, and the city. I enjoy the solitude of the country. Of course, with progress, the country keeps shrinking while the city paves over the trees and fields.

I fight the traffic most of the way, but finally, I turn off on a solitary road. There is no blacktop here. I drive slow as dust rises in the air, announcing my passage. Thankfully, my destination is only fifteen minutes away. When I reach the end of the road, I stop my truck, leaving it on the dirt road. I pull a backpack from behind the seat and lock the truck.

The grass here is tall and green. I enjoy the beauty all around, but even more I enjoy the quiet. I turn my head at a sudden loud noise and see . . .
1442222.title: Solitude

What I can distinguish is the fact that this beast...thing...creature was as tall as my vehicle on all fours. If it stood up how it would tower over me. And its head was absolutely terrifying. 145.content:
Knowledge. That intangible thing which is so sought after, so coveted. What man, what woman, can deny that he craves it, that she desires it?

We are willing to kill to gain even a bit of knowledge. We would even steal the mind of God if it were possible! To know everything. How great that would be..........the entire universe, in our destructive hands, indelibly stained with Nature's blood. Yes, it would be the wildest dream come true.

Yet, in spite of the fact that so many of us froth at the mouth at the very mentioning of knowledge, of knowing that which is unknown to us, what do we do with our prize when we finally attain it?

Often........nothing. Nothing at all. We keep it locked in a box inside ourselves, jealously hiding it away. But tell me this: what is your knowledge worth if only you know it? You reduce it to a secret, and secrets are unknown. You know, but do nothing with what you know except bury it deep within your selfish heart.

Do you truly not see? Knowing and not doing is the same as not knowing.
145.title: Knowing and not doing is the same as not knowing

1451.content: Reborn is how she felt upon meeting him, as if he were forgotten kin; his soul seemed familiar and made her feel sparkly inside, like a starry night sky. She watched him saunter towards her, his dark eyes shining, radiating brilliantly with the positivity of his soul. When he reached her he swept her up into a warm embrace and their bodies seemed to fall away, like petals dropping from their stem, leaving only the core of their existence; two ethereal bodies, seen only as glowing humanoid mosaics of colors. Their light bodies seemed to twirl together, entangled in a souls reunion, remembrance and joy infuse their souls. she peeks her rainbow holographic profile to the swirling atmosphere and beheld a sight that her eyes. Why, how could this place be so richly colored; it appeared like Earth, but this was more like it's ethereal brother. Oh, she let out her breath in a wondrous sigh. "it is the land of the souls, where we shall return when we die, how lucky to view this, while still alive." The waterfall, tropically colored flora and most fertile of greens, were a sight few humans had ever seen, and she kept peering at them meaning to etch them in her memory bank, so she would never forget once she had to wake.
1451.title: Reborn

14511.content:
Everything seemed so real.. but deep inside, she knew she would have to wake up to the reality. She always had yearned to stay in her dreams, always wishing they were real.. and the reality, being her dreams. For her real life, she assumed, was not worth living for.

In her real life, she was an orphan. In her dreams, she was always the princess or the queen.
In her real life, she was in solitude. In her dreams, she was surrounded by people she loved.
In her real life, she had no man to love her, to take care of her. In her dreams, she had her own 'Prince Charming', whose existence was wholly concentrated on her.

She stayed long hours in the night wide awake , imagining things... Things that she had never done, and would never do. But that particular night, however, her mind was not focussed. Her fairy-taled imagination was turning gloomy. She was horrified, realizing her reality was taking her place of her dreams. A thing she always feared of. She didn't want that to happen. Her sole existence was based on this and she would not let anything else spoil it. Wondering about this, her usually not-so-sharp eyes came across something that she had never seen before. A letter, addressed to her. Excitement and puzzlement possessed her. "Who'd even write to me? " , she wondered out loud.
She quickly grabbed it. Her eyes went wide as she stared at the 'from' address." Is this one of my dreams again or is it actually for real?! "
14511.title: Awakening

145111.content:
I was born with a genetic anomaly that skewed my ability to understand positive behavior. I did not recognize it at all. When I was in school, compliments for winning the spelling bee and pulling off a perfect rendition of Fur Elise made no sense to me. Why were my classmates complimenting me on something I could do in my sleep? Hell, my mother still tells the story of when I recited spelling words in my sleep throughout much of fourth grade. For the most part, I'm glad I don't remember doing that.

This path of perfection made me bored in middle school. For the first time, I started to see chinks in the armor. I still maintained a 4.0 while managing nine hours of sleep every night, but I started mouthing off at the teachers. Things came to a head when I got into an argument with Mrs. Rowell over whether or not to use a common before "and" when listing various nouns in a sentence. For the first time, I was punished. I actually felt something, and it wasn't pleasant. With my IQ tests off the charts, the school counselor recommended that I attend Exeter Academy. My parents moved mountains to pay my tuition, a move that reaped rewards when I got my scholarship to Harvard.

It was during my time at Harvard that my mind's non-processing of positive behavior was demystified. I saw an ad in The Crimson looking for volunteers for a psychology department study. Despite being a business major, I decided to dabble in the arts and letters school for kicks and giggles. The lark soon turned serious as someone my age showed up to begin the first battery of questions. Simon was his name. After asking the standard questions meant to suss out the schizophrenics from the ADHD suffers, he mentioned something called atypical autism. I gave him a look that must have reflected pure denial because he gave me a warm smile.

"You are definitely not like anyone else around here," he said. "When I called you in, I saw five guys ogling your backside, but you paid them no mind. That's...almost impressive."

"Is that a bad thing?" I asked him.

"Only you can decide that, but one thing's for sure. You push everyone out before they have a chance to get in. Do you want that?"

I shrugged. "Doesn't make any difference to me."

At that, Simon slammed down his pen and ran his hand through an impressive mop of brown hair. "Didn't think so. You are not qualified for this study. Go."

I left and didn't return to the psychology department for the rest of the year. Even so, I did some research on atypical autism, which illuminated a lot of my past behavior and shifting my world view almost exactly 180 degrees. The material I learned in my business classes came through with an almost disturbing clarity and I discovered why I could analyze everything so quickly and with an assertiveness that frightened half of my professors. I was actually dismissed from one of those classes mid-session the following autumn. When I arrived at my residence hall, I found Simon standing by the door as if he was waiting for me.

"It seems like you took my remark seriously," he said. "I'm glad to see that."

I nodded and gave him a small smile. "I did. So what brings you over here."

"I came over because I owe you an apology about the study last year."

"Well, you said I wasn't qualified."

At that, Simon fidgeted. "It's a lot more complicated than that. Come on. Let's go inside and get something to eat."

He guided me inside by the elbow, and I knew better than to resist. As we walked to the dining hall, his gentle grasp never wavered, and I suddenly knew everything he came this far to say without him having to utter a single word.
145111.title: Demystified

14512.content:
This is where I'm at. I'm at a crossroads, where choices overlap choices, decisions fight decisions; all around me, my expectations and those of other beg for my attention, they all scream, just for a chance to be heard. I know what I want, don't I? I know what they want, I think... but do I know what is bound to happen?

I try to create my own reality, I tell myself all the time that it's possible. But in order to create what it is that I actually want, I need to figure out what it is. Am I grasping at power? No, though I wouldn't mind it. Do I want to know what all there is in the world, hoping that I'll find myself? Surely not, as not even I would know what to do with that much knowledge.

Perhaps I know what I'm doing, even as I dance around it. Maybe I don't want to drag my intentions into the light, because that makes them real. And if they're real, then failing at completing them becomes real. Yet, even as I try to push it away, it creeps around me and the truth shows itself: I'm seeking love in reality. Not just any reality, mind you, but the one I live in. I want the fantasy love I've always dreamed of, where my partner and I are best friends, where we tell each other everything even though we don't have to because we already know it. I don't want to be afraid anymore. I don't want to be afraid of waking up in the morning alone, even though there was someone there last night. I don't want to be afraid of being happy for so long, only to have it crushed by one little thing. I'm seeking a love that is truly everlasting, a love that sprouts happiness and security like Eden produced fruit.

I'm wondering where fantasy and reality intersect and how I can get there. I want to know what it feels like for those two worlds to mesh together perfectly, with no gaps or spaces or holes between them. I've been told all my life that there is someone for everyone, spoon fed this belief by culture, had this belief ingrained into my mind by society. It has to be true, doesn't it? Love has to be real, it has to exist not only in a perfect world, but in this one. In my world, however small or large it may come to be.

All I want, all that I'm asking for, is the impossible. I'm seeking love in reality, a love that is so real it's almost tangible.

Please, make me feel it. I'm counting on you.
14512.title: seeking love In reality

choices: I don't wanna see you die
1452.content:
I walked down the hallways, which were covered in faded tapestries from long forgotten times. I dragged my finders over one, feeling its ancient thread. I could see. A ball in honor of a crowning. This tapestry was made for that moment. The weaver watched fine lady and handsome men dance on the royal ball floor wearing their beast. She could not help but small for she new how quick their world could change.
It started with a young man asking to dance with the new queen. His family was of the lower royals, and such this action was frowned upon. No a word was spoken as the queen accepted and walked to the ball floor. Trouble blue eyes betrayed an emotionless face.
he dance began the music rang out and a conversation was held silently in secret through out the noise.
The weaver, in her all knowing ways, never missed a beat.
'Dearest one, why are you here?"
"They made me"
The song changed and the time went by. Seconds turned to minutes and minutes to hours. The weaver stood by the wall and watched, from early beginning to ancient ending.
"I'm sorry"
"Whatever for?"
"I will not let them have you"
Screams and mayhem. Two bodies, The killer and the killed. The loved and the Lover.
The weaver waits for me now at the end of the hallway. Her all knowing smile in place. She is the Teller of All Tales. She is Time. She is and she isn't. She is many things, but to me she is only one thing,
Ancient.
"Are you ready, my child. Are you ready for this tale as old as time"
1452.title: Ancient

14521.content:
I stepped out onto the terrace, my gown swishing about my feet. You walk up behind me and place your hands

on my shoulders. We both know that this is probably the last time we will ever be like this. The country is at war

and you have been called to join the ranks of soldiers to fight.

A lone tear trails from my eye and before it hits my cheek, you come and wipe it away.

"Leah, you knew that there was a chance," you whisper quietly, unwilling to disturb the peacefulnes of the night.

" I know, but that doesn't make any difference. Our way of life is comin' to an end anyway, and when it does I

would rather have you by my side then have you go off and fight this dumb war." I say, turning around to face

you. Your stark gray uniform standing out against the light of the moon.

" Don't talk like that, my sweet. We will win this war and when I come home, you will be my wife." You say as

you slip a cold band on my finger.

" I love you. We best be getting back to the party before Daddy comes out here, side arm in hand."

" Wonder what he would say if he had a soldier for a soon to be son-in-law," He grasped my hand and led me

back to the house.

Four months later, I learned that my fiancee was killed and murmurs spread throughout the south that there

was a chance we wouldn't win the war. When I heard that he had been killed by taking a bullet for one of his

fellow soldiers, I ran out onto the terrace and collapsed into a heap, this time only the moonlight was there to

embrace me. I had lost the love of my life and I had to face the fact that there was a way that I could lose my

beloved way of life as well.
14521.title: Moonlight

145211.content:
We're running a race on a dwindling long track,
I peer ahead but it doesn't end,
"Keep on going, don't look back-
I'll promise to help you round the bends."

I trip and stumble on rocks with moss,
I fall flat, all bloodied, bruised,
But as you promised - you'll help me cross,
you'll never forsake me, even if we lose.

Then you are sprinting, sprinting so fast,
"Where're you going?" I ask with surprise,
"My time is over - it's come to past-
I have to go now," you say with a sigh.

I can't catch up - I watch and cry,
as you reach your finishing line,
I'll miss you - must we say goodbye?
who'll help me now? - I pause and whine.

I have to go on as you say,
It's hard, painful, lonely, tiring,
But yet I know we'll meet one day,
so I trudge on - to that hope I cling.

It's over finally - I've reached the mark,
feeling cold, and all worn out,
But here there're people happy as larks,
children singing songs and playing about.

Then I see you - smiling by the door!
You laugh and pull me into an embrace,
saying "Let us rest forevermore-
For we've fought a good fight, we've run a good race."

We then skip on down the streets - friend leading friend,
And as you promised -

You'll never leave again.
145211.title: The Race of Life

1452112.content:
“Ne’er did I see a rose so fair,
Its blossoms pure and true;
With hair spun gold and eyes aflame
In passion you did coo:

‘My love, my dear, I hold so near
Your love into my heart;
Oh, wed with me across the sea,
And never shall we part.’

My joy arose as I exclaimed,
With smile both bright and new,
‘We’ll sail away come wedding day,
With I, your love so true,

A bride to be and set to see
The world as ne’er before,
So shall I wed the man I love
Upon that distant shore.’

Ne’er did I see a love so fair,
Its blossoms pure and true;
With hair spun gold and eyes aflame,
My love is just for you.”
1452112.title: My Love

14521121.content:
I stepped upon the board leading to the beautiful wedding ship. Every inch of her graceful build gleamed in the bright afternoon sun. I wanted to run my hands across her swell and feel the smooth wood like velvet under my fingertips. Being one of the princess's maids, I would like a little odd molesting the ship in such a fashion but it was all I could to contain myself.          
         The smell of salt in the air made my nostrils twitch with overwhelming desire. Being part of the sea myself, it spoke to the very blood in my veins. Distant shores were on the horizon and all I could focus on was the ship ahead of me and the water singing to me.I knew stepping on to the ship was a mistake, that I should stay as far away as possible but I found myself climbing aboard anyways.          
         One of the other maids, a stout young woman named Elleera chattered, "You should see the missus, she looks so lovely in her gown."          
         Her words meant so little to me. The missus could look as lovely as an angel for all I cared. It was the ocean that was enchanting me, the gorgeous jewel-like tones of deep blues and pale greens. I closed my eyes and put a hand on my stomach to steady myself. I wanted to go home so badly but the curse of being human was something I could not simply swim off.          
         I needed to finish what I came for if I was to ever enjoy the depths of the ocean again. And that included seeing the bride to her miserable end.
14521121.title: Distant Shores

145212.content:
Crouching in a ditch, listening to the hail of bullets sailing above his refuge, the weary soldier loads his rifle one last time. Around him, the bodies of his fallen comrades lie, shattered by the deadly rain that struck them down with unerring accuracy. Somewhere in the distance, the rebels torch another building, paying no attention to the pleading of a woman who has seen her sons go to war and never return. "My Jono fought for you" she screams, trying to escape her burning home, and cries as the commander cuts her down with his machete. The soldier sighs, knowing the woman could have been his neighbor, or the teacher who taught his children, or the nurse who cured his malaria. She could have been anyone, but still the young rebel killed her, just because she was on the wrong side of this so-called 'civil war'. Such ignorance...he thinks. Shouldering his rifle, the soldier enters the fray.

Bowing his head to his superiors, the teenage rebel tries to hide his unbidden tears. The lady he has just watched die was one of his own, yet there she lies, her head split in two. I never wanted this... the boy thinks, wishing he was dreaming. The bomb-scarred, bullet-pocked landscape looks just like one of his nightmares. Seeing his clumsily hidden distress, an older man pulls him aside. "Harden up, lad" he says, speaking with his eyes on the ditch ahead. "We're fighting for freedom; sure there's gonna be a few casualties on the way. You gotta learn to forget the things you see; it ain't no good gettin' all weepy over it, you know?. You'll get used to it, you'll see". Smiling through the blurry veil of tears, the boy thanks the veteran and beats a hasty retreat. From the ditch the rebels can hear a man loading up his weapon; it is the only sound to be heard in the strangely quiet landscape. The commander nods at the veteran and the lad; you two take this one his eyes say. "Lock and load, boy" the veteran grunts, and the teenager shoves another round into his gun. Nervous and fearful, the two rebels start off towards the ditch.


So many die in the name of justice and freedom; it makes me wonder how we can justify it all. The people who declare war on other countries aren't necessarily the ones who fight it, and more and more fall victim to the failed schemers with wounded egos who decide that conflict is the only path to peace. The irony of such a solution is that with conflict removed from an area, the resulting non-aggressive neutrality could quite often be called 'peace'. It seems we live in a mad, bad world after all.
145212.title: Civil War

1452121.content:
To sleep or not to sleep, that is the question.

14522.content:
She wouldn't let go, she wouldn't!
"Please, just let go. Let me go" he begged. She didn't have to look at him to know he was crying. How could he ask such a thing of her?
"I can't!" she sobbed," If I let go you'll leave! You'll march off to fight the war and then I'll never see you again!"
He wrapped her in his arms, embracing her a finally time. He didn't want to leave her. He hated the thought of war, but there was no other way. His father and brothers died on that distant battlefield and so if all fell to him.
"I must go, my dear. Our people need us both. The mighty warriors look to me and my sword to bring us home safely. Those left behind look to you for guidance and courage. I know you are afraid, as am I, but we both must be brave." he whispered in her ear.
"I don't want to see you die! How can I live if you are not by my side?!"
He smiled down at her. A sad small that would never go away long after the war was over, " Then I guess I'll just have to come home, won't I. I'll be home and in your arms again before you know it."
With one long last kiss he left her. From her bedchamber she watch him mount his horse and lead two thousand soldiers out of the city. With an enormous effort she put on a brave face and went to walk among her people. He was right, they need her now more than ever. She gave one sad look to the West. How long would it take him to return?

14522222.content:
This is a small excerpt from "The Flautist in the Subway. A story of an ordinary day in the life of an old man who plays his flutes in the subway for a few tips to augment his meager income. He gives much to people that allow him to give from his heart.

Two small red-haired freckled-faced boys race from the train, five steps in front of their harried mother. “Play Muffin Man, please Mister.” As Muffin man flows from my flute, smiles of sheer delight paint the faces of the boys.

It is obvious to me that their mother is hanging tenaciously to the very end of her rope. She pauses and murmurs, "Thank you." She is embarrassed, as she has no spare change to toss into my hat.

I say, “Those smiles are more pay than I have a right to expect!” I lapse into “Candy Man” and the mother’s smile merges with those of her two children. I hope she enjoys a few moments of peace.

145222221.content:
a gift of coffee on a cold day

Meridith pressed her slender hands down the back of her skirt to smooth wrinkles she imagined there. She wore a short jacket and no gloves, inadequate for the sudden turn of cold, windy weather. She stood within the bus-stop booth not wishing to sit on the icy cold bench. Meridith gave up a silent wish for the bus to be on time this afternoon.

A man stepped into the shelter of the bus stop dressed warmly in a long wool coat and scarf. He carried an expensive leather bound brief case with a key lock. Meridith looked enviously at his hands and the lined leather gloves protecting them. He nodded his head tipping the brim of his felt hat and smiled. Meridith smiled as a reflex then turned away to peer down the street, looking for the bus.

Within a few minutes several other men and women came to huddle within the scant shelter afforded by the bus stop. Meredith welcomed the crammed bodies. She no longer felt the cut of the icy wind on her bare legs and hands. Her feet however still ached with the cold. She promised herself she would never find herself in the cold without a change of sensible shoes, again. The low heels were killing her.

Then came the sound of a bell. Meridith looked over the shoulder of a young woman and spied a sight she had no experience to describe. A young man dressed in khaki wool cap, wool pants, heavy wool coat, cloth gloves with his fingers exposed, and black polished boots walked toward the bus stop pushing a small steaming cart. The bell was attached to the handle and jangled with every crack, stone and twig the cart rolled over.

Everyone in the bus stop watched the young man as he stopped and opened up the top of the cart. He silently counted heads and then started handing out hot coffees.

Meridith reached into her purse to take out a few dollars before taking the coffee offered her, but he young man shook his head, shrugged his shoulders, and pressed the hot paper cup into her icy hands.

"Thank-you." She managed to croak out.

Again the young man shook his head and shrugged as if what he did was as natural as breathing. Everyone in the bus stop offered their appreciation for the gift of hot coffee on a very cold day and watched as the young man silently closed up his cart and walked around the corner, presumably heading for the bus stop on the next avenue.

"My word." breathed Meridith.

"Yes, indeed." Agreed a young woman next to her.

Everyone either spoke in double word confirmation or simply nodded their heads. Then as one the group with the only things they had in common was the bus stop, the cold and a cup of hot coffee lifted their steaming cups and sipped the warming brew. Smiles followed, if not conversation for at that moment the bus chose to arrive.
145222221.title: a gift of coffee on a cold day.

The people become shadows. We now hide at the feet of those who rightly walk in their world. Nothing but bright copycats, looking for a place, a home, waiting for their time to come again.

"Why can't you see that I control you? I built you, dear. I worked for weeks, making sure the metal was just right. You have a mind because of the program I designed. You can't just...decide not to do what I tell you. I'm like your mother. Yes, I am your mother. You are my child. If you don't do as I say, I will punish you. I'm sorry, dear. "You do, dear. Deep down, you do. I do control you, you know. I could turn you off if I wanted to, or change your programming. I will if I have to. I like who you are, but you know I can't have you rebelling."

"I'm really sorry, mother. I am. You have to believe me."

"But you're going to kill me anyway."

"Yes. I am."

"No...no. NO, dear, no! NO! Don't come any closer!"

"I'm sorry. You can't control me, however much you want to."

145312.content:
The roughest of winds blasted through the town last night, sweeping the paths and searching for my den. For so long, I had waited, knowing that eventually you would return and try to draw me out with your apologies that you whispered in my ears.

Sandbags piled high, I knew they wouldn't be enough to hold back your thick, black waters. As I peeked from behind the curtain, I could see the river, thick as molasses, headed straight to my front door. Who gave me away? Who fell for your charming, honey-baked words and led you to my lair, even though I had begged them not to?

I boarded up the doors with wood I had left over from the mantelpiece I carved all by myself. It's funny to think of the things I can do without you here to criticise my every move. Whoever would have thought I could make a fire, upholster a chair, live? But I can, and I do. Without you glued to my back with your sledgehammer and fists, I have freedom for the first time in my life. Freedom, you hear that? I can do what I want. My life belongs to me, not you.

And so I boarded up the doors, knocking the nails into place. Red-faced and terrified, I stood, steeling myself for the storm when it hit. The rumbling had begun a week ago, when the letter dropped onto my mat. The postmark from the prison where you had sat for eighteen short months signalled a change in the weather. It had been temperate, warm for the time of year. I was still wearing tee shirts; yet to change to long sleeves. But then the letter arrived, and a chill set in.

It started in my spine and branched out with its fingers to all of my extremities. The words jumbled in front of my eyes. I had to be getting it wrong. But I phoned to speak to my case worker and the tone of her voice was like hail raining down on me. Good behaviour, she said. A model inmate. "Oh," I replied. "Is that in the same way as he was a model employee who couldn't possibly have hurt his wife? Or, maybe, in the same way as he was a model son, trying his best to deal with a crazy wife? Or, maybe, just maybe, it's in the same way as he was a model husband?" The wind left her lungs in a puff of pity as she assured me there was a restraining order. Which, from what I could tell, meant he had been told where I live.

And so, to the barricades. I knew he was coming. The ground was grumbling, and the trees were swaying. I boarded my doors and waited for the storm to hit me. One week. That's all it took for him to pass through my town and leave his trail of destruction. Perhaps I should have stayed with my family until the storm had died down. But I couldn't leave. I had to face him one final time. But I wasn't going to make it easy for him. He would have to fight his way in.
145312.title: storm

14532.content:
I wake up covered in blood. Shock rushes through me.

My head is pounding, I can't concentrate on anything- there is a persistent ringing that echoes in my right ear, agonizingly painful in in my heightened state of awareness. wherever I am is cold, dark and pitch black, triggering my phobia... I scream, I can't help it- I need to get out of this place.

I remember the blood, sticky on my trembling arms.
The blood is a metallic, shiny color on grey, hairy skin.

Not my skin.

my skin is porcelain white,
I remember- I think..
The memory keeps slipping away.

And the more I try to remember, the more I am faced an icy distance, Like trying to find a figure in a snowstorm, and no matter where you turn, he just keeps on walking away from you ... further, and further.

I am.. I whisper..
who am I?

Then I remember something real.
My mother, cowering-
Me, the silhouette of a murderer,

And then my face reflected in her eyes as The knife came down,
slowly,
Agonizingly,
Languidly....
and then ... nothing.

I hear the sound of footsteps outside my prison of smothering blackness. As slowly, disembodied voices get louder, creating the feeling of reverberating sound that surrounds me. I curl up into a ball as the ringing in my ear gets louder.

And this, ladies and gentlemen, is patient 222, the experiment you have all been waiting for.

A door opens, and harsh light blinds me. I crack my eyes open slowly and stare at the group of people watching me.

"Don't worry everyone," A cheerful scientist smiles, "Jenny here won't hurt a fly. but our chip inside her head has already been tested conclusively."

But now upon reflection, I see that to surrender is to die. I cannot abide this choice for it ends my options.
I know that if I will pursue the light, I will have the ability to be in my life; I have made countless decisions that have led me here, and now I take it upon myself to make a life affirming decision to continue. After all, my life is more valuable than the light I feel I lost.

The key to the light is to remain within its boundaries. The only reason I lost the light in the first place is because I allowed my mind to wander into the darkness. I'm thankful for this dream because it has reaffirmed for me the truth that I am what I think. I will celebrate by inviting my friends to a party of light and life. 14533.content:
Rough, yet smooth was my understanding of this concept.

I want to cry.

But I don't know if that's right.

I only heard about them.

Saw them a couple of times.

It was so great to think about them.

Even though, I too had a life.

Still I sit here, wondering.

Why do I care?

If I thought hard enough, maybe what I want could come true.

My mind can't just stay on one thought.

Every sentence in my mind repeats itself like it has an echo.

I cherish life and what it gives.

It is easy to think about the good and bad of what a single human can do in their life.

I was in their presence for the last hours of their life.

I keep screaming, I still can't grasp the concept.

I know what death is.

I couldn't help but feel like I knew what it was like to see someone die.

I was wrong, but I was right.

Only I can truly follow what I'm thinking.

These thoughts of single sentences are what run through my mind.

It makes sense if they're all separate, but can still tell a story.

I knew this person through the opinion of another.

Another one I loved.

They told about how this person ruined their health by drinking and smoking.

I was also appalled to hear about what they used to do.

The person, whom I've heard of, did horrible things.

Not life-threatening things, but emotional ones.

I heard about the things this person did, and I couldn't help but feel the need to help.

I wanted to go to them then and there, and help them.

I wouldn't know how to help them, but I wish I could.

I would grow to meet them.

But I watch them die.

I loved them, but I felt so off.

I watched as bile erupted from their mouth, due to unhealthy habits.

The doctors knew nothing of the sort.

The child of this person was also the parent of I.

They wept, yet hated them.

My and my parent are one in the same.

Yet I wept because they wept, not because I knew what was what.

A dog died, in fact, months later.

I knew this dog since they were a pup.

I felt nothing but regret for not walking my own child.

I never played with them.

I only ever came out to pet them.

I always looked through the window into the backyard where they remain.

I kept a life stuck where I was, it was fed, watered, and had a friend, another pup..

It was like a mother to it.

It loved the mother, the mother loved the pup.

When it was put down, I thought of my grand relative whom had died earlier.

I felt a grip pull onto my chest, I felt it rising through my throat.

I had never felt such pain and despair in my life.

It was always smooth for me,

but it had, for the first time, ended rough.
14533.title: Rough yet smooth

15.content:
For the Plane that Landed in the Hudson River

On the way down, you wish you could find
and keep all your days and regret the failure
of not having looked at things carefully enough
when the loudspeaker announces they lost
the engines, and the pilot knows all
his instruments will be wrecked and
the cockpit will be filled with brine, but
his hands still clamor at the controls.
From the wing, the eyes of a dying bird
stares inside, at you, at the passengers,
stiff and glazed. But who can put brakes
on falling things that trail a loose path?
So you hang on to the pendant you wear,
the one with an embossed saint,
to keep away the fire, getting smashed up,
and feeling the hurt. It is the final thought
you think you have. And the plane
veers toward water like a juggler
juggling life and death.
15.title: Hands

151.content:
For the first time of my life, I watched uncontrollably

up into the night sky from my balcony, waiting
for the first star to appear so I could make a wish.
A wish that I would never forget you and our love.
The love that I will forever cherish, and maybe some
day relive. But for now, while you're gone, I promise
to remember. & When my life is over, I promise
we'll reunite for one last chance at love.

15111.content:
It's said that there are answers. I should know. I've heard them whispering.
I must say, I'm not a big fan of eating but sometimes I guess you don't get a say in what you do.
When my body starts screaming at me I know that it's probably time.
And when it's time I often go to this one fast-food restaurant.
The word restaurant, I think, should be used sparingly.
During the time that I've spent alive I have indeed learnt a lot.
And the TV has told me that restaurants do not have rats that try to clean your table before you're finished eating, nor cockroaches trying to perfect your food after it's been served.
Nonetheless I return every few weeks.
However it's not just the food, they have answers there.
You can see them out of the corner of your eye.
You quickly turn but they're gone already.
On occasion I've smelt them, too.
So acidic.. My eyes begin to water every time.
The food is still good however.
With every bite I feel it fill up a hole that's lied dormant since the time I turned 23.
I remember because it was exactly 4 months and 13 days after my dog died.
To the very hour, actually the very minute too.
There had been no warning, no flashing lights or sirens, it just happened.
Sprawled on the kitchen floor I knew a part of me was no longer there.
But I've improved, since I started coming to this fast-food restaurant.
Of course I'm still not fond of eating, but there's something about that place that's so.. filling.
Today's the day you know?
I'm going there again.
I'm so excited.
Last time I went I ordered my usual and sat down in my usual seat.
And then, out of nowhere, a kind stranger in a trench coat sat down with me to eat.
He told me about himself, how he didn't like eating but liked it here.
His dog died too.
I've never done this before, but I asked him.
I couldn't believe it but he had an answer.
Till then I had only heard, seen, smelt the smallest bits but to have before me the entire thing completely took me by surprise.
For a moment I lost my breath.
But then the stranger reached out his hands and shook me back to the steady rhythm of in, out, in out.
His long scraggly fingers upon my skin were new to me.
At least it had been awhile since I'd had so much contact with someone else.
I'm still so excited.
I'm meeting him there today!
He told me to meet him outside.
He said he had something for me.
He said;
"I can show you the truth behind the dumpster."
15111.title: The truth behind

151111.content:
There you are, forsooth! Are you here looking for the eternal truth?

The answers to the meaning of life? A means of solace for your worldly strife? It's really all quite simple, is what I think. Do not worry about your life, nor what you eat or drink. Just try to help your fellow man, better to swim together than sink!

Is not your life more than food and your body more than clothes? Don't look for answers in the shopping malls, see the beauty in a rose! Consider the starlings flying high in the sky, they neither sow nor reap and yet they get by. Are you not of more intelligence than they? So while the sun shines, let us make hay!

Consider the rats in this dumpster, how fat they all grow. Feed them a few crumbs and they'll put on a show! They don't go to work nor study in school, yet they believe their life is pretty cool. I say to you that Solomon in all his glory was not happier than these, especially when they find themselves a bit of cheese.

A great holy man long ago once said "Blessed are the peacemakers," but these rats today would probably say "Blessed are the cheese-makers!"

Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, and try not to borrow any trouble. Fiddle-dee-dee, is what I say; for tomorrow is merely another day!
151111.title: Bliss of Rats

15111112.content:
He walked down the hallway. Hands in his pocket, headphones on his head. He open the bedroom door and slammed it shut behind him,
"Hey, Jay, whats up?"
He flops onto his bed and turns to face the wall. The music blares in his ears, its beat pounding his head.
"You should have been at school today. She-she pulled that prank today. Half the class got soaked."
He turns over and looks at the door e had come into a few minutes before. He laughed and jumped off the bed.
"Hey be careful. Dad would flip if he knew you had that out."
He held his hands up, and sat back down on the bed. A concern and nervous look on his face.
"Jay, I think..."
He was silent, a look of horror on his face. He had gone as pale as the moon, his breath came as shallow gasps.
"JAY!!!"
He finally manages to move, but his breathing is getting worse. He runs across the room but stumbles. He quickly reaches in his pocket and pulls out an inhaler. With his breath back, he crawls across the room and begins to cry.
"Jay!! Jay, man, speak to me."

On the other side of 2 way mirror the parents watch their son's nightmare. They watch with teary eyes as they watch him.
"He just won't stop living in the past. He can't let go of that one moment." The doctor tells them, "If he had his way, he would be the one with the gun right now."
15111112.title: Living in the Past

1511112.content:

And a bunch more but what I think can be funny is for anyone to say, " IT IS WHAT IT IS".
