1541.title: Embrace Death

15411.content:
A man and a woman sit outside, staring into each other's eyes. A spaceship is off in the distance behind them.

"Have you seen the stars tonight?" the man suddenly asks. "They're strange. You can tell we're on another planet just by looking at them."

The woman looks up. "You're right, Luke," she says. "They are very strange. I guess our new home is in a different region of the galaxy than old Earth was." She smiles and shakes her head.

"Jane," Luke says, "I love you so much. I know we just arrived here. Nobody's even given the planet a name yet, but it's already home. Much better than Earth, anyway." He stops, takes a deep breath, and pulls something out of his pocket. "Will you marry me?"

Jane sits and stares at him in silence. "I-I would love to, but how are we going to manage that? We just landed."

"We'll figure something out. Just...please say yes."

"Of course," she breathes. "Yes, Luke, I would be more than happy to marry you." She smiles and stares at him again, then adds, "I just don't think now's the best time. Once we get settles, okay?"

"Yeah." He frowns.

She smiles and leans forward to kiss him. They spend all night out underneath the strange stars.
15411.title: Have You Seen the Stars Tonight

154111.content:
"There's no hope! All of our prisoners have started a rebellion! We're so surely damned!" The captain shrieked.

Meanwhile, under their feet, an army assembled. All with the same mindset. They smashed against the bars that restrained them. A constant chant saturating the air.

"We're no longer your slaves, freedom is our goal. For we, are the Rebels."
154111.title: In a galaxy far, far away? Nope.

1541111.content:
Is there truly such a thing as Demonic Influence? Is there really little creatures that change our actions, telling us to do horrible things or just causing people to be straight up jerks? Or is it just our way to explain what can not be explained, the human brain. Sure we may be able to tell certain things about the brain like what part controls growth, what part controls breathing and so on but besides that it is all just a mystery to us. Perhaps this is why the thought of Demonic Influence and a High Power came to be.

Please do not take this as a bashing of religion, I respect all views as long as it doesn't hurt anyone, I am simply addressing a certain view point. Take for example people who think someone who is showing massive mood swings may need a priest and some might see it as they need mental health. To one side it is demonic influence that is causing that person to have mood swings, to others it is a mental disorder. Each one sees the same thing but registers it as different items. Another example would be people who think homosexuals are sinful and others see it as a normal relationship. It is all a mater of perception dear reader, something that none of us have been able to fully comprehend, why does that one person see things in that way and one in another?

This could very well explain demonic influence as just being certain peoples views on why someone doesn't think like they do, that there must be some evil thing making them think that way when really it could be just their brains are a bit different then ours. Now does this prove that their is no such thing as demonic influence, of course not, this is just a way of possibly explaining it just like demons are the cause is a possible way of explaining it. We may never know the true answer but we each explain it in our own ways
1541111.title: Demonic Influence

15411111.content:
As time elapsed so did the life. People watched in astonishment as slowly their neighbor let go of the ties to the planet. Then she drifted away seeing and hearing nothing, feeling nothing, knowing nothing. The body turned cold and eventually stiff, then after more time the stiffness receded until it also was gone.

This is what everyone thought happened, but things aren't as they seem. The body was dead however, the spirit, well, that was another matter. Unknown to everyone at that time, the spirit left for another dimension and yet longed to remain where it had been for over 93 years. Heaven was a fine and wonderful place but the other place had much to be desired, so this spirit roamed about in between places and eventually people began to realize something had changed since the death of Mrs. Snellington. People like her very much because she was always happy and helpful, wanting to be a friend to everyone. Many times when someone needed help she would not hesitate to help or find someone who could help. She would be greatly missed.

There came a time when the town was caught in a storm and many people needed a lot of help. Unfortunately so many people were struggling there was no one available to help anyone. Surprisingly things were changed for the better. There was no indication of anything out of the ordinary except people got the help they needed from, well, somewhere.
15411111.title: Afterlife

154111112.content:
Some of the folk asked, "Who was that?", not realizing that it was Mrs. Snellington who had been helped them. She had floated in the spirit realm for a while switching between Hall and Heaven and, because she tended more to the former because of it's attractions, she was given the option to return to the planet to serve out her time of Karma.She could, however, take on any human form at will, thus helping various people while looking like different people to her original person.

Mrs. Snellington, who we will from here onward refer to as spirit lady, continued to do good in her Karma service, although she faced temptation in the physical sense. She could opt to take on a human form again and function normally.
154111112.title: Who Was That?

choices: This house is not a home
15412.content:
Truth is so elusive to those who are blind.

Forever I walked with my hands over my eyes.

Each minute that passed was another chance.

The seconds are counting down now.

At my bedside Death waits patiently for me.

Silent tears flow down.

It's not too late, not yet, so why don't I?

Still I cannot bring myself to do it.

Fear breeds doubt, buries itself in my mind.

Again, I deny You.

One final breath slowly exhaled.

With it, my soul sighs, freed from the chains of flesh.

How could I have known?

At Heaven's Gate,

Love and Mercy are ever-entwined as one.
15412.title: At Heaven's Gate

154121.content:
I was a tainted soul, my life full of regrets. When death approached me, I was unwilling. For the remainder of my life, I resisted, uselessly, against a force of nature. I was lost and desperate, and turned to the matters of the afterlife. I pretended to repent of my sins, of murder, theft, and wanton destruction.

I thought that it worked. Even as I struggled to breathe in my age, I thought that death would now be nothing to me, nothing to fear.

Finally, the time came, and I passed through what I thought were the pearly gates of heaven. I walked everywhere, taking in the sights. But something seemed off.

The people here smiled, but their smiles were too wide, almost artificial. It had the effect of looking particularly creepy. Before I could look closer, I was guided to the center of heaven.

A shining light emanated before me, and I was standing in front of a Presence. I wasn't sure what was going to happen next, but I was in bliss. What did it matter?

Then the angels branded me. Suddenly, I was wracked in pain, and my face suddenly forced into a too-wide, artificial smile. What was happening to me? What kind of heaven was this?

The light in front of me enveloped me, and I was transported elsewhere. And then I realized something. All those stories of a man who thinks he went to heaven, but really found himself in...

Suddenly I was face to face with a snake. The biggest I ever saw, whose body coiled around me. It didn't take a genius to figure out who this was.

The serpent's smile was awful, and I shrank in fear. He said to me, "Welcome to eternity. I assure you, your repentance for your sins will be very...thorough."

The brand given to me burned with pain. Pain I would feel for eternity. Damn it all.
154121.title: Serpent's smile

154122.content:
"I went in to the loneliness house,
went on in and I locked the door.
Seen a lot of trouble when I was out and about,
I might not come out no more..."
- Greg brown

I really don't know how it all got started.

Maybe it was the night I came home from my girlfriend's place and got mugged walking from my car to my apartment. These three guys just shoved me down and I hit my head on the sidewalk, and when I woke up my wallet and glasses were gone.

Or maybe it was the day I got out of my car in the Walmart parking lot and got harassed by this crazy old guy who was leaving in the F-150 that was parked next to me. He yelled out "You goddamn socialist scumbag! If I had my shotgun with me I'd waste your sorry ass!" as he drove away.

It took me a minute to figure out what he was talking about. (I forgot I still had the "Obama '08" sticker on my bumper.)

Anyway, I guess I started to think the world was out to get me. Too many crazy and dangerous people out there. I figured the only place I was reasonably safe was at work, or maybe in my apartment.

At work it was pretty secure, I work for a government contractor. We have armed guards and electronic ID badges to open the doors. I started going in early and staying late most days because I felt safer there.

At home my apartment had a gate with a security code access, but my neighbors could just buzz anybody in. So I put an extra deadbolt on my door. And I bought myself a Glock 9mm for backup, just in case.

Then I tucked the pistol in my belt, put on an old baggy hoodie, and drove down to the grocery store to stock up. Mostly canned goods, and enough meat and frozen veggies and orange juice to stuff the freezer. I got enough food to last a month or two, maybe more. Charged it all on my Visa.

My girlfriend dumped me soon after that. I kept making excuses of why I couldn't go over her place, or take her out anywhere. (I guess the thrill of coming over to my shabby apartment to watch TV all the time got old for her.)

So I get up early every day and drive to work before the sun comes up. I stop at the self serve gas station on my way in once a week to fill up, and I pay at the pump. I drive home after work and walk straight from the parking lot to my apartment, don't say nothing to nobody, even if they say hi to me.

I know this isn't normal, I really need to change. A friend of mine at work recommended you, that's why I made the appointment. Do you really think you can help me?
154122.title: This House Is Not a Home

1541221.content:
I listened to my patient with a varying degree of interest. At times, I wasn't so sure how to take it, how I should visibly respond to the source of his inbred trauma. Others, I tried to resist contemplating about the girlfriend. I couldn't reason as to why she didn't stay, didn't make the attempt to provide comfort and solace for his anxieties. But then I concluded, it mayhave not been entirely her fault. Perhaps, he was simply too reserved about his rationale to stay home. Maybe it just didn't add up for her. I also was forced into resistance when I found myself disbelieving the measures to which he went about trying ensure his safety. I mean, nothing so seemingly mundane and simultaneously harrowing had ever happened to me.

And that's when the murkiness of cynicism crept into my ticking brain. How could I ever extend the hand of assistance to an individual whose experience I had never touched on. Sure, the psychological medical practice was a fine way to pick at humans in our society. The mostly objective approach was a fine way to stick and push yard long needles into others without the damagin reprecurssions of absorbing to oneself the disturbance of another. I could easily peel back the scalp and peer into the brain. And pick, pick, pick until I've hit a nerve. But the patient doesn't have the, the, the blessing to peel back my stomach skin and see my intestines. He can't see what's in my brain. That information is not accessible to him because it's necessary that I stick to the traditional method.

Listen. Or pretend to do so. Give him an expression of a statue. Blank in the face, so as not to arouse his emotions. And respond artificially. But I didn't want to appreciate our new relationship in that fashion. That's what would become of this, anyway. We strive to form relationships. It may sound distant, ideal, farfetched and outlandish, but for goodness sake, it's written in our medical oaths! I'm not hoping to help this man. I'm not even hoping for him to help himself. What I hope, is that, by stripping my skin and showing a bit of muscles, and bones and organs, maybe I can show him a reflection of himself that he once thought was perilous. And maybe, he'll also recognize a part of himself that he once thought was safe, comfy, healthy. And if he can reorder some things, and balance himself, then light will go back to being light. And darkness will go back to being darkness.

Funny. He reminds me of a young female patient I had back when I was a school therapist. She was an outlandish creature, but then, if she had opted for "normal" in a school environment, a high school environment, then I may have been more compelled to have the young thing admitted. She was just like this one, though, she seemed to have the ability to be able to discern as to what lightness and darkness was. This young man seems to lack this ability. Or rather, he has the keeness to understand darkness in a real, tangible sense, but could not distinguish darkness in its multiple forms. Cynthiana was always going on about that. That was her name. Cynthiana. Strange girl, philosophically anyways.

I really didn't see what was so significant about shadows and spirits and souls and lightbulbs and dark rooms. They seem like such drab things to be worrying about when homework and farming and gardening seemed to be so important. But my buried, trenched personality trickled out of me, beyond my control. I asked her what a regular day for her was like, in the same fashion that my current patient before me relayed his day. And there was nothing to it. There was not a damn, singl thing that was particularly unusual about her day. Nothing happened. Literally. Nothing happened. And somehow, recalling Cynthiana's daily activities made my heart grow weary. I began seriously considering how painful it may have beenfor this man to go about his business and have to worry if someone was planning to jump, and other related acts.

But then I went back to thinking about her. Cynthiana. She went about her business with seemingly no response at all. Certain events she described should have roused her like any other person. And this was a girl, that, from the knowledge that I've collected from her personal academic records, instructors, peers and even neighbors, did exceptional in her life. She never attributed any of those actions, skills, and abilites to anyone else. And strangely, she could not seem to bring herself the comfort of attributing these things to even herself. It was almost as if she lacked both the light and darkness that one would find in an individual.

And here, sitting in front of me, was a person who deeply felt all his surroundings. Everything he went through, he experienced with the fervor of someone who was virtually without a predisposed disorder. It's strange to consider all this now. It's strange to compare such a distant, and yet close patient to a man who seemed so, so, so normal! His logic, while considerable extreme, was a very basic, simplified reaction to unfortunate, but tangible, real problems. Cynthiana, on the other hand, reacted in a zig-zag pattern that would suggest trauma was present, though none had occured based on wisdom of her being. 'Water off a duck's back,' I thought, whenever she would trudge through my office door. I even told her once, never ever to see me again. There's nothing you need from me. And nothing I need from you, so crawl away from here and try your best not to return. I even managed to say all that as calmly and austerely as possible, without making myself seem like a despot or a firebrand.

But darkness doesn't seek lightness out because it wants balance. And light, certainly does not choose dark because it need an equillibrium. Not the way I view things, at least. And not that my views should take center stage. It's just that realized why Cynthiana was there. I realized why this young man was here. She had no known kin, parent or guardian. And this man, who lost his girlfriend - perhaps the only constant companion that he had at the time - now resigned himself to living his life, permanently, at home. They were seeking humanity. Humans. People. A relationship. I was beginning to feel like I actually knew what I was doing, like I always had, with this profession.

In the end, I didn't throw Ms. Cynthiana away. I actually befriended that strange creature. It was peculiar having such a young friend, but she didn't seem to mind my status in life, so I forced myself to stop worrying about hers. And I will do the same for him. He who sought not therapy, but himself.

First, though, I must say something a bit crude that's been nagging me since he before he even relayed his story:

"You're probably more normal than you give yourself credit for - even now, sitting here in my office. But before I can help you, I need to establish something very pertinent. I need you to hear my story first."

15421.content:
We had been walking for days. We were tired, our feet were tired, and the darkness was winning against the light. We could hear vile creatures slithering and cackling and hissing, just waiting for when our flashlight failed. And I knew it would. The flashlights were holding out much longer than they should have. As if on cue my flashlight flickered then went out. I held my breath, willing for the light to come back on. When it didn't i dropped it to the cave floor, no use caring around extra weight.
"Guys hurry up! You got to see this!" Hunter called froom around the bend ahead.
We ran to him and then stood in jaw dropping wonder. "Have you've ever seen anything more beautiful?" Chris sighed as tears sprang up in his eyes.
Not much but enough sunlight shone down from a crack in the ceiling, and it did wonders to out spirites.
"Come on!" I yelled." the exit has to be close!"
We charged down the tunnel, laughing as we saw the exit around another bed. We only had one stretch of darkness to go and at our pace it wouldn't take long to cross. None of use had noticed that the flash lights had gone out. Hunter disappeared into the darkness and emerged on the other side a few seconds later. Anna and Mary did the same. C.J, Chris, and I hit it at the same time and we knew we were screwed. I screamed as something wrapped around my leg pulling me towards a hidden hole to the side. An evil cackling laughter assuated our ears. Chris grabbed my arm and C.J grabbed his. They pulled towards the light moving me an inch forward before the creature dragged me back again. It laughed again, find us amusing. I could hear more creatures coming closer, not wasteing the promise of an easy meal.
" You have to go NOW!? I roared at my brothers.
They looked at me like I was an idoit. There was n oway they would leave me, we had lost to much already. I heard human feet runninf towards us and felt the rest of our group run to the light. They hadn't been apart of the group long enough to really get to know me. They knew what had to be done thats why they had survived so long.
"Go." I said looking at CJ. He just shook his hand and pulled harder. By no the creature had lost interest and just wanted to feed. With a massive thug i was wrenched from my brothers and dragged further back. I grabbed hold of a rock jutting from a rock. Chris was heading towards me, a srubborn look on his face.
"Daddy! Sta Sta!" A childs voice called.
"Go. You have to be there for him."
I didn't see what he did next since i let go of the rock. I quickly reached for the knife at my side. I may be gonna die but i was gonna go down fightig. With that thought i was fully swallowed by the darkness.

*Sorry i know it was bad T-T. I was trying to see if it would help with my writer's block*

1543.content:
Melodies

His name was Georgio Dorio but he was simply known as Dorio. He now lay in his bed, as he did every day as he waited for death to claim him. Many people in his condition would be in a Hospice but he was fortunate because he had money and could afford home care.

So there he lay in his bed facing the casement windows which were opened every morning so that he had a view of his garden. Of course when the weather was not suitable for having open windows he found himself with only the gloomy view of his bedroom.

Sometimes he listened to music and other times he explored within his own mind, thinking of what had happened in the past, what was happening, what he would like to have happened and what eventually would happen. When he thought of the past there were often melodies that accompanied the memories.

The most common melody, though not common in it’s self, was the intermezzo from the Opera Cavalleria Rusticana by Mascagni. The sadness of the violins at the beginning, the shivers up his spine as the wood winds joined in followed by a harp and then the full orchestra as it tells the story of what is to come, "They have murdered Turiddu!" Dorio said out loud.

As Dorio exclaimed this his son Tito entered the room. “Yes papa, Cavalleria Rusticana,” he said sitting on his father’s bed. “The intermezzo shall be played at your funeral.”

“No Tito no,” Dorio said stroking his sons cheek. “I cannot hear it when I am dead.
Why will you make all the mourners cry when already they will be in sorrow?”

Dorio’s 30 year old son took his father’s hand in his. “Who will cry hearing this music? It will remind us of you and how much you loved it.”

Dorio was sad as he said, “If you do not feel emotion, tears streaming down your face and your whole body becoming one with the music, then you have not heard Mascagni’s intermezzo from Cavalleria Rusticana.”

“That is true for you papa but we do not have your ears or heart so we cannot feel as you do but we can remember you in this beautiful music.”

“Play it to me now my son and we will share it together while we both can.”

Tito selected the CD of the opera and put it in the player by his father’s bed and set it to play at the intermezzo. Tears started to come from Dorio’s eyes as father and son looked at each other, then as the music ended Tito realised that his father’s eyes were no longer looking at him but vacant as if looking into some distant place.

“No papa,” Tito cried out as his eyes filled with tears. “Papa, you have made me hear the music, I am crying for the music and I am crying for you.”
1543.title: Melodies

15432.content: Soft, soothing, violin's woke Dorio to a golden clocktower. Hundreds of golden mechanical gears whirred, the structure itself seemed to be comprised of thousands of them, different types of clocks were arranged on the tower, ticking at different times. Dorio chuckled softly to himself, he knew this was death, but this was not the cold oblivion he had conjured so many times on his deathbed. "My son..." he whispered, "This is true life.". Dorio admired the mechnical tower for what seemed like years until finally he strode past it, ready to further explore this existance that surpassed the prior.
15432.title: Fine music

1551.content:
I didn't know he had a gun.
The pain was intense, but it only lasted a few seconds.
He must have shot me in the heart.
I'd all but forgotten I had one.
I don't recall how it happened, it all happened so fast.
It was my fault.
I did this to myself.
The pain is replaced by warmth.
A feeling of love I've only felt coming from my mother.
It'll break her heart when they tell her this.
I didn't know he had a gun.
I thought I could get away with one more hit.
A tiny restaurant at midnight.
The old man was packing...didn't see that coming.
Bless his heart, he must be horrified right now.
No hate from me, old man. I would've done the same to you.
I didn't know he had a gun.
The warmth is strong now.
Like being back in the womb.
What kind of karma have I collected in my life?
I did more bad than good.
I have a feeling that where I am the good matters more.
It'll all be fine now.
For me anyhow.
I dread my reincarnation.
I'll have to break the promise to forever watch over my mom.
1551.title: Reincarnation

15511.content:
Needless to say, mom wasn't happy about that. Not happy at all. Of course, this was nothing new. I never could make mom happy.

The problem was being the middle kid, of course. Lucas was the oldest, her daring, handsome boy. Jennifer was always her baby. I was the disappointment. Never finished school, never gave her a grandchild, never called home. I'll bet I'm not even in the will.

It's funny, though. I'm the only one who showed up when mom got sick. Lucas couldn't read to her at night, he was too busy with his court cases. Jennifer wasn't there to hold mom's hand while the drugs tore up her insides. She was too busy with her store.

It was Sam, the deadbeat, the disappointment. I was the one who was there for mom. Did she thank me for it? Hell no. All she talks about are Lucas and Jennifer, how she's so proud of them. It's just not fair.

The dark water of the end is closing in around me now. At least, I hope it's the end. Mom won't be far behind me. If there's more after death, I'm sure the first act of her afterlife will be letting me know how disappointed she is.
15511.title: dark water

155111.content:
The teen has a large plastic bag filled with money. The police were hot on his trail in the crowded city. He didn't worry about them, though; stealing money from banks was easy with his new power.
"Stop right now!" a policeman said as he pursued Lucas. Lucas ran up to a fence. He couldn't jump them, but he knew what he could do...
Lucas zapped a hole through the fence with his eyes. The teen could shoot lasers from his eyes.
He ran up to a bike. It was chained to a stop sign. With ease, Lucas broke the chain with his bare hands. He got on the bike and rode as fast as he could.
"Darn," he said as he saw some money coming out of the plastic bag. Police were shooting at the bag, so money would come out. Then, they shot at his tires. The bike was useless now. Lucas flew to the skies, zooming as fast as he could. In minutes, helicopters were on his trail. He flew into one, knocked the pilot unconscious, and drove the copter away from the other police copters.
Life would be a lot easier with his new powers. It'd also be easier to take revenge...

choices: He got up, there was no meteor anymore
1551111.content:
"Jack, what the hell was that noise?" Angry steps pounded down the stairs as Jack's mother descended and yelled at him, "Don't you say you broke something again."

She stopped just at the last stair step of the basement. She had her hands on her hips and hair tied in a tight bun which made her face prominent and look bigger than it actually was. She inspected the entire room and her eyes landed on Jack on the floor.

Jack slowly got up to his feet and shuffled his feet, clearing off the dust that covered his clothes.

"Nothing happened, mum, I just fell," Jack mumbled, his eyes avoiding meeting his mother's.

Jack's mother just hmphed and went back upstairs, satisfied because there wasn't anything broken. Well, at least nothing broken she'd seen. Jack bent over to pick up the shards of the broken glass and disposed of it. He cleaned the floor and made sure there was no dust, no piece of glass.

After he had cleaned the basement and removed the covers from the bed and all the furniture, it looked as good as new. He had moved back in with her mother after a year spent in Ireland, interning in a video game company. When they offered him no job, despite how hard he had worked and proven himself, he saw no reason to stay there and decided to come back home. His mother was always strict but she loved her kids and she made sure Jack knew that the doors to her house were always open for her babies.

There was another reason why Jack returned back. He had discovered something inside of him, something that made him scared of himself. Now that he was surrounded by familiar environment and people, he had eased up quite a bit and he was learning how to control his thing.

He inhaled and exhaled, slowly and deeply. Rubbing his hands together and breathing in and out, he paced the room and then stopped. He closed his eyes and moved his legs up as if he was sitting in a posture in yoga. He felt himself in the air, light and touching no surface.

He squinted one of his eyes and opened slowly to see what or where he was and looking at it, he opened both eyes and chuckled, his features were a mixture of confusion and interest.

"Woah, I can actually fly in air, I can frigging stay in the air like this," He slowly eased himself down on the floor and searched the internet with the words 'The Worhound Effect' but there was nothing on it among the search results. Not even one result showed up. Looked like he had to go outside the house and hit the libraries in order to answer all the buzzing questions that kept arriving in his mind. Like why was he the only one who knew about this incident, why was he influenced by it, what were his abilities besides being able to fly in the sky or the air.

Jack packed a bag and hung it over his shoulder. He went into the kitchen and kissed his mother on her cheek, "Bye, mum. Going to the library now. Will be back late at night. Don't worry about me, okay?"

As soon as he had said that, he left the house and walked down to the library.

It all started when Jack was walking on the countryside in Ireland, taking a break from all the hectic routine and the internship when he saw a meteor fall right in front of him and he blacked out probably by the impact.

608 words

But as with all images of perfection, Jennifer did not possess true perfection. Her flaw was not of a physical nature; no one could say that. Alas! She was cursed with indecision. A curious affliction indeed, but one so intense that it crippled the poor youth every day of her life. The smallest proposition sent her mind spiraling, frantically calculating the pros and cons of the thousands of possibilities.

It is a strange thing to watch the decline of a true wonder of this world.

"It's over, Andrej." The forty year old Slavic spy slowly turned around to see who had said that, yet he knew it was Erik. They were on the balcony of the newly erected Nigerian Presidential Mansion, five stories above ground. The younger Erik was pointing a handgun at him, he thought it was a Desert Eagle. American made.

"You know they'll never accept a German as one of their' own, Erik." Andrej said in his native language, taking a long drag on his cigarette. "It's not about that Andrej. You betrayed us, you went rogue." Erik replied, scratching his clean shaven face with one hand, pointing the gun with the other. "I had to do what was right-" "What you thought was right, Andrej!" "You and I both know what we were helping them do is wrong! That we have to trick ourselves into believing what we do is good, that we weren't helping anyone except for Thompson! We all got a nice fat paycheck and we keep our mouths shut! I couldn't do it anymore! That's why I killed Reed, and Trent, and blew up the facility!"

Eric quickly got to work, cutting a peice of Andrej's hair for proof and taking a picture of the corpse with his phone. The CIA were picky like that. He then put on his gloves, and lifted up the body. Andrej didn't weigh that much for a 5'6 man. He dropped the body over the balcony, where the rest of his team would dispose of the body.

The facility that Andrej had sabotaged was nuclear. They were trying to find a way to make miniature nuclear bombs and missiles without NATO or the Russians knowing.

Andrej hadn't been alone when he virtually destroyed the facility, he'd had a team with him. They were all Nationalists of their respective Eastern European countries, but they were tired of the US and the CIA sticking their' noses in everyone's business.

But that was not the only reason why they had sabotaged the facility and set loose the workers. Andrej and most of his suspected team were of Roma descent, as in they were at least part Gypsy. The CIA and Czech agents had kidnapped Gypsies to do all the heavy lifting while Hungary had sent their best scientists to make the miniature bombs. Hoping to avenge their kin, Andrej's team helped almost all two hundred escape. Eric didn't care much for the Gypsies, he hadn't even known that Andrej was one.

To get Hungary's cooperation, the CIA had promised to help them train a special police force that could rival Poland and help build up the Eastern European economy, as well as give them political power. Hungary had enlisted the help of the governments of the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Austria, and even Romania.

Eric quickly walked back inside the Presidential Mansion. He immediately headed down the stairs, avoiding the political bosses and ambassadors from neighboring nations as well as Spain. Once he was able to walk outside, he and his team got into their blue van, and drove off.

On this particular day, King Dedede was busily giving out presents (Christmas made hime very jolly) while Meta-Knight was out with his first girlfriend (he hardly goes out with her at all). Kirby downed his usual Christmas breakfast quickly to...
1611.title: Welcome to Dream Land!

162.content: The gale winds hurled sleet against the window as I stood and watched the tree limbs swing and sway until it seemed they would break under such forces. The monster snarled with pleasurable rage, but I simply felt a detached numbness about it all. It was true that anger lay just beneath the surface of my unfeeling calm. Such guarded rage against the unfairness and the emptiness of my personal loss; rage locked in so tight that even the tears of my great sadness dwindled into silence. The sleet pounded the glass and the trees writhed like I wanted to scream and pound and tear apart that monstrous unholiness that gripped me into unnatural quiet calm. My happiness was thrown away with little to no disregard for myself, but through the manipulations of she who had promised wonders and all the while lied about those promises she'd made. The treachery went unnoticed because I believed, I so wanted to believe her. And she got away. I stand watching the wind, listening to the sleet, smelling the wetness and the cold, and tasting the bitterness of abandonment and she got away never to witness the destructive torment she left behind. She smiles and laughs and jokes as if nothing ever happened and has the temerity to ask if we could remain as friends. She is clueless and I am unable to let loose the bindings of the insane rage and grief locked so securely within me. In truth I have traded a new monster for the old. She, the deceitress and be-littler has gone away and I am left with the caged rage.
162.title: What got away

1623.content:

1623.title: facing the inner monster

choices: Tell one of the character's adventure in his mind
Start a new story of your choice
16232.content:
I remember now that I wasn't always like this. My mind would go somewhere else, I'd explore that place and then come back in reality, though a different time. I find myself drifting like that quite often, from time to time really. People say it's not good to relive and remain in your past but it's not just that with me. I can shape the past, go to the future, relive and change anything I want and stay there for as long as I want. Or until some stupid, silly nurse injects me with some kind of serum which puts me into a sleep, though peaceful it always is.

The thing is, my so called doctor asks me why I drift away and I do not understand why he doesn't understand. He says I am a mentally challenged person and I am much more immature than my age but that doesn't change the fact that when I am surrounded by people I have no idea about, what am I to do rather, who to keep company other than my very self?

All of them are what people call 'loony bins.' Considering I am in the place where they are, I must be one too. It's complicated, you know. We have the same routine everyday. There is no one who comes to visit and once in every while, someone's birthday is celebrated with a boring cake and then the same pills and routine again.

I never wanted to talk much about what I do here, in his institute. I would much rather talk about the adventures I go on, the people and creatures I meet and see on those voyages from which I am forced to return. You wouldn't believe but I have met the prince of Wales, visited the Downton Abbey and lived there for a few days, shook Kennedy's hand as he became the president.

316 words
16232.title: I remember now

I was to tell them to put it back, and the normal students used to jeer me and whistle and it was embarrising at first but I soon was used to it.

choices: Non-Awful Writing: A Cloud's Silver Lining
163.content:
So, there's this thing called Awful Writing, which kind of sounds like something from English class, but it really isn't, due to the general tendency of high school English teachers to avoid using the word "awful" in order to remain politically correct and to prevent criticism, like that one article about the teacher in New York who attached a McDonald's application to one of his student's papers. You can bet he had a lot of angry parents after him. But he could have been right, because his student's paper could just as well have been filled with long-winded sentences that have nothing to do with anything, such as that one haiku someone wrote about randomness and refrigerators, as well as that one sentence some clown wrote comparing his nose hairs to trees after a rainstorm... actually, I forgot exactly how that one goes. But whatever, let's move on.

Anyway, Awful Writing is also chock full of comparisons to other items which really have nothing to do with the original item being described, but these comparisons are worded in such a way that it's hard to tell, such as the fact that the intellectual movement and phenomenon popularly known as Awful Writing is merely a singular metaphor for the loneliness of human souls in eras of corruption and disillusionment.

There are also random tense changes throughout pieces of Awful Writing, so you may have seen places where you will be unsure of what the characters involved said or did, or would have thought if you were right there in the story with them. So if you were reading a piece of Awful Writing about how a girl learns to tie a shoe, the girl will be struggling with her laces which look like worms and totally grossed her out, though she would be proud of her efforts by the very end of the story when she finally will have learned how not to look like an idiot when faced with a pair of shoes with laces that look like even more disgusting worms.

Awful Writing includes references to the people reading, as well as to the author, so you can be sure that personal pronouns are sprinkled throughout the text like... like rainbow sprinkles on an ice cream that people who love rainbow sprinkles crave. I happen to be one of those people. Are you one of them? You are? Cool! Sometimes I wish I was just a rainbow sprinkle myself, just sitting in the midst of a scoop of ice cream, waiting to be devoured and savored by the person eating me... yum...

Not to mention the fact that there are hardly ever any transitions or proper conclusions in a work of Awful Writing. The pure genius required to master the craft of Awful Writing lies in

(purposefully discontinued - you figure out why )
163.title: Awful Writing

choices: How much more clear does this have to be?
1632.content:
Well, after reading the last chapter about "Awful Writing," I thought I'd jump in and add another chapter about Non-Awful writing. Why would i do this? Think about it! What better way to balance out the scheme of things. Balance is good and beneficial for all individuals. Even animals do well when there is balance. So, off to balanced writing or non-awful writing which ever works for you.

Non-awful writing which has balance generally has a good variety of ingredients. Not too much of this or that. Enough of this and that. The this and the that can be what ever works well with your choice of topic(s).

A good example would to not put a lot icky over done unnecessary descriptive words which do not make the writing better. I like a vivid picture of what is being written about as long as I don't get lost in the words or get completely lost in the written piece. If I get totally lost in useless stuff, I'm gone and probably will not read anything like that again, then again you never know.

I prefer reading something which isn't too full of fluff and awful words. The cat ran up the tree says enough about what the cat did, where it happened, and as for the tree, well the reader gets to decide what kind of tree the cat ran up. Certainly if there were two beings doing something and the writing was written so that the action of what these two were doing was close to the identifying who they were, then I would know who and exactly what they were doing. If there was a lot of awful fluff in between the action of what the who was doing I would certainly be confused.

I like writing and want to share information with people, so I make certain that I'm not confusing them by writing awful.
1632.title: Non-Awful Writing: A Cloud's Silver Lining

16321.content:
To put food on the table? To satisfy my self-righteous inklings? To be heard (or in this case read)? To inform and enlighten? To pass time?

I write for all these reasons and perhaps a hundred more. I can't remember the first time I committed thoughts to paper with enough acuity that it was more than just doodled letters. I remember why I chose to write, however, and the reason was quite silly. I started writing because I couldn't draw.

My brother was skilled with the pencil - the 0.5mm lead stick that etched the foundations of great artwork, or perhaps the literal foundations of architectural wonders. I wasn't. A good friend who was a graphic artist once commented that though he accepted writers as artists, he thought the latter were more creative. I thought otherwise. How can you not be creative with so many ways to communicate at your disposal? A brush. A spray paint canister. A pencil. A highlighter. Anything that can be arranged with the resulting mesh aesthetically sound can be deemed tools of art, and the mesh itself the artwork. Writers only have words. These words with which we are forced to communicate a concept, these letter-weavings that impart abstract ideas - these are what writers work with. Does a writer not need as much creativity, perhaps more, than the artist when he has words to work with while the artist has images? In the aftermath of my friend's comment years after I already embraced writing, in silent contemplation of his probably thoughtless uttering, I realized that I didn't write because I couldn't draw. I wrote because I can never draw as well as I write. I was an artist whose canvas was filled with paragraphs of words, not swathes of colors. And with these words I have grown to learn more and more about myself and the world as I experience it. To the day my fingers ache with arthritis (or carpal tunnel, whichever strikes first), I will be writing (or typing) away.

I write because my every word etches my reality in the greater whole. And of course, I write to make a living, and am blessed to be able to do what I love and earn doing it.
16321.title: Why I write

163211.content: Yes prose flows more than poetry for me, however there are, times when poetry gets going and flowing also. For me writing is an art form which paints pictures with words, imagination, education, and different genres. Prose is great when my rhythms are at rest and when I need to write material which has many sentences, paragraphs, and takes up a large space on the digital canvas. Poetry is nice because I can get into rhythms, write a very short piece, and when the need to add to this picture created with words it is short enough for a quick read and then adding the information. I'm enjoying writing this in one of my favorite places Writing is an anywhere any time, under any circumstances endeavor; with in reason and sometimes, unreason. Being a researcher by nature, having the need to share information with people, and being the recipient of the gift of writing; I can do nothing else. Prose is an environment in which I am very comfortable because I tend to be passionate about writing, what I'm writing about, and sharing with people information which may be helpful to them. This writing is a bit experimental because I'm writing what I'm thinking about for this chapter. I'm not concerned about how long the sentences may be or if they might be too long. I'm curious about what you think of this writing under these circumstances. So, I guess I'm a scientist/researcher when it comes to wanting to know what if and relating my experiments to writing, especially prose.

This sucked! I'll show you what poetry really is!
163212.content:
I prefer poetry... Wait! No I don't! How is a poet able to put that much meaning into so few words? How are they able to breathe so much life into letters that by themselves don't mean anything? What? What did you say? You want me to give them a chance? You want ME to write a poem? No. No, I couldn't. You insist? Well, alright... I guess. Just this once. *Deep Breath* Here goes...

I
Don't Like
Being told
How I should write.
Oh, Come on! Don't Hate!
I'm giving them a chance.
Write what you please, I don't care
At least I gave poems a chance.
I made up this form all by myself.
One syllable to start, then up to ten.
After that, they come back down again.
What is the name of this poem?
If you know the name, please tell.
What? It doesn't have one?
Hey, at least I tried.
Don't judge too soon.
Don't be quick
To hate.
Fin


A note to all Poets: This is terrible, I know. I just wanted to give it a shot and also to send this shout-out to all poets: your stuff is amazing and I envy you. Anyway, peace out!

-Emily

PS. If this is at all good, send me an email of IM me and I might consider doing poetry more!
163212.title: I prefer poetry...

choices: A journal (a real one, not electronic)
1632121.content:
That attempt at poetry brought a smile. <-- there it is.

Free form poetry? I'm not sure if poetry that does not abide by poetic norms can be called poetry..but we're writers, are we not? Our concepts cannot be limited by reality, though we may be limited by words in telling. I scribble verses to once in a while. Not really poems per se, just a writer's inklings dedicated to paper. Here are some I still keep:

+++++++++

-SECOND-

In the grace of a woman,
And the likeness of a child,
Resides a wounded soul--
Strong-willed yet fragile;
As delicate as it is formidable.

Confused, yet certain,
As stubborn as I, perhaps even more;
'To her,' said a distant beckon,
And the lucky fool that was I had to follow.

A chaotic road it was, still is, and as far as I can see, maybe forever will be.
Again I tread a path of my choosing.
If with her, as did most my opted fates, I fail,
I can never deny what it was I felt--
The closest kin to a most joyous moment,
Perhaps t'was the same.
As I lay down my walls,
And let light see me, my shadow, and which was which;
I was granted peace again from my hurdles,
My failures, and my deeds.

For When you are entangled in her trap,
Once you are in her embrace;
Shrouded in her fragrance,
In her warmth;
Resistance is next to unfathomable.
And thus you yield to your most basic weakness--
Thus you claim human fault.

As did I, I must admit.

For you must understand,
For a Spectre to have a home;
The offer seemed far too great,
And the wraith again chose to risk leaving his darkness,
For a better place to belong.

He has yet to regret that decision.
And he will never.

++++++++++++

That was about my wife (obviously). Here's something somewhat darker:

++++++++++++

UNTITLED

All the words prancing inside your head.
Without anything to say, they’re of little use.
Substance without style is comedy.
Style without substance is tragedy.
Nil use of such great potential—that’s murder.
Knowing yet remaining dormant—that’s suicide.

Suicide; letting your life bleed away from under your skin.
Simply breathing, but doing nothing more.
Suicide; or perhaps euthanasia.
When you acknowledge your own folly yet continue to dwell within it.
When you intentionally fail yourself time and time again;
Euthanasia of the ignorant.
Self pity.
Self-mockery.
Stupidity.

Shall heaven grace you with your freedom?
Your peace amidst chaos,
Chaos you yourself created?
Will your existence be significant,
And in so being, shall you be rid of your sorrows?
Your demons, your pains and tragedies?

Will you ever prove the worth of your living?
Brought into this purgatory,
By the same mistakes you commit everyday;
Trudging through your chosen path,
Battling more than your share of hindrances;
Shall you finally be etched into reality?

To whom will you offer fealty?
Have you yet to learn to hate?
Nary a fool would lean his head
On an ax bent on crushing it.
Alone as you are, what choice can you make,
But the only one there is?

For how long do you intend to stay still?
Time cares not for your withered spirit,
And it will not cease its march for you.
Perhaps there will never be surcease,
From your origin to your end,
A final escape from yourself.
Yet for every moment you build rather than destroy,
Accept rather than reject,
Find peace rather than dwell in chaos,

You step closer to knowing
How
And why

You should accept yourself.

And perhaps then,
an exodus would not be as important,
as all the times even a fleeting paradise was in this hell.

+++++++++

Might as well add this one:

+++++++++

Pseudonym Idiosyncrasy

Why should i worry about such mundane matters?
Irrelevant, useless. Just as i am.
Time to stop pretending, lying to myself.
All the world will go on with or without me, my fears, my lies.
Dogs would still chase cats. Cats would still chase mice. Mice would still be virtually blind, feeling their way in and out of their holes.
And their lonely existence would still be more justifiable than that of pathetic, corrupt humans.
They would still crave power, and with it they would be leaders of the ignorant and weak. More so worthy of damnation than any stray dog in any filthy street.
The Earth would continue to decay. All living beings that roam its surface would still age, die, rot.
My role is obviously superfluous. Whether i play out another untold story or not is insignificant.
Salvation and damnation are synonymous.

But i guess i should live, because frankly, i have no choice.
What the heck am i supposed to do, kill myself? What good would that do me?
There’re a lot of stuff to live for; girls, money, freedom if ever there is. All that other philosophical crap goes flying out the window when you have an orgasm. Right?
Hey, that’s one thing to live for.
Besides, life in this purgatory is not half bad once you’ve gotten a glimpse of hell. You’d be so damn happy you’d grow a tail to wag.
Sometimes your psyche just goes psycho, and you have to bash it back into its regular shape, at times literally. I know i do.

Paradise may be out of my reach but i have enough sense not to settle for perdition.
I will strive, for now i have a reason to. I have a place to come home to.
I dare say that is sufficient reason to live, though it seems harder to live than to die.
I will continue because i have a reason to. I will walk on because i want to.
I do not know why i live, but i know i want to live.
I may not be worth life, but i have life, and i believe i should do more than just breathe.



+++++++++


Well...that's it. It's nice that I get to post them here.

choices: Your choice of ideal lover or marital partner
165.content:
If there could exist such a person as the 'ideal' lover, then that person must be complimentary in personality as well as contradictory in appropriate expression as to give the receptive individuals an aspect of unpredictability toward one another. Intelligence or imaginative creativity would be required to keep intimate encounters varied, fresh, surprising, and enjoyable. Also, there should be some innate energy or enthusiasm to prevent laziness within the relationship that could eventually cause one or both intimate partners to take the other for granted, thus diminishing or even extinguishing the 'ideal' portion of what constitutes an 'ideal' lover.

Now having said all that mumble-jumble psycho-babble, let me restate the title into an 'If' statement that may clarify the above title.

'If' you were to meet someone who fit the physical appearance, social and emotional personality, as well as complimentary sexual drive and preferences of your imagined 'ideal' lover, how would you meet and would you celebrate many anniversaries together?

(don't forget the reasoning clarifying your story.)
165.title: The ideal Lover

choices: Steps to being the ideal lover
Steps to being the ideal mate/marriage partner
1653.content:
To find the ideal mate in the marriage covenant, I must address the importance of being the ideal mate in the marriage covenant. It would be disrespectful for me to ask anyone to be that which I am unwilling or unable to be in the first place on my own part.

That being said I must begin by confessing that I am a flawed and imperfect human being. Therefore, I can ask no one to be perfect, since I am not perfect.

The creation of a lasting marriage covenant requires grace to the extreme, compassion without end, and love that is always interested in my loved one's best interest before my own.

The marriage covenant is such an intensely personal and relationally intimate environment that all escape routes must be removed, the bridges must be burned and "the word, divorce, must be ripped out of your personal dictionary" according to the excellent advice given to me.

In short I must love my wife honestly, until I die.
I must forgive her when she offends me, regardless of the condition of her heart.
I must be consistently compassionate towards her needs, seeking her best in every situation.
I must be committed to her without reservation, without limitation, without expiration, and without hesitation.

If I am the person I should be, only the most heartless would consider responding with despite.

LOVE, (the desire for and commitment to another's best,) begets LOVE. If I am the ideal, albeit imperfect, lover in the marriage covenant, then more times than not my dear wife will be the ideal lover as well.

Ideal love begins within me as an honest human being, who confesses to being imperfect, while desiring to live the most self-sacrificing life of which I am capable to the end of the betterment of my wife. With her best interest always in my heart, I will be the ideal lover. Who can't respond favorably to that kind of love?

Admittedly, this kind of marriage is rare, but we are describing the ideal at this moment, are we not?

With regard to any aspect of our lives...be it our writing careers, our physical and mental and spiritual health, and in love and marriage, we are wise to heed the old saying, "Aim for the Earth and you may have a degree of success. Aim for the stars and you will get the Earth thrown in as a bonus."
1653.title: Your choice of ideal lover or marital partner

choices: Do you think you have an open mind?
16533.content:
I strongly agree with what Jay has said in the above message. No one in the world is perfect. Of course, people can be near perfect but it's rarely so. The reason for that is because each of us has different standards, standards of how we want other people to be like, standard of how people clothe themselves, how they talk, what education they receive, how they look, how they present themselves, their financial status, their properties and houses and jobs and so on.

Since the last interactive entries have been about marriage in particular, I'd like to take that as an example.

Suppose you are looking for marriage proposals, someone to marry. You have to set some standards in your mind like:

-- Handsome
-- Honest
-- Has a decent job and no bad record
-- Does not smoke
-- Is family oriented.

These above requirements are easy to find and real. On the other hand, these are the standards of another person:

-- Salary above $100,000
-- Should have a ferari or limousine
-- Must have a Banglow

and etcetra.

This is not common, this is extremely rare and if you ask me, you are asking for someone perfect.

You should have an open mind and be flexible. Sure, have some standards in your mind, see the good qualities of the person and then select him or her as your future better half.

I, for one, do not think that ideal in person is possible. But of course, jobs, professions, there can be ideals. For example, my ideal job or occupation would be the head of the cardio surgery or maybe neuro surgery or something like that.

I think that when you set an ideal in your mind, you are restraining yourself from looking at the vast possibilities around you. You, yourself, bound yourself within walls and boundaries, refusing to come out of them, comparing every person you see with that ideal standard or personality and the harm of doing that is, you find fault in everyone and with everyone. You don't like that person or thing. In your entire life, you keep struggling to achieve your ideal when maybe, the ideal you had been looking for was never good for you, instead the boy you turned down, the woman you called a snob, the job offer you said was not paying enough, maybe those were way better than your ideal. What if the ideal you have been searching for, been trying to achieve for so long in your entire life doesn't even exist? What then?

So, instead of wasting precious time in this small and short life of ours, we should always try to have an open mind and see others for who they are, what we like in them and have moderate and decent ideals that are easy for others to cross and for yourself to find so that you are satisfied and happy and so is the other person or the job.

489 words.
16533.title: Is the ideal possible?

info.brief_description: Write what you wish, do your best, and pass the baton. 500 gps prize per addition. Enjoy!
info.description:
Welcome to the interactive Pass-the-Write-Baton, a 2016 Quills Winner.



Before you write your addition, please READ the rules.

In this interactive, we'll play Pass-the-Write-Baton.
Please keep the content rating on or under 18+.
You may write as long as you wish, but your piece has to fit the title, and to qualify for a reward, it needs to have at least four sentences.
You may write whatever you choose ( poem, prose, fiction, non-fiction, essay, story, scene...etc, but not an entire novel in the same addition for obvious reasons) .
Please refrain from writing anything derogatory against any one group or religion. Those types of entries will be deleted.
You will use the word or phrase in the choice line inside your piece. Before you go, you will leave any words or phrases on the choice lines for the next person.
Leave only one word or one phrase per choice line. You may use common or proper nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs as you choose.
The choices as to the genre and type are entirely yours, but Do NOT spam. Make your writing count. Spams will be deleted.
                    Enjoy!
